bottle poured orange brown & silty with an aroma of fruit n wheat the taste is pretty good carbonated with wheat & spicy citrus flavours with a sweetish sort of sour finish nice with a slice of lemon in it
Dirty laundry soapy Hefeweizen. Phenolic with gym sock taste and aroma. The orange garnish is the best part of this barely drinkable beer.
Not bitter at all. Tastes like orange juice. Heavily hazy bright orange color. Not bad for when you want to try something different.

I’m getting me a t-shirt "My parents visited the States and all they brought me was this lousy beer." It looks like a wit, cloudy slightly-orange yellow with white head. Mild doughy wheat with a barely a hint of coriander and orange. Straight malt taste, how can there not be barley in this, sweet, mild orange, a hint of coriander. Malt bitterness to finishing with a lingering Tang sweetness. Not much of a wit.

Keg at Poundpub, Leek. A cloudy golden colour with a thin white head. Aroma of orange, slight wheat, some yeast, medicine and grass. Taste of light yeast, some wheat, slight orange, brown sugar, apple, cardboard and grassy hops. Light bodied but a fizzy carbonation. A bittersweet, orange then cardboard finish. For £1.50 a pint its drinkable, but it’s a dull, no spice and coriander as promised. Mass produced rubbish.

Bottle at home .... and very welcome 
Nice hazy golden yellow ... 
way tooo fizzy destroys any flavour in its fizz slightly medicinal yeasty bubble gum ... 
drinkable even plesent but not really me.
have a try
One of the best witbeer :) very nice etiquette :) delicate sweet aftertaste...
33cl @ Bottle. Mah, non sembra manco una blanche questa wit americana. Sarà che i belgi abituano troppo bene, ma non vedo grosse differenze con una lager.

Bottle. Hazy bright orange with small white creamy head, orange peel aroma, high carbonation, orange flavored sweetish taste, abrupt finish. Nice and easy to drink, could not discern the coriander though.
pours hazy light orange with a small white head and some lacing. sour yeasty aroma. flavour salt, cardboard. dry finish.
Simple wheat beer. Nothing really to discuss. Overall very basic and lack luster.
Smells like cheap beer. Appears like beer. Tastes like sugar water, saltine cracker, piss, and fungus. Palate average. Overall trash. Better than mgd but not good.
Hazy golden with a white head - Huge orange aroma - Some wheat and malt flavours with citrus and orange flavours as well - Orange and citrus goes into the finish - This was ok
355ml bottle. Creamy small white head. Hazy yellow fruit color. Aroma is newly cutted lawn, pear, herbs, nettles, banana. Taste is sweet with spices, hints of coriander.
Lean dirty and Detergent flavor.cloudy pour no head. Stale wheat. Not good brew for me.

This is a re-rate.  I poured it from the bottle into a pint glass.  It pours a cloudy orange color with a fizzy white head and very little lacing.  The aroma is orange and bread. The taste is very sweet with orange, coriander, and some wheat. It is a bit heavy and filling for the style. It is not the best interpretation of the style. There is worse out there though.
355ml bottle. Small head. Cloudy yellow color. Orange and coriander. Tastes commercial to be called craft

Oh yucky, yucky, yucky Yankee piss drop. Caramel, banana, apple, sweet yucky, sticky bland, and basic ale. What a joke. This is no Belgian style ale, it is actually a complete and utter farce. I absolutlely detest this beer for its sheer mockery of a witbier, bordering on criminal. Utter Bollocks. Keep buying this piss at Wallmart to those whom are obviously uneducated in beer tasting. Oh,gag. Really Blue Moon, you should be held accountable for this misconception of a Belgian-style wheat beer, it is nothing but. Who are you  trying to fool here, obviously those with no taste buds. My rating is so low, because this beer does not represent fully what it claims to represent. It is not a true witbier in my opinion. (and I have consumed many in my time). There are many New Zealand witbier brews that would blow this insipid drop out of the water.   And biers like - Pierre Celis. Jopen Adriaan. EINSTÖK ICELANDIC WHITE ALE. LEFEBVRE BLANCHE DE BRUXELLES
På flaska från Wallmart. Mörk gul färg. Svag doft av citrus. Smakar som en Wiesbeer. Lite citron och skumbanan.
Cloudy yellow color, small white head. Light aroma of orange peel and wheat. Dry sweet taste has orange, lemon, wheat, spices, hops. Thin body and good carbonation. Decent wit.
Buona birra, gusto leggero ma intenso. Dissetante come una blanche che si rispetti, senza perderci in aroma.
Smells very much like orange. Kind of foamy in the mouth. Tastes like wheat with a clear orange zesty aftertaste (although the final aftertaste is mostly wheat with a slight hint of orange).
Tall can. Pours a cloudy gold with a nice white head. Aroma of citrus, spice, and grain. Taste is orange, lemon, coriander, and wheat. Nothing wrong with this mild wit.

35.5cl bottle on 14/06/2015 poured into a tall glass. Hazy light amber colour with a thick creamy white head which quickly dissipates. Sweet fruity and wheat aroma. Medium carbonation. Light body and flavour. Sweet; flavours of wheat, grain, citrus fruits (orange peel, lemon) and slightly spicy. Light, fruity and drinkable.
Cor amarelo turvo. Aroma frutado. Carbonatação baixa. Corpo leve e refrescante, sem amargor, com um toque cítrico. Leve aftertaste.
On tap at Joe’s Bar and Grill in downtown Seattle. A nice yellow orange color, cloudy, moderate white head, not much nose at all. Taste wise a very so so wit. Not much else to say. 2.3.

Slightly hazy yellow body with a medium white head. Aroma is coriander, orange, wheat. Taste is medium sweet with light bitterness. Although quite drinkable I wouldn’t say this is a Belgian white ale.

Dorada amarillenta, muy turbia, tipo weizen. Apenas espuma aroma fresco, citrico. Super frutal, limon, pera. Combinado tambien con claras especias, clavo, pimienta. Final seco. Gran weizen super refrecscante y agradable.

355ml bottle. 11 May 15. Cloudy, deep gold colour with a creamy white head which reduced to a ring and left no lacing. Aroma of citrus, coriander, honey, wheat and yeast (tick, tick, tick). Light to medium sweetness, light bitterness and a little bit of spiciness. Light to medium body, creamy texture, some zestiness and lingering gentle bitterness in a semi-dry finish. A decent tip of the hat to Belgian Witbiers and very drinkable.

Ambrata chiara, velata dai lieviti in sospensione, schiuma bianca fine non molto persistente.
Poco naso, coriandolo e frumento ma tutto molto leggero.
Al palato leggero coriandolo e pepe, scorza d'arancia, frumento in secondo piano, finale pepato con leggera astringenza ed amaro erbaceo da luppolo.
Ben carbonata, corpo medio-leggero.

Orange peel, wheat, spicy, soapy and coriander in the aromaT, pours a cloudy straw color with a dense pillowing head. Wheat, creamy mouthfeel, a bit of the orange peel a little heavy and slightly oily.
Pours a cloudy golden color. Aroma and taste are lightly citrus and somewhat sweet.

GOOD BEGINERS BEERS. I DONT DRINK MUCH BELGIUM WHEATS BUT AT WALMART’S THE CHOICE IS SLIM. BLUE MOON IS LIKE SPICES AND FRUITS BUT YOU CAN FEEL THE CARBONEATION IN YOUR STOMACHE. ITS EASY TO DRINK. YOU CAN REALLY DRINK IT. IF I DONT FEEL LIKE GO FAR AND IM GOING TO THE POOL I CAN STOP AT WALMART’S BYE TRUNKS FRIZBEE BLUE MOON’S MEAT PROPANE AMMO AND EAT AT MACDONALD’S AT THE ONE STOP. PROBLY WHAT ILL DO IS START WITH ONE PLINY (I LOVE IT!!) AND TWO AND THEN DRINK BLUE MOON. IF THE NITE GETS REAL HAREY THEN MAYBE STEELE RESERVE I HIPE NOT COS THAT MEANT THAT MY DUMAS CUSIN SHOW UP AND I MAY WAKE UP IN THE DITCH AGIAN.

apperance - cloudy, a bit darker than white. Aroma - some banana, some other vague fruit. Taste - also non-specific fruits, a pleasantly sweet finish. Mouthfeel is good. There are better witbiers out there at this price, but this is a not unpleasant choice.

First Belgium white for me pours cloudy with small silky head tastesnorange peel with a pepper finish quite a smooth beer with flavours in the background nice beer but much prefer the German wheat beers with the sweeter taste

Pours cloudy gold with quickly disappearing head. Aroma is slightly citrusy, bready, grassy. Has a somewhat artificial tasting citrus flavor, very light, with a sort of musty flavor that comes up through the nose. Great for an American macro, not particularly good compared to other beers.

Some strong stuff. I had this my first time drinking beer, with Bud Light, SA Boston lager and coors light. First one i finished. Kind of strong and for a first time drinker will sit you on your ass. May not seem right for a beer. But it isnt the fact its super strong albeit its 5.4. Its a sneaky kind of beer where it only hits you when you stand up... Ah. good times. Blue moon was my first ale, and i like it and it has a high nostalgia feeling for me.

So I'm giving the beer an 11 because, all in all, it's rather drinkable. Pours a hazy medium orange-gold with a short-lasting white head. Aromas of orange peel and grain. Taste is overwhelmingly orange peel with some salty notes. Unfortunately, a rather thin body and not very much character -- tastes like a less-sweet Orange Crush sometimes.

Belgian style witbier from Denver, from a craft brewery which has apparently been taken over by Coors. Thin, lightly moussy, off-white head breaking open quickly but retaining around the edges, over a completely cloudy peach blonde beer with a ’fog’ of yeast in the middle. Aroma very wheaty and soapy, impressions of green apple peel, fabric softener, freshly cut sorrel, unripe mango, hint of lime, fresh fish, coriander seed, sourdough, something vaguely sulphuric (H2S?), celery, hint of dried orange peel, chalk. Fruity taste, peach, pear, apple, fairly strong and tingling carbo, dull sourish wheat, soft velvety mouthfeel (oats), sweetish touch of banana and peach, bit honeyish pairing well with the grainy wheat sourishness, fairly strong bready yeastiness but still rather refreshing, citrussy touch but more so, a drying coriander effect, though it stays relatively soft in comparison with many Belgian witbiers; not too unpleasant finish (at least for this style) of lingering ’breadiness’ with persisting wheat sourishness, with the drying, resinous coriander effect remaining relatively subtle but also a powder sugar-like, somewhat honeyish sweetness; rather thinnish body. Witbier is not my favorite style I’m afraid, but this is not a truly bad example of it, albeit a dull one, smelling too much of fish and soap, which did put me off a bit. In all, still acceptable introduction to the style I suppose, but underachieving if compared with the best Belgian witbiers - and those are not the many copies of Hoegaarden, to my personal taste.  In fact, I’d even have a Hoegaarden over this; the fact that adding a slice of orange to it is even explicitly advertized on the back label, should have made me more suspicious, I guess.
Bad wheat,stinky cardboard and locker room. Watery cloudy dirty ice machine smell on end. Bleck!
White, frothy, fairly persistent head. Straw yellow, cloudy. Poor at nose. Honey, citrus, wheat. Medium carbonated. Balanced

Insgesamt ein passables, aber kein wirklich gutes Bier.
Das Orangenaroma kommt sehr gut raus, der Koriander hingegen weniger. Insofern natürlich nicht zu vergleiche mit den Vorbildern aus Belgien. Dadurch ist es etwas zu süß geraten, die Erfrischung bleibt völlig aus.
Orange rind and wheat aroma. Taste is charred wheat, orange rind, and a tad bit of sweet brown sugar in the after taste.
355 bottle at Bossa Nova, Chania Greece. Orange hazy color, white head. Aromas of orange, spices. Taste is orange, lemon, spices, yeast. Light body with low carbonation.
0.33l bottle. Hazy light orange color with disappearing white head. Aroma is orange peel and weak wheat aroma. Taste is sweet with wheat notes. Overall it?s worse than I expected.

On tap. Pours a hazy pale yellow with a white head that dissipates to the edges. Aroma has some sweet wheat with a bit of light spice and some light sweet fruits. Flavor has sweet and eathy wheat with light Belgian spice and a hint of sweet fruit b
Origin: Bottle. Vessel: Bottle. Supplier: Morrisons (Bristol). Floral overtones light earthy Base.
All these years and I forgot to rate this..anyway..middle of the road..nothing special..not much else to say.
I didn’t realized this was a macro brew. A good wit-beer with a very slight citrus aroma and sweet flavour.
Cloudy and golden in colour with a good white head. Slightly damp clothing smell with a hint of orange. Leaves quite a dry mouth but nice and wheaty.

Botella. 10/04/2015. BBD: 28/02/2015. 
Aroma a malta, color amarillo oscuro. Sabor espaciado.

A little more carbonated than the typical Belgian White ale, but overall tasty. Light orange/pale yellow golden appearance with decent head. Hazy from the yeast, as I believe it’s unfiltered. Good for a nice hot day, or if looking for a lighter dinner beer with some flavor....which consists of mainly orange, and some other spices. Sweet aftertaste with a slightly yeasty finish.

Bottled. 15cl sample. The aroma has loads of coriander, some orange. Cloudy, yellow - white coloured beer with an off white head. The taste is light sweet, has coriander, grain and citrus. Refreshing but could be more if it wasnt for the coriander load.
Ruikt zoet voor een wit. Uit fles. Smaakt Ok en fris, maar niet heel lekker. Niks speciaals..

I drunk this one first in 2012 in Mallory square Key West FLA, on a pier at the sunset. Again in Serbia 0,355 bottle purchased and consumed in Pozarevac. Pours hazy orange, white gassy foam with decent retention. Nose: pleasant spicy notes, tangerine, sweet wit feel. Mouth: a bit too thin for me but come on, it is meant for sessions. Frizzy end, a bit soapy, not much of that tangerine in the nose but decent wit if you have no other choice.

Is a refreshing beer. The flavour of the species is nice but it goes away considerably fast. Is a beer that I could drink more than once, but if I’ll look for a really good beer to enjoy I wouldn’t look for this one.

Someone left a bottle of this at my house. Pours cloudy dark golden color with off white head. Aromas of wheat, oranges, yeast, and some spices. Inoffensive yet muted witbier flavors. Medium body with average carbonation. I can see why many "non-beer drinkers" like this.
Dark orange with ok scent, better with orange, not too bad of flavor for a mass produced brew again better with orange just to add to a lacking depth
Just a coors with some spices...covers it up enough not to make you just burp grains. Still a horrid beer.
Beer is more or less ok. It’s not a typical and proper witbier, but still it’s quite drinkable and even refreshing.

Cloudy pale amber colour, almost fluorescent. Nice white belgian type top, good on nose. Superb aroma, even better in aftertaste than european pattern. Orange and noble herbs, floral almost and some light coriander and cake. But dominant is Toblerone honey and almond nougat chunks. Something interesting and original is in this beer, very fruity. Great Belgian light body type beer, but with good american touch. Very well balanced, but I repeat: indescribably wonderful taste! Made in Molson Brewery in Montreal, Canada, with UK title North American Craft Beer.

Bottle 0.335L.
Hazy yellow body with large, frothy, white head, mostly lasting with some lacing; high density of medium-sized bubbles.
Heavy hoppy (citrus, orange) and light-to-moderate malty (grains) aroma with notes of spices (coriander).
Moderate sweet flavour with an overall watery feeling.
Light-to-medium body with watery texture; lively carbonation.

12 oz bottle. Appearance is hazy, golden color with medium, off-white head. Aroma is weak with orange, some spice, and alcohol. Taste is similar with mild tart bitterness flavored with some orange and light spicyness. Palate is light-bodied, thin texture, average carbonation, and a semi-dry finish. About what you’d expect from a mass imitation Witbier.
Not really my style of beer. Herbal flavour of nettled cat wee. Little hop. Too sweet and then bitter finish that is too tanin.

Ein Witbier aus den USA. Im Glas etwas dunkler als die bekannten belgischen Vertreter: leuchtend orange, trüb mit weißem Schaum. In der Nase dominiert die Orange, die sich dann auch geschmacklich durchsetzt ohne aufdringlich zu werden. Hinzu kommt etwas Koriander. Ein leicht schmeckendes erfrischendes Bier, welches ohne übertriebene Süße auskommt.
One of the most widely circulated wits out there. Pours cloudy yellow. The orange and coriander dominate to nearly the point of excess. I can’t drink many of these and wouldn’t order them.

09/03/2015 (7,4,7,4,14) Cerveja wit que representa muito bem o estilo. Adocicada com leves toques de canela, baunilha, e mais intenso de laranja. 

01/06/2015 (4,3,5,3,8) Aparência bem tipica de wit, amarelo leitoso, espuma branca e cremosa, de média duração. Aroma tende mais para o amargor do coentro, do que o cítrico da laranja, encorpada pelo trigo, ou pouco ácida, madeira úmida . Paladar de corpo leve, carbonação média. Aftertaste lembra palha seca, bem ao fundo cítrica, talvez pela proximidade da validade (que é hoje). Fica devendo para outras wits européias.

I picked this up as a last resort on my way home. The aroma is not very distinguished. It is a sweeter beer. Which must be why others call it a refreshing beer. I do like that it has a full herb taste from the white wheat and various other oats.

12 oz bottle. Poured into a shaker pint. Hazy orange with modest creamy white head. Light smells of corriander and orange zest. Tastes the same but not as strong as real witbier. This is drinkable for corporate swill, but if there are other options pass.
Hazy orange. Somewhat sweet. Interesting beer, never tasted something like this before. Lots of herbs.
Not a bad beer, but not particularly tasty either. Pretty average in my opinion. Probably good for hot weather.
Good beer at any time. Easy to drink and tasty, especially with an orange in it. Yummy with wings, pizza, and other finger foods
Bottle@Bistro Niko, Atlanta. Blonde beer with a light head. The aroma is citric and dry, and the flavour is dry with some citrusy and yeastiness. Overall a nice witbier style beer.
355ml bottle. Pours cloudy orange with a thick white head. Aroma is dry and spicy. Taste is orange, spice, sweet and dry. I’ve had this draught and bottled is far better

Under blue Moon I saw you
So soon you'll take me
Up in your arms
Too late to beg you or cancel it
Though I know it must be the killing time.
Very pleasant. Not too sure about the added orange. Made a particularly delicious après drink.

On tap at Vynil, Manhattan, NY. Cloudy orange color, short sustained white head, came with an orange slice on the edge of the glass. Looks almost like a weizen... Aroma of witbier, wheat, spices and orange. Palate feels very astringent and dusty, hyper dry. Aroma however is very light. Taste is flat. Short spicy finish. Served very cold, ultra refreshing, not the best thing ever but for sure good for summer.



Bottled. Orange color, cloudy with a big creamy offwhite head, perfumed. As above, but the belgian yeast breaks through and feels a bit more alcoholic. Tart, but less dry, still dusty. Flattish taste with some undecise hops here and there.
Hazy yellow pour, quick white head. Nose is yeast and light wheat. Slightly sweet. Middle is muted orange and spice, followed by slick grain. Finish is a bit more dry, not very distinctive.

Bottle 0.355l at Pivopija NBGD Belgrade Serbia.Pour it hazy yellow color with medium white head.On the nose artichoke, lemon.Taste and aroma of lemon, herbs, pepsi lemon note.Nothing special bit good to try it.

Bottle 0,355L - gift from Gregor. Murky, ocra colour with small, frothy, white head that dissipate fast. Aroma of coriander, parsley, some other vegetable and spices. Taste is really weird, like drinking beer made of vegetable instead of using malt. Light sweet, weird taste. Hard to drink. Kinda soapy finish. I like Belgian wit beers, but this one is awful.

I still remember the first time I encountered this beer in the heat of Memphis Tennesee in the summer of 2013. Served icecold and with a slice of orange, it really gave me a favourable impression that has lasted as I have had it since both bottled and on tap. The mix of coriander and orange augments the wheat nicely keeping the alcohol in check. Very well balanced and to me a beer all of its own. Have not been able to find it here in Denmark, but would definitely buy it if it turns up. It would be interesting to see if it also travels well

It’s an alright white ale - It’s a lot better than most of the mass manufactured white ales on the market. It pours with about a 1 inch white head with a golden orange body. It has hints of orange which contrasts nicely with the bitter flavor.
Blue Moon is kind of a classic for the style, but plenty of others are doing the style better now.
Had a great combination of coriander and orange. It s wonderful wheat beer. Is a bit cloudy.
Bottle. Pours hazy yellow. No head. aroma has some yeasty and earthy tones. nice coriander bite and in overall quite enjoyable wit.

12 oz. bottle from BevMo. Pours a hazy golden yellow with a white head. Aroma of yeast and faint spices. Malt forward. Creamier than a typical witbier. Not overly spicy. Hints of coriander and orange peel. Little hop taste. All in all very enjoyable, interesting and extremely drinkable.

Poured from 12 oz bottle into pint glass.

Appearance: pours a 1" white sudsy head that drops slowly with some mild lacing. Color is hazy golden/orange.

Aroma: mild grassiness, coriander, and orange.

Mouthfeel: light to medium, soda like with a somewhat wet finish.

Flavor: malt breadiness, wheat grass, orange, and some coriander and other spices.

Overall: decent, no off flavors.

From a 355ml bottle on 25/1/2015. Pours a cloudy pale golden with a medium white head which disappears quickly. Has a pleasant light spicy, wheaty nose with some doughy yeast in the mix. The flavour is refreshing with lots of orange, a hint of banana, and more light spices, including coriander. Has a fullish body and average carbonation. I have no doubt this gets punished a bit on here ratings wise simply because it made by Coors, but this is actually a rather good Belgian wit, which is a style not that many brewers manage to nail. Nice work.

Bottle pour hazy gold. Nose slightly sour wheat, hint of spice. Taste watered down throughout but if I think about it, maybe some spice and grainy malt after the initial sweet. Not all that bad for a macrobrew, but certainly not great for style.
Little to zero aroma. Tastes like diluted wheat beer. Terrible but for a buck per bottle not too bad.
This one is ok...not sure if this beer represents its style....not a good beer or a bad beer just in the middle somewhere..........
Cloudy in golden colour medium thickness white head. Very smooth and good wheat. Must taste this overall.

Blonde/blanche pale et trouble. Beau col de mousse blanche crémeuse qui ne tient pas longtemps. Nez de miel et d’agrumes : orange, citron. Bouche sucrée sur le miel, la coriandre et l’orange . Faible amertume, corps interessant pour le style. Très bonne bière blanche !
Sehr trübews hellgelb. orangen Aromen, wenig Koriander, sofort da. Weizig-weich zu trinken, süsslich und wenig bitter. Etwas spritig, Limonen. Abgang soso lala, etwas fehlt diesem Bier.
Bottle at home. Pours hazy golden yellow, taste is coriander, sweet, sugary, light toffee.

cloudy and straw colored, nice hints of citrus, very easy drinking, ideal for summertime on those hot days.
not really started on the Belgian beer yet but this is good stuff and a joy to drink

Pours golden with a thick white head. Aroma is of wheat and citrus. Taste is of wheat and barley. It’s a little bland with a bit of grain on the back end. Not much of a fruity taste as I expected. I’m surprised it’s 5.4%.

Bottiglia 33 cl comprata alla sogegross e bevuta a casa.
Chiara con poca schiuma evanescente.
Corpo fitto, pesate in rapporto allo stile.
Sapore di sapone al limone.
Male

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhold
Hazy blond. Overdose on citrus in nose and taste. Lively carbo. Really? I am paying for this?
Amazing orange aroma. Super smooth with a lemon and wheat taste. The ultimate summer beer.

Delicious white wheat-beer, belgian-style, with light body but wonderful orange+coriander taste and a delightful aroma!

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
Draft at Cruiseport. Pours orange with a white head. Aroma is clove, caramel, cracker. Flavor is white bread, mild banana, clove. Least objectionable beer on tap.
Cor alaranjada turva com pouca formação de espuma. Aroma de laranja, ervas. Paladar com boa acidez e carbonatação, especiarias e salgado.
Bland overall, nothing that stands out. Not a beer I would actively hunt to have on hand.

Slid flagship beer. One of the original craft beers I had back in the day. Can never go wrong with one of these 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
12oz in Seattle. Hazed light gold, small white head. Macro sweet aroma, rather typical wit spicing. Banana cream, smooth body, sweet and bright. Metallic fruit aftertaste. No thanks

Very good beer. Not expensive and sold in small bottle (200ml).
Good belgium beer.
Bottle. Hazy pale orange pour with next to no head. Aroma has quite a lot of yeast plus a hint of citrus. Taste is flat and uninspiring. Low carbonation

Very old backlog rating. 12oz bottle in Philly. It pours a clean straw color with medium white head. Aroma is wheat, grains, grass, citrus. Taste is middle crispy, lightly grainy and grassy. Notes of cereals and citrus. Fairly simple and inoffensive

I was at a gas station, and in the mood for something not completely shitty. So, for the extra 4/5 dollars 12 pack, I grabbed something light yet tasty. But I wouldn’t dare add a slice of orange to it. Beer. Doesn’t. Need. Fruit. (Looking at you Corona..take a lesson from Landshark)

Bottle from conglomerate faceless grocery emporium; hazy golden yellow pour, head is unacceptably massive, this craft brewer had squeezed in all the wit essentials, bravo to the clove, bow down to the banana chips, stale gum in abundance.

Have been down the the whole craft beer thing. IPAs, stouts, lagers, porters, big beers. Now a days they are just too much anymore. A nice easy drinking beer like BM is my go to now. Nice and smooth, not too in your face or some over the top crazy mix of stuff. The stuff is usually Nice and fresh too due to its popularity
Pours from a bottle a turbid amber with a thin white head. Aroma slightly appley? Flavor a mild bittersweet, like a faint bitter orange peel, thin in the mouth.
Goût de banane, pêche et muscade. Faible amertume. Très commerciale et pas mon genre mais potable

draft from a pizza joint in Greenville , South Carolina.
Aroma- Nice citrus aroma with some spice and yeast/hops
Appearance- A nice orange color with a white head
Taste- Has a definite citrus base with a dry finish
Palate- Has a medium body with a creamy texture 
Overall- Not bad, would definitely drink again
Thin head. Hazy orange. Orange zest smell. Very sweet taste. Little carbonation. Too sweet for the style.
Bottle 350ml. Golden-yellow with slight haze. Slight fruit aroma. Yeasty taste with some fruits.
For the price, this is a good starter beer. Easy and not offensive. A good beginner beer to step of a domestic light beer and into some a tad nicer. Is priced lower than most craft.
This golden ale is easy drinking and perfect for a relaxing game watching beverage.
Better than I thought but not my favorite. Super cold from Tommy T fridge............
What can I say, it’s blue moon. Thin body, but they pump enough spices into it to give it a decent flavor. Would prefer not to drink this, but I’ll take it over an American Light Lager, I guess.

have had this beer a few times now on tap and in bottle and i am not convinced i have heard some people say it is really good and all they drink but i just can’t get that excited about it pale appearance fruity aroma with a taste of orange running through it
Heard great things about this beer in particular, all of them were true. It has that particular true Pilsner taste which doesn’t disappoint at all.
355 ml bottle. Pours a straw yellow colour with a medium white head. Aroma of citrus fruits and coriander. Taste is light sour. Above average carbonation. A bit too thin for a good wit.

This is one of the beers that started me branching away from my AB/St. Louis roots. Now just average to me compared to the much tastier beers I drink. Nice color and orangey somewhat sweeter taste. Average aroma and palate. It really does taste better with an orange in it.

A tale of two halves here. It looks great with the unfiltered element giving a very inviting colour and haze. The aroma is sweet and typical of the variety. The taste let’s it down here. I didn’t have it upright in the fridge as I didn’t know it was unfiltered so I may be doing it a disservice. Its meaty and orangey, the oats seem to leave it unbalaced however this gives it a nice mouthful creaminess. The taste goes from orange to meat to thin and back to meat and lemon. Could do better. I wanted to review this higher and I still might be too generous. But the appearance , aroma and look is simply great.
Appearance: a hazy yellow color with a medium head. Aroma: smells like orange peel, lemon and wheat. Tastes like some fruits and other citrus notes. Refreshing but not a good witbier.
Common room, Sheffield. Misty pale orange ale. Aroma of orange peel and peppery wheat. Taste is soft sweetness and very slight sour citrus. Medium body, medium carbonation.

Purchased in a 355ml bottle (if that figure seems a little random, it is the equivalent of 12 fl oz) in Sainsbury’s as ’North American Craft Beer Blue Moon’.’ North American’ is significant, because it is a Denver beer brewed in Toronto. The label is almost identical to the one in the illustration. The beer is a very hazy golden yellow with a white head. Spicy and zesty aromas. The taste is much creamier than a regular witbier, lacking the zestiness of a typical Belgian example. I would guess this comes from the use of oats in the Blue Moon brewing process. It has hints of coriander and orange peel, but little hop taste. This is a very pleasant, interesting and drinkable beer.
Sour hop malt spice aroma. Murky Amber colour poor head and lacing. Fruit Apple hop spice flavour. Fizzy palate.
Dan Murphy’s bottle(28-Oct-2014)Light spice,stale fruit aroma.Cloudy amber,poor head&suds lace.Fruit with some spice flavour.Sweet fruit spice finish&stale aftertaste.

Poured from a 12 oz bottle with a Best Buy date of 02/16/15. 
Aroma has a subdued, slightly stale what character. Medium light citrus notes with some moderate coriander and faint grains of paradise phenolics. Hints of stone fruit esters. 
Pours a hazy orange with a small, thin head that quickly disappears. Minimal lacing and only faint legs. 
Flavor is somewhat sweet with a bit of a sweet finish. Some light what notes with moderate orange character. Orange tastes a bit artificial. Medium light coriander notes. Low bitterness. 
Mouthfeel is medium bodied with medium carbonation. Low astringency and low alcohol warmth. 
Overall, a perfectly fine and boring beer. A bit artificial in the flavor, but more drinkable than a lot of beers I have had from micros. Too sweet for me.

Taste is easy going, sweet wheat with decent Belgian spices. It’s mild and unassuming, but a better mainstream choice than any pale lager I’ve had. Not bad at all, really.

Pours a cloudy burnt orange color with very little head. The aroma is yeasty. Maybe a little funky. There’s a cooked cabbage thing going on. The flavor is better than the aroma. I was given a case of this as a surprise gift, and over the course of a few weeks I drank the whole case. I didn’t dump out one single bottle. So, no, it ain’t great. But it ain’t awful.

From BA review on 2-25-12 -
Poured from bottle into pilsner glass.

Appearance –Pours a very hazy orange color with a big white head. The head fades relatively fast, but leaves a very persistent foam on the brew. 

Smell – A citrus aroma is most pertinent and lasts from start of smell to finish. There is a yeast cake and a little bit of lemon mixing in as well. Quite nice. 

Taste – Sweet malt mixed with some very nice orange citrus flavors; these flavors are present throughout. Toward the middle of the taste some of the yeastiness and a bit of breadiness are present. The yeast and the bread begin to fade more toward the end giving way to a sweeter taste (citrus in nature but also a bit of cane sugar sweet as well). 

Mouthfeel – Medium to slightly above body in nature. It coats the mouth quite nicely. This coupled with some more evanescent bubbles tingles on the tongue and mix very well with some of the sweet citrus flavors that come to the end of the taste. 

Overall – This is really quite a nice refreshing and drinkable beer. It is quite nice in all the categories. A very good session beer.
pours a dark hazy yellow with about a finger of white head. aroma is wheat, citrus, and coriander. flavor is light malts, citrus, coriander, and a hint of soap. medium to soft carbonation.

Pours cloudy golden, almost opaque. Very thin white head that disappears into nothing in seconds. Spicy citrus hop aroma, sweet malt, grassy hops and herbs. Malty flavour, followed by mild bitterness and spiciness. Pretty sweet. It’s okay but I wouldn’t really like to have more than one.

Not sure what to say about this. Well it’s bottled from Beers of Europe. Colour is cloudy orange., with little to no head. I tried this after Hoegaarden another commercial brewed Belgian White beer, and the flavour of spice orange etc. seems absent when compared. A touch disappointed but it’s ok.

Ins Glas ergießt sich ein trübes goldenes Bier mit geringer Schaumkrone. Geruch hefig, malzig, leichte Gewürze, fruchtig säuerlich. Geschmack hefig, fruchtig, minimal säuerlich, Citrus.

Blue Moon is a beer brewed by Coors Brewing Company absent of the Coors labeling. Of course Coors does this to masquerade the beer as a craft brew--an excusable marketing tactic considering the quality of the brew.

It is a belgian style white wheat ale, so it’s notably light in flavor (but not light like a coors light--naturally light). Light flavors of orange and coriander as the labeling suggests are prominent throughout.

Definitely the type of beer to be served in an ice cold mug on a hot summer day. Produces a nice head poured in the aforementioned glass.

A squeeze of orange is almost mandatory to enhance the flavor but it’s an excellent beer regardless.

Probably the greatest beer brewed by an American macrobrewery--which says a lot.

Appearance is gorgeous as the beer is unfiltered--a highly positive trait for a Coors brew.

Better than the vast majority of craft beers. Underrated by beer geeks because it’s brewed by Coors--this beer deserves high marks.

One of my favorites as is highly available.

Better than a Sam Adams, although I’ll find myself going for a Sammy when when I’m in the mood for something strong and robust.

Excellent, excellent beer-- dominates most craft beers.

And the ladies like it, too.

Again some "friend" thinks this is a craft beer we will suck down...yea we will in a beer bong. Wierd fruity nose and Coors light flavor with an aroma of bandaids and an energency room ... Come I. Girls. If I wanna get lit ill do So Co

Bottle from Morrisons. The aroma of this beer doesn’t give a true sense of what’s coming. From the first swig you get a hit of orangepeel followed by a hint of coriander. Quite light and very drinkable. Quite a thick sediment at the bottom of the bottle but this is to be expected from an unfiltered beer.
Draught pint. Very hazy amber with a large white head. Aroma is spicy and citric. Similar flavours, distinct wheat flavour. Sweet, but not overly so. Carries a surprise amount of body. Pretty good.

I poured two 12oz bottles into a weizen glass. They had a best before date of 5/19/14 and came as part of a 12-pack for $14.47 ($1.20 per bottle or $0.10 per ounce).



Appearance: Hazy orange hue (too dark for the style). Translucent with some fine carbonation visible. Pours to a small, white, soapy head which nearly completely dissipates and leaves no lacing.



Smell: Sweet orange scent, but reminiscent of artificial flavoring. Not much authentic Belgian character to it. 



Taste: Blue Moon is usually scoffed at by craft beer enthusiasts, and for good reason. But a lot of us forget that the beer serves a purpose of being a stepping stone from fizzy yellow beer to good beer. And in that capacity, this beer is great. As an actual Belgian White it’s far from a good example of the style. While there’s nothing particularly wrong with the palette here, there’s nothing especially good about it, either. The flavors seem a little inauthentic and what’s there is too simple and mild.



Upon my first swig I was immediately reminded of a pumpkin beer. The orangepeel and coriander spices are noticeable right away. They create for a zingy sensation, though they seem to fade away rather quickly. Through the middle there’s a sweet, almost sugary taste of orange flavoring akin to orange-flavored soda (not rich like orange juice concentrate). It finishes with a surprisingly dull, grainy taste not unlike that of a macro lager, which is actually quite baffling. Personally, I’m not offended by this palette, but it has a long way to go to truly impress me.



Drinkability: Say what you want about the taste, but it’s hard to dispute the fact Blue Moon is highly drinkable. Even drinking it indoors on a cold winter’s night it’s remarkably refreshing. The mouthfeel is on the thinner side and noticeable crisp, but not fizzy. It leaves just a slight pasty aftertaste, though it’s easily tolerable. It doesn’t seem to take full advantage of its 5.4% ABV weight. I’m sure they could deliver the same palette on a lighter, more sessionable body. But it is drinker-friendly for sure.

Good summery beer. Goes well with a good meal. Gotta have that orange slice, though.

Not bad, if you're gonna give money to Coors, it might as well be this brew.

All these years I’ve had this one and forgot to review it until now.
Here’s my notes from 11/11/2011.
The appearance is a hazy pale orange at the bottom but darker orange closer to the top, small white head disappeared within seconds, very little lacing.
The smell is orange, coriander, spices, weak yeast only after it warmed a bit.
The taste is exactly the same as the smell without any yeast.
The palate is basically a light to medium styled body with some harshness assaulting the mouth and tongue all over, sessionable, bland citrusy aftertaste, dull finish.
Overall, well, its not the best witbier on the market according to Belgian standards, but hey for me since I’m not a true Belgian fan, I don’t mind this so much. Its not bad by the pool in the summer or next to the grill.

This is probably the worst looking wit, I’ve ever seen, it’s sort of a hazy yellow that looks like sick piss. Smells decent at least, I get tangy wheat and spices wafting up as well as some vague Belgian yeast notes like banana and tutti frutti. The flavor doesn’t live up to the aroma, there is a cheap lager undercurrent to the tangy wheat and spices. The palate is pretty gross as well, feels like water yet the carbonation manages to be overly harsh as well. I’m disappointed in this one, and would recommend many widely distributed lagers over it. Aroma fresco donde se percibe ligeramente el trigo utilizado, pero es muy fácil de percibir la cascara de naranja, que le da notas muy frescas.

Su apariencia, color amarillo opaco, turbiedad característica del estilo, cuerpo ligero, carbonatacion de baja a media, corona de espuma ligera y de baja retencion.

En boca suave, muy refrescante y con un final ligeramente citrico.

Al paladar es agradable. No se percibe fácilmente el trigo, y no se nota el característico cueroi que ese grano da a la cerveza, pero la cascara de naranja entrega notas críticas muy refrescantes al igual que el aroma.

En general se trata de una cerveza que si bien no reune todas las características de las cervezas del estilo, se bebe fácil, es muy refrescante y aprovecha de muy buena forma los adjuntos utilizados parq dar un toque caracteristya esta cerveza.

ugh. i don’t like wheat beer for some reason, so this will be the review that either proves i’m just a hater to be a hater or explain the reasons why i don’t like wheat beer. here we go. I had these in my fridge for a while, somebody brought them from a barbeque. everybody i know seems to like them, everytime i try to drink them i get a kinda odd salty flavor. anyways heres the pour. Is there such thing as a filtered wheat beer, they are all cloudy like this.. why? cloudy, no visible carbonation, just a hairline of white bubbles around the top of the glass. smell is burnt pasta and oranges. maybe a tiny tiny hint of hops. taste is mostly salt and seltzer. i dont’ know, i don’t really get the hype around this other than the fact that it doesn’t have a whole lot of flavor and it’s easy to drink super cold and fast. here’s a good explanation of what this tastes like: you cook the cup of noodles first before adding the water... oops, then you put seltzer water in there instead of normal water and cook it again, then pour out all the noodles and drink the water. something you would only do once in a blue moon right? pfffft. i’ll finish it anyways, and maybe drink a few more. it’s all that’s left!!

I was always hesitant to try this before since it is brewed by one of the big American macro breweries. I am very glad I did try it, and tried it again It may not be the best example of the style nor the best beer out there, but all in all it is very good. I have had a couple and I am thinking that this might be one of my staple beers during the summer. It is refreshing and very easy to drink.
Poured from can, cloudy yellow with a light head that disappeared into nothingness. Taste is mellow with noticeable orange flavors. Not bad, smooth but a bit bland.
Can. Not getting any aroma out of the can or glass. Pours thick and light amber, almost opaque. Head dissipated quickly. Taste is fresh and smooth. Drinkable, but bland.

12oz can. Cloudy light golden orange with an off white head. Aroma of wheat, citrus, coriander and black pepper. Flavor is light wheat malt, spice and orange peel. Light body with average carbonation. Have had this one plenty of times, not offensive just a bit boring and bland for the style.
One of the first beers that I could tolerate other than the standard light American lagers. While this beer has been everywhere, it is still one of my favorites on a warm day.

Keg at The Counting House. Could’ve done without the slice of orange to be honest. Pours murky brown with almost no head. Quite high carbonation though, big bubbles. Not surprisingly, aromas of orange, but not sure how much is coming from the beer. Nice wheat cereal taste, low bitterness. OK, but easily forgettable.
Appearance was a drawback. ..no head, no lacing, and a murky yellowish color. Tasted better than it looked, but nothing to write home about.

Bottle @ the Trevi fountain in Ceasar’s Palace, Las Vegas. Hazy yellow orange pour, thin white head. Aroma of orange peel, wheat and spices. Flavor is sweet and fruity. Slightly bitter finish. Boring, but drinkable.
Tap. Hazy gold color with white head. Aroma of yeast and fruit. Taste of fruit and yeast. Light and refreshing. A decent beer to order at a pizza place or at a bar on a hot summer night.

Innocuous, bland, non-descript. Light medium yellow body with thin head. Even glass poured, remains highly carbonated, little aroma or taste. Bad excuse to put down a glass of water.

Blue Moon is the my go to beer. It has a very hazy appearance because of the suspended proteins that are in the beer. Anyway on to flavor. Best served in a tall glass. The bitterness is very mild as is the body. This is a beer that can be a great medium between beer lovers and newbies.

Bottled, did not have a glass to pour, so I could not rate the head or color very well. Aroma was very mild spice with hints of slight citrus. So, let’s be honest.  People rating here have a bent against labels owned by the mass produced mega brewers trying to stake a claim in the micro world.  This style of beer was all but extinct 40 years ago.  Kudos for this brand (and Coors) sticking it out.  I much prefer an Allagash White (or ANY Belgian made white), but when I look at tap handles of Bud, Coors Light, and MGD, seeing the last resort as a Blue Moon, I at least can be somewhat satisfied.

Appearance:
Dense hazy orange under a soft bready head which fades into a thin layer that eventually breaks up into small patches. No lace.


Nose:
Freshly cut oranges. Orange zest atop white bread ala breakfast rolls. Orange icing sweetness along the sides is a bit off-putting. Generic spicing in the middle. Candied orange peel and grains of paradise.


Palate:
Medium weight and full bodied mouthfeel. Orange and white breads intermingle in the middle. Thin on the backside with watery generic spices and dried orange peel. Soggy orange bread.


Final Thoughts:
Better than Shock Top but still not a Belgian-style Wit I would willingly choose to drink or drink if someone offered it unless there were a lot of orange slices to make it tolerable. Is it bad? It’s not a drain pour and back in my beer newbie days I drank quite a few 6packs and pints of Blue Moon. As a gateway beer it’s good for what it does – takes people away from the light macro swill of BMC with the only downfall of being left behind for better craft beers.


(An original written work by Beer Ambassador, LLC. Plagiarism is not tolerated.)

Full disclosure, I love this style of beer.  With that said, this is a shockingly decent mass-produced beer from a company that otherwise strives for (and fails) for mediocrity.  Not as good as Hoegarden or some microbrew versions like Allagash White, but if you’re trapped at a place that only offers beers from AB and Coors, you can do worse.

Good go-to beer in a pub or at home. Legit Belgian wheat beer at a commercial microbrew price.

Pours a dark golden yellow which isn't unappealing by itself, but doesn't seem to suit the style (which is presumably a Belgian Wit, which is presumably lighter.) The head vanishes very quickly. Nose of cooked grain, a little citrus, a little corn/fritos, maybe a touch of spice but that's stretching it -- really not much more than say a Yuengling with some lemon juice in it. 

Mouthfeel is odd, rather thick and gummy to my taste. Not much by way of flavor, does have a sharp finish that isn't unpleasant but I can't taste much of anything in the beer itself, certainly nothing I'd normally associate with a Belgian White. 

Best described as a Belgian Wit made by a company that never actually tried one -- just read a little bit about them in other books. Like if the Cold War was going on and Romania tried to brew one, based soley on reputation and what they could discover in libraries. It's kiinndda in the style, but it's a really bad stab at it.

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
5.4% cloudy orange colour with no head, citrus yeast aroma, nice citrus orange taste,
On tap - I passed on the orange slice...  not too bad for a macro trying to play the craft game.
Good spring beer, smooth palate, rougher aftertaste, best available beer at this lousy Mexican bar... Lol

355ml bottle. Cloudy orange appearance. Orange and wheat aroma with the same flavours but with a little spice on the palate also. Slightly too much orange in the flavour for me but a good beer if a wee bit light in general taste.

The quintessential "big brewer, crafty name" beer, Blue Moon can be found just about everywhere and works well as a beer to grab on tap if nothing else is available. Pours a hazy orangeish-yellow with almost no head. Scent is orange, spicy, a little bit of yeast. Taste follows suite with plenty of spicy and fruity notes with a touch of bitter was at the end. Thin body. Not a terrible beer, perfectly acceptable in a pinch, but there are much better wheat beers out there.

Early 2012 - Draught - nice wheat beer, bitter sweet, would have again.  3.9
Bottle June 2012 - buttery taste when warm, bit of citrus, definitely better on draught 3.3
Aug 2012 - v cold bottle - mild flavour when cold.  The butteriness becomes more balanced when cold.  Doesn’t seem as nice in a bottle.  Won’t have again.  3.3

Pours a nice cloudy semi-transparent straw with really no head, but limited lacing. Smells of wheat and orange. Tastes of wheat with a slight orange flavor. Beer is overcarbonated, but very drinkable, with more flavor than most mass produced beers for still having a light body.
On tap at Stroudt’s in Kansas City. Pours a hazy golden orange color with white head. Wheat, citrus, yeasty flavors. Reminds me of when I turned 21.
I use to love this beer, orange in or out. Unfortunately I can’t stand even having one of these, guesz it doesn’t stand the test of time...

I just don’t understand the prices this beer gets... It’s a Belgian style beer. Very orange color...hard to call it a white beer.  Was served with an orange on the glass, as a cocktail. Didn’t taste too bad, yet, couldn’t please me. For an  American beer, in America, price isn’t that cheap. Maybe I am spoiled by being a Belgian :-)

Had this on tap in a frosted mug. It has no head and looks a lot like orange juice. It smells like orange and tastes orange and creamy. It’s pretty good and could be one of the typical beers I get at bars without a good selection now.

Had it half frozen in a frosted mug on tap at Applebee’s. No head by the time I got it. Completely opaque and yellow. An interesting looking beer. Aroma is fruity, orange and cirrus mostly with a hint of hops. Taste is really nice for a mainstream beer. Fruity and refreshing with a hint of hops at the finish. Think summer shandy without the specific lemonade taste. Not complex at all but still a good beer. Would definitely get this again in a pinch.
Fruity, light, very sweet. Not as complex as other Belgium whites I’ve had. Summer beer for sure.
Bottled and draft ; Devon ; UK ; Wheat,orange and spices aroma ; Hazy orange color with bigger lasting head ; Sweet taste with longer finish ; Creamy ; Medium body ; Very pleasant beer.
Pours an hazy peach with a huge head, aroma of apricot, cheese cake, wheat, flavor of pepper, butter, apricot, medium bodied
My favorite overall summer beer. Great unfiltered wheat. Good with orange slice and super cold.

I know it is not considered good form to like this brew, but at least it conforms fairly nicely with the style: cloudy. coriander etc. At least it has more character than Coors other beers, and is more affordable than other beers of its kind.

ON Tap. Pours a hazy orange with slight creamy white head. Aroma is a ripe citrus and slight vanilla malt. Taste is ripened citrus with a very slight spice note. Slighly oily feel. On tap not a bad little thirst quencher.
Poured from 330ml bottle @ The Longhouse, Kilmarnock. Cloudy peach coloured with nice white head. Tastes of orange, coriander, subtle peach. Very smooth and creamy. Much better than expected.
Hazy banana color.  Small head, minor carbonation.  Very little aroma.  Light tasting for its class.  Extremely drinkable session beer!
Bottle, samllish head, very hazy light orange colour, aroma and flavour of oranges and white fruit with just a hint of spice , medium mellow bitterness. Not too complex but nice and easy to drink.
Pours an orange color with white head. Smells of citrus and malt. Flavor is a mix of bitter and sweet and a crisp finish. Overall a very drinkable beer but poor for the style
Bottle. A very special white beer with fruity hints of orange. Although I had it in winter I presume it would be best served on a lazy sunny afternoon.

Smell of corn, yeast, a little peach. Unlively pour, cloudy straw, no lace. Tastes okay, clean but a little oily and soapy. Tastes far more like a pale ale than a wit. I remember this being far more hardier 10 or so years ago when I last had it, but maybe my memory is making things up.

Bottle. Pours cloudy pale golden in color with whitish head. Belgian

being present in flavor. Perfume, bready malts and flowers in 
finish.
Frothy and hoppy. Good carbonation. The texture is nice. A little watery. Some wheat components. No smell
Bottle at the Delday’s. Very cloudy golden colour. Very thin head. Quite gassy, but okay.

Bottle. Murky yellowish orange with a small quickly-disappearing white head. Aroma of yeast, coriander, orange peels, light vegetal notes.
Sweetish flavor of wheat, esters, citrus, some coriander and light grainy notes. Finishes slightly drier and acidic. Light to medium-bodied. Not a great Witbier, but pretty drinkable.

12oz bottle poured into a tumbler glass.
Turbid orange color with a small white head.
Fruity and highly estery nose, with spicy coriander, some soap and floral hops.
Sweetish malt, soft wheat tang, some bread, juicy orange, alcohol and low bitterness.
Light-med body, lively but not very crisp, feels a bit tired and alcoholic. So so.

I like this beer. Goes great with a steak. Pours a cloudy orange color w/a 1/2 head. Goes down smoothly with a slight hint of orange. The optional Orange slice is simply a garnish but adds to this beers sweet aroma. Either you like it or hate it. I like it.
My palate is not sophisticated enough to use all the tasting "buzz" words. It’s OK. The first beer I tried after a long (15 yr) absence from the beer world.
Orange in color and in flavor. A basic Belgian style beer with and average after taste.
Bottle at home. This is one of my favorite Belgian wheat ales to drink while at home and out at a bar.
Ahh, finally an application to properly catalogue my habits.  Now I just need Rate Wine and Rate Mix to round out my collection.
Rating from memory. Like most people, this was one of the first non-American lager beers I tried. If nothing else, it’s good for opening people’s minds.
One finger head, white small bubbles, mostly diminishing, hazy gold color, fruity grain aroma, orange and spice finish.

This is not a good beer. Not something I would order again. The fact that they serve it with an orange wedge just shows how much this beer sucks.

Pours medium muddy orange. Nose is coriander, other spices, a touch orangey, with an oxidized malt sweetness. Flavor is sweet biscuity malts, orange and coriander. Medium sweet finish. Crisp carbonation. Flavor is lacking complexity, freshness, and tartness. is also quite a bit darker side by side with other wits. Why does bjcp list them as a commercial wit?

Drinking a blue moon in an applebees in Sault Saint Marie after driving for stuff hours in a snow storm.  Best beer on trap that is available amidst a sea of macro crap.  Drinking it because there is nothing else.  It is blue moon.

Draught and bottle. Usually love the orange/coriander combo but this one's a little bland for me. Pale orange cloudy pour with then white head.

355ml bottle.

Cloudy yellow with a disappearing white head. Citrus, orange, zest and spicy yeast in the aroma. More orange in the flavour. Fizzy carbonation, smooth finish. Ok.

Hazy amber-orange pour.  Nose of artificial orange zest/dreamsicle with salty wheat malt.  Flavor is more of the citrusy orange and dreamsicle with touches of vanilla, coriander, and wheat malt.  Clean, sweet finish.  Easy drink, if not a tad sweet.  It is what it is.
Light, wheaty musky aroma. Light bodied, wheat flavor. Not wonderful, but not offensive. Decent for one of the big names.
Cloudy orange draft. White head. Tastes like a juicy orange wheat beer. A good beer for people who know nothing about beer.

Pours cloudy orange with a medium foam head.
It smells apricot, peach, curaçao but taste like paper.

Dobre piwo, ale ładniejsze z wyglądu niż w smaku. Ładny i mocno zmętniony kolor z wielkimi fusami drożdży. Zbliżony w smaku do belgijskich white ale jednak tam bardziej wyczuwa się tę skórkę od pomarańczy.

Its nice that Coors went to the trouble of creating this brand which is, on the whole, better than the other micro-brewery-busting-macro-brands.  Has the basic wit characteristics, but with a syrupy texture and almost overwhelming amount of the citrus and spice that characterize the style.
My intro to craft beer, and I still would recommend it as an excellent jumping off point. Pours a cloudy golden orange. Orange cream and wheat. A good bar beer when pickings are slim.

Served in a pint glass with an orange from the tap. The color is a orangish-hay color and is quite hazy with no head. The aroma definitely has a citrus scent. Once sipped, the beer coats your mouth nicely because of how full and thick it is, and the light yet fruity taste is pleasant.

Comprada en @cervezorama. De color dorado blanquecino, buena formación de espuma que desaparece pronto, muy blanca. Ligero aroma especiado de cilantro y naranja, poco cuerpo, trago muy largo. Muy fiel al estilo innegable la gran bebestibilidad. Una cerveza agradable sin más, que se bebe muy bien.

Lager glass. Cloudy pale orange with quickly dissipating head. Smell of wheat and orange peels. Great taste of wheat with the oranges hitting you in the after taste. Finishes light. Very easy to drink.

Pleasantly surprised. Spice and lemony bread aromas. Hazy yellow golden with a big white head. Balanced towards the sweet end but smooth with the spices. Medium bodied with a short finish. Very refreshing.
Cloudy copper.  Wheat.  Citrus, coriander.  Very drinkable.  No head.  Average beer.
330ml bottle. Drank from bottle so no idea how it pours or looks. Tasted a little fruity. Well, tasted a bit strange to be honest - couldn’t put my finger on what it tasted of. Wouldn’t have again.
Im Geruch aromatisch, hefig, Aprikose. Start süßlich, hefig. Mitte hefig, buttriges Gefühl, weich, Zitrus, gewürzt. Gewürzter Abgang, leicht malzig-bitter. Sehr lecker.
citrus, orange, hazy, cloudy, frothy, white foam, medium sweetness, lightly bitter, medium sourness, average carbonation,

Draft.  Pours cloudy, almost orange with a thin white head.  Minimal aroma, maybe citrus and yeast.  Average body, minimal flavor other than the orange they put in it but refreshing.  Seems a lot less peppery than most Belgian Whites and easier to drink.

Had on tap at Red Robin....cloudy orange color with a small white head. No lacing left on glass. Had to swirl to generate head. Smell of yeast, bread, orange. Taste is a watered down version of smell. OK beer.
This is really bad beer from the miller brewing company. Good.... Well not really good at all.

Reviewed from notes.

Bottle, while I was waiting for my flight at Philadelphia airport.
Pours a hazy orange colour beer with a two finger head, quickly gone. Some orange on the aroma. Taste is fruity, of oranges of course, sweet but only enough. Medium thickness, average carbonation, high drinkability. I wish my flight was delayed a bit more.

Aroma of orange and light spice.  Taste is basically a pale lager (though this is actually an ale), unfiltered, with added wheat and orange.  Refreshing, goes down smooth, and is flavorful for a macro product.  Label is nice, availability is good, and price is alright for a Belgian Whit.  However, there is still the fact that it is a Belgian Whit that tastes and feels more like an adjunct lager with added wheat and orange than a Belgian Whit.  It’s not quite as flavorful and substantial as I’d normally expect for the style, maybe a bit to the watery side.  Over all, I miss Sam Adams White Ale. ;)  And often Shock Top hits a similar "macro-whit" type flavor as Blue Moon at a lower price point (Though Blue Moon is probably slightly better than Shock Top as a beer, I should try drinking them back to back at some point for a more proper comparison).  It’s not the Belgian Whit I’d recommend to anyone for whom price or availability is a non-issue- but often it’s the only one in a given store or at a given location, or is one of only two of three in people’s price range.  It’s not bad for what it is, assuming one comes into the experience understanding that this is in essence a compromise between a real Belgian Whit and mass-market American beer drinker sensibilities.

Draft. The aroma is sweet yeast with some funk. The appearance is a murky golden. The taste is kinda citrus and rolls out to a yeasty finish. The yeast finish leaves the palate kinda weird. Overall, an ok beer. I would pick it over some, but not over most.

BEST BEER EVER MADE, but only with an orange (and/or a splash of orange vodka) and on draft.  Bottled is not the same.  Goes well with buffalo chicken pizza.

Maybe my nose is stuffed with alll sorts, and I can’t smell... but I think the aroma is small.
Hazy yellow color.

Great smell, golden amber, lively palate.   However, the taste doesn’t pay off at all.
Can notice hints of citrus in both the taste and aroma.  While not the biggest fan of wheaty or citrusy beer this one I can handle in small doses.

Pours a hazy orangish gold correct with a small white head that leaves little lace. Smell is of citrus orange with some spice. Taste is a very artificial orange taste, kinda like McDonald’s orange juice. Weak wit beer.
From the bottle i didnt get much of a head. Clear with a nice golden color. Aroma more on the malty side. Definite belgian-spice forward to this. Decent overall.

On tap. A whitish yellow, opaque ale with a nice white head. Taste is sweet, hints of orange and coriander. Rather bland. Almost no bitterness. Touch of acidity. Forgettable. Even though I’m told they are the same, I felt the glass I had was inferior to Rickard’s White. Must be in my head.

Very nice and smooth for a lighter beer then I normally drink thanks to the addition of oats in this wheat brew. Very refreshing and great for summer BBQ’s. Nice thick tight head of creamy bubbles and appealing color when poured into a glass from a 22 oz bottle.

Huge orange zest dominates the nose. Pale orange in color with almost no foam. Big bread/biscuit flavor with some strong notes of orange peels. Some subtle hops in the back of the palate. Overall, this is a decent brew with orange and biscuit overtones. I’d give this a C- rating.
Tiene un gran sabor, es mas rica la hoegaarden y mucho menos compleja que la anterior, aun así detecto un sabor moras y plátano una cerveza rica barata y fácil de conseguir en estados unidos

Creamy citrus flavor. Easy to drink and nice banana flavor at the end. Smell is also citrus/banana. Nice beer.

Pours hazy with fluffy ead. Smells mostly if belgian yeast and wheat. Funky flavor, a little watered down. Never did warm up to this one.

One of my favorite beers to drink. I like the unique taste and drinkability. Does not seem to have too much carbonation. Overall a pretty good beer.
A good beer for the summer. Slight orange and spice aroma and taste. Decent for a mass produced wheat beer.
Bland, but a nice mild spiced flavor. A bit of wheat malt, a mild spice, grass. Mildly floral, herbal and a well balanced floral brew. overall, mild,bland but weel drinkable and balanced.

citrus, bread, hazy, medium sweetness, full body, long finish,

This is a decent Belgian style wit that is more useful as an introduction to the general style for a newbie than as a good example of the style. It is mildly enjoyable, with citrus and wheat aromas and a sweet flavor. Hopefully this beer will lead some people to some much more interesting Belgian brews.

Refreshing wheat beer that makes up in drinkability what it lacks in flavor.  Has the slightest bit of sices and banana ueast.  Overpriced if you are at the liquor store, but it is typically the best thing on tap if the bar has no selection.

not nearly as bad as its made out to be. yeah, there’s a little lemon pledge there at the end, but overall id drink it if the only other stuff on tap was bud products.

Draft @ dulles airport. Â Served with a slice of orange!!!. Small head fairly carbonation. Banana coriander notes. Wheat malty aromas. Belgian yeast spicy notes. Quite sweet. Decent introduction to the belgian white style for people who haven’t really explored anything outside the typical macro brews. It has a bit more citrus than I would like, but it looks really nice in a glass. Decent, but there are a lot better options out there.

I think Coors should incorporate this in their campaigns. Beer for transvestites. Like Sean Bean in Accused. I’m rambling. I’ve never worn tights or high heels by the way.

The aroma had a faint Belgian yeasty presence. The color was a mildly cloudy yellow with a bubbly white head. It tasted like a Belgian white light. On tap at the loive garden in burlington vermont.

Blue Moon White Ale goes with anything. Whether you are at a ball game, a party, a bbq, a friend’s house, this beer is perfect. When poured into a chilled glass with a wedge of orange, you can’t ask for much else. It’s affordable and easy to find.

One of my favorite beers at the moment, after turning to whisky for a while I decided to make a return to beers and this has really caught my eye.
Very nice taste with or without orange (I prefer without) it has that proper beer taste but still easy to drink! I would really recommend this!

Bottle. Cloudy orange colour. Aroma of orange peel. The taste is sweet and sour with significant orange tones. As mentioned in earlier reviews it is a more watery than the european versions. One of my favourite styles of beer but this is not as good as many other white beers I have tried.
A great overall craft beer. One of my favorites. The typical beer in the kegerator.
Bright orange color with a pale white head. Very smooth citrus and orange flavor. Wonderful aroma and a great beer for any season.

Not a perfect wheat beer at all but a very decent, and distinctive, attempt. Lovely orangey aroma gives way to a more watery beer than its heavier European counterparts, but the taste is still there and it is delightfully easy to drink as well as being readily available.

Pours a hazy pale orange with a medium white head.  Aroma has light wheaty notes and a touch or coriander.  Flavor has citrus and coriander...definitely a wheaty or cereal note.  Mouthfeel is full and silky/creamy with a cerealy/coriander finish.

12oz bottle into a pint glass.

Pours a hazy yellow-orange with a 2.5 finger soapy head. Head retention was not all that great and lacing non-existant.

Aroma is a little bit metallic but also has banana, clove, bubblegum, and orange. All are fairly subtle and honestly unimpressive.

Flavors is banana and clove with a little bit of bubblegum. A little bit of burnt caramel and some bread. Kind of a slick soapy mouthfeel that is sticky and a little bit sweet. Gets tiresome to drink after awhile.

Overall, this beer is really worse than I remember from a long time ago. There are so many better examples out there of the style. Not something I will even think about having again.

One of my favorites,  Citrus, orange and very drinkable.  Ive tried other blue moon products but none of are as good as this one

Hazy golden color with a frothy white head that dissipates quickly.Light bodied with lots of carbonation, making it very refreshing. Aroma is of floral hops and lots of orange/ citrus. Also a slight bready smell. Taste the perfumey hops and orange throughout.  Has a slight spice with a lingering salty finish.

This American based Belgian style beer rivals it's counterparts in Europe. Enhance the taste with an orange slice! This is one of the best summer beers available; refreshing, feisty and sexy!

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
citrus, floral aroma, pours cloudy orange. medium sourness, light sweetness, Definitely better with some orange.
Decent if there are no better craft brews around.  Good for the warm weather.
Light yellow-orange color with a slightly citrus-spice aroma.  The taste is watered down biscuits, orange and coriander.  The mouthfeel is fizzy and light.  It tastes like a diet Belgian.
Have always enjoyed this beer on a relaxed night. I would not clarify it as a must have, though you probably already have.

I know this is a macro beer but it is actually pretty good, I wouldn’t be put off by that fact... it’s a quite widely available beer - styled to Belgian beer, strong orange and coriander qualities to its aroma and taste... tastes nice with an orange slice in it. Cheers!
Caramel, bread, hay, chocolate, chocolate, resin, herbs, basement aromas, grass, spruce

Certainly not the world’s premier witbier, it is produced by a macrobrewery after all.. However, for a macrobrew, it’s actually quite impressive. Good flavor, decent aroma, great mouthfeel. If my choice is this or Budweiser, hand me a Blue Moon every time. Really shines with an orange wedge. Pretty decent widely available beer.
Golden orange with off white head and syrupy look.  Bubble gum aroma with some citrus and candy fruit.  Taste is sweet slight wheat, rice, citrus.  Finish is sweet and thick.

Pours a cloudy gold with a thick white head. Bready-citrusy aroma. Very light floral aroma also detected. Lots of citrus flavor, but not from the hops. Slight bready flavor, and a little spicy. Enjoyable beer.

(bottle, 35.5cl) Cloudy, orange-golden colour with a big and slightly yellow foamy head. Fruity, yeasty and wheaty aroma with notes of orange- and lemon-peels, accompanied by a mildly spicy touch of coriander and grainy spots in the background. Moderately sweet and slightly sour flavour, rather light bodied with a mildly prickly carbonation. Wheaty, yeasty and mainly citric, slightly zesty taste with rising spicy notes of coriander towards the moderately sweet finish. Not bad, a decent Belgian White. 30.VI.12
Better than Coors, but the fact they dressed it with an orange peel meant it just needed additonal flavor. Faint traces of the Belgian pale style come through, but I’ll take a real Belgian any day
hazy white gold blond coloured body with a little white head a spicy yeasty fruity hoppy aroma a hoppy fruity spicy sweet taste with a sweet bitter finish

A very refreshing and mouth filling white ale. Compared very favourably with Hoe Garrden with a light citrusy bite with a slightly sweet lingering aftertaste. Very enjoyable ale that went well with food.
One of my all time favorites. try with an orange slice as suggested. it has a smooth all around flavor with a light after taste which makes it great for any occasion.

Best before November 12, 2012.



A: Pale straw and orange colored body with heavy carbonation activity even 5 minutes after the pour. A white creamy head once sat on-top now a creamy coating rests on top of the beer.



S: Not much in the aroma, hints at spices and orange, but really lacking here.



T: A clean wheat intro with an orange citrus running strong throughout, but not overpowering, hints of spice. Very easy to drink.



M: Light and crisp.



O: This is what it is, it’s that beer that is always cheap at the bars and is a nice substitute if nothing else is on tap. This is also a nice gateway into craft for some people.

Pour is a rather hazy gold color, looking unflitered. Taste is very much of wheat, and this beer is almost always served with an orange. Flavor has hints of orange, spice and yeast,  but otherwise pretty basic.

Draught @ Chili’s, Minneapolis airport

Served with an orange slice

Aroma is quite nothing with some hay, wheat and citron. Flavour has sweetish citron, some orange, hints of wheat and hay. Easy-going and slightly watery Hoegaarden clone.

Draught @ Minneapolis airport.

Pours murky yellow color with minimal head. Aroma of peach, orange, yeast and grass. Flavour of orange, peach, yeast and spices.

4313
260712. Tap at mccarran airport, las vegas. Pours hazy yellow with a high head. Aroma spices, wheat and lemon. Yeasty sweet lemony taste. Low palate. Not Bad.
Bottle. Pours hazy yellow with a small white head. Aroma is of wheat, lemon and coriander with a note of banana. Flavor is mildly sweet wheat, lemon, yeast, coriander. Not bad actually

Hazy golden pour with a soapy white head. Light aroma of coriander, orange peels, lemon and touch of yeast. Sweet malts, yeast and touch of orange in the flavor. Ends abruptly with almost no carbonation.

Draft in San Francisco Airport, SFO, with a slice of orange. Pours a cloudy but bright yellow color and a fair creamy white head. Aroma is fresh, herbal, with some yeasty, fruity and spicy hints. I get notes of orange peel, grass, basil, lemon, aniseed and green tea. Fine! Taste is mildly sweet with notes of grains, peanuts, citrus and especially rose apple. Pretty nice, simple and refreshing witbier with a crisp taste.
Draught: Hazy yellow color, foamy head. Aroma is light fruity with notes of oranges. Flavor is fresh, light notes of oranges, spices, also in the finish.
Hazy light orange colour. Aroma has some citrus and coriander. Has a fairly soapy feel. Orange is quite dominant. It’s a bit too sweet. Misses sharpness.
Pours hazy blond with a finger head. Smell is light citrus. Taste is orange, wheat, citrus. Ok.

0,35 flaske på Liberty of the Seas: 5,4% brygget med hvete og havre, koriander og curacaoappelsin. Bryggeriet foreslår at den serveres med en appelsinbit på glasset, og det gjorde seg. En god sommerdrikk.
Orange wheat aroma. Cloudy and murky with a decent head. Citrus taste. Great summer or winter drink. Typical Belgian White.
Draft to pint. Looks okay; orange with ample head. Smells doughy and Belgiany. Tastes the same with an average mouthfeel. Meh.
Draft pours a hazy orange color with a medium white head.  Aromas of  wheat, hay, light spice and citrus.  Light bodied, refreshing, but basic
I used to like this when I drank nothing but Coors light, but now that I’ve experimented with other beers this is not as good as I remember it, vanilla

12 oz. bottle to glass (sans orange slice). Pours hazy bright orange with a quick tight white head that fades to a thin collar. Aroma is citrus bready and malt/yeast. Taste has a citrus hop flavor and then the yeast and wheat really show through. Palate is thin and chalky dry.

Bottle 355 ml. Thanks to Minderbinder. Hazy pale yellow with a medium fully (and quickly) diminishing white head. Aroma of spices (coriander), orange and wheat. Taste of coriander and orange peel. Too much orange peel and coriander for me. Bad balance and not that refreshing because of  overwhelming orange/coriander.

Pours a hazy golden color with a rapidly disappearing off-white head. The aroma is oranges, coriander and yeast. The taste is bready (oats) with citrus notes. Hop taste not detected. There is a lingering bread-like aftertaste. The mouthfeel is medium and very smooth with just a touch of carbination. Refreshing.

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Cloudy and slightly heavy, just what I like in a wheat.  Another suprisingly good one from a heavyweight brewer.  The spices are not overpowering and the finish is clean.  A great starting point for someone jumping off the plain beer wagon.

Bottle 355ml.
Pours hazy whitish blond. Aroma is of spices (coriander), citrus (orange), wheat, yeast. Taste is of coriander, orange, wheat, sligth alcohol. Overall: decent beer in my opinion. Refreshing. Balance not too shabby.

Draft.  Pours a very cloudy soft yellow color with a small amount of head that quickly fades.  Aroma of orange, lemon, flowers, and wheat.  Taste is mostly citrus and wheat.  A little spiciness helps.  The belgian yeast flavor you get for most Witbiers is not detectable.  Smooth and the finish and light on the tongue.  A pretty good summer beer that is very refreshing on a hot day.  There are others that I like much better though.

On tap served very cold.
Very stron citrus aroma with floral notes. Hay as well can be discerned. It has the typical white cloudy robe, sparkling as well. Does not form a lot of head at all. Tastes really sweet and oily. Has a short finish and feels very astringent. Not the best white I’d had, but since it was well above 100 deg Fahrenheit, it did feel good. The orange peel flavour is too overtaking though in my opinion.
From the can. Pours a hazy orange with a thick foam. Aroma of citrus and spice. Oats makes this fairly smooth with some residual bitterness. Some citrus in the finish.
Bottle from a shop. I actually find this beer offensive. It’s fairly grim in many different ways.

Bottle 355ml. An unusual wheat beer, good malty body, almost no banana or agrume notes but a very pleasant melon, almond and massepin notes with a round and resinous hops. A very special and pleasant one but not a wit for sure !
Fine stateside belgian wheat! Nothing crazy or unique, but very solid belgian style wheat ale!

Bottle at Mike and Laura’s wedding. Pours hazy yellow with a thick White head. Like a real Wheat beer. That’s where the similarity ends. Nose is knock-out orange and coriander. Like it’s been laced with essence. Flavour is overly sweet and basically unacceptable. I remember drinking this on tap in New Orleans in 2005 because it was the closest thing to Hefeweizen. I enjoyed it then but that was before I became a dick about beer.

Decent enough Belgian white. Nice drink ability. Easily available white. Not bad stuff 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

355ml bottle [brewed by Molson in Canada]. Hazy golden colour with small to average totally fading frothy white head. Fruity aroma, mainly grapefruit, some citrus, some orange. Taste is slightly sweet fruity, some bitter grapefruit-like notes, a bit earthy.
Good everyday beer. Milky golden color, not much head. Has a subtle hint of honey flavor. Good everyday beer.
Wasn’t at all impressed with this. VERY hoppy beer. Far to gassy for my liking. From the bottle. not a fan
Not much head. Golden color, can feel the spiceness. Very drinkable specially in a hot summer
Delicious everyman beer. The one beer all my beer drinking friends agree on and share every time.

From a can into a plastic cup, drank in Citizen’s Bank Park home of the Philadelphia Phillies.  Pours a hazy tan with maybe an inch of head and only a little lacing (maybe due to the plastic cup).  Decent fruity aroma with cloves.  Mouthfeel is pretty thin for a wheat beer, I usually expect something a lot creamier.  Taste is also pretty subdued.  It tastes like a wheatbeer but much more watered down.  All the elements are there, spice, (barely any) bubblegum, fruit, but very moderate.  Meh.  I was really hopeing for something better from this beer but it’s below average at best.  More drinkable that the macros but I wouldn’t have more than one before switching to water.  By the time it warmed up it became totally undrinkable.
From bottle. Hazy amber golden. Slightly herbal aroma, quite lactic, little peppery. Taste is very earthy and vegetal, peppery and a little herbal. Fairly acceptable on the palate. This was rank
Good tasting beer but leaves a different aftertaste.  It’s a middle of the road beer for me.
Decently priced.  Best with an orange slice from tap.  Helped start the revolution of smaller batch brews across America.
The citrus really helps to improve the overall taste of an otherwise decent beer. Drink with an orange slice.
Has obvious wheat character and qualities, but is bland compared to many of its counterparts.
