Classic beer for myself, when it comes to wheat beers its not the greatest I personally find allegash to be better but good beer none the less.

Bottle from Tesco. Thanks Janette. Cloudy light amber brown colour, not much head. Aroma of mild chicken tikka masalla. Bland flowery fruity aroma. Quite smooth. An interesting interpretation of a Belgian white.
Recommended this by several people over the years, finally got around to reviewing; pretty solid for a lower-end witbier, but far from the top.

On tap and bottle. Hazy orange color. Smell of fruit, oranges. Taste is sweet, fruity. Nice summer beer. Overall, I rally liked this beer for several years. This was my favorite before my taste developed to IPAs and Stouts. Can't drink it as much now, but still a solid beer.

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Pours a murky hazy light-pale orange, with no head. Beer is very subtle. There’s a coriander "hay" like taste, which dominates the roof of the mouth. It starts off pleasant enough, with subtle hay/wheat tastes and orange-peel - but gets a bit boring after a while. There’s something missing but can’t quite put my finger on it.
Pours a dark golden color. Smell is alive with oranges and spice. Taste is refreshing, oranges and spice, a touch of wheat. Overall an enjoyable beer.
Strong coriander/citrus taste. Silky mouthfeel.possibly result of oats in the malt. Almost rotten aroma. Pretty fruity
Good summer beer.  Having an orange is helpful.  Cloudy orange color with moderate head.
Aroma of orange and wheat.  Pours cloudy orange with hardly any head.  Taste is wheat, citrus, and malts.  Good beer.
Bottle from b&m in Chester-le-Street. A cloudy yellow beer with lemon, orange and melon flavours and a sweet zesty finish.
Draft at olive garden. Pour is a haze orange yellow with a thin head. Taste is a bitter grass. Finish is a clean bitter. Very good beer.
Nice citrus aroma with a nice foamy head. Very nice light and citrus flavor. Very refreshing.

Pours a hazy orange colour, not really a white beer. Aroma is orange, cream, subtle spice, hint of banana. Palate is a bit thin, would be nice if the oats gave more of a fuller mouthfeel. Taste is a bit boring. There’s the usual witbeer flavours but the finish is too short lived. I’m into the smell more than the taste. Average.
Great taste with a great price. Not too bitter but not to sweet. Nice hint of orange flavor.
Fuck yeah.  This is classic BELGIUM shit right here.  right up there with stella and delirium tremens for best belgiums ever.

Dark golden/orange pour with hardly any head (doesn’t look like a wit) aroma of orange and wheat very light.... taste is of wheat, oranges ,sweet malts little sugary with a light spicy bite of coriander .. dry finish meh low carbonation medium body
---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

orange amber colour, very hazy thick-looking liquid, pours no head. the aromascape is wheatish with a very pleasant herby nature to it. this is accompanied by a citrusy, but pleasantly sweet fruity aroma seeping from the glass. smells extremely sweet and inviting. the taste is light but well balanced; very enjoyable. there is an initial sourness to this, but the sweetness quickly grabs it and brings up some of that extremely subtle bitterness. and i mean very, very subtle. the palate is dry and light with a slick texture. suits the herb side well and overall nature of the beer.
nothing world changing but an enjoyable light herb wheat style beer, maybe good for a summer day on the porch.
Draught at bar. Thick orange color, white head. Bitter sweet taste with orange, grass, spices and clove. Pretty ok, but far from the best american wheats.
Nod bad for a mass produced American Witbier. Has nice bits of wheat, coriander, faint orange...finishes very smooth, almost creamy. Drank it at room temperature, sans orange from a tumbler.

One beer I had at a mother’s day cookout last weekend.  Bottle poured, a cloudy golden color.  Aroma of orange, coriander, grass and light malt.  Taste is sweet and creamy, not a bad macrobrew witbier.
From notes.  Bottle.  Slightly hazy dark yellow with white head. Aroma is wheat, orange peel and some coriander. Flavour is the same with a touch of bitterness.

Opaque light good , small white head that doesn’t last. Bready citrusy aroma with a hint of earthy coriander. Flavor is light but nicely rounded. Pretty ok flavor of wheat dough, orange citrus, drying grainy coriander and some light pale malty sweetness. Perhaps a bit overrated publicly, but in a blind taste test I wouldn’t knock this too bad.

My girl wanted a Blue Moon with lunch and I want to get to 100 beers by 12/31/12. So here’s #25 for 2012

A few month old 12oz bottle brewed In Golden, Colorado, drank from a shaker. Aroma sweet wet wheat, some coriander spice, alcohol, slightly musky. Murky cider color 1/2 inch white head no lacing. Taste is light, earthy, mild citrus and spice notes in the finish. Medium palate, finishes very smooth and creamy. Not bad at all. Like most Belgium style beers I liked it better at room temperature. Will re-rate.
on tap at olive garden, kissimmee FL. FL VC #16. a dumbed down wit for the masses. decent quaff, but lacking a lot of what makes the style enjoyable. id drink it over any other BMC product.
This is a very cloudy golden beer. It’s got a level of sweetness to it and very spicy - I can’t tell if that’s nutmeg or what in there, but it’s got the citrus notes to it. Meh.
Pours cloudy amber wtih a small white head. Aroma is orange, light malt and light grass. Flavour is orange, malt, light flower and light grass.
Citrus nose; satumas and a slight spicy note in the taste, a hint of hoppiness in the fairly thin finish; a pleasant creamy mouthfeel; an alright beer for the style but not on my re-buy list.

Pretty much what everyone else has said - a bit of spice and wheat, a bit watered down, but not bad for a macro version of the witbier style.  I had this early in my beer days and remember it being much more interesting than the common pale lagers I was drinking at the time.  Still, compare this to Hoegaarden, and you’ll realize it’s an average "transition beer" at best.

(bottle) Cloudy amber, no head. Citrus with slight ester aroma. Med body and medium carbonation. Flavour is sweet and citrus with some interesting yeast and spice notes. Overall a reasonable mainstrwam brewery version of a non mainstream style, but will disappoint those looking for the real thing.

This beer tastes as murky as it looks.  Not only is it cloyingly sweet, the sweetness is more reminiscent of HFCS than a nice caramel or bready malt.  Although the style calls for a spicy, yeasty taste, I still feel the flavor is unclean, as if it were immature.  For those that homebrew, it’s like trying beer straight from primary on day 2.

Beyond that, it lacks any noble/euro hops flavor/aroma.  It might have coriander but it certainly isn’t fresh.  TANG-like orange aroma permeates the senses.  I don’t want to sound harsh, but even if you’re in a mood to drink this beer it doesn’t settle very well.
Pours a cloudy orange with white head that quickly dissipates.  Medium body with orange aroma and taste.  Good with or without the traditional orange slice
A decent wheat beer with orange flavours and a bit of spice adding to the complexity. A cloyingly sweet finish though. More so than most in the style even.
Served in bottle so hard to judge appeatance, also served too cold. Taste is typical wheat beer, but bit too sweet. (Houston 201201)
Very popular with the ladies. I can see why, it doesn’t taste like beer but still it’s not bad.

Draft in Edinburgh (and many times in the states). This is a darkish witbier with a distinct orange hue (and slice). Definite hints of wheat and the ubiquitous orange, but I feel not as spicy or complex as the Belgian versions. Unnecessarily strong at 5.4% too, especially for such a perfect summer/daytime beer. Good amid a sea of mass produced mediocrity.

Spicy citrus aroma with very light floral hop in the background. Cloudy pale gold/orange appearance. Taste is spicy upfront then fades to the citrus finish. The spices give it a good bite but not hoppy at all, head retention almost non existent, good carbonation. Good beer, definite go-to choice for summer time. (tasted by itself but I’ve enjoyed many with the traditional orange slice)

Bottle into weizen, no freshness date
four finger white head!! 
The beer tastes like sourdough bread, and  Belgian candi sugar
The cloudiness suggests being unfiltered, but I don’t know if it is, or is not.  
The mouthfeel is too watery to really feel like a beer, or a witbier for that matter.  

Try Hoegarden instead.

Originally reviewed: 6/13/11. 12oz bottle, best by Oct. 3, 2011 printed on the side. Poured into a pint glass. Pours a cloudy pale gold with a thick 2-finger white head. No retention; no lace left behind. The nose is full of citrus tones of lemon and orange. Some mild stale graininess to the nose. Faint sweet-smelling spices. Not bad. The mouth is firm. Good spritzy carbonation gives this one a fresh feel. The flavor is not all that bad on this one. Mild spices, lemon juice, bready aftertaste. Whispers of tartness on the finish. 

I gotta admit, I really enjoy the "Blue Moon" movement for the most part (with the exception of their Pumpkin-version). Their brews are quaffable and the flavors are mild and easy going. I’d have this one again, and I will for sure revisit this one on draft.

33cl bottle. Hazy yellow/orange with almost no head. Nose : lemon lollypop
, mandarine, some little yeast, clove. Sip : Water body with delicate oil smoothness and medium carbonation. Sweet soap water, lemon juice, orange zest flavors. Drinkable stuff, nothing more and no , I’m not going to put any fruit into my beer, I rather choose a beer with a better citrus twist.

Bottle from ASDA in Hamilton cons 2012-04-17 Uddingston
AR: coriander, yeast, lemon peel
AP: hazy honey colored hue, wee fizzy deminishing head
F: coriander, mandarine juice, fizzy, schweppers lemonade, a bit sour, low bitterness

Draft at an Applebee’s. Pick your poison situation. For becoming a mass distributed beer, Blue Moon is what it is. It’s a wheat of moderate quality, yet pretty dependable. You can pick up on the wheat right off the bat with hints of spice coming in and a little orange on the aftertaste. If you allow them to put an orang slice in this draft, you’re a punk. Just saying.
From the tap came a cloudy brew with barely any head. Very faint aromas of bubble gum and malt. Medium bodied with mild bubble gum flavor. Meh !
Tap. Hazy yellow amber with no real head. Smells grassy, appley, citizenry, and a hint of spice. Tastes sweet and pop corny and grassy. Medium bodied.	Lingering sweetness.
Pours a cloudy orange color with a white head. Aroma of sweet malts, wheat, citrus and lemon peel. Taste is very similar with some hints of banana. Body is on the thin side with good drinkability.

Sunday 9th May 2010 (Mothers Day), this beer was taken in the ’Spenser’s Bar’ of the Grand Canyon Hotel (Williams, Arizona), after a Railroad round trip out to the South Rim.

The beer came with a mucky, murky, cloudy, yellowy, orangey body. No head and only a poor attempt at having a collar. Most likely not helped by a segment of orange stuck to the glass rim.

The smell was almost typical Witbier, semi-sour lemons and pink grapefruits being the aromas I picked up.

A bit over carbonated for my taste, but almost true to style, Belgian wise, anyway. The flavours more or less followed the smells, not bad at all.

This style isn’t a favourite of mine, but I’m glad I gave this a go, it did refresh me after the journey, but I didn’t have two, one was more than enough for me.

Pours golden yellow and opaque, thick white head diss altars quickly, smells lightly of orange peel and wheat, sweet orange peel and wheat taste, lightly carbonated on the tongue with a slightly dry and thick texture.
Pours opaque yellow with minimal head. Tastes of citrus and spices. Probably the best beer that you can buy in a gas station

The beer pours a hazy yellow color with a large white head. The aroma is manly made up of wheat with a little bit of coriander and pepper, as well as a little bit of orange peel. The flavor has a mix of coriander and orange peel, with some wheat thrown in as well. Thin mouthfeel and medium carbonation. Nothing too exciting, but not too bad.
Pours a cloudy orange color with a small white head. The aroma is orange and citrus. Taste is sweet orange and tangerine.  Smooth finish with a light body.  Overall a decent brew.

bottle   pours hazy orange  with white head that is transient . aroma is spicy yeasty and orangey  . taste is fruity and spicy  . medium carbonation . it’s ok but lacks the complexity and depth of the best in this style

For a mass produced beer this is pretty good. Flavors are prominent and aren’t too out of balance. Orange, wheat, coriander and other spices. Something that tastes a little of rubber but somehow it’s not off putting. A good session beer. Hate to admit something made by coors is pretty good.

Appearance was the best part, orangish golden with hazy 1 finger diminishing white rocky head, no lacing. Aromas where wheat ,oats, little grass.Slight sweetness in malt, with slight sourish yeasts. Taste was wheat and straw with hints of sour yeasts, hops where mild pine with slight sweetness of malts upfront. Palate was smooth with spritzy carbonation. Medium body with an average oily sour finish. Strange Wheaty  Brew...

Bottle.  Aromas are citrus and sweet.  Taste is sweet and citrusy with no notable bitterness.  Body is light with average carbonation.  Overall, not a great example of anything.  Better than fizzy yellow stuff, but not by much
Pours a cloudy orange yellow. Big white head that dissipates quickly. Smells like fresh citrus, and sweet malts. Taste is similar. Gotta give them credit for trying to brew a decent beer.
I’m a big fan of the oat and Belgian wit yeast. Blue moon is a pioneer ale.  The beer deserves respect.

Hazy medium gold with some light fizz and a a thick white lasting frothy head. Smell of wheat, straw, orange, light citrus hops. Medium prickly thin body. Strong taste of wheat. Little bit of banana that works very well with the orange. Some citrus hops. Coriander dry finish. Very refreshing. An excellent pint. Is this the same as Rickards White?

Blue Moon is what it is.  It is the typical entry point on the sweeter side (Sam Adams on the bitter side) for BMC drinkers to get into "better" beer.  While not what I consider "craft" beer, Blue Moon is a fairly stable, if boring, wit.

Hazy orange with white head.  Smells like wheat, orange, a little coriander, a little clove.  Taste is a fairly flat (read: boring) orange/coriander/wheat.  Nothing shines here.  Fairly high carbonation.

Aroma: Orange peel and oats.



Appearance: Dull orange hazy body. Pure white head that lasts. Slight lacing. 



Taste: Sweet, soft wheat flavour. Coriander bitterness. Slight soapy taste. 



Palate: Medium bodied. Very little carbonation. 



Overall: Quite a flat taste and not the most refreshing of beers, but very drinkable.
Tap @ Elephant & Castle, Chicago. Hazy golden colour with a whit head. Wheaty aroma. Flavour is wheaty, a bit yeasty and with a hint of citrus.
Bottle. Unclear dark yellow with tiny white head. Aroma is wheat, orange peel, fruit and a little coriander. Flavour is wheat, medium sweet, orange peel, little coriander, hops and a little bitter.
Bottle from Kris Wines. Nice head with medium duration. Color is golden. Aroma and taste are butterscotch, coriander, cheese, malt and hops.
Unclear yellow with a white head. Aroma is sweet, wheaty, spicy, orange peel and buttery. Flavor is quite sweet. Sweet finish. 210312
Jonathan’s favorite cruise time beer. Nice coriander and orange peel refresh-ness.
It’s ok, all senses are a bit flat, but easily drinkable - average session beer
hazy orange color, aroma of orange, coriander, wheat, flavor is the same, some spices, not very good, not even for the style
By far the best offering from coors. Orange yellow color with a decent head. Smell of oranges and similar taste. Good drinkability and thin to moderate body.

Maybe my first introduction to a Belgian White should have been something other than this one. The appearance was disappointing with low head retention but the color wasa vibrant dark gold. This being one of my first Belgian whites one might say I wasn’t mature enough to properly judge BM. The flavor was bitter and the spices and fruits were too sour. Adding an orange to BM didn’t help me change my mind. Palate was a harsh bite. Once the temp. rose a little its bitterness and sourness grew much worse. Definitely not a beer I would attempt to try again.

Bottle 355 ml from Bier-Bienne (CH). Orangy blonde opalescent, white creamy head fugacious, living sparkling. Scents of wheat and orange, yeast, coriander. The taste is relatively low acid, gree apple, orange, yeast and sipy palette. It’s clean, a bit dry, but thirst-quenching without other.
Enjoyable every now and then, especially in the summer or when out to dinner and the choices are limited.
Bottle - pours pale cloudy orange, some carbonation, no head. Light sweet taste to it with a medium body. Opted not to include the recommended orange peel. Nothing special.

Great beer that got bought out by the big guy. Don’t let it fool you. Great brewers and great beer. I had a blast meeting the crew and hanging out at gabf this year with them. Try the peanut butter. 

Look golden yellow with a lot of activity. The activity will never end. 
Smell. Orange and citrus. 
Taste orange with lime. Spice perhaps coriander nice on the nose. Gets better as the temp outside rises. 
Feel lots of co2. Not my favorite but better then some on feel. 

Overall nice goto beer.
A beer is not perfect in and of itself if the best way to drink it is to add something.  In this case an orange makes this a damn good beer.
Tap - average size foamy head, hazy dark straw color, sweet malty aroma and flavor with mild citrus hops

aroma some spice, hard to finger the spice but a blend, color, hazy light amber, nice head, some lacing, taste, slight bitterness, followed by fruity spice blend, nice light maltness backend, overall, not bad I would buy again.

11/13/11 blue moon.

First time ive Really had this... and first time on tap

F+A= loads of orange...even the acid, dust and pale malt. Its on the sweet side fo sho, lightly spiced but no way a wit...mediocre Monotonous boring american wheat.  5/2.5-/5/3/12-

A bit of savory on the end

Botttle, Poured a orange-yellow color, minimal head.  Aroma of mild orange, coriander, spice.  Med-light sweetness.  Above ave carbonation.  Light body.  Havent had this in awhile.  I can see why they recommend the orange.  The flavor has a good presence in here, along with some coriander spice. A bit too sweet for my taste but drinkable.

a: light sraw color, slightly hazy with a foamy head that quickly reduced, very little lacing

s: hints of corriander and orange peel

t: sweet taste with hints of orange,

m&d: very light mouthfeel helped by slight carbonation.

Bottle from Tesco, Syston.  This looks good - cloudy orange with a nice sized head considering it came from a bottle.  A mild, yeasty aroma - typical of the style.  Smooth on the palate.  The taste lets it down, though - despite nice initial bitter lemonyness* it is short lived and doesn’t have enough depth of flavour.  Neither excellent nor bad. *Not really a word.
The smell is fruity in its aroma. Very nice pour with a light white head. The taste has a bit more fruity flavor then I am used to but it was smooth. The aftertaste is a bit metallic but not too bad.

The beer that wooed me away from light lagers.  I don’t care who brews it, this is a delicious, solid beer.  I enjoy it with an orange slice as well.  Goes down smooth and easy.. and a big step up from it’s main competitor (shock top).

355ml bottle. Large though fading rocky white, deeply cloudy dull light orange, rather lively too. Vanilla cheesecake dominates on the nose, quite biscuity with cereal notes like Frosties. Cereal, lemon and vanilla on the palate. Somewhat thin and empty from the mid-palate onwards. Medium carbonation, almost nonexistent bitterness/finish. Dull, sweet and single-minded but inoffensive.

Ahhhh, this is a perfect reminder that the beer "always tasted better back in the 90s..." Those 90s really knew how to throw a party - way better than the 80s. What beer do you remember from the 80s? Exactly. The 90s belonged to THIS beer. Too bad it’s 2012 now...

There’s a lot of people out there who feel the need to hate on this beer just because it’s a Coors product. Personally, I took the opposite approach. I went into it not expecting much, but I was pleasantly surprised. It’s a light beer, yellow-orange in color with decent flavor and a smooth finish. Also, I’m not one for fruiting beer, but try adding the orange slice typically served with this beer. it complements the flavors in the beer extremely well.

Draught at Treasure Island Casino. Strong bubblegum and sweet banana aromas are pleasing on the nose with some sice thrown in for good measure. Looks good in the glass, although it was a plastic cup. Pale yellow colour with a small white flat head. The flavour was pleasing in the mouth and I found this to be a very easy to drink beer that I could easily drink several of.
Smokey look almost. Very smooth. Good head. Went down great. Heavy beer. Great for dinners
this beer just tastes good...from start to finish, this is my go to beer when i cannot make a choice...it is easy to drink but not a guzzler...i can even drink it warm.

355 ml bottle. Mild banana/yeast aromas. Cloudy yellow, medium white head. Tastes of banana, citrus fruit, mildly sweet. Medium body, creamy texture, average carbonation. Medium citrusy finish. Nice light tasting summer beer. Don’t like that it’s a macro but I’ll give credit where credit is due.
Pale orange body, small white head. Ok yeasty aroma with wheat and lemon. Light body, moderate carbonation. Spicy and dusty witbier flavour with some coconut.
I had this one a long time ago. If I have the chance to drink it again, I’ll update this rating
Det doftar åtminstone lite belgisk veteöl, om än artificiellt. Men smaken är vattnig och tunn. A disgrace, som engelsmännen säger.
A good common standby... Reliably Tasty but only slightly better than average...not as good in bottle..x2

Pouring gave a nice foamy head to the glass.  A strong citrusy aroma was gfollowed by the trademark somewhat strong citrus taste.  It left a clean taste on the palate and overall was an enjoyable beer, although better suited to summer.

Pours a cloudy orange yellow. Big white head that dissipates quickly. Smells like fresh citrus, and sweet malts. Taste like fresh spices, lots of sweet citrus fruits, and crisp sweet malts. Clean crisp after taste. This is a sweet beer, but is not sugary, just fruity and malty. I think this is very refreshing.

355ml Bottle in UK, branded "North American Craft Beer". Pours a murky hazy light-pale orange, with no head. Beer is very subtle. There’s a coriander "hay" like taste, which dominates the roof of the mouth. It starts off pleasant enough, with subtle hay/wheat tastes and orange-peel - but gets a bit boring after a while. There’s something missing but can’t quite put my finger on it.
Bottled 355ml. The nose is dominated by coconut. Murky pale orange appearance. Sweet. Caramel showing up. Some residual sugars in the finish which is reminiscent of coriander and coconut. Decent.
pours murky yellow with a white small head. aroma of coriander and citrus. taste is sweet, spicy, citrus, with low carbonation. perfectly enjoyable.

Pours a hazy orange with a short lived white foam that retreats to the edges. The aroma contains subtle coriander and citrus notes, but the main component is wheat funk. Flavor wise the wheat dominates but there is also almost a candy like citrus flavor as well. This has a much heavier body than most Belgian white ales and fairly low carbonation. It is drinkable, but there are many better white ales out there.
Bottle from the liquor store. Taste is orange. Smells like orange mixed with coors. Oh wait..thats what this is. Not bad for mass produced.

355ml bottle @ Limon Restaurant, San Francisco, CA



Pretty basic and bulky wheat ale with hints of spices and malts. Slightly different from the original Belgian ones, but still kinda enjoyable with spicy food.
One of the better mass produced beers; it was surprisingly not bad. Sweet citrusy flavor with the belgian wheat and yeast characteristics typical of a witbeir.

Bottle.  Pours a coudy orange.  Small white head that left a nice creamy ring around the glass.  Suprisingly good lacing.  Citrus aroma.  Mild wheat flavor.  A bit sweet.  Very smooth texture.  Light and extremely drinkable.  One of the better mass produced beers.  Always a good choice as a go to beer around the house.
Good, but I can’t drink too much of this.  It is good in the summer time. But it is a little too sweet...."Gut Rot."

Enjoyed from bottle in Orange, CA at my hotel room before a weekend at the NAMM convention while watching a Clippers game.  Appearance a murky bright gold with a thin white head.  Aroma of orange peel, some malt, a bit of sweetness.  Taste for a mass produced beer really isn’t that bad, but there are definitely better craft versions of this.  The orange peel equally comes out in flavor and it finishes crisp.  I’ve had Blue Moon probably a hundred times in my life, it exposed me to different non-lager styles but I definitely had horrible gas the morning after drinking many bottles of this.  Surprised I haven’t rated it until now, guess its been a while since I’ve had it.  Not bad, giving extra points sine it is a pivotal beer to my drinking upbringing.

Bottle, out of my Hennepin glass. The Maudite glass is washed, but recently, so I’m still rocking the Hennepin tonight. Pours cloudy green-cold, 1-finger white head, short-lived, poor lacing. Nose is spicy wheat, coriander, some citrus, little else. Flavours of faded citrus, cream of wheat, some real spice and tang in the finish. Dead-similar to Rickards White, but maybe a touch more citrus, and a shade less watery.

Draught at Viaduct Tavern, London. Very hazy yellow brown color. Fairly citrusy aroma with orange zest and mango. Sweetish wheaty flavor with low bitterness, citrus, citric acidity and some herbal notes. Fairly full body for this style of beer with some oiliness in palate.
12 oz bottle pours hazy copper with a white head.  Aroma is fruit and yeast.  Taste is also heavy on the yeast with a subtle sweetness.

Long one of my favorite bar draws, as it’s always crisp and comes with an orange piece. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
Kennyshomebrewing.blogspot.com
Too much orange and too sweet -- problems only exacerbated by adding an orange slice. Still, the best option at many less adventurous bars.

I enjoy this beer pretty much as a go to beer thats decent in almost any situation. Normally I take it with an orange slice but for this particular rating I am going without it. Bottom line, decent but nothing special. Aromas of creamy malt, light touch of wheat and some lemon in there.

Bottle from Sainsburys. Cloudy pale blond with short-lived white bubbly head. Aroma is a bit soapy, bit creamy malt, lots of wheat. Taste quite creamy, bit of lemon, something strange in there too. Not so much wheat but a hint there. Bit of butter too and something herbal. Not so bad, but not really that great.

Bottle from tesco. Typical wheat pour with a fast disappearing head. When I was younger I didnt like wheat beer. A few trips to germany and Belgium put that right. This stuff is foul, drain pour.

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
Bottle @ home. Cloudy hazy yellow, small white head. Smells wweird, wheat and paint somehow. Taste malts, some sort of sweet-sourness. Low carbo, low body.

first off reviews of beers are so subjective I rarely read them nor expect anyone to put much stock in my reviews. Let me preface this review by saying my wife gives the bitter beer face for every beer I ever had her try. This blue moon was the only beer she not only drank more than a sip of but finished it and liked it. Figures I finally get her to like a beer and its an expensive one. I personally like this beer as well. it is very smooth, not bitter, hint of orange and just a very smoot, good tasting beer.

From the iced mug at Billy’s Tavern in Troy Hill, Pittsburgh.  Immediate tastes of orange as it was poured into the mug with an orange segment dividing the rim.  Pleasant aromas and a smoothness that is not common in American imitations of Belgian whites.  Surprisingly good.
olor leve a citricos y al paladar suave sin nada de especial,es una cerveza suave bastante agradable

A - pours cloudy deep yellow with  high white head and some lacing.

S - citrus notes - oranges, light spices 


T - simple wheat/ grains on the nose, coriander and oranges on the palate.  Strange buttery ending


O - OK beer. drinkable, less than average. 

5-

December 29, 2011 bottle at my buddy Dan’s house.   Aroma is coriander and orange. Taste is similar with some wheat / grain.  First time having this since started rating but in past remember a cloudy orange pour with some decent head.
I like the availability of this beer. I would choose it over Bud,Miller or Coors . Yes I know it is brewed by Coors

Bottle from Brass Monkey. Served with a wedge of orange. Pours hazy yellow with fully white head. Citrus and spice aroma. Balanced flavour that has a buttery richness. I find this a little sickly and the finish is a bit rough but overall a decent beer.

Pours super hazy and bright yellow with a medium sized white head. 



Surprisingly the first thing I smelled as I brought the glass up to my nose was dead leaves, which is sort of weird and unexpected for a wit, this fades fast though leaving room for the coriander and orange to dominate the bouquet. This beer doesn’t smell like much though, honestly the beer is pretty neutral on aroma unless I really swish it around in the glass and get my nose in there. As pronounced as the aromatic spices are in the flavor of this beer I would imagine that they would be a little more detectable in the aroma, I guess not. 



The flavor is almost brash with it’s use of spicing, I dig coriander and orange peel & I like them together so this isn’t much of a problem for me but it’s very obvious that the primary focus of this beer is on spices. The beer is fruity, sweet but not sticky, spicy in a yeast driven way (in addition to the spice driven flavor). The beer is mildly tart and really nicely full flavored. 
 

Seriously though get out of here with all these super low ratings, this isn’t one of the great witbiers but it would be rated far more highly if it were from even some crappy brewpub.

Bottle from Tesco, Forres

Orange-yellow, cloudy, bubbly white head that dissipates to thin layer, reasonable lacing 

Aroma - Oranges, light spices, apricot, no hops. 

Taste - Orange, some spices, buttery popcorn, muddled, quite bland, not great .

Palate - soft carb, smooth, light to medium body. Finish - quite rapid, orange, popcorn with a rather unpleasant buttery tail.

Overall -  Not great, yukky buttery finish - drain pour. Disappointed with this one.
Draft. Hazy orange with a ring of head. Very spicy nose. Taste is tons of spice some citrus.
Pretty much standard for an American "Belgian". Drinkable and not bad for the price. ............,.......................,.................

Two bars in Miami.
AROMA: citrus, grass
APPEARANCE: typical witbier yellow
TASTE: light sweetness, lightly bitter, medium sourness
PALATE: medium body, slick feel, lively, abrupt finish
OVERALL: a witbier indeed, but without any character, the citrus needs to be balanced against other aromas, bit too slick which takes away the refreshing nature of witbier
For a mass produced beer, it definitely holds its flavor well. Out of the "mainstream" brews this is usually my go to beer.
Poured into pint glass from 12oz bottle. Hazy yellow color with white head. Smells and tastes of citrus and wheat. Inoffensive mouthfeel. A decent brew a notch above the usual adjunct lagers.

Usually my number one choice when I’m at a bar and it’s on tap. Have always enjoyed its sweetness effect and enjoyed the smooth taste as well. Some people may say they can’t drink a number of these in one sitting but I disagree. May be more expensive than other beers but worth the extra dollar in my eyes. No aftertaste to it makes it one of my favorite choices.
Draft. Pours orange with thick white head. Smells of citrus fruit and some spice. Not bad for a macro.

Had this in the JFK airport and it cost me 8.70.  Worst money I’ve paid for a beer besides the Keith’s I had at  a Blue Jay’s game.  There’s something that tries to be wheat in the beginning that quickly gives way to bleach.  Foul aftertaste minimal, but present nonetheless.

[Keg at Copa, Reading] Cloudy yellow-orange with a moderate, regular white head and a sligth fizz.  Decent orange and lemon aroma and initial flavour, before it goes rather old and dusty with hints of soap and cardboard.  Dry finish.  Poor, apart from the aroma.

I love Belgian style beers and this one is very good.  When chilled, this beer goes down smooth with a nice finish.  Like some Belgian styles you can certainly taste the orange on the finish while there are hints of it in the bouquet.
Blue moon is my go to beer of the generic brands. It is seasonal brands are even better.

Hazy orange color with medium white head. Sweet wheaty aroma, with orange, some hay and soap.. Wheaty taste, with lemon and orange peel, soem grass, yeast, dry finish slightly bitter. Couldn’ taste the coriander (which is fine by my taste :D ).

I must admit I was pleasantly surprised by Blue Moon.  It poured a lovely pale orange with a very strong aroma and taste of fresh oranges and lemon and a good white head.  There was a spicy touch to it and one I can’t put my finger on.  It was adequately carbonated for me and very smooth on the palate.  This would be a decent session beer and I would happily remove all the Coors Light in Irish pubs and replace with this.
Pours orange in color with thin white foamy head.  Smells straight orange peel.  Tastes orange and coriander.  A simple?but well done beer.
Good beer. Decent wheat that you can find in most areas. Easy to find, and always refreshing, put pretty boring. ---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

One of the only coors beers  that’s worth drinking.Not a great beer but in a pinch easy finding and has flavors that fit the style well.Pours cloudy yellow with small white head.Aroma lite with citrus and coriander  flavors about the same.

Poured from 22oz bottle -  How many years have I avoided this one?  10?  I completely dismissed this as garbage, but the joke is on me!  I really dig this white ale.  The hints of spice, banana, and yes, coriander really do come through.  Citrus tones pervade.  Smooth as hell with lively carbonation.  I stand corrected MillerCoors, I do like this.

This beer pours a hazy orange hay color with a thin dissipating head.  Aroma is poor, smells almost stale and yet of spicey bread.  Taste isn’t too bad, notes of orange and coriander in a wheat beer, exactly as described.  This beer is pretty plain and a very uncomplex, straightforward beer.

12oz bottle from Pick’s poured into a Trappist glass. Pours a hazy bright orange with minimal head. Aroma of wheat, orange and spices. Taste is light sweet and very very light sour. Taste of wheat and orange. Light bodied with a very minimal creamy texture. Lively carbonation and not much of a finish. Overall, not too bad. Drinkable, but not my favorite.

Draught at the Montagu Pyke, London. Creamy white good mostly lasting head. Dark yellow colour. Light malty and hoppy aroma. Ugly seward water notes. Light bitter flavor. Strong orange notes. Average finish. Oily palate. Not a pleasent experience.

355ml bottle poured a cloudy golden-orange color with a quickly dissipating white head and little lacing.  Aroma of orange peel and spices.  Taste is orange peel with some spices light malty sweetness and a light hoppy bitterness.   A decent witbier brewed by a macrobrewery.  Quite surprising actually.

Draft in Colorado. Pours orange with some cloudiness. Big orange peel on the nose. This beer smells brilliant. Nice orange tang on the tongue. Flavorful without being cloying. Clean finisher. If Coors can make this why do they waste time making Coors Light?

Video review at: http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=sPs8BKZTN3Y



Appearance: Unfiltered amber, no head, no lacing



Smell: Orange rind, coriander, distant clove



Taste: Medium body, orange rind, coriander, bit of lemon crêpe, creamy wheat, bready malts, tiny bit of dirt, orange candy + sourness on finish, medium carbonation, drinkable



Pairings: Salad

Reviewed from notes. Nose is sweet malts and citrus. Poured a cloudy light orange with white head. Taste is again, sweet malts and light citrus with some coriander accents. Very drinkable with enchiladas haha.
Cloudy golden color. Aroma yeasty wheat malt, citrus and coriander, taste citrus, coriander. Very soft herbal notes. Medium carbonation.

On tap at Uptown Sports.  Pours a cloudy, light orange color with quickly diminishing white head.  Minimal lacing.  Aroma is faintly orange.  Sweet, lightly bodied with a thin texture.  Easy to drink, decent session beer.
yellow-tan and hazy with a thin pure white head. Distinctive wheat smell, with a slight hint of fruitiness, Relatively thick texture. Tastes very wheat like, with a sour aftertaste.
Bottle 0,355ltr: Hazy yellow brew under the "North American Craft Beer" name, full of taste with an slightly little bit sourness hint. Good try by an big commercial brewery.

Tasted 9/20/2011 from bottle into tulip glass. Hazy, golden color. Malty sweetness with subtle and harmonious aromas: fresh baked bread, citrus tartness, peppery coriander spice. Just the right amount of complex Belgian yeast characteristics. Highly carbonated with good white head retention, some lacing. I know this is brewed by Coors and adored by girls, but c’mon! Admit it, this is good beer. Afficionados should be thrilled a passable spiced Belgian Witbier is available to the masses at every imaginable outlet in the USA and abroad. Who would have believed it a decade or two ago? Let’s encourage this.
UPDATE: Okay, I stand corrected. Blue Moon just kinda sucks. It’s a crowd-pleaser but not a good example of style.

Blue Moon Belgian White has a very thick, fluffy, off-white head and a hazy orange appearance. The aroma is slight, but one does pick up some white bread and a touch of spice. Taste is of bread and a bit of orange, which actually comes out stronger as one drinks more of the beer. There is some spiciness in the taste, but not a whole lot of it. Mouthfeel is soft, and Blue Moon Belgian White finishes mostly wet and easy drinking. Overall, this is a fairly good wheat beer, and I suppose it’s worth trying.

RJT
Draft @ Gramecy Cafe, NY. Pretty decent witbier served with orange. Good for summer days by the beach.
a nice begineer wheat beer. Pours orange with a white head. Nose and taste of of a touch of spice, citrus, and wheat. Nothing special.

Good well rounded, easy to drink refreshing beer. Light color with good head that dissipates by sip 2 or 3.

Classic wheaty, sitrus flavors with minimal hop bitterness going on and a subtle spice note from the invariably present coriander.

355ml bottle at Texas Roadhouse in Bangor ME. For my review see "Rickards White." I thought maybe if it was made in a different brewery or subconsciously the different packaging and location my make some kind of a difference, but they didn’t. It was exactly Rickards White. The only thing I find odd is that while these beers are completely identical, Blue Moon has a much higher rating. Do Americans have lower standards? Who can tell?

Appearance: deep orange, with a creamy white head.   Aroma: orange, crushed wheat, lemon zest, a little yeast.   Taste:  cream of wheat, sugared orange rind	.   Finish:  furry, fuzzy, with crackery, musty notes of wheat and citrus.  Notes: Surprisingly decent.  If you find yourself in a bar with limited macro selection, they’ll probably have this and it’s your best bet.

beer with a slice of orange! are you having a laugh?
the pour was lovely. an almost resinous consistency and a beautiful deep orangey rust colour with a fluffy white head. as far as the taste goes, interesting.  the mix of citrus orange and spice is pleasant but i’m not convinced it really works.
please leave the orange slice well alone

9.10.2011 - Houston, TX
Bottle

Classic large produced white ale with a characteristic hint of orange. Bit much else to it but enjoyable. My wife’s favorite (only one she will drink) beer.

Pours a weak yellow and hazy body. Smells yeasty and a bit of citrus is in the mix, but overall sweet. Tasted lightly of hops with a wheaty-smooth mouth feel and a hint of orange. This is a very drinkable and light beer - great with a sandwich of just about any type.

Serving glass: Poured from bottle into a tall glass.

Appearance: Dull cloudy orange-yellow. Fairly active but the head disappears very fast, leaving nothing behind.

Aroma: Sweet wheat and oats, with some orange but only a touch of coriander.

Taste: Lots of wheat, with a decent level of orange peel. The coriander, clove and tart notes are barely perceptible.

Palate: Very high carbonation, light to medium body. Does not finish as dry as a good Wit should.

Overall: Very simple Witbier that does not have the strong spicy and tart characteristics that I expect. I swear this used to be more flavorful. Has this been toned down or have my tastes changed?

330ml bottle. Yellow orange color with white- brown head. I have to admit I didn’t think high of it at first. But it’s taste is pretty fine- caramel and fruits and it’s aroma too. I wanted a little more bitter at the end but that’s ok. Worth if the price is right.

Aroma is a hay/basement combo. Has a ’metallic’ sort of presence. Possesses a golden amber color that is coupled with a hazy-liquid appearance. Head proved minimal upon the pour, settling quickly into oblivion. For its short life, it was minimal and white. Despite this, brew does contain some persistant carbonation. Light sour taste, with a strong citrus background. Light-bodied with a thin texture. The finish is long and astrigent. Pretty decent Belgian White.

Bottled.
Hazy pale yellow with a white head. Aroma moderate malty, wheat, ligt fruity, coriander and orange. Flavor light sweet, moderate spicy. Medium body. To spicy.

Poured from a bottle into a pilsner glass. Color was hazy golden. About ¾ inches of head on initial pour. Nice lacing on the top, minimal film on sides.

Wheaty smell, maybe a bit of grass. Faint sniff of lemon. 

Good combination of flavors, beginning with wheat, followed by a lemon/orange/orange peel mix, ending with some spices. I want to say a cinnamon stick, but it may be something else. 

Light-to-medium body. Average-to-lively carbonation. The taste got a bit old after awhile, leaving a thick, syrup aftertaste. Also seemed to get flat fairly quick.

I’ve had this plenty of times, but this was my first time rating it. I had nothing bad to say about it for the first half, but the last half was quite disappointing. Much better than the Summer Honey Wheat, though.

A - Citrus (orange) with grass and wheat
A - Hazy light gold, with white head
T - Sweet and sour
P - soft to medium and thin
O - A fruity Hefen
This beer is decently spicy and pours a nice off orange color..must be drank with an orange slice

A dark yellow, almost orange beer with minimal head.  The aroma is very nice and heavy on oranges.  The flavor is weaker with a decent yeast and citrus taste.  Unoffensive and certainly highly drinkable.

Klassiskt weissbierutseende. Skummet försvinner ovanligt fort. Kraftig citrusdoft och kryddor som jag har svårt att bestämma. Inte den tydliga koriandern som t.ex. Hoegaarden. Väldigt lite "ölsmak" mest den där citrusen från doften. En törstsläckare i ett varmt klimat, kanske.

Pours a milky gold with a 1 finger, soapy white head. Aroma is of orange blossom scented decorative soap, light spice. Flavor is much the same with a bit of dust, sweet wheat and some sweetish vegetal notes. Palate is light, watery and a little chalky with a fairly light, but sharp carbonation. Not really my thing, and not a very good example of a Witbier.

Balanced mix of wheat & orange along with some good citrus notes that compliment the aroma well. There is also some milder coriander notes and a little spiciness too.  Could have been stronger though.


Cloudy orange colour that has tinges of yellow throughout & forms a bubbly white head that fades after 30sec.


Orange, wheat & citrus matches nose & there is also some coriander & a general spiciness. Orange flavour is slightly too strong though.


Medium body & a slight spicy tang to the drink. It is creamy, smooth & easy to drink without really blowing me away.



A pretty solid, good beer & one that I’ll go back too at some point in the future no doubt.



Featured in the 1001 Beers Blog:

Tap: Hazy golden with sediments floating and a frothy white head. Sweet, fruity aroma with some spices (coriander?) and hints of yeast. Soapy, citrusy taste. Thin body, creamy texture. Short, semi-sweet finish. A little bland, but better than expected.

12 oz bottle.  Pours pale, hazy gold with a white head.  Aroma is pretty much just yeasty bubble gum and cloves.  Flavor leads with orange zest, bubble gum and cloves, some herbal flavor.  Not too bad really, but not exciting either.

Bottle from Tesco. Smells of weak wallpaper paste. Looks like the toilet bowl after a bout of diarrhoea. Tastes of weak lemonade and oat flavoured water. Quite refreshing I suppose but a bit vacuous even for a wheat beer.
This beer is really pretty decent, but still nothing much to it.  I like some more complexity.
This is an excellent standby beer. It’s much more available than other beers. Not too heavy either.

Cloudy gold in color with a very thin layer of white head. Aroma is very citrusy and fruity (too much for any beer in my opinion). Taste is fine but a little too artificial and again fruity. This is a fine beer to have around if you like light and fruity but I would recommend the Leinenkugel Sunset Wheat if you enjoy overly fruity beers (I don’t). All the same, Blue Moon is a refreshing beer that tastes almost like a mimosa (especially if you opt for the orange slice that goes with it).
Bière de style Witbier de 5.4% d’alcool, belle couleur, rafraichissante, belle  mousse, Caro à bien aimé, cadeau du beau-frère de son retour de vacances à Myrtle Beach.

Good "In case of Emergency" beer. I don’t really bother smelling it. I enjoy the heavy haze in the golden color. The taste is definitely tolerable and enjoyable for an inexpensive trip to the nearest gas station.

Bottle brewed in Canada. Hazy yellow colour, tiny white head and disgusting floaties. Spicy sweet aroma but almost smells artificial like a fizzy soft drink. Not disgusting to taste but the spicing seems so artificial and overwhelms any beer character to it. Not good.
Draught. Cloudy orange with a reddish-pink tint. Aroma of citrus, strawberry. Very sweet and fruity taste; too sweet for my tastes, but a decent refreshing beer.
Draft. I love this style of beer, but this one is only mediocre. Kind of bland and watery compared to many good beers in this style.
Not bad for a macro.  Somewhat sweet flavor in an otherwise average beer.  Nice easy to find winter beer.

I know it’s an unfiltered  wheat an it’s cloudy.  no head, no lacing, perfect urine sample yellow. Smells of "beer vomit toilet" and "hot day restaurant dumpster". It tastes like rotten fruit, lemonade and a hint of taco burp. This is another reason why the Reinheitsgebot is still a good idea. Carbonation...dead in 60 seconds. Avoid like the plague. If you like this try Oly or Hamms in a keg that was hand pumped to almost empty, left in the sun for a week then chilled back down...nummy.
Its a bit above averege but ther are a lot better wheat beers for pretty much the same price

Keg at Red Squirrel. NB. I tried this as per serving suggestion with a slice of orange! Pours a cloudy pink - orange colour with a fair white head. Aroma of orange, cinnamon; cloves and coriander. Similar flavours with a full-on cinnamon, orange linger. Also had this in a bottle. Pours a cloudy golden colour with a thick white head. Aroma of orange zest, coriander, caramel, marzipan and alcohol. Similar flavours with mild carbonation and a foamy mouth-feel. Lingering liquorice and mildly sweet (5,4,4,1,12).
Pleasantly delicious but without volume. Smooth and light in the ABV. It’s the perfect middle beer; it will floor the light beer drinker and placate the enthusiast (depending on level of snobbery :))
Had a draft at a SF Giants game. Strong orange flavor and i didn’t add the orange. Cold and refreshing. Helped wash down the garlic fries.
Commercial beer what more can I say.  Light in taste light in smell and very thin.

I think just about everyone by now has had Blue Moon - even one of your relatives who fought in the Civil War, way before the beer was made, has somehow tried the wheaty confection. With that said, rating this beer is unnecessary, but I’ll drag my legs on anyway. There is a plump orange flavor that pushes the brew’s wheat insides around. Pretty daft, overall, but drinkable in the summer. Lacking in complexity, Blue Moon’s flagship brew is standard fare, unworthy, perhaps, of its heady notoriety.
A great widely available Belgian beer that has a very distinctive citrus flavor that goes well with a orange peel in the glass.

It bours a hazy orange with a fluffly white head, surprisingly good looking for a BMC product. Aroma is of orange peel, bread with a very slight citrusy hoppiness. The taste is mainly orange peel and bready malts not too bad. I really like the palate on this one, it’s medium bodied yet refreshing, this is the best part of the beer.
Overall this a decent brew I can get at a reasonable price, I believe it would have better ratings if it wasn’t a BMC beer.

Bottle. Pours a hazy gold with a very light head. Nose is orange, toast, a touch of metal. As for evaluating its taste, I have a dichotomy. If this is a Belgian-style wit, it sucks rocks. If it’s a mass-produced, BMC beer, it’s not bad. I think I’ll file it under ’drink this if there’s nothing craft on tap’ and move on with my life.

Bottle. Pours a clouded golden orange color with a foamy white head.  Prickly carbonation and a mixture of spices in the aroma.  Flavors of orange peel and coriander to go along with the yeast notes.  Slightly tart finish.

Blue Moon is that great half-way beer that scares Bud Light drinkers with its cloudiness and "beer aficionados" with its coriander spice notes. For what it is though, I find it enjoyable. It helps that it produces a fuzzy, carefree kind of buzz as a session beer without any nasty hangover, which for a macro is impressive. An early stepping stone on the long journey of beer appreciation.

once of my first beers outside of the typical bud and miller and all that. golden hazy pour with a clove and banana aroma, flavor is quite fruity but its a watery beer, not great but ill always have a place for it.
Hazy golden color, with a nice white head.  Smells of spice and yeast, tastes of citrus and coriander, spicy and refreshing.
12oz bottle. Hazy orange juice color, no head. orange and lemon aroma and nose. Sweet taste. Soft carbonation, quick finish. A classic, even without the orange slice.

355ml bottle. Pours a cloudy golden/orange with some head and gentle bubbles. The nose has oranges and cream though not much of a hint of the coriander. The taste has cream, vanilla, then a sweet mandarin end. The palate is pretty good - medium in structure with a thick creamy texture but the finish is a little sweet. Overall, I enjoyed this, though I do particularly like the style, anyway.
Aroma of wheat and orange which is confirmed with taste.  A very good Belgian white.
Pours a cloudy orange from the bottle, aroma of wheat, and hint of orange, a classic wheat beer that a macro didn’t screw up the style.
A great beer that is unparalleled when paired with an orange.  A very refreshing Belgian ale that goes down rather smooth.

Not too poorly done for something so macro, but not great either, almost like orange juice beer rather than Belgian white. Appears orange. Smells like orange juice and some spice. Tastes like carbonated orange juice with beer in it. Body is medium-thin. Though it has decent qualities, eventually it becomes a little cloying and hard to get through.

had on draft because of poor offerings at westword music showcase.  Pours an  opaque yellowish white with small grey head.  Aroma of typical belgian spices.  Actually has some body to it, less watery than I remembered, I think its a bit better on draft.  Notes of clove, wheat, other spices.  Could be less sweet and more wheaty.  Anyway, one BMC offering thats not horrible, doesn’t stand up to a hoegaarden but it worked.

Not a fan, tastes chalky despite their best efforts to offer up orange, other citrus and flowery flavors.  Although it is somewhat appealing to the eye, there is no aroma.  Everyone’s had a Blue Moon before, because unfortunately for many chain restaurants this is what is considered a premium beer.  
Come on chain restaurants of the world, it’s time to embrace the movement!

wheat spice and orange in that order for aroma,none too strong..cloudy orange amber liquid head dissipates quickly no lacing..tastes heavy hand on the coriander upfront..weak hint of orange generally flat ..not very carbonated,light and watery generally..overall not much to recommend I’d rather have a regular coors drank it because it was a gift
Pours light golden with a nice white head.  Aroma is of malts, orange and wheat.  Taste is not too bad, fruity with some malts.  Very smooth.

As far as a beer from Coors goes, this is a winner!  However, when held up to the standards of...well...pretty much any other beer in the state...it’s a letdown.  Sure, it kinda tastes good with an orange slice, but ya know, I want a beer that tastes good by itself.  If putting A1 on a steak makes it taste better; it’s a crappy steak.
(bottled) Witbier’ may seldom be complex but they’re flavoursome and most agreable to my palate. Notes of orange ...sweet upfront , then mellow dry, tart citrusy spicy rivers.  Assertive bier.
Blue Moon is a very drinking White Ale that I really like to drink in the summertime.  Not too citrusy and just enough bitterness to satisfy the hop head in me.
Bottle to dimpled mug.  Pours a hazy medium yellow with a sparse white head.  Not much lacing.  Has a soapy taste to it, and a thick mouthfeel.  Lively carbonation, and malty notes.
It lacks balance and overdoes the citrus. I do appreciate the creaminess provided by the oats, but I wish the taste were less one-dimensional.

Bottle 12 oz. @ RoyalCaribbean / Vision of the Seas. Light hazy yellow pour with a small white head Aroma of yeast and wheat and a little spice. The taste is slightly sweet without hops. Creamy mouthfeel and slightly sweet finish.

Blue Moon is indeed hazy and unfiltered, its dirty appearance a rarity amongst macro offerings.  The head, though, is classically shitty fizz, up and gone with great haste.  Smells pale, soapy, and spicy, not great, but, again, a revelation when coming from Coors.  The flavor gives just the right amount of watery complexity to appeal to those wanting to branch out from the usual piss-beer selections at the bar.  Wheaty on the start with slight hefe leanings as the brew slides into a bubbly, invisible finish.    Overcarbonated (of course) and dull, this beer still stands above almost, if not all, of its fellow brewery products.  But that’s not really a compliment.  (5/2/09)

Was suprised to see Coors makes this.  Had it in LA and obviously mistook it for a micro beer (it was in the early hours of the morning and seemed good at the time).  Spicy and tart though a little watery.    If this sort of beer is being produced by macro beers in the US... they have come along way.

Bright orange dominate the aroma with wheat playing a nice supporting role. Hazy dusted sunset with a white head that starts billowy and leaves whispers throughout. Crisp orange flavor really powers this beer. A little puckering and some soap on the finish. Finishes quickly. Maybe a little too focused on the orange.

Typical mass produced “micro” American beer.  The name sells this beer.  Overall, nothing great about this beer.  Not even a good “Belgian style” beer.  Overly sweet, and not a lot of good hop flavor.  With or without an orange peel, not a good brew.  The price and name will attract drinkers.

bottle, interesting aroma, like butter and sweet hop, pale, hazy, white foam, medium sweetness, lightly bitter, realy similar to witbier,medium body, sticky, lively, long finish, crispy, average good,

On tap @ Old Chicago Denver. Milky, hazy, light yellow orange appearance with a white head. Medium coriander, a touch sour, orange peel, light to medium yeast, wheat malty nose. Fairly light bodied, easy drinking with a touch of that macrobrew flavor, orange peel, medium to heavy coriander, a bit tart, light wheaty flavor with a coriander, orange peel aftertaste. I find this one of the most solid beers by a macrobrewery.
If you want something not-too-expensive and pretty-good tasting, I recommend this particular ale.
Bottle. Pours a hazy golden, thin white head. Aroma of orange citrus and wheat.   Flavor is sweet, medium body with a refreshing tangy finish. Overall one of the better macro brews in my opinion.
Dull beer lacking in character and dominated by the orange peel they stick in it to make it less boring.
On tap.  Pours light golden with a white head.  Aroma of citrus, and light malts and tin.  Not a very good flavor.  Not a very good beer.

When I drink blue moon, I hear the beer saying, " hey look at me I want to get into the Belgian beer market bu still taste lik fermented elephant piss just like coors light" it’s like they have no idea how to make beerthat aside, ver fruity and crap malts tasting it’s like the fruits are trying to hide the cheap Ingredients used hey people like it but then again people like nascar

Half, from keg@The White Horse at Parsons Green. Snowy white top. Cloydy, but bright orangey-golden body. Smell of oranges/tangerines and some doughy malts. Sappy citrus flavor. Restrained, lightly sweet malts. Faint coriander. Body is light plus. Feels kind of bland in the mouth. Drinkable, lacks some attitude.

Served in a 32oz draft at an Iron Pigs game in Allentown Pa.  A small white head, with a sludgy apricot color.  Smells of wheat and orange and with lots of sweetness.  This is a light/medium beer that tastes of orange and goes down smooth with short tangy finish.  This is a great beer to drink and watch Minor Leage ball with, threw down 3 in 7 innings!

Served in a pilsner glass. Reviewed from notes.

Pours a very murky apricot-orange color. White head and a bit of lacing. Too murky as it is completely opaque and full of haze. Nose is light orange citrus with a tad bit of spicing and a bit of light wheat. Taste is wheat, orange, and sugar; definitely quite a bit cloying, which carries over into the feel. Drinks well enough, but this is a surprisingly heavy witbier.

Serving type: on-tap

Reviewed on: 11-09-2010
Well no suprise here for me as this is my fav beer.  I have drank many imposters and none to me have been as overall as good from the pour to the smooth finish

I love the cloudy haze of Blue Moon. Accented with an orange slice, such a good utility infielder of a beer. Good with any meal or just by itself on a spring or summer day. Tangy but not overdone.  A+.

This beer is produced by SABMiller. There it is. Let’s get that over with and try not to let that prejudice drinking it as so many opinionated people have below. Pours cloudy orange amber. Aroma is oranges, and citrous from the hops. Taste is burst of orange, some coriander and spice. Not much bitterness, but a bit of burnt caramel on the finsih. Very distinctive flavour and nice on the palate.
355ml bottle.  Pours a very hazy orange with a medium frothy head.  Aroma is coriander and chip shop fish batter.  Taste is mostly coriander with some orange in the finish.  Pretty thin.
A Witbier that should get more respect. I still love it and I want my orange.
Wit bier very much like Hoegaarden, but a little less citrusy, tried with a slice of orange as suggested on the label, but this did very little for the flavour
One of the first beers I enjoyed, especially the scent and hint of orange on the nose and tongue. Must have it on tap, where the taste is much more fresh than in the bottle.

Not to bad but i expected much better. I dont know what this is but it aint no belgian wheat.But my choice over many macros. pours yellow and smells a bit of wit and orage but not much. Not much taste either just some spicines,. Very easy to drink.

Pours an extremely unattractive unclear yellow-orange.  Aroma is there, but that’s about it.  I smell some wheat, some orange, but none of it smells all that strong, or that good.  Taste is bland american pilsner with a little wheat and orange.  Finish is short, wheaty, and dry.  Just not a good beer to me - I’d take it over a Budweiser I suppose...
On tap.  A murky yellow beer with little head.  Has a bit of a spicy flavor and some sour notes.  Overall, not too bad.

This ale is not "white" in color, not even gold, it is NOT a witbier, it is NOT form belgium, it is produced by SABMiller, it is artificially orange and it tastes like sugar syrup. one of the worst beers I have ever sipped. Orange Dimeatap.

Andsled is no beer snob and couldn’t really care if the beer is lovingly brewed by a bunch of monks or on some stainless steel production line. The taste is more important than the method of production. However the hi-jacking of the phrase “craft beer” by a global conglomerate is a bit rich. The product is wheat beer of the Hoegaarden family – flavoured with coriander and orange peel. The barman recommended a wedge of orange be added and as I could sense he was happier mixing cocktails than pulling pints, agreed to the garnish. It proved to be too overpowering and swamped the beer’s flavours. It’s not Hoegaarden quality but it’s a fair stab at it and will try it again sans fruit.
More thoughts at http://hophead.tumblr.com

Served on tape with a slice of orange, it’s a very hazy, near murky pour of brownish orange beer topped with a creamy white head.  The nose is very mild - almost watery - with a touch of banana skin.  In the mouth, orange and banana add colour to a capricious wheat body.  The malts are present as a honey sweetness.  This overpowers all of the traditional tartness you’d want of the style.  So it’s a refreshing beer but one that sorely lacks complexity.
With its cloudy golden yellow color, and citrus flavor (with a hint of spices), this beer is best served with an orange to help accentuate its features.
Has a soft orange milky color with lots of bubbles. Has a creamy orange aroma and taste. Not a bad brew at all. Very refreshing aftertaste.

(12oz Bottle thanks to zdk9) cloudy pour, orange with no head. Nose of fruity pebbles, orange peel, wheat and cinnamon. Taste of cereal grain, spices, wheat, decently sweet. Nice soft carbonation, decent airboat if not a bit overly orange flavored which seems a bit artificial.

Had this at a friend’s house. I am no fan of the politics of the mother corporation, but while I won’t spend JCB dollars on the beer neither will I turn down a freebie. Slick is really the primary adjective here. It is the simulacrum of beer, an overly sweet echo of an already underwhelming style. Cloudy orange, blah blah blah. Drinking this beer is like watching American Idol. It’s not like you’re interested in the music; you’re fascinated by the window into the machinations of shit culture. Similarly, this isn’t really an enjoyable beer but a market revelation.
Cloudy orange color. Aroma is of coriander and has a nice and refreshing citrus taste. Good if you are looking for something simple and drinkable and better to cool yourself.
Watery for a witbier, but overall not bad, although too much orange flavor detracts from the score.
Good beer, widely available. There are certainly better wheat beers out there...but this one is good.

Pours a breathtaking greyish-green with a cumulonimbus head. Amazing lacing. Heavy oaky aroma, with notes of bacon and sour milk. Stunning lemony palate, maybe a little rosewater and biscuit malt. Mouth-filling mouthfeel and saccharine finish

Cloudy orange color. Aroma is of coriander and has a nice and refreshing citrus taste. Its taste is certainly much simpler than most other witbiers, but still very good if you are looking for something simple and drinkable.

Served with a slice of orange, this beer was very sweet and tasted like orange squash. It could be enjoyed, but in a trashy way like putting black currant or lime cordial into cheap lager. It might make a nice radler or shandy mixed with a bit of lemonade, Sprite, or Seven Up.
Yellow Orangish in color. a little hazy/cloudy. small head. Nice citrus taste. Overall a very drinkable beer,  especially in the summer. Adding a slice of orange is the way to go.
Good summer beer with a medium head.  Beer has a honey citrus taste to it. Good beer to try.

Hazy orange, thin white head.  Very cloudy.

Coriander is obvious in the aroma and so is the wheat sweetness.

Good witbier, spicy and sweet.  Lacks the complexity or depth of flavor that many witbiers bring.  Very light in taste but with a fairly creamy body.  Still drinkable and decent.  Nothing to seek out and nothing to avoid.

First rating
12 fl oz bottle on Majesty of the Seas cruise ship in the carribean somewhere, on January 24, 2011
Opted for the version without orange in the glass
Cloudy light yellow color; big, fluffy, lasting white head. Sweet, spicy, citrus cent, some yeast. Sweet, spicy, citrus taste. Moussy mouthfeel, low bitterness.
7/4/7/3/14=3.5

Rerate
Sampled at Denver ChopHouse at DIA, on October 15, 2012
Cloudy yellow color, white head. Funky, esters, perfume taste. Medium to spritzy mouthfeel, low bitterness. Sweet, orange, fruity scent.
7/3/7/3/13=3.3

Pours a cloudy gold/orange with a nice white head. Aroma of citrus and lemon peel, some light hints of bannana, some sweet maltiness and light wheat notes. Taste is same as aroma. Palate is light to med body with nice carbonation and crisp mouthfeel. Finishes with some citrus flavors light sweet malt ending with some slight nutty notes. Overall a nice refreshing and easy drinking belgian.

This is a great beer. It’s fruity but not in an invasive way. It goes great with most foods. I do not recommend drinking more than a few stand alone without food. In other words, it’s not a beer you want to drink if your looking to get intoxicated. It think it goes best with typical bar foods chicken wings and fries fit the bill.
Bottle. Aroma of soft fruits and orange. Cloudy lemon brown, looks a bit like a just add water fruit drink. Flavour is a bit syrupy and artifical.

Originally rated June 2010. Tried this one at B.B King’s Blues Club in downtown Memphis on my trip to Tennessee. Came with a piece of orange, but I through it out. Pours a cloudy beige-orange colour with a little white head. The aroma is quite on the orange side. Same for the taste, quite present. What is interesting is the touch of maple syrup I tasted in the aftertaste. Refreshing overall and a nice light witbier.

Of course I’ve had this beer a bunch in the past, but now I’m finally getting to rating it.) Pours cloudy yellow-orange into a well-cleaned pint glass. Head is smooth, pure white, and decent on a slow pour, though it doesn’t stick for long. Aroma is yeasty sanitizer on metal. Head is gone within a minute. Taste is very sweet and orangey. Very sweet. Easy to see why this is a big seller for MillerCoors. Perfectly drinkable beer, if a bit one-dimensional. I definitely prefer it without the orange garnish.

Poured into a Bodega branded pint glass.
A- Moderately hazy. There is some thick sediment on the bottom of the bottle, I think this ones been in my friends fridge for a while. No head, even after trying to stir up the sediment.

S- Not bad, I mean it actually does have the coriander and wheat. Orange is strong, probably much stronger than most wits. Still its pleasant.

T- Very strong on orange with coriander and wheat coming across as an afterthought. It has a creamy, orange sherbert finish.

M- Pretty dry but carbonation is way, way too high.

Not a bad effort. I think everyone here has had this a least a few times, including myself.

THOUGHTS: I couldn’t believe I never rated this before. I got a six pack of it for a Christmas gift and on a whim checked to see how I had rated it, only to find out that I never did rate it. It was pretty much just a dumbed down and watered down wit. I’ve had worse ones from other breweries, though. It was well made, but strives to appeal to the masses. It was almost like orange juice mixed with iced tea and 7 Up. It does make for a nice transition beer for macro drinkers trying to get into craft beer.
TECHNICAL: Bottle. Poured a milky, light to medium slightly brownish orange that sort of looked like dirty water in a bucket after the first time you wring out a mop when mopping the floor. It also had an average, off-white head that mostly diminished. The aroma had light yeast, orange juice, iced tea, a hint of coriander and a hint of honey. The initial flavor was lightly acidic and moderately sweet; while the finish was moderately acidic and lightly sweet with a short to average duration. There was orange juice, iced tea, seltzer water, a little wheat, slight coriander and yeast. The medium body was sort of creamy with rather fizzy carbonation and a lightly astringent finish.

Poured into a pint glass.

3.5 A: Not too bad looking. Hazy yellow orange with a finger of frothy head. Moderate retention, moderate lacing.

3.0 S: Once again not bad. Wheat/hay aroma make up the majority. A bit yeasty as well. The biggest thing missing is any hint of spice (especially clove).

3.5 T: Pleasant wheat backbone. The spices that were missing from the nose now appear. Pepper leads the spices. I can’t really name any other spices here simply cause I don’t know what exactly most spices taste like. No sign of clove, which I think is a must in a witbier. Not really any hop character, but that’s not really a surprise from a mass marketed beer.

3.5 M: Medium body. Good carbonation. I’d score it higher, but something is amiss and I’m afraid I can’t identify what it is.

4.5 D: It’s the kind of drink that you can handle all night. It’s not the greatest, but definitely an all-nighter kind of beer.

Close to the best I’d expect from a macro brewery, so well done. This was a gift from my uncle. If I can help it, I won’t be buying this in the future as Coors has enough money.

Serving type: bottle

Reviewed on: 12-04-2008 05:22:04

Cloudy orange and yellow color.  White, slightly soapy head with average size.  Minimal retention and average lacing.  The head was gone pretty quick and left a small ring.  The nose is of some orange citrus and banana.  I detected some spices.  Probably the coriander.  I am also picking up the fresh wheat.  The taste revealed once again some orange, banana, wheat, spices (coriander, pepper).  I did get some type of artificial sweetener.  Kind of tasted like a sweetart.  A touch of bitterness came through also.  Medium to thin mouthfeel.  Rather watery.  It is crisp and refreshing and smooth.  Not much left on the palate.  This could be a thirst quencher however.  I would consider this beer to be average to slightly above average.  It does have some ok qualities as far as ease of drinkability.  Would be great in the Summer.  It does, however seem a bit "contrived".  I could still drink a few though.
great orange flavor, best served on a fresh tap with orange slice, cloudy appearance, light palate

Pours orange hazy colour with a timid white head. Fresh aroma of grass, spices. Refreshing taste with notes of citrus, lightly sour. Light body, oily feel, soft carbonation and a mellow mild sweet after taste. Good.

Poured from a 22 oz. bomber into a big hefe glass. Big, noisy, bubbly head disappeared within seconds.  Citrisy aroma.  Smelled like oranges, even without the orange to complement it.  Taste is all orange.  Rather one dimensional, but still a decent beer.
Aroma is a little lacking.   Hard to find much of the citrus or spice.  Taste is better, a little short but a nice hint of citrus at the end.  Feels a bit runny on the mouth.
interesting taste, cloudy colour. fruity tastes. good beer, would prob try again

For a beer from a major brewer and highly accessible, this is remarkably above-average.This truly defines "light session" beer, the kind of thing one would go after to quench one’s thirst without an insult to one’s palate. It’s obviously not going to hold a candle to anything from Europe BUT for a main stream U.S. beer, very good!

Draft @ Bengals game.  Pours a slightly hazy light amber color with a medium whitish head.  Aroma is mild yeast, light fruit and spices, mild sweet malt.  The flavor is much of the same.  Better than the usual stuff, but...
Coors version of Shock Top. A little sharper in taste but the same run of the mill, mass produced "craft beer." Not bad if your a couple beers in though.
Bottle from Peckhams. Hazy straw yellow colour, white head. Aroma is wheat, banana, yeasty. Flavour is wheat, light sweet and sour fruits. A bit odd.
the citrus, predominately orange was too much, hardly any other taste stood out. highly carbonated. though it was slightly refreshing, it was much too light and far to citrusy.
Draft.  Hazy yellow pour.  Citrus flavors, but nothing indistinguishable.  Refreshing, but nothing special.  Also a good go to when there’s nothing else respectable.

Pours a cloudy orange in the glass sans the orange slice.  Herbaceous aroma of cilantro, cumin and some citrus.  Very herbal flavor profile, more cilantro followed by a nutty dry finish.  Overall, not too bad.  A half way decent brew to fall back on when there is nothing better offered.
When this first came out, I thought it was fabulous.  After growing through many more Belgian whites, I found it was less than most of the others.  As an American big brewer brew, it works well.

Bottle @ Mex resturant, Denver, CO. Pours hazy orange with a small white head. Aroma is wheat, yeast, banana and other sweet fruit. Taste is like aroma with added lemon and light spices ( coriands ). Thin watery body. 271110

Aroma: malty, Hopps, sweet citrus. Lovely bouquet

Appearance: A nice amber  the color beer should be clear and deep with a good head if on draft.

Taste: I have always been partial to beer you can drink at any time with any meal and this is one of them. Light hops, with a good whet flavor. Highly floral citrus.

Palate:Mild body in regards to carbonation and body. fantastically drinkable. Nice orange finish

Overall: Love it! Best on tap it has one of the largest improvements from bottle to tap. Goes well with all things i can drink this one all day

Yellow and good white head. Wheat, orange, dough, grass. Nice balance between the dry hops and sweetness. Tasty example of the style. It’s a refreshing beer that’s easy to find so a real good alternative to a light lager when it’s hot outside.
Great citrus, possibly orange.  Cloudy orange pour. Taste of spice and citrus.  White head.  Not a bad beer at all, very drinkable but not terribly complex.
It’s consumable, but not worth the bottle its stored in. If you want something surprisingly palatable from Coors, try their Grand Cru.

Bottle. Poured an opaque yellow orange with a white head. Nose was citrus and a touch of spice. Notes of slight grain, citrus and coriander, finishing dry and clean. not a great representative of the style.
Smells light and refreshing. Pours a cloudy yellow on tap. Tastes of light something fruity.

On tap at Olive Garden. Poured a hazy yelloe with minimal head. Aroma of flowers and oranges. Taste was actually decent. Lots of orange flavor with hints of spices. A better beer then what I expected.

Bottle pours hazy orange with a white head.  Aroma shows orange, wheat, and a touch of coriander.  Flavor shows the same with a slight bit of lemon.  Overall body is light to moderate, soft, and the finish is dry.

This Witbier poured a cloudy medium yellow colour with a quick living, bright white head. to the nose there are scents of dough, orange citrus and vanilla. First taste was smooth with orange citrus flavours most prodominant. Slight bite to the carbonation and a slight spice flavour with grassy hops. Finish is lingering with a little vanilla.

Hazy darker yellow coloured beer with some average carbonation and almost no white head. Yeasty sweet vanilla hinted aroma. Medium to full palate. Finish is creamy yeasty sweet with some wheat hints. Medium white.

From bottle. Small head that dissipates quickly. Aroma of oranges but fairly bland. Light orange cloudy appearance similar to a wheat beer. Smooth creamy palate with flavors of light hops, hint of citrus and lightly spiced. Bottle suggests garnishing with an orange slice, no chance this ain’t a cocktail!

Pours a hazy golden color with a thin white head. The aroma has hints of the orange peel. The flavor is not bad with the hints of orange but is a little thin. Not bad for a macrobrew and my wife will pick this over complete crap like light beer which makes me glad.

Hazy dark golden, not much head. Smells of sweet orange and citrus bitterness, some spices. Taste is orange citrus, mildly sweet with decent malt smoothness. body if lite to medium, medium carbonation, smooth creamy malts. A good value for the price. Not a bad place to start if your tired of traditional american commercial brews - bud, coors, mgd etc. etc.

Bottle. Pours straw yellow with no head. You can actually hear this fizz like pop. Not a good sign. Aromas of straw and banana, maybe I’m confusing this with some orange peel/coriander but I don’t think so. Pretty bland taste, some notes of spice and light bitterness. Way over carbonated. Fizzes in my throat. This is fantastic!! Not really.
Fra kran på White Horse, Parsons Green 5 Okt 10. Gulbrun på farge. Uklar. Lavt kremskum. Ikke pen. Smaken litt syrlig. Svak sitrus.

Tired of the taste of the usual mainstream beers, this was my first crossover to something much better. Wheat Beers are great if you don’t want your beer to fight back before swallowing. Light and smooth. A great starter to new adventure.

Draft at Ausiello’s.  Cloudy orange with minimal head. Vague sweet citrus, powder, and toast aroma. Seltzery up front but more pleasantly fruity and wheaty notes follow. This beer is about the orange peel to the diminution of yeast character, which the "Belgian" mantle would suggest, but "clean" is not the most egregious way to disappoint.
