Not too shabby. It pours a deep, opaque honey color with loads of carbonation. It smells a tad sour, but it tastes very sweet and citrusy with a nice buzzy sparkle aftertaste, although a bit thin. Decent.

Pours a pale golden with a white head. Smells lightly of oranges and malt. Certainly tastes sweet with its faint citrus undertones. The palate of Blue Moon can be described as light bodied, with a smooth texture and has a fair amount of carbonation and finishes smooth and almost sweet. Overall an average beer. Garnish with an orange slice and enjoy.

The first witbier I ever tried. I have since tried much better variations on the style, but Blue Moon is still a nice and refreshing beer. And yes...the slice of orange is nice with it. 

K-3.2
S-3.0

12 oz. bottle. Pours a slightly hazy orange with a thin white head. The aroma is grassy hops, orange peels, and wheat. The flavor is sweet backed with a significant bitter and sour taste. The palate is light and highly carbonated. Not bad, but not amazing, but then again, I expect a lot from a witbier.

Draught beer served in weizen glass with an orange slice. Noticable citrus in the aroma and taste. very cloudy yellowish orange appearance. has some sweetness to it and a refreshing finish. This is one of the more solid mainstream beers.
Hmm, not bad for a corporate beer.  I’m not partial to wheat beers in general, but this was okay (once the Torpedo IPA ran out).

A good beer for everyday drinking.  It’s an easy Belgian White.  In fact, it seems to defy the category.  It refreshing, however, and provides for a nice, fruity, thick change from the pale ales, and lagers of the world.  Compared to other Belgian Whites, it doesn’t stand up.  But when taken by itself, it provides a pleasant and unique taste and texture.
Pedestrian Belgian White..decent citrus aroma, frothy head that dissipates rapidly..light and smooth..good thirst quencher

Draught. Murky orange with slight amber tinge. Mild carbonation with a decent amount of froth. I was surprised that Molson/coors could make a beer a decent as this. Its not fantastic, but its more then drinakbale. It lacks any complex flavours or nose. Its like a watered down version of the real thing. I suppose its a gatway beer for the regular coors crowd.. but not for a beerophile..

Pours a cloudy orange, with a very small off-white head.  Aroma is yeasty, with citrus notes, and spices.  Flavor is very sweet, with orange peel, some spices, and wheat.  Finishes a little dry and crisp.
One of the better commercially available Belgian-style witbiers. Definitely a must to add a nice fat orange slice for a sweet-tasting garnish that enhances the aroma.
Sweeter and less tart than some White ales.  Not too bad really. Serving: Tap and Bottle
Draught. Citric aroma. Small white head. Citric flavour, OK spicy note, refreshing clove. Low bitterness. Better than expected.
From a bottle,coriander,thin body,creamy,orange peels,decent beer.would not go out of my way for this beer
Its great with a fat slice of orange in it. My favorite beer for shooting pool at the bars.

Bottle. Pours a hazy yellow color wit ha small white head. Has a fruity wheaty citrus and coriander aroma. Sweetish wheat malty citrus flavor with spicy hints. Has a sweetish wheat malty citrus finish.
Can’t believe I haven’t rated this yet. A very average wibier made and massmarked by coors. So ok, w’re done here.

For a beer from a major brewer and highly accessible, this is remarkably above-average.This truly defines "light session" beer, the kind of thing one would go after to quench one’s thirst without an insult to one’s palate. It’s obviously not going to hold a candle to anything from Europe BUT for a main stream U.S. beer, very good!
Pours hazy light yellow with a light head. Aroma is mostly wheat, as is the flavor. Not quite Hooegarden but quite nice.
12 oz bottle. Smells of sweet citrus and herbs with an hazy orange color. The taste is sweet and light with higher carbonation. Pretty decent in my novice opinion.
Nose is sweet, hints of corriander, taste is bland, liek they replaces the wheat with corn.

Looks like some cloudy orange juice (minus the pulp) with foamy white head.  Aroma is full of orange and spice.  Taste follows through with dark citrus flavors and spices like nutmeg.  Though not an impressive beer, this macro is quite easy to drink and keeps hope alive for macros.
This beer was one of my first forays into beers besides Miller and Bud.  I know it’s not sophisticated and very much mainstream, but I do enjoy it now and again.
i don’t know about bottled but draft blue moon is pretty and tasty, best served with a slice of fresh orange

Being from Coors I didn’t think this would be any good. Have you ever had glass of beer from the bottom of the keg? Well personally I think this is the best beer in the keg. I must have got one of the last glasses in the keg because it was fabulous! I was floored. I could not believe it! So today I tried a 22oz. bottle hoping for the best. To say the least I was very disappointed. Imagine taking a good unfiltered wheat beer and diluting it with three bottles of water and then doubling the carbonation. Was it horrible? No. Was is good? No. Will I buy it again? Maybe on tap once more. Rating based on the bottle.
12 oz bottle.  Pours cloudy, pale amber in colour.  Slight orangey aroma.  Taste is slighty wheaty. Not bad.

Poured into a frosted Pilsner with an orange slice on the rim. Hazy gold with a medium, white head. Aroma is of faint spice and herbs. This is a very earthy beer that I feel would almost be good warmed up. It probably would not be good though all things considered. Taste is where the spiciness comes out but palate is where this beer starts to lose it’s potential drinkers. It has that plain lager aftertaste that does not particularly belong in a Belgian White. This is a good beer that you can find at most restaurants and definitely at any grocery store. You should not be let down with this beer.

This is my pick up a six pack and go to the byob party beer.  I will also say that adding a orange to this beer really brings it flavors out.  I down graded this one because of that reason.  No beer should need any garnishments.  I think this is a good beer to drink if you want to step away from the everyday American norm... Bud, Miller and Coors

Bottle poured into a beer glass, white lasting head, cloudy amber, sweet orange and spice aroma that carries over well into the flavor, very smooth and pleasing taste creamy finish reminds me of a creamsicle
On tap, poured hazy wheat colored, aroma is full of orange peel, very nice flavor but nothing complex about it,  a guilty pleasure for sure!
On tap, with orange. Cloudy orange pour, thin head, citris aroma, good flavor, you can def taste the coriander.  I enjoyed it.

Half pint, served from tap at the Fullers pub called The Jugged Hare, Victoria. Very unclear, light gold body. Ring around the rim of the glass. Sweet banana and wheat to the nose. Sweet fruity taste. Soft in the mouth. Has got a rather vapid flavour and was far too sweet. Completely wrong choice to my salty food – a decent pint of Fullers London Pride came to my rescue (London, 16.07.2010).

Bottle- Pours a hazy orange with a moderate head that fades to a faint lace. Has a light fruity & floral aroma. Has a bit of spice & citrus but the sweetness seems to be a bit too much, not what I was expecting. A light bodied beer, slightly refreshing and smooth. Not sure if I could drink more than one due to the sweetness. This seems to be a trendy beer at the moment. Let’s see where it is in 5 years. At least its a big step up from the Silver Bullet.

A light refreshing brew that has become very common in many bars and restaurants. Sometimes this is the only thing worth drining (other than the macro lagers). This one beats Shock Top, by a few whiskers, but if you enjoy Hoegaarden or Allagash White, don’t expect this to come close.
Hazy milky yellow with a medium white head. Yeasty aroma with lemons, lime and wheat. Flavour had yeast, wheat, lemons and lime. Finished sweet.

On tap at Not Your Average Joe’s. I was expecting something like Hoegaarden, but was disappointed. Blue Moon had the orange peel and the spice, but totally lacked the puckering sourness. Drank it on a summer night and found it refreshing.

Was a decent brew, but i couldnt stop getting sucker punched by the overwhelming amount of coriander. the orange peel part was okay and after the coriander part was over, the rest was a decent finish.
On tap, with orange.  Cloudy orange pour, no head or lace, orange aroma (even after I removed the wedge), thin palate, good flavor, worth the try and good with dinner.

Blue Moon is still a really good beer especially with orange, but I had it just plain this time around. It pours out in a cloudy orange tint with a decently sized white head. It has a slight citrus aroma and a mild flavor of citrus. It’s very mild but really good nonetheless. This is a beer that’s pretty simple on the tongue. There’s no complex flavors or aftertastes, what you see is what you get. And you definitely get a good brew for the money. Drink this regularly.

Blue Moon Belgian White was a decent light beer.  I particularly liked the citrus twist but after a while I found it to be too much and I wanted more of the malted wheat taste.  Overall this beer stood above many of the other wheat beers I’ve tasted.

This was my first Keg for my Kegerator and I do not regret it. I know there are better beers out there but after all the blue moon  I drank I think I am an expert now! To really appreciate the beer avoid the orange, although it does make it taste better I just found that it hid the actual "Beer" flavors and aromas, which is what i was looking for. I love wheat beers but there are better than this out there, a whole keg of this wasn’t a waste, but i’ll go for some other wheat beers next time. Very drinkable, easy to pound several.

didn’t this beer use to be good?
this is one of the dullest corporate beers ever.
Not in the  least bit refreshing.  A total waste.
feh!

Bottle from errrr, probably Harborne. OK Wit. Not much bite, and a little papery on the finish. After a bottle’s worth of swigging I do get some soft flavours: flowers, ginger, chalk, slight lemon. Better on draught on the occasions I’ve sampled it in the America.
A hazy yellow pour with white head.  It has a light citrus aroma balanced with grainy malts.  The sweet taste is crisp and finishes with lingering spices and hints of orange.
An overdone style (wheat with orange and coriander) but it carries out those flavors well. Sweeter than I generally care for, but decent none-the-less.

Not bad for an offering by Coors. Almost non-existent aroma, slightly cloudy golden appearance. Taste range is subtle with hints of orange. Slight thickness makes this beer appealing to my palate. Not bad if the only other options are traditional "macros".
VERY thick white head, with a light gold body. is spicy and refreshing at the same time. not too bad, but there is much better

One of the better average tap brews you’ll find at your local burger joint. But thats not saying too much. Tastes pretty good at first, with some floral and citrus notes,  but finishes pretty bad. Overall not bad though

Overall I have always thought this beer flows nicely.  Its a widely distributed belgian wheat, but it affirms the type of a classic brew.  Love the orange flair, the citurs segues, and the mild complexity of it all.  Head derives too slowly but helps usher in the sizable contribution from the malt.  Look out for the spices.

Bottle:
Quick disappearing white foamy head.
Smell wheat, hops, spices, fruit, yeast, sweets.
Color is hazy yellow
Taste is very sweet and fruity (citrus, orange, lemon). Also wheat and some hints of spices.
The aftertaste hurt my teeth, way too sweet.
According to the label it’s based on the Belgian white beer, though it’s not that bad, Hoegaarden is just way better!
floral, citrus, golden, hazy, minimal head, light sweetness, lightly bitter, light body, thin feel, average carbonation,
This beer actually tastes ok for being a cloudy appearance. The aftertaste is horrible though. Wouldn’t exactly buy this regularly.
Thin head.  Cloudy golden color.  Nice aroma.  Matches flavor of the beer.  Can add orange if you like.  Much better than the Honey Moon Summer Ale.

Blue Moon pours a deep yellow with a very thin foam that fizzles quickly.  The aroma is quite weak, but there is a hint of orange and lemon.  The beer is a bit bland tasting, no hops, no malt, just a slickness that runs to the back of the throat.  In that respect, it’s refreshing, but no aftertaste to follow it up.  For a macrobrew, it’s better than most, but does not stand up to hand-crafted witbiers.

Pours cloudy yellowish tan. The nose is orangey & sweet. The orange aroma continues throughout. Malty, smooth, a little sweet and a little tart. Nice drink for summer. Not a bad drink any other time, for that matter.

(Draught at Stone Street Tavern NYC). OK, I know this is a macrobrew and not the reason I joined this site, but on a hot day, sitting at an outside table and with a orange wedge; it tasted great today.
citrus backround, with hardly any characteristics of a beer from belgium.  swishy danes
i’m a fan of white ales and this one is no exception. it would have been at least a 4 but it’s mostly produced in canada now and it’s not hockey. enough said.
Toss an orange into this and I’m all in. I won’t take the time to proclaim myself some badass expert, just want to say I love this brew

This beer lacks a good fragrance of other Belgium whites. It does have a nice hazy golden color. It has an slightly acidic wheat taste with a little hint of fruit. Normally served with an orange slice. I prefer it without.

bottle. Pours golden, orange, cloudy, minimal white head. Smells of orange, tinge of skunk and herbs of some sort.  medium sweetness. medium body, soft carbonation with a lingering aftertaste.  Not much character, but it’ll do.
Not a bad beer, but not a very balanced taste to it. I’m not compelled to drink it when the weather isn’t warm, but it makes a decent beer.

Pours yellow with 1 finger foamy white head. smell is citrus and yeast.
taste is...bready... not bad.
Light fruity taste - nice middle of the road beer to enjoy on a summer day.

Served from tap into a Weizen glass.  Poured a yellow-orange that was quite hazy, had a one finger white head, that did not produce any lacing.  The aroma was comprised mainly of citrus.  Flavor was citrus and sweet that was light on the palate with low carbonation.  Overall this is a nice smooth beer that makes a good way for new comers to white ales to get started.  Also nice for when you are eating a large meal as it is not very filling.  It is not a bad brew, but it’s not that good either...
Pours a nice golden color in the glass. Good head. Nose and taste of light citrus, some barley and wheat. Rated 2/3/2000

Poured a cloudy orange/straw with a thin off-white head. Aroma: spice, citrus, hops. Taste: watery start but then going to citrus, lots of spice, hops, wheat. Mild to medium carbonation. Not much body... but not a bad beer for the style.

Pours a cloudy yellow with a one finger head that quickly fades a light lace. Smells of oranges tastes of orange and wheat malt. Light to medium mouthfeel good carbonation. Not as tasty as everyone makes it out to be.  I bet it used to be better before Coors got a hold of it and probably cut corners.
Orange tasting, usually comes with an orange or lemon slice.  Wheaty, fruity. Orange in color

Aroma of orange, coriander and caramel with some sweet fresh fruityness. Pours golden hazy with rich white head. Crisp fruity dry orange and bananas flavor with notes of bitterness. Well balanced between crisp- bitter and wheat-oats roundness on palate. Finish is à bit flat with dry bitter fruity aftertaste.

12 ounce bottle.  Served in a nonic pint glass, the beer pours a cloudy golden/orange color with a half inch off-white head.  Head retention is low, lacing is decent.  The aroma is nice, but a bit weak.  It smells like wheat, orange, and some coriander.  Taste is just like the aroma, but stronger.  It’s mostly wheat and orange, along with a bit of coriander.  Mouthfeel/body is light, it has decent carbonation and it’s quite refreshing.  Drinkability is good, it wouldn’t be hard to drink quite a few of these at a time.  It’s not the best witbier I’ve had, but it’s a decent enough brew.  And it’s a good choice if you’re at a bar and can’t find anything better, since Blue Moon is found pretty much everywhere for the most part.

Blue Moon Brewing Company	Belgian White Belgian Style Wheat Ale.  5.2% ABV--10 IBU’s.

1998 12 oz. Bottle.  (3.0 / 5.0)  Hazy deep straw golden color.  Light spicy orange and coriander flavor and aroma.  Body is thick for lightness.  Finishes light and dry.  Nice.  Sampled 1/31/1999.

2001 12 oz. Bottle.  (4.25 / 5.0)  Hazy dark aged lemon orange juice color.  Mild lace head.  Spicy malty wheat coriander front.  Tangy creamy malty mellow citrus yeast ester banana spicy hot wheat body.  Smooth complex mild hop hot end.  Sampled 10/29/2003.

2008 12 oz. 4.00% ABV--10 IBU’s Bottle.  (3.5 / 5.0)  Foamy lacy white head.  Light sediment.  Cloudy thin bright white gold color.  Mild Belgian coriander orange peel mild hop front.  Mild wheat spice thin Belgian body.  Refreshing weak coriander hop spice end.  Very light but tastier than expected.  Served Warm.  Sampled In Brainard, Minnesota From WalMart 8/26/2008.  6-Pack $7.49.

2008-B 12 oz. 5.40% ABV--10 IBU’s. Bottle.  (3.5 / 5.0) Rich loose sediment.  Foamy big mild lace white head.  Cloudy lemon orange color.  Mild wheat spice coriander orange peel mild hop front.  Mild sweet mellow Belgian wheat body.  Mild citrus orange peel hint mild hop end.  Mellow refreshing bland Wit.  Sampled 8/30/2008.  6-Pack $6.99.

2009 22 oz. 5.40% ABV 10	 IBU Bottle.  (4.25 / 5.0)  Rich loose sediment.  Fizzy flat mild white head.  Cloudy bright orange color.  Delicate smooth coriander orange peel mild hop fruit ester front.  Crisp zesty refreshing mild creamy wheat malt mild coriander citrus body.  Flat orange zest mild hot coriander end.  OK.  Sampled 8/12/2009.  2 @ $3.49.

Blue Moon Brewing Company--Adolph J. Coors Brewing Company	Belgian White--Belgian-Style Wheat Ale--A refreshing, unfiltered wheat ale brewed and spiced in the Belgian tradition for a uniquely complex taste & an uncommonly smooth finish--2010 12 oz. Bottle.  5.40% ABV.  10 IBU’s?  (4.0 / 5.0)  Wit.  Rich sediment.  Big foamy mild lace quickly dissipating white head.  Cloudy bright white lemon color.  Spicy floral coriander orange peel zesty mild Belgian ester hop front.  Tangy crisp orange citrus clean spicy wheat malt body.  Refreshing clean citrus Wit end.  Sampled 6/30/2010.  6-Pack $6.99.
Yeah it’s pretty commercial and not very "real" of a beligan white, but we should at least give Coors some credit for trying to make something authentic.

Very cloudy, almost artificial look of uniform solid suspension. Avg wheat beer, very mild, no distinct taste.  Medium body, soft carbnation.  Nothing offensive in this beer... reasonable choice for a wheat beer at bars with limited taps.

The aroma is almost all orange with some lemon and spice. The appearance is decent, hazy orange, but the head is gone within 60 seconds. Similar to the aroma the taste is all orange, but not good orange, artificial orange and some subtle lemon notes. It’s a little like drinking a sunkist. It is on tap in most pubs which is definitely a step in the right direction, but it’s not comparable to drinking a good imitation (see Allagash White, Ommegang Wit), let alone a real Belgian White.

I have not tried Blue Moon for 15 years, but yesterday had to drink it on occasion. Pours hazy orange with a large white head.
Nose of yeast, citrus fruit with hints of spicy hops and apples.
Medium crisp body, with citrus, sweet malt and spicy hops on the palate. Finish is sweet in the beginning then becomes spicy and dry. Surprised and impressed by this brew.

And yet another wit.  12 oz. bottle to weizen glass.  Pours cloudy golden with quickly diminishing white head.  Typical citrus with a touch of hay.  Fairly sweet with a nice sour note in the finish.  Decent palate that is well carbonated.  I was surprised how well I liked this considering the source.

Had from bottle.  Pours a golden orange color with a slight white head which is quickly gone.  Very small bit of head remains around edges of glass and there is no lacing to speak of.  Aromas of wheat and very minuscule hints of orange and citrus.  Tastes of orange and slight sweetness.  Cloudy appearance deceives the watery texture and taste.  It’s got drinkability though, and that’s all the masses seem to care about.  As for taste, not so much.

Draft. Pours clear orange with a creamy white head. Aroma of wheat, hay, straw, and subtle notes of orange peel. Absolutely no body and the palate is thin and watery. Average at best. I do not understand the hype surrounding this beer.

Appearance- very bubbly cloudy pale orange body with white head that quickly disolves and leaves no lacing.
Smell- Strong citrus smell with wheat in the background, flowery smell can be faintly dected also
Taste- very smooth wheat taste with citrus accents. The aftertaste is a little sour but is consistant with the initial taste.
Mouth feel- highly overcarbonated which almost hides the great taste
Drinkability- It tastes good and finishes clean which makes it very drinkable.

I have been dabating whether to rate this beer on its own or as a representation of the Belgian White. This beer is very popular and is available on draft at most bars where they add an orange slice. Its a great alternative to the macro or light lager which is often the only other beers they have available on draft. On its own this stands proud above other common American beers.

That being said-this beer isn’t a solid example of a Belgian White. I get annoyed when I am enjoying witbier and the bartender comments that it is similar to blue moon. It is highly overcarbonated and doesn’t have the typical light taste of a witbier.

Serving type: on-tap

Reviewed on: 03-13-2007 14:28:25
--

12 ounce bottle.  I purchased a 6er of this for some bitch who I thought was gonna put out.  Needless to say, she was ragging.  She then got a DWI later that weekend and lost her license.  Anyway, this is a rating from one of the remaining bottles.  Aroma has nice, lightly spicy aroma with plenty of orange zest present and grains of paradise.  Quite sweet.  Pretty aromatic.  Moderately hazy golden body that has a very quickly dissipating small white head.  Virtually no head present.  Starts quite carbonated and rather spicy.  Has some of the orange and mild coriander flavors in the middle with a milky maltiness present.  Finishes with a little more citrus flavor.  There seems to be a bit of a corny adjunct flavor late in the afterfinish.  All in all, not bad at all.  Much better than a lot of mediocre brewers’ beers.

12 oz bottle from Trader Joe’s.  Hazy yellow, like my pee when I’m battling an infection.  Nose is sweet ammonia and yeast, again, like my infection laden pee.  Taste.  Bleh.  I’ve had wits I liked.  This is just not one of them.  Drain, here I come.

12fl oz bottle from the local liquor and cigar shop in Malibu. Belgian Wit Style, 5.4% ABV. Pours cloudy yellow with a vivacious head. Bready and spicy aroma. Typical wit flavours of coriander and orange zest overly minimal bitterness as expected. The colour of the beer suggests less pilsner malt used, so a touch more malty as expected. Nice dry finish. Just an ok beer. I don’t go much for this style anyway when it comes down to choosing between it and others.
A very very average whitbeer. It lacks in flavor that I am used to in most whits.
Pours hazy yellow with white head.  Smells of orange and corriander.  Taste is smooth and balanced.  Nice mouthfeel, medium bodied.  Overall, a very smooth, nice tasting beer from BMC.

One of my old favorites.
Pours cloudy yellow in color.
Citrus in the aroma.
Fairly smooth taste with citrus.

Yellow-orange pour with a fairly big white head on it. Smells of oranges and coriander and the taste is virtually identical, with almost too much sweetness to it. No bitterness of note. Though a little over-sweetened, it still represents one of the best widely-avilable on-tap beers from a macro brewery.

On tap at Applebees in Niagara Falls NY.  The pour was hazy, but lifeless and no trace of head.  Only the slightest hint of citurs in the aroma.  Flavour was bland.  Not impressed, but I’m thinking the keg was off.  I’ll have to try it again sometime.

This is a great craft beer from a macro. Coors hit the nail on the head with this one. Aroma is great - a light hops aroma mixed with a bit of hay. Taste is of a light citrus and hops. Smooth drink with a mild tingle to the tongue.

Bottle.  Pours a hazy golden orange with a medium white head.  Aroma is citrus, lightly sweet.  Flavor is orange (lots!), coriander, a bit of clove, earthy yeast, slightly sweet.  Slightly creamy palate, but still crisp.  A flavorful, refreshing beer.
this is a really good drinking experience. This is some true belgium wheat ale
excellent beer all year round. Add an orange peel to bring out the true flavors. Frothy head with a bold body.

Bottle.

A - Hazy golden, orangish, amber. Decent sized white head with average retention and very little lacing.

S - Fair amount of citrus, both orange and lemon. Also a bit of clove and coriander. A little wheat and yeast smell.

T - Decent wheat and malt flavor as a base which provides a bit of sweetness. Good amount of citrus (lemon and orange) and spice (coriander, clove, pepper) also shine through. All this leads to a fairly sweet and slightly spiced drink.

M - Medium body with good carbonation. Slightly creamy and fairly crisp.

D - Good drinkability. Good balance and mix of flavors and easy to drink.

Notes: Used to be my favorite beer before I got into craft beer. The flavors seem a little light now, average for the style but pretty good for being an inbetweener of macro and craft.

This is my absolute favorite beer. I definitely prefer it on tap over the bottle though. 
It’s flavorful, yet easy to drink in the summer or winter.

I love Belgian Wits, particularly in the Spring/Summer seasons.  Blue Moon almost has too much citrus for my taste (even without an orange garnish) but it is still a quality beer in my favorite category.
Bottle. Hazy golden pour with frothy white head.  Citrus, pencil, spice, bread, wheat and fruit.    Light bodied with some sweetness.  Decent but not exciting.

12 oz. bottle to a 1/2 pint glass. The pour was a hazy, orangy gold, with frothy, white foam to the head that remained for awhile, then reduced to a ring and film, and left some ribbons and spots of lacing. The aroma was mid-fruit and citrus as oranges, light spiciness, bready malt, a touch of yeast, and light graininess. The flavor added some light hop bitterness to the mix. Somewhat light bodied, lively carbonated, crisp and rather refreshing without the fruit.
Pours a fading ring of white head with a hazy, golden body.  Aromas of malt, yeast, zest, and spice.  Flavor is bready, yeasty, some orange and coriander.  Decent body.  Fading finish.

Purchased at The Fresh Market, Greenville, NC

Looked great on pour; decent taste even though this isn’t my favorite style.
12 oz. golden pour from bottle.  Nice clean citrus taste and nose makes for a refreshing session type beer.  Not bad on a summer day when you don’t want something heavy or high abv.

A: The pour is a cloudy orange color with a small white head on top. Fairly typical for a witbier.

S: A very intense citrus smell fills the nostrils on the first sniff. Further investigation gives off some slight spice notes, but the orange is really hard to get past.

T: Like the aroma, the primary sensation on the tongue is the orange flavor. The spice is absent for the most part with the exception of a hint on the aftertaste. The finish has a slight bitterness to it.

M: The body is medium with a moderate and tingly carbonation.

D: This beer is probably responsible for the "serve an orange with your wheat beer" trend here in the US. The beer is decent enough, but an overly powerful orange flavor and aroma is just a bit much for me.

Hate the fact that this is made by Coors; One of the best of the mass produced Belgian White Ales.  Has a sweet orange and spice filled mouthful, with the citrus ringing out through the aftertaste.  Finish is clean.
Pours orange with a thin white head.  Aroma is of wheat, orange and yeast.  Taste is the same.  Not a bad beer but not that good either.

Citrus aroma with earthy aromas. Slightly cloudy and medium golden colour. I have had better ’white’ beers but it was ok. Medium head and carbonation. Slightly sour palate with medium body. Overall underwhelming but glad I tried it.
Pours a hazy orange color with a nice but not lasting white head.Very nice aroma.Fruity taste mostly orange. This beer was a surprice for me.

I really like Blue Moon, has a nice aroma of citrus. Tastes like fresh oranges, with a slightly bitter aftertaste. A favorite in bottle form or from the tap. Pours a orange/brown color with a nice head. Put an orange slice in the bottle, and a wedge on the lip of the glass. Good beer.

(12 ounce bottle - pint glass)  Pours a cloudy burnt orange color with no head.  Aroma is of citrus.  Taste is of a wheat malt with notes of citrus.  Mouthfeel has a watery texture, finish is astringent, has lively carbonation and great drinkability.
cereal, floral, pale, orange, light sweetness, light body, thin feel, lively, long finish,
nope, just nope. reminded of the who’s wont get fooled again, wont ever think a macro can make a decent beer again. done and done.

Im an ameatur,, regarding lager,,but ,, I have had enough to say that this struck me as delicious,, & different.. smooth,, & I loved it.. tried it christmas eve brought over from one of our guests, that is familiar with specialty brewed beer... I just purchased some the other day & it was delicious.  would absolutely reccomend.

Pours a hazy yellow, small white head that leaves a littl lacing.  Aroma of citrus, coriander and wheat.  Not to sweet, has a clean crisp finish.  Nice beer for a macro, has been very reliable over the years.  Always nice to see this on tap in bars that only carry macros.

12oz bottle.  Hazy orange-tan color, soda-like head that fades out after a minute.  Orange-citrus and wheat aroma.  Medium bodied, with a solid citrus edge.  A little corny, lacks the real deep vanilla smoothness of a quality Wit.  The coriander is well incorporated, not standing out too much.  Overall a pretty decent offering, but still sub-par for the style.

Fruity nose. Yellowish orange pour. Decent amount of yellowish white head.
 Taste of lighter fruits, perhaps the slightly bitter skins of grapes or blueberries.
 Clean, disappearing finish.

Holy crap it’s Rickards White in the US. With another name! Unsure if the vast machine of MolsonCoors has two different recipes or if this just a case of brand and market. In any case, hazy golden orange pour with a weak bubbly white head. Aroma is coriander, orange zest, and yeasty wheat. Taste is a wheaty, citrusy sweetness complimented by a subtle spiciness.
Pours a golden orange color with a three finger, white head.  Fruity, hoppy nose that kind of matches the orange color.  The taste has hints of pine, very very fruity.  Just isn’t my kind of beer.

22oz "Big Bloke" at Outback (w/orange no less!!).  Arrived w/o head and way too cold.  Hazy orange-amber.  Aroma of orange zest, yeasty and slight wheat.  Flavor of orange (dreamsicle), lemon, coriander and light to medium sweetness (honey).  Fine, lively carbonation with medium mouthfeel. Citrus bitter and clean, short finish. Not very complex, but, moderately enjoyable.

Delcious beer at first. Orangey. but not too much so. Quite sweet. Fruitier than Hoegaarden, which I also love. A lot of Witbiers have a tartness I don’t like. There’s none of that in this. However, about half way through a bottle, it begins to become a bit cloying. Wouldn’t want to drink this all day.

Still very nice as an occasional beer.
19th September 2009. Cloudy orange amber beer. A bit watery but not erribly so. Fruity - a bit more orange than lemon. Serviceable beer.
This was a pretty good beer that I had a couple of months ago. A noticeable lemon taste but I can’t remember the more subtle flavours as I’ve only had this once and that was a good while ago.
Blue Moon on a Blue Moon. Is what it is. Watery, some aroma of citrus. It is smooth drinking and the price is right

On tap. Yellow-gold and hazy with a white head. Aroma is orange, lemon, yeast, a hint of coriander. Flavor is sourdough bread, citrus with a little spicy hops. Body is light, beer is refreshing. Not bad for a macro doing a witbier.

Pours a golden orange with minimal off-white head. Aroma is weak with small whiffs of orange peel and a tad of wheat. Taste isn’t bad, but I didn’t like how everything flowed together - it seemed a bit dominated by the coriander.  Overall not bad though. Easy to drink.
This my daily run of the mill beer. Its my Pepsi or Coke. A decent beer at a decent price. Very smooth with very little after taste. Very refreshing and not heavy or dark.

(bottle into tumbler)  Pours a hazy dark amber with a nice sized white head that lasted fairly well.  It’s a bit surprising that this is macrobrewed!  Aroma had a hint of honey, but was primarily citrus, chiefly orange.  Thankfully I was spared what most find the obligatory orange slice on the glass when this is served at a bar.  Mouthfeel was very creamy with pleasant carbonation.  The taste of the orange was rather forward, but not overpowering, and there was a nice crisp finish.  This has always been one of my standbys!

Bottle - Pours hazy yellow with a very small white head. Smells wheaty with just a tough of spice. Taste is bubble gum, sweet wheat, Fruit Roll-up, apricot. More body than expected. Pleasant, but a little too sweet, and fairly boring.
Pours hazy yellow with stark white head, tastes of a normal white beer with orange and coriander with a lemony and estery finish.  Not bad for a mass produced beer, but not my style.
TAP: hazy light orange pour, white fluffy head. Aroma is coriander, orange zest. Medium-light mouthfeel, taste is wheat, coriander, and orange/lemon. Decent white ale.
Nice white beer... Great aroma, good orangy flavor. I’ll be honest, I am not a fan of fruity white ale beers but this one isn’t bad. I can’t drink this every day but my wife loves it.

this beer has a very unique taste, topped off with a slice of an orange. although thick, the ale goes down smooth.
Earlier Rating: 12/9/2009 Total Score: 5
this beer has a very unique taste, topped off with a slice of an orange. although thick, the ale goes down smooth.

Poured a hazy gold with a moderate white head.  Aroma of coriander and orange with a little wheat.  Flavor is lots of coriander and orange, a touch of toasty wheat, some peach like fruitiness, and yeast.  It’s more dominated by the coriander than I like, but it’s not bad at all.  This is a decent example of a wit and one of the best beers put out by a macrobrewer.
Bottle at mellow mushroom. Scent of orange, taste is sweet and spicy, gave to the wife to finish.
Orange in the aroma, color, and taste.  Quite a bit of carbonation.. solid performing wheat beer that’s in mass distribution.

Refrigerated bottle poured into a weizen glass.  Pours a light pale cloudy orange with medium head that dissapates fairly quickly, medium carbonation, and descent lacing.  The taste is orange and a hint coriander.
On Tap in the USA. Well Orange and little head. Heavy Citrus taste. Not reall a good beer. It has a soft element to it but has too much carbs and fake flavoring to it.

Has a light wheat color with a light orange-yellow hue when poured. Head was thin and white. Aroma was filled with spice and citrus, which was also in the taste. Taste overall was a bit watery, but good overall.  There are better witbiers out there, but you can’t go wrong with this, probably a good starter beer as well.
This is another great "beginner" beer. Very easy to drink, and paired well with some fresh orange juice dripped in.
Overall a good beer.  Nice aroma, good flavor with a sweet, yet yeasty taste.
very popular wheat beer available everywhere standard setup with and orange
Draft.  Poured cloudy orange in color with a thin beige head. Aroma of wheat and orange citrus. Tastes of oranges, wheat, coriander. Overall pretty fruity and thin.
I don’t care what everybody says - this is a nice subtle light wit. The coriander realy comes through, and makes for an easy drink.

On Tap at the Clocktower Bar, Coors Field, Denver 27/09/2009
Floral hop aroma. Golden coloured hazy in appearance and hoppy with a crisp slightly dry and creamy malt finish.
On tap at Olive Garden. Cloudy blond with a thin head. Citrus hops with faint malt taste. I turned down the offer of an orange slice. Surprisingly pleasantly with soup and salad.

Draft: Poured a hazy orangey color ale with a small foamy had with average retention and minimal lacing. Aroma of sugary wheat malt with light bubblegum notes. Taste is bit too sweet for the style with some bubblegum notes. Body is about average with good carbonation. Not bad too not spiced enough with too much residual sugar.

12 ounce bottle from Whole Foods Market, Charlottesville, VA. Pours a hazy lemon yellow color with a large creamy, fizzy head. Fair head retention and lacing. Aroma is bready with bitter citrus notes. Taste is peach, banana, bread and a nutty finish. Medium bodied.
22 oz. bottle- Pours hazy orange with a dissipating head, aroma is wheat and very fruity. The flavor is the same, a very drinkable yet mass produced craft beer.

Bottle, The Peacock, Liverpool.  Served with a slce of orange...Clocked this was from Coors and feared the worst. Poured a hazy orange colour with a fast fading head.
Wheaty and vaguely spicy citrus aroma. 
Pretty watery flavour with slight citrus notes. Probably needed the orange slice to beef the flavour up. Rather uninspiring fayre really and a pity this is masquerading as a ’north american craft beer’ over here when its brewed by a megabucks brewer and is far from a shining example of the genre. Avoid.

Sampled many times over the past ten years. Pours a semi-hazy pale golden colored brew with a fast dissolving white head. Aroma of golden grain malt, coriander, a hint of yeast and some grassy hops. Taste is light bodied, lots of carbonation with flavors of golden grain malt, coriander some orange zest and a touch of yeast. Finish is light crisp with very little fruit aftertaste.
I like the witbier!  This is similar to New Belgium’s Mothership Wit, which is my favorite beer.

(Bottled) I had this one in a diner and it was served near freezing temperature and the glass was frozen, too. The colour is pale orange and beer is cloudy. There was  fruitiness and some coriander in the aroma after the beer had warmed a bit. It’s quite light bodied and carbonation in very high. Beer tastes of coriander and there is fruitiness, sweetness and light bitterness in flavour as well. Very short and lightly fruity aftertaste.
Blue Moon is pretty good, but the fact that Coors makes it knocks down the prestige a bit. Check it out, but don’t try to impress anyone with it.
Great on tap. Nice aroma and taste, though just a little bland. turned off by the murky orange color but otherwise a nice beer to have with dinner.

Pours clouded golden orange. with a white head. Aroma is oranges and bread(yeast)
Flavor is light yeast, with some orange and citrus High carbonation. still an all around drinking beer. This one of the "craft" beers that got me into beer rating.

Tap. Cloudy golden white color with frothy head and orange slice on the rim of the glass (was removed and eaten before drank). Aroma of orange, spice, maybe some bread. Flavor of coriander, orange, and wheat with another citrus note in background. Medium bodied with lively carbonation. Palatable but bland.

Pours cloudy golden white.  Very overrated beer that was great when I was younger.  Creamy frothy head.  The aroma is piny, citrus, wheat.  Has a funny color and alot of carb the citrus peel taste is weird and hurts the beer.

12 oz. bottle. Cloudy pale golden colour with a mostly lasting creamy and frothy off-white head. Pleasant coriander and spicy citrus aroma. Lightly bready malts with a muted spicy coriander finish. Light bodied, very refreshing. Hmmm, found this much better than Rickard’s White which is supposed to be the same thing. I’ll chalk it up to circumstance in this case.
Worst. Beer. Ever.  Mass produced junk.  Can’t believe people like this stuff

Draft.
A pleasant pour, but by no means an exceptional pour.
 A strange, brown - yellow color. Not orange..LOL
 This beer actually looks like Metamucil and I  could not get over that! 
I am not trying to be derogatory here.
 A light body, lively carbonation.A cloudy body with some particulate matter.
I prefer it without the large chunk of orange that is usually jammed on the rim . Enough of a fruity taste without the orange says Doug.
Orange, cloudy appearance with a citrus aroma. Very smooth and easy to drink. I enjoy this with an orange peel. One of my favorites.

Very weak beer. Weak on taste, smell, mouth feel, everything.

Yes. it is drinkable. But with SO MANY other GREAT witbiers out there, WHY ever settle for this?!?!?!?!?!
Bottled.. Cloudy golden orange with a dissipating white head.. Aroma was orange peels and that’s about all I could pick up.. Flavor followed suit. Lots of carbonation.
"A really enjoyable beer. This beer pours an orange/golden color with a thick white head. Aromas of citrus and wheat. Goes down smooth, serve with a slice of orange and enjoy.

I like to just eat that orange the bartenders always so proudly grace my glass with. I don’t like the fruit in the beer. On tap this seems to be thicker and more cloudy with a touch more flavor. Lots of wheat, some citrus, sweet and not awful. Simple

Pours a hazy yellowish color. Head disappears quickly. Mild Citrus and floral taste and aroma. This was my first Belgian white beer and while it’s not the best out there, It sparked in interest for me to try many others in the style.

This is one definitely better on tap than bottled. And skip the orange -- it destroys the balance. To me, this is a pleasant white ale that is simple and cozy. Smooth flavor with citrus zest and coriander on the tongue. Fairly short finish and much better cold than warm. A perfect relax beer for any time of year when you just want to come home, collapse, and not think too much. If you’re not in the mood for the strong flavors of the IPA, Stout, or Porter, reach over for one of these.
Poured hazy golden yellow, simple, sweet, citrus, little grainy, little yeasty, little spice.
tried it with an orange wedge i really enjoyed it has nice orange color went well with hot wings

12-oz. Pours a murky medium toffeeish amber. Loose scattering of fizzy little bubble clusters but mostly headless. Laceless and legless to be sure. Mild, slightly sweaty coriander and toast nose. Creamy, medium, flat body. Cloying orangey sweet mid-palate. Not much complexity here, and not a lot of what flavor there is. Cloying, aspartame-y finish.
I was unimpressed with this as a wheat and in general.  Strange thing is that I really enjoy all the Blue Moon seasonals.

On tap. Pours a cloudy golden orange with a small white head. Floral aroma with spice and adjunct sweetness. Flavor is watery and sweet. This is like the pale lager macro swill of "Belgian Whites". Has a corn syrup sweetness, and yeastless flavor. Not very good at all.
Pours a cloudy golden color with a white head. Aroma of spices and fruit. Flavor oranges, fruit, and wheat. A pretty good mass produced beer.

Appearance: Light orange. Cloudy and some fine sediments. Little bit of white head.
Aroma: Wheat and orange. Some hops and spices.
Taste: Some wheat and citrus fruit. Quite watery.
Info: 355ml bottle, 12/9-2009

Pours to a medium, tan colored head. Has a different, fruity type aroma. Has a cloudy appearence as you would expect with a wheat beer. Has a pop to the palate when consumed and does not leave an aftertaste. The waiter stated most people put an orange wedge in it, but he didn’t have one for me so I did not try it that way.

orange murky color, not alot of lasting head. mostly fruity tasting, yet non-offensive. drink with a "wedge" of orange to achieve maximum desired taste. decent american go at a belgian white &#40witbier&#41. great winter brew. i’ll buy it the once in a while when i crave this type and hoegaarden isn’t an option.

Has orange aroma, although that was boosted by the orange on the rim.  This is about as Belgian as I am, which is not at all.  No yeast flavor at all!  Funky non-Belgian aftertaste.  Exactly what you expect a "Belgian" made by Coors to taste like.  Non offensive and bland.

355 ml bottle. From the US. Courtesy of Brandman.

Hazy yellow-orange colour with small white head. Quite sweet caramel and wheat aroma with spices and fruity notes. Same goes with the flavour. Very smooth.



Draught at the Head of the River, Oxford, England.

Hazy orange yellow colour with tiny white head. Mild aroma of citrus, yeast and orange. Flavour is yeast, malt, wheat, orange and citrus.
Easy and smooth.

This is an OK beer. Some of my friends claim this to be the greatest beer in the world, but I definitely don’t find that to be true. It is commonly consumed with an orange, though it doesn’t add much flavor to the already orange tasting beer.
Bottle - Hazy gold in colour. Slightly fruity and spicy aroma. Slightly tangy and fruity taste with some spicy hints. Slightly thin and disappointing.

It smells a bit like oranges and a bit like caramel and a lot like vomit. It is cloudy orange. Some mild bitterness, orange, bread and gastric acid forms the flavour of this questionable brew. This is... not good. Blech. Oh, and the finish is dry. 

 Note to self: Never go from Pliny the Elder to Blue Moon.
I have had this many times from the bottle and on tap.  For what it is, this is a pretty decent American version of a wit.

Very murky appearance with tons of yeast floating about. Real nice bronze/honey color. Very little head. Smells of citrus and lightly of the yeast. Really light flavor with hints of citrus. Tons of carbonation, good thirst quencher, though it still goes down pretty smooth.
I really enjoy this beer. I drink it often. I enjoy the flavor of belgian white

I warn:  I am not writing this review while sipping on Blue Moon; it is from memory from many times past.  Blue Moon is, in some ways, the perfect entry into "craft beer."  It is easy to drink, well-suited for a slice of orange, and goes down with little bitterness.  Problem is, as a "Belgian White" style beer, it is relatively bland and uninteresting.  No discernible spice to it, little complexity.  Just a hot-day sipper.  Which is not entirely bad.
I enjoyed it. I thought the beer poured well into the glass. It took a couple to convince me that I liked the tase. I hated the lable.
I really think this tastes worse than budweiser.  Even with the orange slice, it comes off as watered-down, an d is not at all refreshing.  I shall not be wasting money on this again.

Probably the best of the big 3 beers I have had. Head is a foamy white and when poured into a Weizen glass the appearance is absolutely amazing, with slight goldish/hazy yellow coloring throughout. I have had this beer on tap, which is delicious, and from the bottle, which is also very good, but not quite as good as on tap. It is almost always served with an orange, which I detest, but is simple enough to have them bring it out naked. 

Taste is a thick bready/light citrus that goes smoothly down the gullet.

Ive been a fan of BM for a while, only recently have I recognized the simplicity of this brew. Overall great taste...especially being an American brewed beer. Credit to Coors. brewing company to come up with a clever marketing strategy to distinguish this brew from the usual big 3 offerings.

12 oz bottle.  After Ommegang’s Witte, I thought this one would pale in comparison.  After all, this is mass-produced.  I was pleasantly surprised to find it tasting better than Ommegang.  My overall impression of Blue Moon is surprisingly higher.  The one thing that brought this beer down in score is the aroma.  I detected none.  Blue Moon is one of the greatest craft-like beers brewed by the big three (Bud, Coors, Miller).

On draft, this pours a golden orange with a foamy white head.  Aroma of orange, wheat and spice.  Nice refreshing taste of citrus with some hops, spice and grasses.  Certainly not the best White I have ever had but solid enough to drink on a hot day and you need a refreshing beer to take the edge off.
This beer is one of my favorites. Takes a break from the ordinary beer taste when you add the orange to it.
I just got back from drinking wheat ales from germany so I may be biased when I say that this is one bland beer.
Smooth and  hazy pour. Has the flavor of citrus and orange. Refreshing when everything else ran out.
On tap. Pours an orange-light brown color. Smells of some fruits, as well as some yeast. Added orange gives it a nice taste. Very drinkable beer.
Good go-to beer. Particularly refreshing with a crisp flavor and moderate carbonation. Can have one or several with no regrets.

Poured from the 12oz. bottle into a pint glass.

The color is light orange with a foamy white head.

The smell is strong of yeast, a bit spicey with a fruity flavour.

The taste is crisp, hints of spice and fruits such as orange and lemon.

A good mellow beer, well-bodied and easy drinking.

An unclear orange beer with the fastest disappearing head ever. Taste was orange, slight spice, & average tasting. Definitely tastes like an American macro trying to get a cut of the growing craft beer market but fails to deliver.
Clear straw, white head.  Citrus aroma with notes of banana.  Taste of orange peel and maybe coriander.  Decent mildly bitter finish.

A very standard Belgian White.  Nothing too risky and nothing that would offend.  Very enjoyable but not very memorable. 
Taste and aroma are spicy and orange.
22 oz. bottle purchased at Safeway in Lynnwood, WA.  Pours a cloudy orange with a fizzy white head.  Flavor:  Citrus, coriander, and sweet malt.
Bottle.  Pours a hazy orange and a medium to large white head.  The aroma is sweet caramels, citrus, and malty yeast.  The flavor is almost artificially sweet, too sweet and heavily cirtus fruity.
hazy orange with a lasting white head. Aroma of caramel, with lemon and orange peel, and a hint of butter. Sweet orange or tangerine dominated flavour
12oz bottle at the Tagalong Golf Resort in Birchwood WI. Hazy yellow/gold. Slight lemon yeasty aroma. Flavor is light and citrusy.

Pours a hazy orange, not surprising considering it’s a Belgian White.  Aroma is rather weak compared to other Belgian Whites. Flavor is of coriander and some spice -- an expected orange peel flavor. A little weak on the spice, which makes it less interesting and too bland. It’s good for a Coors beer, but there are much better Belgian Whites available -- even for the same price.
Great tasting, lightly unfiltered.  Great with an orange slice.  Not very fruity.  Great summer beer.

Pint draft.  Pours cloudy yellow-orange with light orange head.  Orange citrus dominates the aroma and flavor.  Also wheat, coriander, and malt.  Seems artificially flavored.  First few sips are the best.  Grainy mouthfeel with medium body.  Seemingly on tap everywhere so I’ve had a decent amount of these, with diminishing returns.

Aroma is hay, citrus, with some hops. Appearance is straw yellow with white head that goes away quickly. Quite a bit of carbonation. Flavor was, in my opinion, kinda nasty. Lightly bitter, lightly sour, some citrus notes. Ugh, I dunno. I expected more. Went down, uhh, barely. Kinda oily. Overall, didn’t like it. Had some good moments, but was pretty bland. 

Re-rate: This has grown on me. specifically with a Guinness. by itself, it’s better than i gave it credit for.

From tap at Breakwater, Oceanside. Pours hazy yellow with a small white head. Light eastery and soapy spiced aroma. Sweet and mild coriander flavoured. Sweet fruity, yeasty and mild spiced flavoured. Mild acidic and dry finish.

Cloudy golden pour with a small white head that recedes very quickly.  According to BJCP this style shoud have "quite good" head retention.  Citrus aroma of orange and lemon - kinda smells like fruity pebbles.  Flavor is sweet carbonation at the beginning, very little complexity, finishing with a grainy dryness.  Medium light body with lively carbonation and no harshness from orange or alcohol.  Whatever.

THIS IS ONE OF MY WIFES FAVORITE BEERS, PERSONALY I CANT DRINK IT. IT POURS A VERY CLOUDY GREENISH ORANGE COLOR WITH NO HEAD DOSN’T EVEN LOOK LIKE BEER IT ACTUALLY LOOKS LIKE ICE-T/LEMONADE MIX, TASTES LIKE A SKUNKY CRISPY ROTEN ORANGE, NOT MY STYLE IF I WANT A DRINK THAT TASTE BAD IT ATLEAST SHOULD HAVE A TON OF ALCOHOL IN IT.
Bottle. Hazy ggolden body, with a medium offwhite head. Aroma is citrus, coriander, and orange. Flavor is wheat, citrus and oranges.

Orange in color with minimal head and lacing. A distinct smell of citrus fruit especially orange. A drinkable beer with a meal but not a beer you go out of your way to sample. A decent mass produced attempt at a White Ale.
Very creamy brew, coupled with a hint of orange.  Would buy this one again.
It looks like a great beer. It’s probably the most opaque thing to come out of golden colorado. Taste comes up short, but I hope it becomes a gateway drug for people to find good belgian white ales.
This beer is the training wheels for people interested in making a switch from BMC. It’s slightly fruity and easy to drink. I don’t seek this beer out but I’ve pounded a boat load in my day.

Bottle 12fl.oz.
Unclear hazy light to medium yellow orange color with a average to large, frothy to creamy, good, fully lasting, white head. Aroma is light to moderate malty, wheat, orange, moderate yeasty, soap, coriander. Flavor is moderate sweet and bitter with a average to long duration. Body is medium to light, texture is creamy, carbonation is soft. [20090412]
Pours an orange/tan color with a small white head. Has a hint of orange citrus flavor. Not a bad beer.

Bottled, BB Oct 09.  Poured hazy peach with a nice creamy initial cap of white head.. settled down to a fine film.  The aroma picked up sweet candied oranges and fresh wheat over supporting bready character.. accents of coriander and mild white pepper.  The flavor had caramel and sweet bread at the core with not-too-tart orange zest and spicy wheat around.. finished sweet and clean.  Lighter-bodied with heavy, rolling carbonation on the palate.. well-balanced.. a bit sweet for my liking, but very drinkable.

Orange in color with minimal head and lacing.  A distinct smell of citrus fruit especially orange.  A drinkable beer with a meal but not a beer you go out of your way to sample.  A decent mass produced attempt at a White Ale.

FRom the 22 fl. oz. bottle marked OCT0509-E50861.  I was a bit surpirsed that I had not rated it yet.  It pours a cloudy orange-yellow with almost no head.  The aroma is a little yeasty and wheaty.  I noticed the coriander and orange peel in the taste.  It isn’t a bad one from Miller but it is a much weaker witbier than getting an authentic one from a Belgian Abbey.

This beer is nice combination of spice and fruit.  You really can taste the orange especially with one in the beer, but there is still a nice spice component. 

Its very a nice looking orange brown color with a great white head.

Fruity aroma with some spice, and the flavor follows appropriately, the orange inherent in the brew wasn’t too obvious for me, but was present, and the coriander supplied a pleasant spicy finish.  Something a little different, definitely worth a look.

Some people are overrating this beer, n00bs!!!  This is not an easy category, and this beer does not fair well.  Pour is a darker amber than one would expect, although the haze is right on.  Leaves a respectable head depending on the speed of pour, leaving moderate but wet lacing.  The orange and light citrus is available in the aroma, but there is definitely some skunkiness that screams MMAACCRROO!!!  Great with a burger, or another aggressive meal that does not require a more fragile, complex beer.  This is a "one glass a night" beer, I don’t know anyone who drinks it marathon style.
fruity aroma, great when you add an orange slice. very smooth and easy to drink
Nice fruity flavor and aroma. Goes down smooth with creamy texture. Good with a slice of orange in it.

1 pt glass on tap at Red Lobster. A cloudy yellow pour with a small white head. The aroma was fairly muted as this was served way to cold. There was just a hint of spice in the nose. The taste was citrus with cardamom and yeast. The mouthfeel was light and malty. The finish was short with a chemical aftertaste. Overall: initially this went down pretty good, it paired especially well with the blackened snapper, but as I finished the dinner it just became tedious.
Not bad for a mass produced Witbier.  I usually get one if it’s the only "craft" beer at the restaurant, or if it’s on special on tap.

Classic Metamucil look. Good ammount of sand grain sized sediment, a crazy ammount of carbonation and a white rocky head that produces some slippery lacing. Aroma is mild but is not bad aside from the hint of skunk very early on. The wheat and banana (mild) are softly blended and there is also some cirtus - most definetly orange - and acutally there is more citrus fruits than banana - way more (this evovles during tasting). On occasion I can notice a really dry, dusty wheat aroma. The citrus and banana are good together - I’m glad not to get a face full of that banana chip reek. Also spice is to be found - not sure what it is, but it’s not harsh or pungent. It’s a good spin and I really like it. Taste is quite plesant and highly drinkable. Mild again. Wheat, yeast and a touch of fruit (maybe even some pinapple notes tossed in the mix) . Not much to say as it’s pretty straight forward. Mouthfeel is average, just above light bodied, slight drying quality in the middle, touch of sourness sometimes. Got a tasty spicy blob of sediment/mush too. Definetly overcarbonated. Nothing too interesting here, but it sure beats getting an over-the-top bananafest.
On tap at Mustang Harry’s (NYC): Hazy orange pour. Little to no head. The taste is always a consistent creamy luscious tasting of orange, peach, and spicy coriander. Pleasant. #016 on 14062009, DG.

One of my father’s favorites so I gave it a try. 

Nice orange color and crisp feel. Has a nice clean smell with hints of citrus. Goes good with an orange slice. 

While I liked the taste and the look of it, I found it less smooth to drink and quite filling. I was rather bloaty after just one. I got rather uncomfortable after 2 and I dont know if this is just me, but I couldnt see myself drinking it on a night out as I looked borderline pregnant after the two I had.
Bottle.  Hazy apricot pour, medium carbonation with an orange aroma.  Flavor was creamy orange, peach, and finshes with some pleasant bitterness.  Good beer and a nice everyday summer brew

Who hasn’t tried this beer?  This is the one of the only white ales found in every bar/liquor store.  Heavy carbonated with a citrus taste.  Nice mouth feel just mass produced and you can taste it.  I recommend you mix it with a shot of chambord it make it much more manageable.

Bottle. Average fizzy white head that mostly diminished. Spare display of lacework. Cloudy golden color. Aroma of yeast, mild spice, wheat, mild banana like, fruity, citrus. Quite tasty actually. Light to medium bodied with an average carbonation. Light sweet flavor with a hint of acidic. Light citrus like finish.
Taste of coriander and citrus. Little head to know head.  Goes down real smooth with a mostly light mouthfeel.  For the price it is not that bad.
The orange aroma is pleasant.  But its flavor is just okay.  If this beer is not extremely cold it goes down hill fast!

Bottle. Pours a cloudy golden color with a medium sized white head. Aroma of citrus, wheat, and a hint of spice. Flavor is of sweet wheat, and citrus. Not bad... I seem to remember it being better, but I don’t really know if anything has changed.

Pours a blended orange-yellow with standard white head. Aroma of orange and a bit of male. Hints of blueberry muffins, lemon, and orange. Just because it’s made by MillerCoors doesn’t mean it’s bad, Rather good brew.

I remember drinking this for the first time about 2001 with a big slice of orange when it was delicious and not corporate and overly popular. It pours a perfectly cloudy golden yellow color with a nice white head on top. It is an easy drinking simple wheat. It truly tastes much better with a slice of orange to bring out some of the flavors that the brewer intended to taste but don’t shine through as well.

I can’t believe I used to like this!  Ugh...this stuff is awful!  Pours somewhat cloudy with great chunks floating.  Very little head formation and no retention.  Tastes of light fruit and there’s some awful taste in this as well.  I could barely choke this down.  Luckily, there’s no finish to speak of.

Never quite understood the niche this beer has garnered. Any beer that needs to be hussied up with fruit isn’t worth drinking. And trust me, it needs every bit of that orange juice to choke it down. Virtually flavorless on it’s own. Maybe the best Coors has to offer, but what is that really saying?

bottle/can/tap. Poured hazy orange-yellow with fading white head. Sweet fruity orange peel aroma. Light body, bubbly carbonation, creamy mouthfeel. Flavour of orange citrus peel and faint belgian yeast, a touch of peppery spice but an easy drinking wheat.

Paired with and without an orange slice.
Yellowish - light orange colored beer.
Wheat beer, more filling.
Unfiltered, cloudy beer.
Slight citrus smell.
Spicy taste.
Well balanced.
Better on draft.
A great beer!

Bottled - Aroma is orange. Had a few bottles with and without an orange peel in the bottle neck. Couldn’t really distinguish too much difference with it in, due to orange taste already. Cloudy and with a nice lacing head (especially when orange is added) Overall easy drinkabilty and great taste! Well crafted beer! ----- Now after having it on tap I have to give it a better rating! This stuff is amazing! I just love the orange crispness!
Cloudy yellowish color beer with good earthy grain and slight hop aroma.  Very drinkable even in wamer weather.  Has  a clean finish with a coriander and orange peel flavor.

This is a great warm weather beer. So light, spritzy, citrusy yet tasty. Pours a cloudy yellow orange color and served with an orange slice. The aroma is spicy (coriander), and lemony, orangy. The flavor is the same with a touch of soapiness and wheat in the finish. One of the better macros (its brewed by Coors) and better yet, my wife loves it!
Pours a very hazy orange with a white head. Has a nice citrus taste and goes down smooth. It is definitely a good beer, and for the price it’s hard to beat.

Bottle  - Pours cloudy orange with a low white head that disappears fast.  I have had it on tap before, and I can say I think it’s better than bottled.  It is very easy to drink, has hints of orange and other spices.  Very little lacing when my glass is empty.  A nice beer if you enjoy light beers, but has much more taste.
Cloudy pour, aroma and flavor of rain with spice and citrus. A solid brew and great with a slice of orange on a hot day.

This is a very good beer off of a tap - crisp, refreshing, and very good tasting. 
Pours with a hazy orange hue, with a small white head that is mostly diminshing. Spicy flavor with some citrus in the taste. 
Really good beer to sip while watching a game!
Orange-y taste with enough crispness to make it refreshing.  It is a little muddy, but not bad.

Bottle, from Sainsburys, Lincoln. Hazy orange gold, thin short lived white headand low condition. Citrus sweet nose with a suggestion of clove spiciness, soft and dry in the mouth with a thin spiciness and slight lemony citrus note, short muted finish with a slight chalky yeast note and low coriander spiciness.
Bottle. Gives the impression that it comes from a micro when its really from those nice suits at Coors. Slightly cloudy and a bit creamy. Some spiciness.Not what I had expected in more ways than one.
Not terribly impressed with this much-overhyped, orange-garnished white ale. Its murky, nebulous appearance foreshadows an odd and bitter taste.

Aroma of orange, with a medium head and golden-yellow appearance. Flavor starts with spice and ends smoothly with a creamy taste and texture. Overall, not the best Belgian White, but a decent domestic version.
One of the most refreshing and enjoyable Belgian white ales I’ve ever had. Served with an orange slice as a perfect compliment, it’s never the same by itself again.
Bottle. Not exactly what I expect from a Belgian white beer. The feel was okay and the mildly spicy finish was decent.
On tap at the Jet Rock Bar at the PHL airport.  Cloudy dark yellow colour, no head or lacing.  Citrusy aroma, though no yeast, Refreshing carbonated citrus flavour.
(bottle). Pours a light gold color. Small white head. Orange peel aroma. Orange and wheat flavors, with light alcohol. Smooth finish. Moderate carbonation.

12 oz. bottle.  Pours a hazy deep gold with a small, pillowy, white head.  Citrus and yeast fill the nose.  Orange, apricot, honey, and a touch of mustiness are all in the aroma.  Medium high carbonation with a medium yet slightly dry mouthfeel.  Spice, coriander, a little biscuit, a little hay, a faint sweetness, and a bit of sourness on the palate.  The finish is short and clean.  A reasonable wit, but not the greatest.

Smooth, easily gulpable ale. Not much to write home about:
 Smooth, mild spiced, and real great with a slice of orange. 
 Went good with Pizza tonight.Maybe it tasted especially good because it was free: I’d not buy it myself.
The face of white beers.... well, pours a cloudy golden white with thick white head.  Aroma of wheat, orange, and a little spice.  Flavor is identical.  Very refreshing, maybe just not my style.

It has a very heavy aroma of spices (nutmeg, oranges, coriander and the like). Its taste is just as good. It has the flavours of orange, coriander and other spices. The beer is also unfiltered, so it has chunks of the aforementioned spices and fruits inside of the beer itself as well. It’s neither too thick nor too thin, and it goes down very nice. It’s very bubbly and carbonated as well.
Cloudy and orange when poured, thick head that reflects its color.  Good aroma with light spice/orange flavors..

Sampled February 2009

Pours into my wine glass with a frothy, quarter finger thick, large bubbled off-white colored head.  The beer is a hazy, amber-gold color.  The aroma smells of grassy coriander with a backdrop of citrus that becomes more prominent as I take subsequent draughts of the aroma.  As the beer warms up the aroma begins to remind me of watered down orange juice.



Lightly sweet tasting with lots of coriander flavors, a touch of grassy grain and some cracker like malt notes.  The citrus flavors are noticeable up front and move to a prickly, carbonic tasting, peppery carbonation that is pretty substantial.  The carbonation is actually a bit too much, but some aggressive swirling brings it down to a more manageable level.  Somehow the citrus character here starts to become more of a washed out orange juice like flavor than a bright citrus oil note that I would prefer.  This is pretty light bodied, enough so that the initial carbonation made it seem a bit too fizzy.



Not bad, but seems fairly boring for a Wit.  I was honestly expecting a bit more from this beer; more fermentation complexity would definitely be appreciated.

Pours watered-down Orangina orange with a strong aroma of orange rinds to match.  Very fizzy look with about 1 finger of medium consistency head.  Flavor is a mellow, watery orange and wheat.  Not much going on here.  Good thing it’s hot tonight in San Diego, because that’s about all the appeal this beer has.  It’s not bad, just nothing special.
Crushed with Jakebra.  Somewhat decent nose mainly of oranges and spice.  Flavor is kind of rough and not great.  Much poop and little awesomeness.  Not sure why people find it so appealing.
Hoegaarden’s ass juice- coriander, orange, and ash. At Beerfest Miami 09. poopers.

Bottle, cannot believe I haven’t rated this before. Pours with a cloudy orange to white body and a small fizzy white head that fades. Aroma is citrus and a bit of spice. Taste is very watery and wheaty with light orange peel and spice.
Fizzy and dry.
pours a cloudy orange color and has a nice fruity taste.  Its good for a beer that you can find most anywhere

Brown bottle, 355 ml, best before JUL2009, gift from Jean Hamilton, savoured on April 17 2009; eye: burnt caramel, hazy, tiny particles of suspended matter, lots of effervescence, sheet of creamy white head, light lacing; nose: light wheat, light coriander; mouth: a bit thin, light wheat, light coriander, light orange, light orange, good presence of malt, fizzy finale in light wheat with presence of coriander, light-medium body, slightly bitter, quite sweet, foamy texture, rather carbonated; overall: correct

FRANÇAIS

Bouteille brune, 355 ml, meilleure avant JUL2009, cadeau de Jean Hamilton, savourée le 17 avril 2009; œil : caramel brûlé, voilée, petites particules en suspension, très effervescente, couverture de mousse blanche crémeuse, légère dentelle; nez : léger froment, léger coriandre; bouche : un peu mince, sucre, léger froment, léger coriandre, léger orange, bonne présence de malt, finale pétillante en léger froment avec petite présence de coriandre, corps léger-moyen, très légèrement amère, pas mal sucrée, texture mousseuse, plutôt carbonatée; en résumé :correct

Bottle. Pours a hazy orange gold with a short lived head. Smells sweet and fruity with a hint of spice and sewage...yeah, i think it’s sewage. Taste is light with a bit of hops, orange peel, and sewage. Ohhhhhh, it’s a coors product, yeah thats why. After a few sips, I just can’t get myself to finish it. So instead of sewer-water, coors made us some unfiltered, spiced sewer water. A fine macro-craft will rejoin the sewer tonight.

Pours hazy orange-gold. Has light citrus/lemon aroma and a hint of actual Belgian yeast. Flavor is sweet citrus, yeasty banana with creamy mouthfeel. Starts spicy but finishes sweet. Better than I remembered, still not equal to a true Belgian.

Bottle from Sainsburys. Cloudy orange in colour with a slight white head. Thin aroma of grain, oranges and yeast. Flavour was rather malty, with some more orange fruit, indeterminate spicing and short dry finish. Forgettable.
I love Blue Moon. At first I thought it was hokey to have a beer with an orange slice, but gave it a try and fell in love with it. It’s not a Rolls Royce, but definitely a Cadillac.

Aroma: nothing distinctive, but I had a cold, so I’ll let this pass

Appearance: Light orange, a little cloudy

Flavor: Nothing really stuck out except for a vague bitterness or tartness at the end...nothing bad though.  The orange peel was needed to provided a mild fruity flavor.  

Palate: Good amount of carbonation

Overall: I don’t think I like this as much as I used to, but it is still decent enough
Love this beer. Wheat ales are my favorite ales. Draft or bottle both are great. I nice beer for grilling out. Goes great with hot wings.

Avoided this in my local supermarket for months because of it’s obvious massive manchester bitter city connections. It wasn’t that bad but I’d never regularly buy anything connected with that shower of shite. Murky light brown orange. Interesting flavour which wasn’t that bad, the usual fruit avalanche. Meh, not that offensive but poor for a variety of reasons.

Bottled	A hazy light brown coloured beer with a white head.  The aroma has good spices: coriander and curacao which is nicely orangey.  The taste is similar.  Again nicely spicy and refreshing.  A good finish.  Authentic Belgian wit.	Score 3.4
Subsequent ratings scored 2.9 and 3.4. Average becomes 3.2
Somewhat girly. Fruity but still pretty tasty. Doesn’t completely drown out the beer taste. Not my favorite but don’t hate it.
creamy sweet.  doesn’t taste much like beer.  A nice gateway beer for non beer drinkers since it tastes like juice, especially with a bunch of fruit pieces dumped in it.
Cloudy with small head.  Good flavor, prefer on tap vs. bottled.  One of the better Belgians I have had.

I love the drinkability of Blue Moon.  This wheaty wits are fantastic on a hot day, and Blue Moon tops my list of them.  Hell, it’s inspired me to brew my own!  Pours a cloudy golden with slight orange highlights.  Aroma is definite coriander and orangey-citrus.  Flavor is a smooth combo of bitter orange and crisp, refreshing wheat.  The oat gives it a smooth, rounded body which I love.  Awesome production beer!
Cloudy orange color, some citrus flavor and a little creamy and sweet.  The kind of beer I would only drink when the other options are of the American macroo-brew variety.

Tap. Why the hell did the bartender put a piece of fruit in this? Maybe to add some flavor... Get that shit outta here. Poured hazy orange with a fluffy white head. Aroma of nothing. Some citrus flavor. Probably from the orange slice. Lots of tools drinking this nowadays.

Thick, completely opaque pour soupy with bits. Heavily perfumed coriander and lemon aroma with background wheat. Coriander, lemon meringue and lemon puff flavour with a sweetener-like bitterness and n/a toasted cereal notes. No edge or sparkle but plenty of cardboard. Fake and forced like a French supermarket effort. Clumsy oat and coriander soup. Not at all surprised that Coors are behind it. Overpriced curiosity courtesy of Warwick Sainsbury’s.
Had this one on draft at a restaurant with limited selection. Smooth and drinkable. A little citrus there, color a cloudy orangish with white head. Not my favorite style but I’d have another.

Aug 2018. Queens Head, Bewly. Bottle. Watery wheat beer. Quite pleasant. 2.8

March 2009. 355ml unfiltered bottle. Mild and attractive. This is a pleasantly drinkable confection. It lacks aggression and impact and perhaps a bit of character, and there is a tendency for the experience to be rather laid back - but this is a pleasant enough beer with gentle hints of orange and the modest warmth of a restrained pinch of spice. I wouldn’t rave about it, but I wouldn’t object to another one either. 2.8

Tap. Pours a hazy orange with a small white head. Nose is citrusy, cinnamon, clove. Strong wheat taste with light amounts of spice. Overall, a decent beer, not the best belgian white, but refreshing nonetheless.

Bottle - from sampler pack. Light golden, very cloudy. Slight spicy aroma. So-so. Way underpronounced Belgian White flavor. Might be a good version for those used to drinking US mass market lagers, but if you’ve ever had a craftbrewed version, or one actually from Belgium this doesn’t come close.

Location: 
You can get this one anywhere, and I have had it many times.




Overall Impression: 
I like this beer a lot when I’m really thirsty, not so much for slow drinking, but it definately serves its purpose.  You can get this one anywhere, and it’s better then many of the beer that fit that category.

Pours from bottle gold an pretty clear.  Not horrible, but not the best by any means.  Good for a drinking to get drunk beer if you’re not a bud or miller fan..... which who is.   Anyway, somewhat citrusy, hint of wheat.  Ok. I may keep it in my fridge for the friends I have over that I don’t want to drink my good stuff.
Pours deep hazy gold into a tumbler.  White head quickly recedes to hug rim leaving no lacing. Mild coriander and wheat aromas. Soft and medicinal. Lasting sour finish.

not great. i’m so sorry that this beer is like EVERYWHERE. worse than that, i’m sorry that everyone thinks this is fabulouser than miller lite or pabst, as if blue moon were the next logical progression up from domestic lagers. seriously, it’s not good.
Wouldn’t drink it without an orange. With the orange it is very refreshing and light bodied.  Pours a light yellow.
With or without orange, no thanks.  This was one of my earliest beers and I didn’t have a taste for it at the time.
Bottle. Aroma is wheat and malts. Flavor is citrus wheat and citrus. Very smooth brew.

I’m not going into details for an average beer. Let’s say this, if your trying to go half way cheap but still have an enjoyable drinking experience (that means 5-6 beers not a shit show), blue moon is a good way to go.  It’s for sure a step up from the traditional trash beers like bud light, miller, etc... The ladies seem to love this one as well.

The pleasant aromas consist of citrus and a little wheat.  This is slightly cloudy and golden in color. I can barely taste any spice in this beer. At least for a White.  It tastes mildly sweet with a good citrus flavor.  It’s light in body and seems a tiny bit watery to me, but not bad at all.  This is a Belgian White for the non-adventurous IMO.  I don’t mind drinking this at all, but it’s just a little generic for my taste.

Bottled, 355ml from Sainsburys, Banbury. Clouded gold with white head, floaters. Reasonable aroma, vaguely citric with a pomaigne type touch, the flavour is also a thin citricity, some zest, sweet and spicy. There appears to be a need to get citrus notes into this at the expense of solid brewing as there is little background, the appearance of a forced beer. It’s ok, but I’m not rushing to try the other one in my garage for a while.

Bottle 355 ml 
 
Appearance:  hazed amber gold with medium creamy top. 3-
Nose:  Citric , zesty fresh nose, slight hop side , grainy bottom.6+ 
Flavor/Palate : Citric ,refreshing brew. Orange feel , zesty clean , smooth , drinkable flavored ale. Balancing hop feel at finish.
Pours light orange.  Too sweet for my liking.  Wheaty texture.  Many have raved but I’ll stick to something a little more malty.
Slight citrus and spice(coriander). A very good replica of the traditional belgian whites.  Excellent beer.
Pours a light orange with a white head. Aroma/flavour of oranges and light spices. Sort of a sweet finish. Fairly good stuff.

Pours a hazy golden orange with a thin white head.... Aroma is fairly wheaty without the usual spiciness but with a twang of orange aroma... Flavor follows the aroma, without the spiciness that defines many of the quality witbiers that i like... Medium bodied easy drinking, this is a quality beer for the masses...

Awesome beer. Light orange poor and body. You can smell the citrus before you drink this sacrament. Very good taste of orange, light drink, just all around good beer. No complaints about this beer on my end.
