Light orange hazy body with a good sized white head that fully dissapears. Aroma of citrus and malts.  Light bodied beer. Classic belgian flavors with an orange twist at the end.  Refeshing beer  Could get a little sweet if you had more than one though.
Citrusy with a watery mid-palate.  Head disappears quickly into the hazy, orange-yellow brew.  A beer for summer sessions.
Draught: Pours a darker gold with a medim white head. Holds a small lacing when the glass empties. Smells of wheat and malts. Leaves the palate refreshed and ready more. Good summer brew!

Bottle (12oz).  Yep, says "brewed in Toronto" on it - I had to go to Buffalo to buy it.  Cloudy pale orange-amber with an average fizzy white head.  Smells decent enough - apple, light coriander, mild sweet yeast.  The taste is sweet, slightly papery, I get a little peach and dry floral spiciness.  Solid bodied, nicely carbonated, thickly malty with no ugly aftertaste - frankly, this is a very pleasant surprise - perhaps a little too sugary and lacking in balancing coriander bitterness
Bottle. (Review of past tastings from memory) I do not like this beer. Maybe it is the style or maybe it is me but I even after a couple trys I just haven’t been able to enjoy this one.

Yellowish-gold hazy appearance with a thin white head.  spice flavors nearly overwhelmed by orange. Some coriander noticable, but not fully developed.  Unremarkable mothfeel, but easy to drink and sessionable.

12oz bottle. Pours a cloudy golden-yellow with a thin white head. Aroma is mostly orange and yeast...as is the flavor. Goes down pretty smooth...Nice mouthfeel, bit of an aftertaste. Its ok...I guess a decent session beer...seems like a drinkable "light beer" to me.
Bottle.  As with most Belgians, it pours hazy off-yellow with a slight head.  Flavor is slightly citrus, but noticeable, with a slightly spicy finish.  Decent Belgian wheat for a decent price.
Pours a cloudy tan with a small, quickly dissipating head. Perfect with an orange as you can pick up orange notes on the finish. Refreshing.
Hazy dark golden in color with a nice white lacy head.  Delicate wheat aroma drifts into your nose.  Taste is of wheat with a slightly fruity notes.
Everything is out of balance. Very watery.....unpleasant spice. Not a very good beer.

Bottle.  Hazy gold and orange with a large white head.  Aromas are lots of sweet wheat and oats with spices and citrus.  Flavours are sweet citrus and smooth almost milky wheat.  Hoppy and herbal with spices on the finish.  Decent and refreshing.

A very smooth looking body with a cloudy yellow/orange color. Not much for head, delicious citrusy orange, lightly spiced flavour start to finnish.
very pleasant mild white beer and very unieque. One of my personal favorites.
Amber in color with a thin head....tasted almost soapy at first with a strange aftertaste...not a big fan but mabe my taste was off lol

Bottle.  Pours a hazy yellow with very thin white head.  Smells like wheat with spice, a little bit of yeast in there.  Heavy wheat taste with hints of spice.  Very easy to drink, very thin mouthfeel with not much carbonation.  Decent.

Holy Yeast infection Batman!  Wow, the Yeast flavor is prominent....and yet tasty.  Nice aroma.  Could start a good evening of Blatz drinking.  Or you could bake bread with it.....either way you are a winner with Blatz quality!!!!  Long live Val!

Cloudy orange, fruity start to finish; nicely balanced. Light carbonation, scant white head. Orange blossom aroma and flavour, faintly tart aftertaste. Excellent with a slice of orange, a very nice American version of a Belgian White, though less complex than the Belgian versions.
Living in AL, this is the only "micro" I can get locally on draft.  Usually my go to because it is the only choice unless I want Bud or Miller.  Hazy pour with orange aroma.  Easy drinking.

Light, wheaty aroma with some citrus undertones. Cloudy, translucent appearance. Flavor has citrus elements with nearly no hoppiness and small amounts of maltiness. Palate is non-distinct. A fairly mundane brew, but drinkable when no better options are available.
Decent beer, great taste that is smooth and refreshing. goes great with a orange slice.
Decent American white beer for the masses. Smooth, refreshing, and effervescent. Lacks some of the depth of flavor and character of some other wheat beers, but pretty good nonetheless.

Pours opaque light golden color with a frothy off-white head. Aroma is light spice and grains with a hint of citrus. Flavor isn’t as good or pronounced as a good representation of the style, yeasty grains with some spice and orange peel.

Had on tap, poured yellowish orangy color. really smooth going down. tasted a little fruity, actually it tasted like fruity pebbles cereal to me. But still I thought this was a pretty decent brew anyway, especially for a coors product! I would definitley have this again......but honestly I would have to not have the best of selections like I did tonight.

Bottle Shop in South Beach Miami. Fairly tired and dull sweet wheat malt profile, lack of spice or citrus character. Main weaknesses are the feel of the palate,the lack of varied aromas, and the marked superiority of easily found Belgian Wits like Brussels White , Blanche de Chambly or Hoegaarden.

I first had on tap and loved it. Tried from bottle and it tasted different, darker and kind of stale. Still a good beer but doesn’t really taste like a true  Belgian witbier. The label should say "Belgian Style" and not "Belgian Ale". Shock Top actually tastes closer to one to me than this.
bottle into my mouth. Uhhhhhhhhhhhhhhhhhhhhhhhhhhhhhhhhhhhhhhhhhhhhhh not a true belgian white!!!

Appearance: Cloudy, dull, golden-orange body with a small, fizzy, white head.

Smell: Notes of orangey citrus and perky spices infuse the wheaty nose of Blue Moon.

Taste: Tangy, lightly creamy malted wheat. A taste of citrus zest and a fair dose of spice interrupts the brief sweetness. Light, spicy hops and bitterness provides a bit of balance. Finishes tangy with a light, lingering hint of spice and orange.

Mouthfeel: Medium-bodied. Medium, fizzy carbonation.

Drinkability: It certainly has some stuff going for it. It’s very easily available, rather drinkable, relatively inexpensive, and isn’t altogether dreadful.
good taste, great flavor. lots of carbonation. malty with a hint of orange.
On draft, straw colored and hazy with lots of carbonation. Flavor is watery malt  and vaguely orange with some mineral. No funk or nuance.
Great summer beer. Light and refreshing. This is another one that I don’t think tastes as good out of the bottle.

Bottle - poured into shaker glass.  Maybe it was how I poured it, but it had nearly a 1 1/2 inch white head.  Yellow, orange cloudy appearance.  Smooth, fruity and easy going down, almost a "light" beer feeling.  Not heavy at all, it was alright.
Bottle. Cloudy yellow/orange with a white head.  Belgium wit clone. Rather bland to be honest.

On tap at The Rake, Borough Market.  Cloudy orange gold with thin white head.  In a Belgian wit style.  A little soapy, but good orange fruit flaours.  Its pretty good.  Fullish fruit flavour.  OK carbonation decent beer to start the day with.  Some crystallised tangerine fruit too.

not extremely bad, but by no means impressive. the aroma was the best part of the experience. it was very light,  yet there was too much going on in the flavor. i dont even remember a finish. not a fan.
a nice beer considerd its owend by coors. i like it alot better, not the best whit but realy good. pretty sweet. citrus notes

12oz bottle.  Pours a nice inch head that quickly fades into a hazy orangeyellow color.  Smells of sweet malts, coriander and spice.  Taste is mostly of malt, citrus with a hint of spice.  Very easy drink and easy to find.

Bottle at home ... a very odd find in sainsburys... and very welcome due to a thread on this and one of the buds as some peoples idea of good beer ... Nice hazy golden yellow ... spicy bubblegum... way tooo fizzy destroys any flavour in its fizz ... defizzing you get a slightly medicinal yeasty bubble gum ... drinkable even plesent but not really me.
Solid offering considering it is from Coors. Refreshing but not as smooth as something like Hoegaarden, which is somehow considered the same style. Wheaty with hints of orange, some spices.

Bottle that I found in Sainsburys, Kidlington, Oxon recently, consumed Dec 08. Pours hazy golden moving to light amber with a large white fluffy head. Nice wheaty nose with some spices and yeastiness in there. This is far better than expected and actually quite decent and refreshing. If I was being critical I suppose the spices and citrusiness which are very much in evidence are not quite subtle enough and its a little sweet but I really didnt mind it at all despite these faults. A7 A4 F6 P3 OV13   3.3

Ok, I am finally getting around to rating Blue Moon. From the bottle it pours a hazy gold with smallish white head. The aroma is butterscotch, orange, coriander, maybe some honey. The flavor is unsurprising, given the aroma. Butterscotch sweetness dominates, with an ungraceful spiciness around it. Drinkable, but unimpressive.
I enjoyed this beer. I had it on tap with an orange.  I really enjoy wheat beers and this was flavorful and refreshing
Saborosa e leve, fácil de tomar. Mas falta aroma na cerveja pra combinar com sua coloração.

This unfiltered wheat ale has an apricot hue when viewed through a glass. There’s a prominent citrus flavor present here - oranges come to mind. The consistency is a somewhat thin - perhaps a bit too watery. The brew is certainly easy to drink and tastes good - an above average beer that most people can agree on. As far as Hefeweizens go Blue Moon isn’t mind blowing, but I have yet to find a cheaper wheat ale of comparable quality.
Tap the first time. Yellow with a thick white head. Nice taste of wheat and orange. smooth on the palate. Nice finish.

[355ml bottle from Sainsbury’s - labelled as "North American Craft Beer" rather than "Belgian White Ale" and brewed by BMBC in Toronto.] Cloudy orange with thin white head; aroma has some citrus and some grain; flavour the same, rather soapy and floury mouthfeel. Refreshing, but nothing more.

Cloudy orange gold pour with a very lacey head.  Scent of citrus and taste of correander and orange as expected.  Definately a Wit Beer.  Not a bad one at that.  Very drinkable.  Between a Mill Street Wit and a Hoegaarden to me.

Murky orange with a white head. Sweet slightly gluey taste with some grainy background. Taste has a little citrus at the beginning and some soapy dryness at the end. The rest is sweety oaty biscuit. It has some redeeming features. For instance, it quenches your thirst if you drink it cold and very fast.

Lightly peppery, gentle citrus nose.  Pours orange and cloudy.  Flavour is not great - a bit cloying and a bit too soft drinky.  Finish spreads out into dirty socks and dishwater that used orange scented washing up liquid.  Disappointing.

I sampled this brew a number of times when in Las Vegas.  It purports to be a "Belgian White", but is clearly a poor American imitation.  It looks vaguely right with a frothy head and cloud appearance, but that’s where the resemblance to a Belgian White ends.  As per comments below, it is very soapy.  It is overly sweet and citrusy in a fake way.  The Americans should stick to the Pale Ales, which they do well and leave this sort of thing to the Belgians and Germans.

Drank straight from the bottle, which was stupid of me since I tried to make myself start pouring all beers I drink into a glass for the sake of ratings, but eh.

When I opened it there was a cool cloudiness to it, almost as if there were a little smoke in the bottle. Very foamy, not bitter which is good, but it didn’t have a great taste to it. Kind of like soapy bread water. It was smooth though, great mouthfeel. 

Smells of citrus and soap. Not amazing, but not terrible. 

Has a good ABV though so if you don’t like it but its around you can drink it fast and start feeling good. As far as finding an enjoyable beer, I’d say keep searching.

Had this beer before, but never paid much attention to what was going on.

Poured an enourmous white head. Straw-colored, cloudy.

The bottle suggests orange peel and coriander as ingredients. The coriander is obvious in the nose, but you have to search for the orange peel. Eventually, your nose will find it.

No lacing, but very smooth mouthfeel. No bitter aftertaste, just the taste of sweet wheat.

Very easy drinking.

I was in the grocery store the other day trying to pick out a liquor because my girlfriend only really drinks liquors when I overheard a couple in the next aisle bickering about what beer to get. The guy was trying to buy some coors or something, but the girl said that Blue Moon was the best beer in the world. I then blacked out.  I was told I made a bit of  a scene making stabbing motions into my chest.

I’ve heard the argument that this beer is a "gateway" into better beer. It doesn’t matter. This is not a good beer by any means. What little flavor it has is soapy.

I’ve had this on tap and in bottles a million times.  Cloudy orange-grey body with a thin off white head.  Orange rind, and citrus zest and soap aromas.  More soapy lemon and orange with a nice wheat body and a good finish.

An excellent beer!!  Hard to believe this is distributed by Coors.  What I heard, the brewery that originally created Blue Moon was bought up by Coors but Coors left the brewmasters alone with their original recipe and let them keep creating this magnificent beer!

Pours an unusual, opaque yellow with a fluffy off-white head.  Very, very dry with a spicy zing and a bit of a creamy orange taste to it, as well as wheat and banana.  Fairly carbonated.  No aftertaste and light on the palate.  An enjoyable beer.

Oddly colored fluorescent cloudy yellow.  A faint aroma of orange.  It is both creamy but sparkly from the carbonation.  Typically yeasty.  Dry finish. Not sure why this is called a """"Belgian White"""".  Not sure why this beer costs $3 for 22ox. Weaksauceish.

If an orange is involved and it’s free I can choke this beer down, but even then it’s a struggle roughly akin to trying to swim the amazon while wearing a suit made of beef. Inexorably and excruciatingly terrible.

Bottle. Pours a bright, hazy bright orange with a decent fluffy, white head. Aroma is orange peel (I didn’t add an orange slice), lemon, maybe some wheatgrass. Taste is somewhere in between a hefeweizen and a watery witbier. Medium to light palate. Very smooth, citrusy, and refreshing. Neutral aftertaste. My favorite beer from Coors- that’s saying a lot. Gets +1 pt for being Canadian. The best of the Blue Moon Series (the seasonals are all abominable).
Bottle. Medium highh creamy lasting white head. Hazy light yellow green body. Banana, abrricot, lemon aroma. Heavily carbonated acidic lemon flavor. Short aftertaste.

Totally took me by surprise.  Tried this a couple years ago and thought it tasted like regurgatated beer.  Now I drink alot of it.  Smells of wheat, coriander, and slightly citrusy.  Pours golden amber.  Forget the orange because it masks the true spicy and citrusy flavor that is bottled within.  Perfectly balanced between wheat and spice.  If you dont like it the first time, definately give it a try again as your taste preferences change.

I’ve had this a bunch.  Usually from tap into a pint glass.  Rich amber color with a white frothy head.  Served with an orange slice, it’s hard to smell anything but that, but there is definitely smells of wheat and other summery fruits.  With an orange, tastes of wheat and citrus.  Pretty good every day bar style beer.
This is very decent beer , great on tap ! The orange thing is weird, we should stick with the traditional lemon slice?
Tap. Cloudy golden color, small head. Aroma of some banana and wheat. Quite sweet taste. Ok stuff.
Not terrible.  Orangey on the pour.  Watery citrus flavor.  Not bad for Coors
Pours cloudy yelowish/orange. Citrusy nose with a crisp taste with decent after bite. Not as strong as other belgian whites I’ve had but this is a very decent beer. Very drinkable.

Pours a slightly hazy light orange with a thin white head. Wheat aroma and taste. Orange slice compliments the wheat flavor well. Somehow this beer is more filling than you would guess from its look and taste. This one’s good on occasion.
Very light, crisp, and cool. Tastes mostly of wheat and slightly of citrus. Very nicely balanced.
Bottle Poured cloudy orange with nice white head. Taste is Wheat with a bit of citrus hops. The best brew made by Coors by far.
BOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOO NO THANK YOU TO THIS

Cloudy golden poor, small off-white head.  Aromas of tangerine, yeast, resin, apple-pear.  Lactose feel, medium carbonation, lightly sweet, zesty.  Nice smooth citrusy goodness... far from overpowering but just nicely balanced.  Very good Witbier!

(Bouteille de 341 ml. - Dégusté avec french tickler) Une biere de couleur Or brumeux avec un bon collet moyennement collant couleur blanc. Odeur de pommes, sel, tangerine. Gout de blé, pain et un peu de miel.

Good wheat beer, since it’s left unfiltered it has a unique taste, that for some reason always makes me full. Can’t drink more than 3 of these in a night, but as maybe a pre BBQ beer it’s great. Light orange color, very carbonated, slightly sweet and tart, light mouthfeel. Not bad to start a night with but not the best.

Bottle @ Porterhouse, London.

Pours hazy and lightly pale yellow with a fine, frothy, white head. Low duration. sweet aroma, with a good dose of coriander, light vanilla, some citrus and wheat. Medium carbonation, okay mouthfeel. Flavour is very soft, sweet wheat, light citric and a medium aftertaste of coriander. Quite a fair beer.
Bottle. Pours a hazy gold color with good size head.  Smells of wheat and citrus.  Tastes similar.

Pours a nice deep thick bronze and gold.  Great head from the tap.  Very nice at first taste, hints of wheat and citrus.  This had a bit of a sweet flavor to it, which was a nice little surprise.  I’ve had  "Shock Top"  which is another Belgian White produced by Anheuser- Busch, it’s good, but it isn’t better than Blue Moon.  This is a solid beer.

Golden cloudy pour with a good foamy head that lasts a while.  Sweet citrus, malt, yeast and wheat in the aroma.  Flavor is also sweet and citrusy, with a bit of the grain, yeast and some spice coming through.  Not a great Wit, but definitely doable.

This is a solid Belgian wit. I often will have this if I’m out at a sportsbar or some other place that is limited in it’s beer selection. Nice thick wheatiness good color and texture. I don’t put fruit slices in my beer, but some people like it with orange.
I had the 3.2% ABV, the 6% is much better.  Citric, light, slight sour, highly carbonated.  This would be good on a picnic.
Nice wheat ale. Goes good with an orange slice. It’s a little sweet, but I kind of like that sometimes. The color is weak, but that’s to be expected in a wheat ale.
A cloudy appearance with a small head. Has a nice citrus smell with a smooth intial taste followed by a lack luster finish. A bit too sweet for my tastes. Lots of fruit taste in it.
Hazy in color, tastes of citrus....smooth and drinkable. Nicely balanced, a pretty good wheat beer.

Bottle.  Poured a hazy yellow color with a small white head.  Aroma of citrus and wheat.  Flavor is more citrus with a decent balance of wheat.  A little too sweet.  Medium body with mild carbonation.

Bottle.  Pour is a cloudy straw color with a bit of a white head and agressive aromas of 7-up like lemon/lime with a touch of sweetness.  Flavor is a little better, but still reminds me of 7-up.  The citrus balances out the wheat and yeast graininess, but it still is a little too sweet.  Not going to win any awards by my books, but OK.
cloudy pale yellow with suspended yeast chunks.  lemon aroma with a thin dry taste.
ubiquitous tap, cloudy yellow color, decent head, nose is slightly fruity, flavor is lemon, dry and watery, not much finish

Pours a very hazy golden.  Aroma was strong of wheat and citrus, most noticably orange.  The flavor is watered down, but better than most would expect from Coors.  It finishes with a nice after taste.  For what it is, this is not a bad choice.

For a Belgium white made my Coors I was suprised. I imagine that is why they bought the company because I definitely do enjoy the beer. I have had it on tap and in the bottle and would prefer the tap, but either way this is a great beer and one of the better Belgium wheats I have had. The wheat taste is good with nice hint of spice and fruit.
This is exactly what you would expect from Coors. It is weak. It has hardly any aroma, and the flavor is very weak. In fact, it tastes remarkably like regular Coors with spicy hints
nose of wheat, flavor very clean with nice clean finish. nicely balanced. taste like wheat beer & very drinkable
Mild spice with a great creamy appearance.  Not much afterthought. Decent beer all around
Not entirely impressive, this white beer has too much spice for me.  Rides the unbalanced line with a bitterness I feel a white beer should not have.
NOT BAD FOR A COORS PRODUCT. AS FAR AS BELGIUM WHITE BEERS GO THIS ONE IS LITTLE BELOW AVERAGE. I WOULD MUCH RATHER HAVE A HOEGARDEN.

Blue Moon reminds me of the band Wilco.  Everyone seems to love them and put them on this pedestal for doing something different and worth noting.  They get credited for brilliant use of "sonic textures" and re-defining rock music. In actuality they’re a bland, uninteresting, mediocre at best group that people are "fans" of for the social status that goes along with it.  Wilco is band for the hipsters - and those hipsters drink Blue Moon.
Not being a fan of Belgian whites and not being a fan of Coors, I wasn’t surprised that my eyes started tearing when I took a sip of this, hold the orange and hold the beer, not bad for me
Just like a real white micro (read crisp ester yeast), brewed by Molson/Coors. Travesty.
A very good ale, the wheat with a bit of orange make for an interesting combination to taste.  Everyone should try this at least once and may be satisfied.
I don’t understand the obsession with this one. Its ok. But I agree with mexifinn, its too fruity, and adding an orange just makes it worse.

Tastes a bit like a Zima with some moldy and gritty orange peels mixed in for texture... sorry, but not actually a beer to me, more of a fruit drink... only redeeming quality was the higher than avg. alcohol content.

This beer pours a hazy orange color with a medium white head.  The aroma is very much of citrus and a bit of wheat.  Flavor is predominantly citrus and some spices.  Soft moutheel.  It’s OK, but not great, and due to its lack of character, obviously comes from a mega brewer.  I won’t be anxious to buy it again.
Pours a cloudy yellow-orange with a foamy white head.  Aroma is citrus and a little spice.  Taste is orange and some spice.  One of the better macro beers available.  Not bad overall.
I find this beer in a bar in dallas tx, lightly orange colour , citrus aroma, the flavour is citrus fruits.

Certainly one of the better macros out there.  Cloudy golden orange; a bit less head than hoped for.  This is a big ol’ spice bomb.  Lots of citrus (lemon and orange) but in a somewhat thin way; loads of curacao and coriander.  Nothing subtle about it, but definitely quite drinkable.
This was somewhat of a positive surprise. Thin head, cloudy light yellow, reasonable spice  with cardamom, citrus flavors, a bit of similar spice in the mouth, but very watery and minimal finish.

On tap, pint glass.  Dull opaque gold with a finger’s worth of a quickly dissipating fluffy white head.  Aroma of lemon.  Citrus flavor initially also of lemon, then turning darker, towards orange.  A banana sweetness becomes more evident in the finish.  A hint of nutmeg gives a buzz to the tongue.  Flavorful, but a  musty staleness is a significant defect.
Bottle. Pours unclear yellow with a white head. Light lemony and wheaty aroma. Light body. Flavor has a bit of lemony zest and a hint of spice. Decent at best.

12oz bottle from Publix Supermarket. Pours a hazy light caramel color with a thick white head that settles rapidly to nothing. Little lacing. Aroma is wheaty with some notes of syrup, maybe molasses, some spice, and mild fruit notes. Flavor is fairly mild with some wheat notes, lemon-citrus, and some spice. Generally light body with a slightly lemony finish. Drinkable, but does not compare with the European beers of the same style.
The best mass produced belgium wheat beer moneyt can buy in your regular supermarket/deli.

Bottled@The Rake, London. Golden colour, lots of particles floating around, mediumsized white head. Aroma is spices, wheat, US hops and some mild notes of earh. Flavour is citrus fruits, herbal notes and quite a lot of grass and mild spices.

A respectable attempt at a wheat beer by the big guys, but in an underhanded way.  It pours a slightly hazy gold color with an aroma of citrus, but upon tasting it reveals something different.  The flavor gives a hint of citrus and spice, but also some corn and rice.  If served with a piece off ruit, however, this taste is masked well.  I will avoid it simply because it is a Coors beer, and Coors should take ownership of it and stamp their name on it.

Slight citrus aroma with a hazy orange pour with little bits of orange zest and white head. Has a spiced and citrus taste, which is surprisingly complex for a macro, and with a sweet finish. A pretty good attempt at a Belgian white from Coors of all people, but still obviously leaves much to be desired.
Murky looking brew with rather nice aroma and enjoyable on the palate. Sort of light but smooth and really drinkable. I actually like this a lot.Very,very good on tap with some fruit eh.

Overall a decent attempt at a belgian from a macro. Smells average for a belgian, nothing to strong but meets standards. Some wheat tastes there with a bit of an orange citrus, but an overwhelming carbonic sting destroys any semblance of enjoyment there. A shame, this would have been quality without it, but carbonation once again takes hold of a hopeful macro and flushes it down the toilet.

Good solid introduction to the classes of beer outside of BMC. I enjoy the light taste, though the bready feeling makes me want to change brews before I "get full". Not too much to say, some wheat, a little citrus and that’s all there is. I’d recommends for anyone who wants to get someone drinking something new.

22 ounce bottle.  Pours a cloudy orange with a nice, large, off white head.  Taste and aroma are of wheat and citrus.  Is fairly sweet.  For the price, this is a really nice beer, that is very easy to drink and enjoy.

Tasted somewhere along my trip through the States.

Pretty dull, but drinkable white beer.

2008 Bottle - Pours cloudy tan with a small white head, bready citrus aroma with some spice, this beer was a bit of a surprise...I had it years ago and thought it was piss...slightly better this time, decent spicy grainy beer...light but with substance, I probably won’t drink this again because there are about 1,001 wits that are better, but better than expected...

RateBeer Rating, Style and Glass: 46, Belgian Wit, Tumbler, Weizen
ABV, Volume & Calories: 5.4 % in 22 fl oz. estimated at 300 C
Purchased at: Martin’s in Waynesboro, VA for $2.49

Aroma: minimal, citrus, snow. 6 out of 10.

Visuals: cloudy, orange, white persistent head, okay lace. 4 out of 5.

Taste: wheat, banana, mold. 7 out of 10.

Palate: slate, medium finish, sweet. 3 out of 5.

Overall: Not quite as good as other macro Belgian styles, such as Hoegaarden. I’ll likely have it again, since it’s everywhere. It’s not a favorite. 13 out of 20.

On tap. Hazy orange body with a creamy white head. Fresh, fruity aroma with citrus. Flavor is fruity, spicy and quite typical with some orange and a sharp bitter finish. A quite nice one from the big one.

My first Belgium white. Had it at Ruby Tuesday’s. Not sure I could really get much aroma out of it, but the taste was pretty good. Very much citrus-orange like to me. Clarity was kinda cloudy like. Not bad.

Draught at local dive bar. Looks nice in an artificial way, like a woman with breast implants. Very thick and very white, I repeat very white head atop a hazy golden body. Fruity aromas. Watery body. Soda pop sweetness becomes more insipid with each sip. A disturbing Franken-bier that tastes and feels like it was conceived and concocted in a laboratory.
Blue moon is the best cheap beer out there. It is an amazing wheat beer and tastes quite good. It doesn’t have nasty after taste and is very available.
A decent Belgian White. Had it on draft at the Holliday Inn 48 street in Denver. A good fruit flavour

Pours a hazy orange color with a big off white head. Aroma is of wheaty malt and citrus fruits, particularly orange. Flavor was a lot frutier than the aroma. Its almost like drinking orange flavored beer. This is my beer of choice at bars with no micro selections
Possibly the best mass-market, widely available beer around.  It’s my go-to beer at mediocre restaurants/bars, because it’s usually available.  But it really is enjoyable, nice citrus flavor.

Very run of the mill witbier.  This was the beginning of the big beer guys (like Coors) attempting to pass of their crap as a craft beer by changing the label.  I’d had this before, but after drinking it last night, I decided I should rate it.  The aroma had wheat, orange peel, coriander, and was mostly spicy.  the appearance was typical to the style, a golden, hazy color with white foam.  The flavor was very ordinary for a witbier, but certainly not bad.  There are many other witbiers out there I would get first, but I would drink this if there were nothing else.
A pleasent enough beer. Has nice aroma, appearance is kind of cloudy, nice taste and easy on the palate. I had this one on tap at a Delaware eatery, I’ll drink this one again in the future.
This is a decent attempt at a belgian white. I would still drink hoegaarden over this any day but it’s an ok beer.
Very good with an orange slice, goes great with food. A great way to get a great beer at any bar. A definite go-to beer when at a bar.

Ah, my gateway beer. This was the one that made me realize beer could taste and taste GOOD.  Pale cloudy orange with a nice 2" head.  Sweet citrus smell and taste.  I love this on a hot, humid day (and there’s no other kind here in the 5-6 month summer).  Easy to find, easier to drink, this is my constant fallback drink, my tasty walk down memory lane each time I pop one open.

Not really a favorite, but I use this as my go to beer when first walking into somewhere new.  It’s very common to an orange slice to the glass since the beer is brewed with orange peels.  Not as orange flavored as the commercial Shock Top.  It’s kind of hit or miss with some people since many are opposed to fruity tasting beers...... Don’t be fooled though, it’s not some girly hard orangejuice.  It’s beer

i was stuck in the dallas/fort worth airport, where i sampled this on tap at a T.G.I.F.  pours cloudy yellow, no herad, tiny white bubbles.  i was slightly amused when the bartender served it with a slice of orange.  it smelled of orange, but then i threw the slice away.  i smelled some wheatiness, and possibly orange (don’t know how much orange was residual from the slice).  flavoe has a bit of spicey-sour hint, with banana tones.  a bit effervescent on the tongue.  not bad, but i am not wheat fan.

I like how bartenders put an orange in it.  I love beer flavored oranges!  Anyways, orange colored but not as appealing as I’d like.  Weak on flavors of obviously orange, and small amount of hops.  No bitterness unfortunately.
One of the better commercial beers out there. Orange colored Wit Bier, with a strong body, although I hate how bartenders automatically throw an orange in the beer now!

On tap at TGIFriday’s in Torrance, CA.

Cloudy golden orange beer with a small white head.  Malty citrus aroma.  Flavor is malt sweetness with a bit of yeast.  The beer has a bite which is different, but pleasant.  Finish is very slight bitterness with some sweet.  Very good summer beer.

on Tap at Dubliner Pub in Omaha, NE.  Cloudy yellow color, poor foamy, probably because the weitress and she put some orange on the glass. Te aroma is citrus, with some notes of lemmon and orange, flavor is quite bitter. Mouthfeel is citrus.

White ale, whatever that means, it sounds like watered down pale ale which is not a good thing. The flavor is light with light malts and tastes like defrosted lager of the bad vriety. The only thing this white ale has going for it is the dreamy label on the bottle but as a beer it falls short and I can’t imagine adding orange to it. At the end, you really can’t expect a decent brew from Coors who make sparkling yellow water and call it beer. They are no different when it comes to their ales.
Not bad considering its lineage. Just different enough from the regular suspects to stand out.

12oz.  I have had this more than once but have finally gotten around to rating it.  Pours white tending to yellow with a white head.  Nose is a sugar bowl.  Body is loads of sweet, perfumed corn syrup.  I’ll pass.

Draft at Blue Claws stadium. Ah where to begin my adventure of the Blue Moon Belgian White Ale, how about the begining. Well it was a warm Friday night in July and I was at a minor league ball game and thought to myself, "hey Dave how bout a beer". I replied to myself, "sure sounds good now lets go see what they have". So I saunter over to the rat trap bar in center field which unabashedly proclaims their allegance to Coors by having enough neon and plastic signage covering every third inch of the building so that the batter at home plate has something to aim for. Well I look at my choices, Coors LIght, Coors Extra Gold, another tap handle of Coors Light and wait what’s this a Belgian White Ale the tap handle proclaims, why yes indeed that will do. So I pluck down my hard earned $5.25 in US currency while Sid, well he looked like a Sid anyway, fills up my lovely 14 oz plastic shaker. I moisten my lips as I am filled with anticipation of the joyous aromas and bountiful flavors which are sure to be found inside my plastic grail of golden nectar. After the hazy orange liquid begins to overflow the glass, which is obviously the way to pour beer since every barkeep at this fine institution pours this way, Sid eventually decides that the glass can hold no more and shuts the tap off. But wait he’s not done yet, oh no not yet. Next comes the magic of the Blue Moon Belgian White Ale because inside every glass is a lovely slice of dried up warm orange. Yes I rejoice as the slice of dead rotting fruit is plopped on top of the quarter inch of foamy head that was allowed to remain. Finally the finsihed product is handed to me and my hand trembles as I pick up my long awaited treat. My heart skips a beat and my lip quivers with anticipation as I raise the mighty plastic cup to my undeserving mouth. I close my eyes inhale deeply and finally take a sip. Meh, sucks.

Bottle and Draught many times.

Foamy head with  slight citrus in the nose.  Its witbeir lite.  The body is thin and the whole package has a boring 15% of the way there feel.  I don’t care who brews it, no need to hate on breweries just because they are big.  This beer is lacking in flavor and stylistic quality...thats the issue.
Bottle and Tap. A decent attempt at a witbier, considering it’s from Coors. Nice spice notes. It isn’t as good as Hoegaarden or other Belgian Whites, but it is enjoyable nonetheless.

An American bastardization of a wonderful Belgian style. Why must the U.S. commercialize and f**k up everything good? Maybe after reading the Declaration of Independence in the New York Times and thinking about the current "President" I’m a bit riled up. None the less, this is a great looking beer that I expect to taste amazing, but winds up tasting like Coors+   If I wanted Coors with orange I’d get a can of Coors for half the price and squeeze an orange slice into it and thicken it up with some corn syrup. Get it together people. THIS IS NOT A GOOD BEER!
Poured cloudy with no head.  Aroma is sweet.  Taste crisp and citrus.  Bland and boring overall.

A nice witbier.  Overall nicely balanced with a nice orange flavor that is emphasized with a citrus hop finish.  I can’t drink a lot of seasonal or highly flavored beers, but this is a nice change of pace.

Bottle poured to glass.  A moderatly well hopped brew that smelt of citrus and a slight yeasty sourdough smell.  Hazy orangish,yellow brew with a creamy white head of 1 fingers width that disipates quickly.  A wonderfully sweet initial flavor with a light acidic,bitter after taste of citrus fruits.  A very well balance beer.  I declinded the orange garnish b/c It is not beer.   $ 3.25 @ The stones throw

Served with a slice of orange? nice touch i guess, but i’m not a fan of booze with "vegetables"... Offish citric yeast smell. Orangey hazy look with a thin white head. Very watery and tasteless. very drinkable, since theres nothing there to dislike, and then theres always the dodgy bit of orange....
can’t believe I haven’t rated this yet.   Not a bad beer for a macro brewery and a decent introduction to the world of beers.
I really found this to an unpleasant beer. When I tried it on tap I had to have orange in it and it was still very unpleasant to me. In a bottle I found it even more unpleasant.

Pours cloudy amber with a thick foamy white head. Lots of visible effervescence. Aroma is semi-sweet maltiness with citrus notes. Flavor is mostly malty, only lightly bitter. Some spice and citrus in there as well. Bubbly, a bit too thin. A refreshing warm-weather brew - nothing terribly special, but very drinkable.

High marks for orange smell and hazy appearance, but the taste and thin watery texture take a lot away. Orange and spice very prevalent. A good summer beer I suppose, but I won’t go out of my way for this.
Draft.  Pours a hazy straw color with fair white head.  Smells clean and tastes very fruity with some spice.  Semi-bitter finish.  Reminds me of Leni’s Sunset Wheat.  Not a big fan of this one.

This is a very good beer for being what I would consider a macro.  It beats the hell out of just about every domestic out there.  The look of it is great, but then again, I’ve always enjoyed the copper unfiltered look with a thick head.  Smell is forgetable.  Taste very sweet of oranges and incredible smooth.  Too weak on the beer taste- a little watery. However, it’s great for those who aren’t beer freaks, or you’re wanting to sip on something not very complex.

The mix between the water and the actual beer isn’t quite right.  It just doesn’t taste very good.  At first it won’t be so bad but the after taste really isn’t appetizing at all.  Kind of a let down.
Light orange with a little haze and a white persistant head.  Very smooth with a little citrus but also kind of light and watered down.  Not bad but not great.

Cloudy murky orange color.  Citrusy flavor with wheat.  Some sweetness and a slight tang.  A bit watered down making it rather thin bodied and less flavorful than it could be.  Smooth with a slight citrus flavor lingering.

Opaque orange color. Mellow, citrusy aroma. Thin off-white head. Fruity and easy to drink. Mild carbonation and decent mouth feel for such a thin-bodied beer. Tangy, orangey, wheaty taste. Maybe some tangerine. If you’re looking for an alternative to boring lagers that isn’t too heavy, this would be a good beer to try. For the craft beer fan, this could have a little more taste and not be so watery. For the average beer drinker, it should be pleasantly surprising.
A watered down beer. Me no liky. I can tast a little hint of fruitiness, but real watery.
On tap at the Hopyard.  Tried with AgentSteve.  Cloudy yellow.  White fine bubble head.  Nice banana and clove aroma.  Almost hefeweizenish.  Easy to drink.  Sweetish.
Exactly what you’d expect from a witbier made by an American macro company. Take a good witbier and add 20% more water.

Bottle.  The best beer Coors makes IMO.  citrus smell, citrus taste, unfiltered pour.  thin off white head.  You have to give blue moon props for being a good solid beer that’s distributed basically everywhere.

A murky orange colored beer, served with an orange wedge.  Probably the best beer from Coors if you’re more into craft.  Decent flavor (obviously citrus/orange) even if it’s a little sweet for my taste.

sweet oat and lemon/orange aroma, hazy yellow/gold, aggressively carbonated, respectable head.  very simple, overly sweet.  plenty of wheat character and the citrus tastes artificial, or concentrate at least.  I really hate blue moon on principle, but this is the best i’ve had of their line so far.  they do get some credit in the end for the unfiltered sediment and yeast on the bottom of the bottle.  the line of what is and isn’t an artistic beer is becoming increasingly blurred, in part to the overconsumption of this beer.  bah.  i guess that means i’ll have to continue drinking the beers to know for sure.

On tap at the Coney.  Pours Hazy, murky orange with white head that retreats to rimming white.  Nose is citrus and spice with wheat malt.  Lots of wheat malt flavor with mild citrus and clove notes, some mild hop crispness at the end.  Standard macro wit, but a great gateway beer into the craft world
I really like Blue Moon.  It has a hefe look and taste.  It can be enjoyed in a bottle or on tap.  Goes great with Guiness (Eclipse).

On tap @ The Hopyard, pours hazy golden with a decent white head that lingers. The nose is cloves and banana. The flavor is the same with a very smooth, drinkable, mellow flavor and finish. This would get more props if it wasn’t brewed by Coors.

(WBA) courtesy of Laurent Mousson - fully cloudy orange in colour, little foam; strong aroma of curaçao and orange peels; sweet with a touch of acidity, thin to medium-bodied; aftertaste of coriander and relatively dry

Has a nice head that stays for quite some time. It does have a hoppy orange taste, but I recommend the orange slice. I see some naysayers on this website don’t recommend the orange, but blue moon was made to have an orange slice.

is this true to style? i do not taste much coriander or oranges... it is a shame that this beer is served with an orange slice at most restaurants near my house..... pours a murky gold color. taste is of wheat, grass, and spices. not much here. disappointed.

For being available just about anywhere, Blue Moon sure is a good beer. Highly refreshing with a smooth citrus flavor. It’s nowhere near the "true" Belgian Whites, but will do in a pinch. Enjoyable year round.
Very smooth, I love its appearance, but don’t fall for putting an orange slice in the beer, it really adds nothing to the experience.

It’s made by Coors, need I say more?I completely agree with v64 on this one. People may think it’s good but that’s only because they have not tried good beer and or other far superior beers of this style. This is a beer for that pretentious guy who lives down the hall and wants to seem classy but has no idea about good beer. That being said it is decent tasting, easy to drink beer.
Would never buy but won’t turn one down

An inferior Belgian white in my opinion. Doesn’t have a strong aroma, but some citrus can be detected. The taste is just bland compared to other Belgian whites. It’s watery and the flavor barely comes through. Not worth it.
great beer to sit back and drink a few, this isn’t one of those sipping beers, it’s light, has a decent aroma to it, white head with an orange peel taste to it, smooth aftertaste
A very drinkable beer.  It has a hint of orange and coriamer in its taste.  It is available year round.
Bottle. Pours a pale yellow body with a thick white head.  Aroma is wheat and citrus fruit, i often add fruit to it.  It works no hops or etoh an easy slugger via coors.
I find this a lot better than it’s counterpart, Rising moon. It’s good, cheap, and everywhere.

One of the better mass produced "refreshing summer" wheat beers.  The orange really helped.  Bright nose with a fairly well balanced flavor to match with orange and light spice, but kind of watery and dull at the finish, makes me grimace and want to take another drink quick.

Puta
Esta mierda es de coors.  Joder por eso esta pura mirda
Caliente, un poco dulce y alcohol
Pours slightly cloudy light gold/orange, with fluffy white head, aroma is orangy and spicy, flavor is balanced with spice, orange peel, and maltyniss, nice beer
wonderful classic "white ale" look when poured.  great overtone of citrus (especially if you’re one to throw an orange slice in on top) goes down very smooth and hearty.

Pours a cloudy orange color.
Smell is heavy on the citrus especially orange with a touch of malt and wheat. Taste is full of malt and orange peel. Mouthfeel was good with heavy carbonation and an overall light feeling. This is a very drinkable beer.
Bottle. Has a nice, fairly sweet taste and good aroma. The best thing I have tasted from Coors.
Smell of orange from a thick, white foam heading an unfiltered, golden body. Flavorful at first,  dying away to a very mild hop finish. Medium bodied. Worth trying, but not overwhelming.
Bottle. Didn’t use orange, isn’t needed, it tastes great without it. Love this wheat beer.

On tap at bar that just carried BMC.  The pint was a yeasty haze pale color with a smallish head.  The aroma was orange and clove.  The flavor was mild, but showed some wheatiness.  The palate held its own.  Meh.

I often buy a 12 pack of this at a local right aid not because its an awsome beer, but because it top’s all the other beers there and every where else locally. Nice spicy notes of orange and coriander. Malts settled at the bottom. Good wheat beer!
Very delightful aroma with lovely murkiness.  Slight flavor of citrus, not as heavy as some wheat beers.  Should be properly seved with a slice of orange, which makes all the difference in the world.

There are now two beers available almost everywhere in the US that do a good job of presenting a tasty alternative to the bland pale lager American macro blahs: Guiness and now, Blue Moon Belgian White.
This alone should warrent some praise for this beer.
pours a cloudy yellow with a light head very light flavour of orange and lemon alright but not the best wheat
From a bottle.  poured golden orange with a white head.  Very good flavor and the orange is not necessary.  Drink ice cold on a hot summer day.
An excellent beer for the money and the availablity is great. I do not understand why most people add an orange when it already has strong hints of orange in the beer.
12oz bottle, this was an ok beer to drink, this is what you get when you put beer and sunkist together

[bottle] Poured a hazy gold with moderate white head. Aroma is orange peel, a hint of cloves, and a little breadiness. Mouthfeel is medium/light. Flavor is pretty sweet and wheaty, orange peel is the dominant feature I thought, and kind of took over the beer in general. Decent but not great.

this has long been my favorite beer to drink.  I enjoy it both with an orange and without.  it looks golden orange and its great to drink.  i buy it in bottles but prefer to drink it from a tall draft glass.
Bottle six pack.  Comparable to Leinenkugels Sunset wheat.  Not a huge fan, but its good to drink.... add a slice of orange
With a lemon this is good for a warm summer’s day, and girls go nuts for it.  All-told, not bad, but there are many many better examples out there of the Belgian Wit style.
On tap. Some interesting qualities about this one. Refreshing and drinkable. I like that this one is available when there is nothing else good on tap.
Tap, bottle, whatever. Watery, bland, lightly corny. Hints of what makes a wit good but not nearly enough of it. Could do with more spice, wheatiness, and more importantly more body.
(Bottle) To be honest I dont feel like writing about a beer that has been written about 1500 other times. To sum it up it is not a bad beer. Better in the summer time. Good macro.

Blue Moon pours yellow orange and hazy.  A thick and creamy smooth head forms which leaves behind some lacing that slowly slides down the sides of the glass. The texture is smooth and a little oily. Its aroma is light with orange and wheat notes. The favor is a nice mix of sweet orange peel, coriander and wheat malts. The finish is wheaty and a little dry. Blue Moon is very refreshing and drinkable. I like to enjoy it with a slice of orange. [orange slice was not used for review]

Blue Moon may go down as the beer that "started it all" for me. While it is in the "Belgian tradition," Blue Moon is made by Coors. And before I actually went to Belgium and knew what that tradition entailed, I thought Blue Moon was the best beer out there. I know better now.

That being said, I think Blue Moon is one of the better beers widely available in the United States. A smooth beer that looks good and tastes great. Nice creamy head, orange tint, citrus flavor - an excellent way to start appreciating beers. But keep in mind: it’s only a start.

12 oz. bottle poured cloudy orange marmalade color with small white frothy head. Aroma of citrus and wheat. Front palate of creamy orange with middle of corriander and cloves and a smooth, mildly earthy finish. Easy to drink, easy to pair with a variety of dishes, especially fish with a fruit salsa or hearty salad in the summer time.

A very nice white ale, with a creamy finish that would keep me coming back.  

I’ve re-sampled this brew several timnes, and each tasting brings increased respect and admiration.  Maybe some are put off by its Coors heritage--I suggest just giving it fair hearing (tasting).

Poured a golden tan with a very foamy head.  Smelled pretty pleasant being slightly fruity.  It tasted like a wheaty/banana-ish hefeweizen and was pretty decent.  It was my first experience with blue moon and although wheat beers aren’t usually my thing, this was pretty enjoyable and drinkable.

is this a Coors product or Molson - or are they now under the same banner?  Either way, it is an attempt to bring Belgian ale into the North American mainstream.  That is a worthwhile effort, and it is nice to even see a witbier when one goes into a 7-11.  However, this is hardly the best.  I agree with the raters who compared it to orangeade, or who said they would rather see Hoegarden on tap than this.  Blue Moon tastes more like a Yankee hefe with spices than a Belgian.  It looks nice, and there is some coriander and orange peel.  My opinion of it has gone down, tho, as it has become available everywhere in the USA.  Come on people, there are better wits.
Blue Moon Belgian White Ale is decent. It is smooth and it has a wheat and orange taste, maybe some lemon

Draught  Orangeish beer with a good, dense white head. Coriandersoup, even not citrussy, spicy. Rather sweet flavour, with nary any sourness, and just tons of coriander. Very slick MF - soupy, as said. Ouch. Even Hoegaarden is a relief, compared to this.

If new to the craft beer world within the last 5 years, its hard to deny this beer probably helped you along in the beginning. Pours a hazey, cloudy orangeish yellow colour with a fairly large head. Aroma is enticing, soft fruit, oranges, cloves and coriander. Taste is wheaty, sweet with a soft creamy texture.
12oz twist-off bottle.  Pours hazy orange, with  white foamy head.  Aroma of  spice and orange zest.  Flavor of wheat, spice, and a dirty sink finish.  Vague attempt of a Belgian Wit.

Had it on tap off 128 in Boston (before the brewery/restaurant closed).  Good experience.  Citrus nose.  Cloudy appearance.  Very bubbly.  Good choice on a sunny 4th of July to bring in the fireworks.

Poured opaque orange with a thin head that quickly dissipated. Fragrance of fruit and wheat. Flat mouth feel, then fizzy, and definite citrus tang with very faint echo of wheat. This concluded with an orangey bitterness and  then little else. Ok, its beer...orange ade beer, still not bad on a summer day, but not much to offer in the way of complexity.

Overall a decent beer.  This one was poured from a bottle and had a decently thick white head for about thirty seconds which then diminished. Cloudy orange in appearance.  Aroma was strong of citrus and flavor was light on hops with a strong orange flavor. Even though it is Americanized, I enjoy this beer in the summer months.  Definitely tastes a lot better from the tap than from the bottle.

Seems like all American attempts at a "Belgian White Ale" are quite similar.  Not that that’s bad, necessarily, but if it’s an "American Belgian White" it’s going to taste like oranges, have a nose of citrus fruit, have a cloudy orange color, and a soda-pop like carbonation.  Yep, that describes Blue Moon!  They really ought to market the stuff under the name "Mikes Hard Orangeade".  Crazy thing is, I kind of like it!  I like Leinenkugels Sunset Wheat too, and might have a hard time telling this stuff from Leinenkugels in a blind test.  Guess I’m not enough of a beer snob.

Dirty blond and tan pour that was somewhat unattractive.  The head was almost two fingers tall and was gone quickly.  Spots of lacing.  The aroma was bad.  Smelled like wheat and spice brewed in dirty dishwater.  Tasted better.dry wheat and mild spice against some thin tart citrus.  The mouthfeel was thin, lots of carbonation.

Poured into a goblet.  Light in color even for the style, with a fizzy white head that recedes without leaving behind any lacing.  Aroma is lemony and wheaty, with maybe a touch of spice.  Pretty average.  Tastes watered down, with the predictable citrus and grain.  Seriously lacking the complexity that makes, say, St. Bernardus Witbier so great.  Mouthfeel is highly carbonated and thin.  High drinkability.

A dirty water/cloudy look to it but seemed to pour an okay head. Easy to detect the citrus, lemon flavor but it was pretty smooth. Pretty refreshing on a 90 degree day (which it was). They served it with an orange slice on the glass though. Why? It’s already got PLENTY of citrus taste to it! My buddy threw the orange in the drink and did regret that, glad I didn’t. I can certainly see this being a "chick beer" which is why I probably won’t have it too often.

Deep golden color......very hazy......almost completely opaque.  Pillowy, white head that fades a little fast.  Very faint citrus aroma.  Spicy notes with hints of clove up front......smooth mouthfeel for a wheat, yet still has a noticeable crispness.  Sweet, very citrusy back, with a slight tart finish.
This beer is good not anything spectacular. But can definitely throw plenty of these down in a night and still feel like a champ.

12 bottle: pours cloudy light brown with decent white head. aroma very bland and malty, flavor somewhat watered down no real taste to pick up on other than malty. not a very good beer its sad to see the belgian name used so carelessly.
Big name, big reputation but pretty blah overall. No real aroma to speak of. Decent wheat flavor.

On tap at the local unnoteworthy bar.  Pours orange with a small white head.  Served with an orange slice, which made it hard to pick out the aroma, but I assume it was nothing special.  Not many specific tastes to pick out--some spices, a hint of wheat.  Easy to drink I suppose.  Not really a good example of a witbier, but better than the pale lagers it’s served alongside of.

Shaker from a bottle.  Poured a hazy orange-yellow color with a nice white head.  It has a very citrus smell and taste.  Overall, I like this beer and it is pretty much my fall back beer when I can’t get anything new to try.

Bottle

Pours a cloudy white with a foamy white head. Aroma of malt, banana, orange, wheat and spices. Has a wheat, sweet taste with spices for the flavor. The sweetness is very artificial and injected and does not seem natural. Still somewhat decent for a Coors product, probably their best.
not much of a head. orangey citrus flavor. textured wheat on my palate. a pleasant surprise! a solid choice.
Little head, cloudy, orange tint - different, fun, light, citrus, orange flavor, good beginner beer.
I love the flavor of this beer - the spicing is unique and the appearance is great for the style.  Hints of orange, coriander and sweet malt.  Good stuff.

i like witbier, especially when it is from Belgium.  So, witbier from coors?  Wow, lets get my low expecations going.  What is this?  Not horrible.  So, was it the fact that this beat my low expectations or is it actually a decent beer?  I’ll give it the benefit of a doubt.  not bad, not bad at all.

Poured a strange light orange color.  Aroma was not very good, it reminded me of cheap beer.  Taste was pretty good, with notes of wheat and orange.  It was a little watered down in my opinion however.  Overall very drinkable.

... I hate to admit it, but this is still one of my moderate favorites.  I have had this many times, on draft and in the bottle, so maybe I have accustomed myself to the taste.  Either way, it has nice citrus notes, that go great in a pitcher with orange wedges.  Cloudy and unfiltered, with a light head, this is one of the best mass produced Wits other than Hoegaarden.

i like the orange-y smell of the beer, and i like the color and appearance of this cloudy drink. but the flavor is a little odd. it tastes like cheap beer infused with orange peels and spices. its a little bitter and painfully unbalanced. on a side note, don’t waste your time with the orange slice they serve with it at the bar, it just reinforces the orange peel flavor and detracts from the beverage as a whole. all i have to say is "meh".

Oh man, I hate this beer!  I love white beers in general, but this one for me is pretty bad.  I taste a high amount of clove, orange, and some other things that I can’t quite place.  Every time that I have had this, I could not get over the awful after taste.  Do yourself a favor - grab a Hoegarden instead to sample a true white beer.
Pours a cloudy amber, with a fizzy white head.  Not much aroma.  Flavor is of the standard Wit variety (citrus), but a bit too sweet for my taste.  Palate is light and fizzy, leaving me a bit gassy.

I had some at my family Easter dinner, with a wedge of orange.  It was pretty good stuff.  I had a second, then a third, and my wife had to drive home.  I usually dring Ayinger or Weihenstephaner, but this stuff will do nicely.  May pick up a 12 pack just to have around.

I don’t understand why people hate on Blue Moon.  It’s a darn good beer if you consider that it’s mass-produced and available pretty much anywhere.  I like it on tap more, but for this review I bought myself a 12-pack of bottles.  Nice poor, not too much head.  Aroma consists of orange and other citrus.  Very nice taste to it, and has a relatively clean finish.  I can definitely put quite a few of these back with no problem.
Pours a hazy golden color, Aroma is citrus and wheat. Flavor is wheat and orange. I don’t understand while people like this. My mom loves this shit but she hates every other beer I give her to try.
Bottle/tap.  Pours a hazy orange with a white head.  Aroma is fruity - more orange than anything.  Taste is light and fruity.  A good beer when selection is limited.
On tap : Cloudy pour with a finger of white foamy head.  Citrus, wheat, and orange peel nose.  Taste is much the same, with a nice clean feel.  Some carbonation.  Nice finish.  A good macro.
This beer is the one to reach for when you are looking at a bunch of macro brewed crap.  It is cloudy and has a nice aroma of citrus and spices.

Pours a cloudy golden color.  What little head there is dissipates quickly.  Very citrusy aroma.  Nice balance of yeast and citrus in the flavor.  Slightly more acidic than most beers of this style, but not overpowering.  I’ve had better, but certainly not bad for a Coors product.
This is my favorite everyday beer.  It is refreshing with subtle hints of orange and coriander, however, neither of those flavors are too spicy, cloying, or intense.
Pours a very cloudy yellow. Faint citrus aroma.  Flavor is wheat, citrus, maybe a touch of coriander.  All citrus in the follow through, a touch astringent. It’s solid but nothing special.

this is a nice witbier. had it many times but this is the first time since creating my ratebeer account. very drinkable with a nice mouthfeel, positive lingering sensation. flavor is unique compared to other belgian whites, more of a spiced complexion. tasty, not even close to others in the category like hacker pschorr or hoegaarden, but nonetheless a good one to put down. very solid considering its availability.

Pours a nice, hazy amber, as a wheat beer should. Nice white fluffy head. Crisp, citrusy aroma. Taste has a nice balance of citrus and hop with a clean finish. Subtle lacing of the glass as it goes on. A great, every-day beer.

Pours an opaque honey golden with some white head that does not last. Aroma is not strong, but has a good citrus component, and is typical of a witbier. Flavor is mainly wheaty and has orangy hints. This is a typical "white" beer, refreshing and smooth.

Had on tap at Rookies bar.  I’ve had this beer a few times in the past and I could never quite remember if I liked it or not.  Now I see why, it’s nothing more than average.  The glass I had came without the head and was of the cloudy yellow variety.  I could taste some orange in there, perhaps that’s because they put one in my glass.  Kind of an astringent finish.  Like I said, nothing special here, just a beer.
very nice wheat beer with a slight hint of orange. definitely one of the better beers i have tried. will drink again

I must admit, I didn’t care for this beer the first time I had it.  I sampled it again the other day and it didn’t taste anything like I remembered! I very cirtus and wheaty flavor is very easy to drink.  Was garnished with an orange.  This wouldn’t be a session beer for me, but I would have one again.

This was my "Green eggs and ham." I didn’t want to try it, didn’t want to try it, but then I did reluctantly did tryi t and guess what sam I am?..I do like it, I do like Blue moon belgian white.  12 ounce bottle from Glenville beverage. dirty yellow, nice head that sticks around for a little bit. Wheat, hops, and fruity. What’s not to like? It’s not my everyday beer, but if it’s offered, Ill take one gladly!

12oz bottle.   Murky light amber/orange with a white head that leaves a layer of foam.   Sweaty, yeasy aroma with a little orange.   Spicey, tangy flavor.   Not bitter, and not too sweet.   Crisp I guess.   Light, but the yeast adds some body; too much carbonation, but that would add to the refreshment.  This seems like one of the  most popular beers around, and I can see how the flavors appeal to a wide swath of less experienced drinkers, but the orange flavor gets a little much in the end, and the sweaty aroma could be toned down a bit.
Goes great with a variety of foods. After three beers, the orange taste is a little too much. The first beer is wonderful.

On tap at Old Chicago. Pours a very cloudy bright orange with a thin lasting white head, usually served too cold which hurts the head I think. Aroma is orangey, even if they dont throw the orange in there, with some light wheat malts, citrus, light lemon and some coriander. Flavor is aslo very citrusy with lots of orange zest, sweet, wheaty and has a slight herbal and hoppy bitterness in the end. Finishes with a wierd slick zestiness to it, but still easy to drink and sometimes can be refreshing. Probably not the most authentic in its style, but a great beer to turn people on to craft beer. It actually has a good amount of flavor to it, so its way better than any other BMC product.
For a less expensive, readily available brew, it’ll do just fine.  Enjoyed this brew with steamed clams with garlic and butter, a match very close to perfection.
Creamy white Ale. Pretty much what I expected. Well balanced, but nothing really that interesting about it. Enjoyable overall.
This beer has become very popular, great underneath guiness as a darkside of the moon, a nice citrus wheat, i thinks its better in bottle than draft

Best drink available at the Olive Garden last night - ugh.  Decent looking but a little too watery and thin.  Nice wheat malt backbone that is very smooth and dominates the finish but is spoiled by a funky orange citrus presence that most likely came along with the 1/4 Sunkist Orange that came floating in the glass.
a very tasteful  wheat beer with just the right amount of citrus taste. A great summer beer, but good anytime. I feel the tap beer is much better then the bottle.

This beer is made for ladies due to the fact, if you have to add fruit to beer then you should drink a wine cooler. Overall a fairly decent beer but would not go out of way to have another. Tastes like Leines sunset wheat but slightly better.
Nice citrus aroma, but flavor is very muted. Nice white head when poured. Adding an orange really improves this beer.

aroma of wheat and citrus. small white head and a little carbonation. flavor is a bit weak for me and a little bitter. had this on tap and I thought maybe the tap was flat. It does have an easy palate and that’s always a good thing. Not my favorite wheat but it’s not shite either.
(USA) Light Amber color with sm-White Head. Has a Citrus Aroma and light Crisp taste. Not bad!!!

~Pours a cloudy light orange colour with a thick creamy head.
~ Fruity, spicy scent. Coriander perhaps? Smells like Honey Nut Cherrios
~ Orange, sugary taste almost like an orange cream pop. Nice Wheat flavor. Like Honey Nut Cherrios :)
~Smooth and creamy palate that almost sticks inside your mouth. No afterbite from hops.
~I like this beer. Much better than Hoegaarden. It’s not my favorite
style to drink, but I will probably end up purchasing this again. Good dessert beer.

Blue Moon Belgian White Ale very nice for a big beer company.  Aroma is present.  Appearance is that hazy expected hay color.  Flavor is supra smooth.  Palate is super mild.  Beautiful, but not Hoegaarden.

Blue Moon is my beer of choice. It is the the perfect beer for almost all occasions. If you get this beer get it with a slice or orange in the bottle, but nothing beats it on tap with a freshly cut orange slice in it.
Bottle. Hazy yellow/orange color, white head. Spicy, malty wheat aroma with fruity notes. Malty wheat flavor, some spices. Decent beer.

It is an absolute triumph for beer fans that this brew has become commonplace and popular. Are there better beers out there? Absolutely. Are most of those beers hard to find in broad distribution? Quite so. Pour is very typical of the style, cloudy with a modest head. The aroma comes across as a pilsener, but the flavor is distinctly that of a wheat ale. Sweet and drinkable with coriander and orange zest prominent in the finish. There is almost nothing to dislike about this beer, and it’s excellent with food.
Tan and cloudy; smells sweet and wheat.  Tastes nice, crisp, refreshing, sweet on finish.  Nice white ale essence.

Light, stark and bitter nose.  Yellow/golden murky presentation typical of the style.  The first taste is hoppy, bitter, and rather unenjoyable.  It is light and crisp on the tongue with an after taste that leaves a medium mouthfeel.  Probably better with food than alone.  I would say it is representative of the style, unfortunately the style does not suit my palate.
Pours a cloudy yellow with tiny white head. Smells of citrus and wheat. tastes like orange, coriander, and citrus. Not a bad wheat ale, however, I do not like additives in beer very much at all.
Pours murky tan. Cloudy. The head is sticky and creamy. Creamy mouthfeel, crisp finish. Good beer...had it without the orange, and that might’ve been for the best.
best of the white ales that i’ve had, out of the tap has almost no head, maybe because of the orange slice the stick to the top of the glass. hazy dark golden color.
I prefer sans orange slice.  Nice light and fruity brew... able to have a few without the sweet flavoring become too intense.
In a beer desert like Mississippi, this is a welcome sight in any bar. A decent true to style wit. A bit light in body and overly fizzy, but enjoyable.
The beer that got me into beer.  I like the orange flavor and aromas.   Orange slice inside is a nice addition.  Great for football game watching.

Tasted 2/17/08.  12oz bottle.  Unfiltered and hazy with a golden orange hue.  Finger width of dense white head.  Grainy citrus perfumy aromas with an orange zest note.  Light bodied and crisp.  Citrusy.  Off-dry finish.  Crisp effervescence.  Orange with a slight peppery flavor.  Moderate.
Excellent beer, although I prefer not to drink it with an orange.  Good flavor and texture.

Light orange color with a good smell. What I like to do with this is to pour into in a pilsner glass and then put 2-3 slices of orange on the top. Let those orange slices "soak" the beer as you drink and when finishing the last drop, eat the oranges. They’re just awesome! Good all around drink to have. Haven’t met anyone that doesn’t appreciate this brew.

Not a wheat beer (ale) fan, however this was not bad.  Had this both on tap and in bottles.  A light citrus gold pour, hazy with a small white head.  Very unassuming mild Belgian White.  Glad there is an orange because it needs some body although have drank this without.  Very appealing, my wife’s favorite and the lady’s seem to like it a lot!
Nice nutty aroma.  Pours cloud with a head that leaves quickly  Nice start and good finish.  Crisp belgian, refreshing.

Bottle.  Nice hazy golden pour with little lacing.  Love the fact that this has become a staple in many bars, at least there is something better than the domestics.  Excellent citrus aroma backed up with a nice taste.

Tasted damn good but after about the 5th one it gets old. Excellent citrus aroma and poured a nice golden color. The beer was pretty sweet but not overpowering and the texture was slick and went down easy. Overall one of my favorite beers!!
Nice white beer...  Great aroma, good orangy flavor.  I’ll be honest, I am not a fan of fruity beers but this one isn’t bad.  I can’t drink this every day but my wife loves it.

Hazy dark golden in color with a nice white lacy head.  Delicate wheat aroma drifts into your nose.  Taste is of wheat with a slightly fruity notes.  Probably the best beer I have ever had from Coors.
I used to love the blue moon alot more then I started tasting real belgium whites.  Best in tap, very cold with a slice of orange
this beer is good on occasion.  best served with an orange slice. also best served on tap
So-so on this one. The look of the beer in it’s glass is more appealing than the actual taste. Leagues above similar priced beer such as Heiniken or Beck’s.

On tap served with an orange slice.  All I could really smell was the orange, even after removing it from the glass.  The orange smell was pleasant, and complimented the beer, but I would have liked to been able to enjoy the beer without it.  The beer was ok...not the best.
12 ounce bottle. Had it at Longhorn Pembroke Pines, FL Labeled brewed by BMBC Toronto, Canada Available for $1.29 at Total Wine.
A great color is about as far as i’ll go with the positives. While its not a bad beer, especially with a slice of orange, its not one of my favorites. Not horrible though.

This is truly one of my stand-bys.  I love the fruity / spicy aroma.  It has that great cloudy light gold appearance with a great white head that sticks around for awhile.  It has great body and a very spicy finish.  A great beer especially on a warm day.
Nice smooth taste,  great with a orange slice very affordable above average beer

Bills itself as a craft beer but its produced by Molson-Coors.  Despite this it has a nice smooth taste with a hint of citrus.  Cloudy-gold appearance with white head after the pour.  Not a fan of fruit in my beer but its actually quite refreshing with a slice of orange.  Well worth a try to any wheat beer drinker and a good one to introduce to your ’mainstream’ beer drinking friends.

Blue Moon Belgian White Ale is a good beer. Nice aroma and better than average flavor make this a good option in any occasion. 

My favorite part about Blue Moon is the mass availability in all types of bars as well as the affordable cost. 

The only negative I can think of is that it is brewed by Coors!

Bottle. Pours hazy golden with some suspended particles and dense, moderate white head. Aroma of grainy wheat and light doughy yeast. Flavor is textured grains, some raw nearly-adjunct grain flavors distract a bit, mild orange peel, citrus, vanilla and very subtle bitterness. Creamy, lively mouthfeel with a moderately full consistency.
Not a bad beer coming from Coors. I like the hint of orange. Goes great with an orange slice, much like a Corona and lime. Refreshing and not to heavy. Good beer overall.

not the best beer in the world but really not that bad if you compare it weak american force feed crap beer , first time i had was at pizza pub it came with an quartered wedge of orange was quit refreshing

a guy in the elevator at my hotel gave me this...I haven’t had it in a long time and was never overly interested in having it again....brownish yellow lemonade color with a white head...slightly funky sour aroma...medium mouthfeel with noticeable carbonation...light sweet taste with a hint of malt liquer...overall refreshing

Blue Moon is actually a good beer...very good in fact when you consider that it’s brewed by Coors.  Citrus-y flavor with little bitterness.  Great with dinner or on a hot day.  This is the one I recommend to less experienced beer drinkers, and also a good choice for more mature ones as well.  This is the one...the American macro that is actually a high quality brew!
one of my favorite beers. thick orange/golden colored with a creamy white head. has a very distinct, sweet aftertaste. good with an orange slice and good beer to drink anytime

Pours a hazy light golden, almost orange color, with slowly disappearing, thin, creamy, white head. Flavor is wheat with citrus, orange and coriander. Light to medium body and medium carbonation. A go-to at venues offering nothing but macros.

I was expecting some nasty off flavors and really thin body, but what i got wasn’t that bad at all.  Really ugly, but the flavor had some spice and citrus in there and a pleasant sweetness.  Nothing exciting but I would definitely take it over amber bock, negra modelo, newcastle, and its other macro peers.

(Draft) Cloudy orangish body with no head (gotta serve that sucker ice cold and right to the top!), served with an orange slice. Light citrusy aroma (orange, lemon). Mouthfeel smoothish, kind of light. Flavor is citrusy and that’s about it. Not bad but lacked any yeasty freshness that I’d expect from a draft wheat. Waitress said this was a hefeweizen - well not quite but still not too bad of a summer lawnmower beer.
cloudy golden orange in appearance.  light, pleasant fruit tones highlight this popular beer that is easy drinking and quite refreshing.

I didn’t know there was a Coors, Belgium? Unclear orange beer with creamy white noisy head. Quite a considerable amount of sediment! Aroma of wheat, oranges/fruit and....soap! Flavor is sweet and wheat y with notes of orange peel. Rather short wheat y finish...better with an orange slice, but drinkable.

Used to really dislike this beer...has grown on me a little but still not something I go out of my way to purchase.  

really best on tap...continues to grow on me
this is a beer I like it has a hint of orange and is an unfiltered beer so do not get upset if you see floaters when you pour it into a glass

Poured orange and very cloudy with an unexpected thick head. Lacing was decent throughout.
Definite orange aroma and other spices, both of which came through in the taste as well.
Light carbonation, a smooth beer going down, and left a very pleasant aftertaste.
Not my favorite style of beer, but I enjoyed this one with a very spicy meal.
Nothing too special but a cut above many beers and other the best beer available in a given location.  Not worth purchasing otherwise though

Orange, cloudy color. Aroma is of spices, citrus, and wheat. Flavor is malty- like a wheat beer, a bit sweet balanced by some acidity.  Also has an orange flavor with some spiciness. Fairly dry at the finish. No strong flavors and very drinkable.

A cloudy light orange colored white wheat ale with oats and some added favors. Poured cloudy with about one-half inch of white head. A suprisingly mild tasting beer with no bad traits. I like a little more flavor in my brew. Haven’t tried the orange peel thing yet. Surprised it is 5.4% abv. can’t taste it. The bottle says it is brewed in Toronto Canada and imported by Coors.  A good almost a craft beer. Not a bad choice from the convenience store. Paid $6.99 US for the six pack.
Cloudy gold color. The orange garnish totally threw of the nose of this beer, but it had mild aroma of citrus and malts. Watery mild citrus flavor, very smooth, but very boring.
Beer has a nice color, and smooth taste.  Not overly commplicated but has nice citris flavor. Goes well with food.  Good from the bottle but even better from the tap.  Nice every day beer.

Surprisingly tasty white beer. Somewhat one dimensional but pleasing. I wouldn’t choose it at a store with a decent selection but it’s definitely the best six-pack on offer at my local gas station. Will buy again.

This beer is a must. i just recently tasted it on tap for the first time at The Sandbar in Athens Ga, i’ve always been a huge fan of it out of the bottle, so you can imagine my delight when sampling out of the tap. It has a very thick head and a some what cloudy appearance like most white beers. Very nice citrus taste. I definetly suggest putting a slice of orange in it. Great beer
A smooth citrus flavor that is enjoyable with food but also just when hanging out. Probably my go to midrange, macro beer along with bass when at a bar. Orange slice is a nice touch.
Good beer, never tried it off the tap. Suprisingly high level of carbonation with a faint citrus aroma. Finishes very clean and sweet.

Bottle.  Served in pint glass- M&D condo.  Sweet citrus smell- slight hint of Froot Loops.  Cloudy, yellow / light orange color, with some yeast still floating around in the glass.  High level of carbonation.  Orange, very sweet up-front, some bitterness at the end to balance.  Not terribly complex- waited for another layer of flavor to appear, but to no avail.  Overall not a bad beer.
Bland, flavorless, soulless...there are much better Witbiers out there, Moylans coming to the top of the list. Only drink this if you have to.

Got this on tap at my sister’s wedding rehearsal dinner. Served with an orange slice. It was a very dark orange color with a nice frothy white head. The aroma consisted of a strong smell of citrus and wheat. The taste was extremely fruity and full of citrus hints. I was surprised as to how flavorful this beer was. Decent lacing on the glass. Overall, an enjoyable beer.
This is one my personal favorites.  Not one though you want to drink too much of.  Great flavorful beer. Great with food.
A pleasant citrus flavor combined with belgium wheat aroma makes for a refreshing  and satisfying beer.
I hadn’t realized this was a macro brew.  A good wit-beer with a very slight citrus aroma and sweet flavour.
