Bottle:Poured a white yellow with a white head. The aroma is citrus and wheat. The taste is a nice soft citrus not to overwhelming and wheat.
The best thing Coors ever made... If you order it at a bar be prepared to get a slice of orange...

I was meeting a non-beer Afciando friend at an Olive Garden and was not expecting to have a beer, he recommended this to me, so I had to try considering the source.  They gave it to me with an Orange Slice.  Was not a bad sessionable wheat, a little funky twist with an orange, I can see why some people may gravitate to this, nothing else to choose from, or it is a fun change up from the other availabel macros.
what to say about this classic macro does belgian whithing? its fine... kept me up in between the lull of the end of my beers and my new years beer.

Flowery, hoppy aroma.  Cloudy golden color,  a little murkier than I was expecting.  Decent head that lingered for awhile. Light-bodied, with wheat, citrus, and hops flavor.  Ample carbonation.  I enjoy this beer with an orange wedge in it, preferably draft.

Bottle sans glass at restaurant to go unnamed...Didn’t expect much.  Floral aroma.  Sweet, w/obvious orange flavoring.  Slightly soapy finish (is this the hops? perhaps...), but drinkable.  Smooth & unsurprising.
Candy sweetish with coriander up front.  Too much fruit flavour going on-and that’s without the orange wedge.  For the style though...not so bad.

12 oz bottle poured into tumbler- poured cloudy and murky golden color, an above average white head formed and stayed.  Complex aroma of yeast, light (still green) wheat, and oranges.  Hits the mouth with a well defined light to medium body, alot of wheat notes that have not been killed off are noticeable throughout, finish is smooth.  While the almighty beer-pagners like to trash the brewery of this one and the beer itself, this beer is not bad at all; it fits the style, and even better from being on draft from my "memory".
Quite good but sometimes a little incipit. It has some orange hints and nice spciy features.

fizzy, all carbonation. taste like nothing. got stuck drinking this at a christmas party after an afternoon of drinking Stoudts DIPA at home. so not a good idea. its like eating a can of spam after a night at Mortons.
A sweetish, heavily carbonated, wheat ale. Wheat, grass, and coriander on the nose, with strong wheat and coriander flavor. Kind of like candy, very drinkable, with wide appeal.

On tap at the FIreside in Ambler, PA (And 100 other places in the area).  This has become a popular beer, I imagine because of the "make an utterly non-offensive beer and everyone with love it"  tradition of the big breweries.  To me, this barely qualifies as a beer; it’s so over-the-top fruity, sweet, and completely imbalanced; I challenge you to comment on the hop character - there isn’t any.  Pours a soft yellow, like a weak pilsener.  Aroma is ridiculously citrusy, like someone dunked an orange in there before serving.  Extremely sweet, fruity taste.  Hard to imagine it’s 5.4%.
One of Coors’ best beers (doesn’t say much).  Poured a soapy yellow, white body with a frothy white head.  Nose of mild spices and tang.  Not too bad.  Not too great.

This beer is a sweet and smooth Belgian ale with a great aroma. Many people say that this beer is often served with an orange slice, but personally I believe that this beer is amazing just the way it is. The only drawback is the price.
popular beer where i live.  Bottle and draft are both good.  Usually served with orange.  Adds a nice tang to it.
From bottle and tap, pours dark orange and usually served with orange slice. Has very sweet aroma and sweet taste with a presence of wheat. Overall pretty good.
From a bottle .  Pours hazy and orange with small white head.  Smell is citrusy and sweet.  Taste is more citrus and some wheat.  Decent brew.
I think its a pretty good beer, I just have this thing about beers that need fruit to make it right.  Blue moon is only good with an orange in it, thats what kills it.

Bottle.  Poured to a dark cloudy golden color with a fluffy white head that disappeared.  Very little fizz medium body with a light sryupy consistency.  Slight wheat and barely aroma, with a hint of oats.  Quick begining with little flavor, middle taste was full of flavor (wheat, fruits, cider), the end was quick with the after taste lingering.  The aftertaste was sweet, but not too bad.  Clean & crisp flavors.  Overall not a bad beer.
Great beer, have had it on tap. It tastes great with a garnish of orange. Great beer.

I really did not care for this. I heard some good things at first. Has some spice to it but appeared to have flavors that shouldn’t go together. Too citrusy for my taste. had a nice crisp feel though.

16 oz draught at The Airliner (Iowa City, IA). Poured into a conical pint. Poured a darker hazy gold-ish color. Smell is coriander and some wheat. Taste is orange and wheat, but dominated mostly by coriander. Thicker and heavier than I would have liked my Wit. An ok Wit by an American Macrobrewer that is an admirable attempt to bring something different to the mass market they serve, although not well balanced taste wise and a little heavy for my liking.

I had this on tap and was shocked to find that Coors makes something this good.  It is a very nice, pleasant, refreshing, crisp, yet tasty beer.  It is cloudy gold with a decent white head that soon diminishes to s foamy ring.  The aroma is citrus and lightly toasted grain.  The taste is similar, with a mixed grain-citrus (esp.orange) character that has some sweetness balanced by a nice citrusy bite and tartness, making it tasty yet crisp.  It has a pleasant toasted grain aftertaste and is very enjoyable.

Bottle:  Poured a dirty water look.  Cloudy with sediment floating and slowly sinking.  Even the head was a dirty white.  Not exactly what I was looking for with an ale.  First taste is that they just took a mass quanity beer like coors or bud mixed the 2 and added some sediment for show?  

Any time you have to add something to a beer (orange, lemon) takes away from the supposed taste.
Actually a nice american version of a belgian white, made by Coors no less. Great beer to have on hand for female company, chicks dig it.

Bottlle.  Poured a pale blonde with lots of sediment and a thick head.  Smells very sweet and citrusy--mainly peach, apricot, and corriander.  Taste is slightly dry citrus of mediocre sweetness.  Orange, apricot, and sweet tea.  Finish is a dull sweet tea flavor.  Amazing that this is made by Coors.
bottle.  poured a hazy semi dark golden color with a creamy white head. had a malty aroma. smooth piny taste with a finish of lemon. overall i would recommend this beer.

I love unfiltered beer. This is no exception. Great flavor and aroma. However it does have a bit of a metallic taste. They sell this down the street of my house so this is a beer that I do partake often.

Good beer. nice full flavor. However, I highly reccomend serving it with an orange slice garnish. Without the orange the beer is not as good, but with the orange it is phenominal. Nice good ale. I reccomend it.
While slumming for beer, this is a nonchalant brew, which will neither turn you on or off to its style.  While it has no stand out features, it also has no terrible ones.

On tap.  Poured a hazy dark golden color.  I didn’t get anything from the aroma on this one, which is odd.  The flavor seemed to be dominated by light lemon.  There wasn’t a whole lot else going on.  This was OK, but nothing I’d probably order again.
Citrusy overtones.  Fruity texture.  A great body, I was delightfully surprised.  Will definitely be buying more of these and others from this company soon.
This was one of my ’introduction to good beer’ beers. I had a bottle recently again, and it is undrinkable. Not at all to style. Thin and watery, no tartness at all. Just awful.

pours a golden amber with a creamy white head.  aroma is malt, light fruit, touch of pine.  taste is smooth, a little sweet, light fruit, light malt.  a nice beer if there’s nothing else on tap.  try it with an orange slice in it, it adds an interesting zing.
I had this beer at a restaurant in New Jersey, and I found it light, fruity, and refreshing. A big creamy head, it tasted like citrus fruit. highly recommended if you like Wheat Ales.
I first had his beer in lovely downtown Novato. it comes with an orange slice which actually makes it interesting. smooth and creamy like your typical Belgian creamy ale. it’s a good girly brew...
I like this beer a lot, and I can usually get it anywhere I go. When there isn’t much of a selection, Blue Moon is an easy choice.

I am trying to think of the first Blue Moon I ever had and the tap I had at the DIA Bennigan’s in Denver, CO because those two were by far the best.  When this beer is good, yes it actually tastes faintly of blueberries.  Like Sunshine wheat... but with blueberries.  Man it can be good.
great beer for being everywhere.   clean drinking with no serious aftertaste throw an orange in there and pretend your important.
Pale, cloudy with big head,yeasty aroma.  heavy carbonation, crisp,  dancing on the tongue. Spicy flavor with bitter background of organge peel.
For a wheat-beer, excellent brew.  Very drinkable and great with seafood.  I will buy this one again.
This is one of the best beers from a macro.  Incredibly fruity.  Refreshing..too bad it is made by Coors.
Poured a cloudy yellow color. Fruity taste with a touch of spice. The orange added makes it even better. Easy to drink, one of your better macros.

No orange slice, thankfully.  Hazy glowing golden color with a medium, thick head.  Lightly spicey, sweet malts, citrus fruits.  Flavor is sweet malts, orange and citrus fruit, and a touch of spice.  Smooth body.  Nothing special, but it is refreshing and readily available.  I would drink this all night over the normal macros.

draft, with slice of orange.  more grainy than citrus, which is what i was looking forward to.  couldn’t get enough juice out of that orange and into the beer to level it out.  crisp finish, but slightly awkward taste.  could be just a bad keg.
loved it reminded a lot of a hefeweizen.. nice body and very refreshing beer with a nice crisp finish
Very nice beer to drink during summer evenings and very refreshing after a day of work.

Cloudy orangish-yellow, with small head. Sweet, fruity aroma, lots of citrus. Flavor is medium bodied wheat,, citrus, and smooth. Mouthfeel is medium smooth and medium carbonated at the same time. Like drinking a hefeweizen in the winter. Great with a big fat orange slice squeezed in. Why? Because they said so.

It’s really tasty when served ice cold.  The citrusy taste is really refreshing, but doesn’t mix well when eating with certain foods.  The color is nice and hazy, and smells amazing.  Great beer...but kinda pricy.  Or Randall Road House rips me off with its high prices.

12 oz bottle.  Pours a hazy orange color with a tall white head.  Citrus in the nose.  Lemon and oranges with a little grain.  Similar flavors that become more and more grainy.  The spices and the grain and then this tangy off flavor comes out.  It just becomes bad quick.  But hey my step mom’s favorite.
Tap in NY, USA. Pale yellow hefeish looks, dense head. Fruity nose and flavor. Some apple and banana, maybe orange. Quite horrible, doesn’t taste much like beer. Sweet and fruit it is tho.

Pours a milky pale golden. Aroma is light and slightly sweet. Served with a slice of orange, which adds another layer of flavor. Compliments the wheaty undertones very well. First sip is smooth and creamy. It has a moderate citrus flavor, completely un-bitter. Not bad.

Not a bad beer if you are in the mood for something a little sweet and light.  Nice head with foggy color, sweet smell, and a nice taste.  Not the smoothest finish, but again, this is not a beer that will enter the hall of fame.  Nice and simple but pretty tasty overall.
The first Belgain white I ever had. Definately a heck of a lot better with an orange slice in it. Not bad for a mass produced beer. A good wheat ale, just nothing special.
It has ok flavor. That lingers on the palate. I want my beer to taste like a beer should not fruity. If I wanted fruity I would get a wine cooler.

This is the worst of a company known for abominations.  The orange and coriander combine to form an almost tomato soup like taste.  The only saving grace is you can eat the orange slice it’s served with.
Had this beer both on tap and from the bottle. Nice, unfiltered orange. Smells (mostly) and tastes (slightly) of orange. I recommend with summer foods, not a beer to be drank alone.
Pours a deep orange with a creamy head.  Very citrusy/fruity aroma and flavor.  Smooth finish.  I am impressed that this beer is made by Coors.
12 oz.  bottle.  Pours a hazy, orange color with a small white head.  Aroma of lemon and orange.  Thin citrus mouthfeel with a very floral finish.
very good beer, i love the taste. a little weird smelling to me but it’s still good
Someone suggested to me that it tasted like perfume and I couldn’t get that out of my mind.  Watery, unbalanced.  Perfumy.  Could use some malt to balance.

Cloudy orange color with quickly vanishing head. Aroma and taste are  fruity and sweet. I’ll also admit that I didn’t thinkI’d like it as much as I did, given the Coors tie-ins, but this is a solid summer beer.  Unspectacular, but enjoyable.

This ale pours cloudy orange in color, with a small with head. Light citrus aroma with lemon, orange, honey and spice flavor. This is a good white ale that has been a nice summer beer for me. This is proof that large breweries can make a quality product.

Pretty darn good for something out of Coors, I think alot of people actually think this is European.  Not my favorite style by any means but this is par for the course.  More of a lemon smell and taste, gotta be in the mood for this one.  I do like the appearance of both the beer and the botttle it comes in.

Very good beer, coriander and orange peel serve as an excellent spice base for this unfiltered beverage.  Great as a dinner drink.  It is truly a remarkable white ale. I love the Amber-Orange color as well (Nice Presentation)
On tap at Bradley Airport (Hartfort, CT.) Yellow-orange colour. Citrusy nose. Butterscotch and citrus taste. Prickly mouthfeel. limey. Okay, especially for MolsonCoors.
Light aroma, really nice taste. Typical of the regular Belgian Whites, but overall just a great beer for a reasonable price.
Nice beer.  Pours a cloudy orangish color.  Very similar to any other belgian white.  Nice for the price.

12 oz bottle, gift from the fridge.  Hazy orange color with large white long lasting head.  Aroma of sweet malt, orange and lemon.  Flavor is very grainy, medium sweet and medium light fruit.  Medium body with some stinging carb and light chalkiness.  Has a lot of good qualities but that corniness really comes out as it warms up and it turns from a nice belgian style witte to an American style macro.
One of the better Macro Beers available at many Bars around the country. Has a Sweet Lemony taste and smmoth texture. One of my favs for a night out.

Decent brew. Made by Coors so ingredients can be a concern.  Not great, not bad. Drinkable.UPDATE: Had no other choice but to drink this beer tonight, really not a bad brew. To much citrus but a much better pick then the BMC that it’s right next too. Not a good example of a Wit but a decent brew to drink when there’s a limited choice.
Light yellow with heavy cloudyness.  Lemony and dry.  A lot of yeast flavor in the beer. Ok not great.
The scent is of lemon and honey, and the flavor very light with slight hints of lemon.  Very smooth, but way too light for me.  It just needs something.
Coors light with wheat instead of brewer’s rice.....if that doesn’t say it all I don’t know what does.
Not a fan of this one.  It pours good with a nice head, good aroma.  Not a fan of the flavour.
Good summber ale. Orange lemom citrus flavors noticealbe. Light body, easy going down. Cloudy color. Not to bad.
this beer is not my type of beer but the flavor is fantastic although it looks like the beer was made of oat meal it still tast like a good football beer

I am not a witbier fan at all but this hit the spot sitting on the patio waiting for my food.  No fan of the fruity aroma, cloudy appearance or most aspects of the flavor but was pleasantly surprised.

Not really my kind of beer in general, though I do like this one. Its not one of the best beers out there, but it is drinkable and has some flavor. The Harvest Moon seasonal made by Blue Moon is quite good though.

I like the texture and mouthfeel of this a lot more than the taste. Refreshing, yes. However, there are much better Belgian whites. But not bad for a macro-brew. (Of course, had I known that, I probably wouldn’t have tried it at all.)
Considering that this is brewed by a macro in coors its not bad but still lacks in flavor

Bottle.  It’s taken a long while for me to get around to rating this, probably owing to its ubiquity – it’d always be there.  Grainy nose with a touch of malt and jarring, non-meshing coriander.  Dirty, cloudy golden with a huge hunk of yeast (really, guys, too much here) and a soapy lacing off-white head.  Initial impressions are of an unclean failure.  Very crisp, lightish-medium body, taste is bready malt with a strong grain presence and swift flashes of orange peel.  Malt profile really isn’t as bad as I was expecting, and the end result is generally enjoyable.  Coriander backs off noticeably in the midbody and toward the end (to the benefit of everyone involved), though my teeth do still feel a bit rattled.  As far as wits go, this is somewhat sloppy, but for something coming from the vaults of Coors, it’s quite impressive.
[2007.09.26: 2.7]

Re-rate, fresh screw-top bottle. Have had these over the years when nothing better was available and have come to appreciate that.  Blue Moon seems to have enough independence from Coors for my liking, and the product itself, the most important part, is more than acceptable.  Not coriander soup, and getting nice little bits of bready yeast bloom here and there.  [2014.12.03: 2.9]

On draft.  Pours cloudy yellow with white head.  Crisp, decent, refreshing, a hint of that Belgian sweetness, but not much.  Refreshing.  Beats Shiner Bock and most other macro brew options.  Quite surprised that this is a Coors.

On tap and served in a tall weizen glass.  This beer poured a slightly hazy golden/orange color with a small, off-white head that quickly disappeared.  Some very light lacing was left around the glass.  The aroma of the beer was made up of light citrus notes and some mildly sweet wheat malt.  The flavor was very mild with sublte wheat notes and a touch of light citrus.  The mouthfeel was light-bodied with a healthy dose of carbonation.  A decent beer to fall back on if nothing good is available.
A great summer beer with an orange.  A nice spin on a Belgian White.  Very drinkable especially on a nice sunny day.  Nice milky light yellow color and aroma.
Pours a deep gold with a thick head. The taste has a citrus flavor and a distinct wheat after taste. I prefer it over Magic Hat’s Hocuc Pocus.
Wasn’t thrilled with this beer. Pours a hazy gold with medium head. Yeasty/bread-like. Nothing special, although not bad at all.
Smell is heavy yeast, breadlike. Pours a hazy deep straw color with a decent head. Taste is complex. Sweet wheat and citrus flavors. Very enjoyable and refreshing.
Everything is great about this beer...add an orange.... the taste is thick and full of accents from citrus...taste the wheat also

Draft sample @ Chili’s in Fargo, ND. Hazy dark gold in colour with strong carbonation. Aromas of orange, banana, light spice, malted wheat, and a bit of sulfur. In the mouth, the citrus elements become less specifically orange, while the wheat flavor intensifies. The spices drop away, except for a touch of peppery hops. Fairly thick in the mouth, but in an almost artificial way. A pretty good attempt by a macro.

Had this beer on 5/10/2000.  Aroma is light with a slightly sour scent.  Color is a pale hazy yellow with good carbonation and head.  Taste is mildly sour and tangy.  Starting with a medium body it goes down with a tangy crisp feel.  Finish is a sour white flavor and a gentle bitterness.  It’s not the best White I’ve had and it’s not even close to Celis, but it is a good drinking beer.
Always on tap.  I love that orange cloudy pour and spice-like citrus aroma.  Cut an orange in half, squeeze and toss it in a pitcher.  Yum.
Surprised to find out this was a Coors brew. Wish the flavor was a little stronger.

12 ounce bottle in pint glass.   Coudy pale orange with nice white head.  Faint lemon-spice aroma.  Bland flavor, missing the point of being a Belgian white, slight watery caramel-orange flavor.  Light body, medium carbonation.  Not much happening here, but not a drain pour.

A Sim rate (on tap at the Dark Room, LES New York): I can’t believe no one mentioned coconut as that’s ALL I got from ths one. I even double-checked the label to make sure I’m rating the right beer. Aroma of coconut and pineapple. A perfect pina colada. Subtle and nice enough. Creamy appearance with decent lacing. Flavour is too too coconut. Nice at first, but hard to stomach for long. Wheaty with a hoppy tinge. Pina colada again.

I’ve had Blue Moon on tap and in the bottle and far prefer it on tap.  BM has become one of my favorite widely available brews.  On tap at Buffalo Wild wings (my favorite), it pours a medium-dark cloudy orangeish color, not opaque. Served with slice of orange most of the time.  Aroma is very inviting, smells citrusy, like faint orange/lemon zest with floral and wheat accents.  Decently smooth and light, the citrus and floral theme definitely carries over in the flavor.  From the bottle, BM has a more pronounced citrus flavor and more "floral" if you will, but loses some of the magic that it retains from the tap...not sure how to describe it...maybe more of a wheat flavor on tap that is missing from the bottle.  Doesn’t really taste as natural or good from the bottle, so I’d highly suggest draft.  Overall, when this is on the drink list (on tap), I’ll definitely pick it over the common macros.  At least it has some real flavors to it.  Goes great with some wings from BWW!  Not bad from Coors, nice job.
On tap, it had a light body with thin head, nothing to die for, but a big step up for Coors.

Bottle-Not sure if this can be a true Witbier, but not too bad.  Decent stuff to get in a bar or restaurant.  No head with a cloudy, light orange color.  Some citrus (orange) aroma and with some of that citrus lip smacking feel.  
Pizza Gallery

Pours cloudy orange. The bottle I drank left a bit of sediment in the bottom. They always put an orange in this when I get it at the bar. The smell is orange and spicy, tastes a lot like it smells. Good beer.
of course the ratebeer community is not a a fan of witbiers, nor of macros designed to look like micros, but this is a good beer.

On draft at Beef O’ Brady’s. Color is cloudy orange. There was barely any white head left by the time the waitress arrived with my beer, but I didn’t expect much even if I’d poured it myself. Damn, she put an orange slice in it. Why does everyone do that now? Oh well...loose lacing from the frosted glass. Nose is orange from the orange slice (surprise!). Not much else. Wheat, more freakin’ orange, some cream qualities. Medium body/ carbonation. Light and airey mouthfeel. Very one-dimensional, but good for a macro-brew. I’d choose this out of most crap at the bar.

My introduction to wheats so I’m thankful for that. I enjoyed this beer highly until I explored true Hefeweizens. It just doesn’t hold up at all. While most Hefe’s taste fruity Bluemoon tastes of celery to me.
This a great beer that is easy to find especially at a bar. Great mix with a hint of lemon and spice. Very enjoyable.

One of my favorite "on tap and easy to find" bar beers.  Cloudy and creamy with a slight taste of citrus and spice.  Yes, garnish it with an orange, as these tastes will then be dramatically accented.  Goes down easy and is quite satisfying, even if it isn’t a "true" Belgian...rather, is "Belgian-Style".
This is not a great example of a belgian white. It lacks the citrus flavor I would expect. No real spices either. The apearance is ok with a nice head. refreshing but there are much better options.
bottle in the States.  Nothing remarkable.  Slight hints of spice and sweet but nothing deserving of a "Belgian" title.  However, amazing that the Coors factory turned this out.
I love this beer.  Served on tap at my local pub.  Nobody has any idea how surprised i am Coors released this.
murky dark gold with a small white head.  flavor is of sugar cereal, grains, coriander, lemon.  high carbonation.  light bodied.  grainy cereal aroma.  pretty decent.

Name: Belgin White

Date: 02/23/1996

Mode: Draft

Source: Taco Mac, Sandy Springs



cloudy yellow, whispy head sweet fruity aroma, high carbonation, tangy with a sweet tart aftertaste

--------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

Name: Belgin White

Date: 06/14/2001



lots of sweetness from start to finish, cross between carmel and belgian candy

--------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

Name: Belgin White

Date: 06/09/2005



nice spicy aroma, good creamy body, light malt flavor with a touch of spices, clean but not exciting



Aroma: 6/10; Appearance: 5/10; Flavor: 7/10; Palate: 8/10; Overall: 16/20

Rating: 3.6/5.0
Score: ***/4

--------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

The score was calculated based upon the notes and an old scoring system.

This beer is served everywhere and thats a good thing. It is a better option than the usuals and won’t break the bank. Pours cloudy orange with foamy white head. Some carbonation. Hints of citrus and wheat but not overwhelming. Great job by Coors. Surprising..

Pours a cloudy apricot, with a big foamy head that stays as lace.

Smells of gumballs, coriander and orange juice.  It hints at more than the usual sweetness.

The mouthfeel is sparkling mineral water.

The taste is heavy on the coriander, citrus rind, honeysuckle, and the hops are barely noticeable.  A bit less tangy and bit too sweet for the style.

Not on par with other Wits I’ve had, but decent enough on a nice day.
Pretty decent belgian beer. Little to no head. Golden pour. Aroma has banana bread smell. Citrus taste.....well made beer should not require you to add a slice of fruit to it.

Decent refreshing beer, especially enjoyable at the beach.  Cloudy, hefe pour with diminishing head.  Light aroma, not too sweet.  Good taste, thankfully light on the banana and cloves and heavier on the wheat and grain flavor. Surprisingly quality product from Coors.

I like that I can generally count on getting this one the other choices are "both kinds."  Its a decent drinkable beer that I never really get tired of.  Smooth mouth feel and nice citrus clove taste.
Again, please do not put an orange in my beer. A decent brew with a citrus tatse and a very smooth finish. A cloudy golden pour with a small head. Not amazing, but OK.
I had no idea this was from Coors so I was not biased when I tried this. This is actually a rather good wit clone, clovy, citrusy and spicy. It aint no Hoegaarden but very decent and drinkable.

Draught at Cassidy’s Pub (Manhattan - NY).
 Creamy head of good persistence with beautiful yellow/orange color, much luminosity and a lot hazy with a good fizz. Fresh and top heavy aroma with rumors of fresh fruit like mandarin, lemon and dried flowers. Smooth and sweetish taste with alcoholic content apparently absent. Rather "young" and decidedly watery body.

I’ve had this one draught and bottle numerous times. I have never gotten sick of this cloudy orange brew! It is extremely drinkable, either cold or room temperature. It is not the most complex Wit, nor is it awful. I think for an American rendition of a Belgian classic, this one is excellent.

On draft. Very milky-yellow look reminded me of GOlen Monkey by Victory. For me, the taste wasn’t all that spectacular but it went well with my chicken sandwich and had a very milky-like aftertaste. White ales aren’t my kind of beer. It was served with a slice of orange on the side.

12 oz bottle total wine and more, Draft Firewaters, NJ Tropicana. Pours a cloudy/murkey brownish copper. Smells are citrus but no idea if that from the orange which is always added.  Honestly I didn’t know it was a coors product until someone told me.  If only all there products were on the same level

the flavour seems actually very good, it’s not off in any way it really is amazing this came from Coors, I did not realise it was a major company product when I got it. this is one great session summer beer, it’s available all over the place and has actual style to it.

This is a great beer and hands-down the best coors product.  Why don’t they go to the same lengths to make all their beers this good? Everybody has rated this beer, so it would be difficult for me to say something original.  I will say this, this would be a great keg party beer - rage on!

Blue Moon Belgian White (bottle) reeks of lemon! It’s yeasty enough that it maintains that usual banana taste, but the citrus is just overbearing. It is a witbier, but the actual wheat taste was almost completely obscured. However, having said that, too much flavor in one direction is better than no flavor at all, so I’d still grab one of these over almost every other BMC product.
Love wheat beers these days. At first I hated this one but now I realize how wrong I was. Nice color, great taste...looking forward to having another soon.

Draft. Mild banana aroma. Dark yellow color, very cloudy. Nice looking for a wit, pretty classic appearance. The flavor’s very thin. Banana, citrus, really mild. Not much to it besides banana. Overly bubbly finish, went down kinda fizzy. Drinkable, but not one I’d look forward to having again.

nice thick head; mild wheat and citrus aroma.  slight citrus taste with a good hop finish.  Overall, I found this tasted more like a standard lager - with some additions.  better than most, but certainly nothing special.  fairly disappointing.
355 ml bottle.  Pours a cloudy pale copper with a copious white head.  Mildly spicy nose with a touch of pepper.  Light body.  Semi-sweet with citrus notes offset by a slightly tart finish.

Weaker aroma than most other witbiers. I believe they want you to add a lemon or orange slice to dominate the aroma. Nice unfiltered appearance, though color is a bit light for my preferences. Tastes OK - lacks a bit of the flavor variety that other brewers offer.  Decent beer for warm weather drinking.

Of the beers that are "widely available" (both in bottles and on tap) this would have to be my favourite. A "heavier" beer in comparison to many beers of the same cloudy orange colour. Citrus taste within the bev but the brew is often served with an orange slice as well. Very refreshing on a hot day. Note: huge difference between bottle and draught taste. MUCH more citrus-y from the bottle!
mmmm. Over the top correander, and is that an adjunct I taste? Couldn’t be if it was brewed at Coors. Kidding aside, you can do worse.
Bottle. Nothing special in the aroma. Flavor was very vegetable like, sour, only a very slight hint of citrus, but that is drowned out by the vegetable overtones. Not a good representative of a Wit.

Pours an murky golden colour with a thin white head. The aroma is bland, with notes of wheat and soap (thanks ungstrup for that note, was rackin my brain to try and figure that one out.) Flavour is malty sweet with some dry lackluster wheat flavours and some citrus in the finish.

NOT a Witbier, not a Belgian White.  An impersonation of a Wit, with citrusy taste and aroma, with onion in there too somewhere, I suppose for flavor balance.  Hazy orange pour.  A good introduction to craft beers, but hardly worth sticking with for long.

No need to stick an orange slice in here, barkeep! My first experience with a macro-micro...quite a bit of citrus, but overall a light body with somewhat bland, pervasive malt presence. Carbs are a bit harsh. Pretty good, a lot better than I’d hoped for, but there’s better.

12oz bottle.  I suppose I rated this because I was board.  No other reason to rate this thing.  Pours rather hazy with a color somewhere between orange and onion peal.  Very mellow aroma with hints of banana bread and very light spice.  Flavor is basic but has wheat with lemon citrus.  Basically wheat malt and light grain with hints of citrus underneath.  Musty mouth feel that is medium in weight but toward the watery side.  Personally, if I’m going to drink this stuff, I’d rather have it on draft with a chunk of fruit floating in it.  By itself it’s nothing I really want to drink.

My review must be updated now that I’m not longer a witbier newbie. I had this last night for the first time in a long time...and it doesn’t even taste like a Belgian White. I mean, there’s no detectable belgian yeasty flavor or anything. Poured orangish yellow with small head. Aroma was citrusy. Taste was citrusy. A tad bitter aftertaste. There are much better wits out there.
Orangy hazy in colour with a slight white head.  Aroma follows, orange, wheat, slightly soapy..?  Flavour is sweet and wheaty with notes of citrus.  A nice witbier style beer.
great fruity taste, amazing quality for a domestic, mass produced beer you can find practically anywhere. Agreeable aroma and smooth taste.

On Tap,12oz bottle, Sans Fruit, This is my best go too beer at all the bars around town, easy drinking with a touch of coriander and smoothness going down, when all else is gone reach for Blue Moon, Hooray Beer.

On draught.  Fairly malty and a touch over-carbonated.  Aroma is grainy, citrus, coriander.  This is a reasonable example of a wit, certainly when you consider that it came from Coors.  It’s a bit too malty and fruity for the style, but easy to find and usually cheap.

Certainly not a great wit, but an excellent value beer.  This can be found on tap all over the place, often when the only other options are true garbage.  Refreshing beer that I end up drinking fairly often... and another rating I don’t know how I let go this long!

All I have to say is that for the price this is a good beer. Pours a hazy orange color with a medium sized white head. The taste is very fruity and consists of orange, lemon, coriander, and mild spices.
Bottle. Citrus flavor, unfiltered natural crisp, smooth, fruity refreshing taste. Not surprised Coor’s hides the fact that they brew this. Not a typical Coor’s product. Very,very solid beer.
Bottle.  Poured  a cloudy, light orange.  Nice Belgian white.  A littte sweet with a citrus flavor.  Enjoyed it.

12 Oz Bottle from Ralph’s in Los Angeles - Citrusy sweet aroma. Most obvious flavor is the citrus which almost dominates the palate.  Pretty light, a hallmark of its parent company Coors, but no hops. In microseconds goes from sweet malt to citrus flavor.  A crisp finish.

Appearance - Hazy yellow-orange, as a witbier should.

Overall, not a bad beer considering its macro parenting.

Enjoyed on tap @ Molly Branigans in AZ.  Served with an orange on the glass.  A bit girly, but certainly a tasty beverage.  Not sure how much the orange contributed to the fruit flavor of the beer, but that is what stood out.  A very drinkable beer.  Finished the glass very satisfied.

Draught @ The Cheesecake Factory: This one isn’t in Canada yet, but I’ve heard lots about it; finally found the opportunity to try it.  Came very light yellow, very little head, and with a fairly pale aroma offering subtle yeast, orange, and grains.  Mouthfeel is quite carbonated, more than I like, and fairly muted.  Obviously a weiss for the masses, and I suppose it’s pretty good at that.  Not something i’m anxious to have again, but decent enough.

Except for a bit of sediment, I think this is a near perfect beer. Like drinking sparkling nectar... lovely orange-ish color, delightful ’pop’ on the palate, filled with subtle spice. I like it best absolutely ICE cold... with a little slice of orange. My lands, I think I’m in love... ;o)

Tapped at Anaheim Stadium for an Angels baseball game. This tasted so much better than the Bud light I had before it. It was orange like colored with a slightly sweet spiced flavor. Good for watching a game and far better than the Macro crud available in most of the stands there.

355 mL bottle.  Hazy, translucent orange (not white), with decent head that quickly recedes to a film.  Mild aroma of citrus and wet hay.  Taste is a little maltier and much more citrusy (word?) than the standard.  Average carbonation, with a slightly flat finish.  There are far better examples of the style.
Pours hazy as a good Witbier should. The best way to sum up the whole experience is that it is a slightly citrus take on the standard beer.
Pours a hazy golden color with a two inch white fluffy head. Aroma is fruity. Tatse is a little watery. An OK beer I guess.....Just not my thing.
not a bad american wit, acutally surprised coors could make something this good.  not bad for a mass produced beer, and nice on a hot, summer day.

12 oz. bottle into a weizen glass... appropriately large weizen head on a sediment-rich brownish-orange body...citrus aroma with a slight grassiness...sourness and a bit of fizziness on the tongue...smooth, crisp, watery(?) with a slight malt aftertaste... a perfect summer brew and a good mainstream introduction to the unfiltered world of weizens... more complex beers are out there than this American attempt...
Nice fuity citrusey finish doesn’t really even nedd the orange but works well with it.  Very refreshing easy to drink taste.
Cloudy yellow pour with small short lasting head, served with an orange.  Sweet fruity aroma with a nice sweet fruity citrus finish.  This was good.

Pours basically like any other Belgian witbier, a cloudy yellow with a nice head.  Aroma faintly citrus with earthy and grass notes included as well.  Decent taste, but it’s uncomplex and quickly dissipates.  I agree that an orange wedge helps the beer, and it’s good in a pinch, but there are far better witbiers out there.
Your average American Wit.  Good head formation.  Medium body.  Finishes quickly.  The orange wedge improves the overall character.
350 mL bottle.  Hazy yellow with a fluffy white head.  Aroma of citrus and spice.  Malty vaguely citrus taste with a sweet semi-spiced finish.
Draught... orange color with a creamy head. It took some getting used to, but this beer grew on me with each sip. Not an overall great beer, but some interesting qualities. Not bad for a Coors.
Didn’t know it was a hefeweizen until I looked at the bottle after drinking it.  Very non-offensive...which always results in bland.
Boring taste.  Second witbier and not impressed at all.  Drank from bottle so can’t comment on appearance.

Aroma is of lemon, piss and pepper.  Looks almost like a good hefeweizen, but with some urine added for good measure.  Palate is nice, but too watery.  Overall, not too bad, but not too good.  If I liked the taste of lemon, I might have more patience for this hefepeeweizen.  As it is, reminds me of modelo negro with a lemon wedge.
a nice belgian white. nice spice and flavor with a good orange feel to it. i like it because its very common on tap, but i hate when they throw that gay piece of fruit in it haha. but overall nice.
another beer that i buy just to have in the house.  this was the 3rd or 4th beer i have ever tried.

It’s a dark cloudy orange with a light orangish whitish head. Has a great blend of spices. Nice and refreshing and very filling. May want to pace yourself on these. It’s just a tad too much emphasis on the orange peel, though. Other than that, a very good wheat beer.
On tap. Poured hazy orange with white head. Couldn’t really get anything strong out of the aroma. Flavors of hops, citrus, and spice. Very light.

Hazy orange with a white head and thin lacing. Smells mainly of spices and pepper. Tastes of wheat, spices and (again) pepper. Actually taste isn’t as bad as I was kind of expecting. Palate is a 3-way split with a smooth start, a little carbonation and then a tiny bit of astringency at the end. All in all, Blue Moon is "ok" but quality vs. price doesn’t win it for me.

Hazy cloudy gold from the pour with a white head that lost itself quickly....Nice sweet aroma...Initial sweetness when tasted...but this diminishes nicely into something that teasing a little bitter (but it never arrives..nice tease).  The mouth feel is decent.  Flavor stays with me...I would get this one again....

Pours a dark cloudy orange color with a medium sized light orange/white head that doesn’t last too long after turning into a nice lacing.  Taste of sweet spices.  It’s pretty filling, so you might only want to drink one or two at at time, but it’s a good tasting beer and it’s readily available most of the time.  A pretty good macro brewed white wheat ale.

Pours murky orange with a small foamy white head. Mild aroma of coriander, with a hint of rotting oranges. Really nothing going on the flavor. Very muted spice and some lemon/orange zest, but mainly just watery. Palate is light watery, with a non-existent finish. The popularity of this beer is a mystery to me. Spend the extra dollar and move on to Hoegaarden.

pours a cloudy orange juice color with a bit of head.  Tastes like a slightly lighter hefeweizen with the same traditional flavors.  I’m not a big hefeweizen fan, so this isn’t my favorite.  Has that clove spiced taste youd expect.  Ok, but if I were to drink this I’d add lemon or orange to cut some of that clove flavor I don’t care for.

TAP  My favorite easily obtainable macro, get it on tap and fresh (forget bottled!) - I prefer with an orange, but still good without. Light, slightly tart sweet, wonderful cloudly golden orange appearance.
I just don’t understand the popularity of this beer.  Interesting concept but I feel the orange is just too overpowering.

ON TAP at The Fireplace, Tunkhannock, PA. Not bad, but not a favorite among the white and/or wheat beers I have sampled so far. Maybe if the orange "spicing" weren’t so hit-you-over-the-head dominant, especially in  in such a mellow style brew, I would have enjoyed it more. Gotta give Coors an A for effort in coming up with this as their pub-targeted offering though. A step up from their mainstream macros - as opposed to Miller’s cheapo Red Dog step down from already low standards. BUY AGAIN? Probably not
Not a bad beer. A full body beer, a lighter wheat ale that doesn’t live up to a true wheat ale. Obvious pinches of orange peel. A great finish. Don’t garnish with an orange.
Just a great drinking beer. very smooth. taste better without the orange. Came with a free Blue Moon 23oz glass at Buffalo Wild Wings
A great try at a micro-brew style from Coors.  This spicy beer has hints of orange and coriander.  One of the better mass-produced offerings.
Bottle.Cloudy,medium orange color.White head.Smells like citrus and bread.Sweet and sour flavor,with a grainy texture.Not bad.

A pretty good beer.  poured at an angle so the head was short lasting.  The colour is a hazy amber~orange and the head is white.  I probably wouldn’t have tasted the orange if I wasn’t told about it before hand.  Only the second wheat beer that I have had, the other being a Paulaner Hefeweissbier.  I personally like the Paulaner better.  I drank this from a lager glass
Not a bad try for Coors. A little bland. It needed the added orange slice to spice it up a bit.
xxx Not a bad mass produced beer by any means,  When you consider its brewed by coors it puts it in a whole new light haha.

Blue Moon Belgian White Ale
12 oz bottle
Moderate pour in a weizen glass
Best before 10/07, observed 06/30/07(actual blue moon day!)

Poured a hazy bright orange yellow with a medium slightly lasting fizzy white head.

Smelt of moderate citrus, white bread and laundry detergent lavender.

Taste was upfront moderate bittersweet oranges and perfume followed by a moderate bitter yeasty dough and light sweet and sour orange on a moderate finish.

Palate was light to medium bodied, slightly oily on a dry finish, fizzy and lightly astringent and puckering.

Overall, this is a fairly standard light witbier.  Common and mass marketed, it’s a great intro to the beer world, but nothing too excellent.  Enjoyed it thoroughly though on an actual blue moon day!

22oz draft with an orange slice from BW3 in the burg.  had a very cloudy orangish appearance.  too much orange in the first one(had the slice in the beer), so the second one I took it out and it was a much better, due the orange/citrus flavoring.  very smooth and extremely easy to drink
A good white ale.  Great with a lemon or an orange.  Cloudy yellow.  Nice citrusy smell and taste.  I like this beer.  It’s good.

bottle: My 100th rating. Wow! There is a lot going on here. The light drinkability of a wheat meets the complexity of citrus with outstanding results. This beer is so flavourful it’s almost like I don’t have enough neuroreceptors to fully appreciate it. Unique and different. Let’ s hope Coors doesn’t screw this up.

Bought under the pretense of being a straight wheat style ale, did not know there was orange flavoring.  Orange flavoring does not go well with beer flavor.  Yuck!  Very disappointing, thank God for the German Purity Law.
a favorite of mine really. the color, the flavor, the aftertaste. its pretty good. common enough to find when your away from home in bars and liquor stores.
This is my favorite style.  The aroma and appearance are great.  The flavor is good, but not for it’s style.  Overall an alright witbier for it’s availability.

The aroma and palate are the weak points of this beer. Not much to smell and the palate gives off a pretty sour punch.  However, the appearance is great.  Nice and cloudy with a good head on top.  For a mass produced, summer style beer, this is surprisingly good.

Really nice refreshing tart wheat flavor.  Definitely skimped on the corriander, but not in any way I find detrimental to the beer.  Also seem to have gone light on the orange peel, which is surprising, but leads to a good, balanced beer.  Honestly, there’s not many better beers for a hot day.  This is not half assed, this is a legit attempt at a tasty witbier.  Significantly better than some micro versions.  I hate to pay for something from one of the big boys, but this is a really nice beer.
12oz bottle. hazy orange fruity and subtle spices in the nose. not really a good wit but it is refreshing, wheaty, and citrusy.

Good beer, easy to find, and popular. I’m spoiled by all the real Belgians available now, but this one still holds up. Orange-like in color and taste, with hints of spice (perhaps clove or nutmeg?), it goes well with spicy food, particularly buffalo wings. One could do a lot worse than Blue Moon and wings, you know.
draft.  Pours hazy orange yellow.  Smells fruity, tastes fruity, but tolerable.  Good beer to survive on when there is nothing better.  Actually there’s nothing quite like it.
Good wheat beer.  Belgium style, Witbier, and has a nice thick hazy depth to it.  Good smooth rich taste.  Not as good a Hacker but solid for a refreshing taste
nice cheap white beer, too filling to drink lots of but nice for just a glass or two. nice and worth a shot, check it out if a college student for good times.,

even though coors makes it, i must admit i like this beer. its a basic american attempt at a belgian wit. in a glass very cloudy golden color, medium head, scents of orange and coriander. can be found in a lot of places that only have macros so thats a plus.
On tap. Way too much going on here. More like Blue Nun(none as in pleasant taste). There was a unidentifiable taste from start to finsih. Had to work at it to empty my glass.

on tap:  Unbelievable flavour. On a lunch break from a humid shopping spree ,I find this on tap at the local Uno Grill.  I couldn’t believe my taste buds.  Now granted I was more than ready for a cold beer, but this surpassed all expectations.  Incredible mouthfeel of citrus and then this huge kick of malts.  It’s practically the perfect marraige of citrus & beer, as far as I can tell.  This amazing, cloudy brew reminds of the apricot taste in St. Peter’s Organic Ale or the dark fruity flavours of Chimay, only better. You often hear about exotic flavours in beers & they don’t live up to expectations, either by overwhelming the beer or just not showing up.  This balance of citrus & beer is on par with the chocolate in Young’s Double Chocolate Stout.  WARNING:  Subsequently, I have had elsewhere on tap in Michigan and the bottled product which weren’t  anywhere like my original taste of Blue Moon.  Even on tap, it didn’t seem to have the thick white head my original had, nor the malty base.  Ironically I read on the side of the bottle that Molson brewed this up here in Toronto so I bet they have screwed up another beer with their low quality malts (e.g. Creemore).

Bottle or on tap...Even though this beer is a Coors product, it is easy to distance that fact while drinking these down. This "Belgian -Style" white beer is really good! Pours a dirty pale yellow, sometimes so dirty you may find deposits on the bottom of bottles. Very light tasting, great for summer...don’t let them serve it with the orange wedge, this beer already has enough hints of citrus in it.
Really solid beer to drink. One of my favorites to drink when just chilling around with friends. Biggest problem with this beer is that it is overpriced.
Blue Moon is an excellent beer! Great taste that does not leave a bitter aftertaste.

I never trust a beer that has fruit in it.  Are they trying to tell us you will get scurvy if drinking this beer?  It has an uncommonly average taste with an uncommonly average smell.  To bad it doesn’t have an uncommonly average price.  I am beginning to think people are actually influenced by the price of beers than the beers themself.
It pours filmy, smells bad, and tastes like dish soap. Definitely not a good beer, plus any beer that needs a slice of orange loses points.
Great tasting beer, good to chill on if your DD for the night.  Only problem with this beer is the extent of the hangover it delivers when drinking.

Poured a hazy straw color with a foamy white head.  It smelled of slight citrus and bread.  A little over carbonated at first but it got better.  I found it very drinkable and balanced, but definitely not my favorite.

12oz Bottle - Yellowy golden color, whitish head that fades fast.  Citrusy, more spiced than Sam Adams White, but still not like a good Wit should be.  Good beer.  Very drinkable, respectable flavor for an American brewed Wit.  Not outstanding, but pretty good.
Pours a golden straw color with frothy white head. Very strong citrus notes, but a little sour aftertaste that was not so pleasant.

Nose is standard wheat beer nose with slight notes of spice.  This baby pours a beautiful glass, but it doesn’t last as the thick white head quickly disappears.  Flavor is well balanced, drinkable, but hard to find the subtle notes through the carbonation.  Really can’t find the orange and coriander which should be present.  I’ll call it lightly spiced.  Decent mouthfeel and nice wheaty finish.  Overall very drinkable, not at the standard set by some better witbiers, but I’ll have another.
Cloudy gold colour, creamy white head. First sip is full of coriander, no real sense of the orange promised on the label, but there’s definite citrus notes. very enjoyable indeed.
A good beer, I would never turn one down.  Pretty standard for a Belgian Witbier, although it doesn’t stand out in any way, and I’d much rather have a Hoegaarden.  Good, but not great.

Smells like bread? Maybe. Spice and fruit? No to my nose. Hazy peach color with a decent white head. Starts with a carbonation hit, and as that goes away the medium body thins. There’s something like stone fruit, something hinting of yeast, something hinting of spice. Mostly all hints. Maybe lemon in the finish. Maybe. Damn drinkable, but this is to a Belgian wit, as Bud is to beer. Pretty drinkable though, and I wouldn’t turn down a free bottle.

On tap with dinner at the local steakhouse.  Went well with the "crab cakes" that were certainly not up to my Chesapeake Bay standards.  Regardless,  beer actually served at ideal termperature and proper glassware.  A smooth drinking style.  I was surprsed that coors could make something so far from the normal product they force upon us.
I thought this was going to be horrible being that it’s from Coors brewing. Cloudy pour with 1 finger thick head. Lemon and bready taste. It’s not horrible its just below average.

12 oz bottle: Pours a slightly hazy straw. Minimal head quickly vanishes Not much nose, just some sweet citrus and very light spice? Taste doesn’t match with mostly a yeast character. On a second taste, slight muted hint of orange. Very little body but a slightly unpleasant after taste. It should be said that this is a slightly older bottle but it has been properly stored.

bengal tiger orange pour with smallish white head.  Very sweet wheat flavor with slight coriander backdrop.  (this beer’s flavor changes very noticeably season to season).  Very heavy for belgian white, but gets a few extra points for the fact that in most bars in america this is the best beer they have on tap.... so atleast some decent beer is being exposed to the masses.  Doing for the orange what corona did for the lime!

Served w/ a orange wedge.  Pours translucent orange with virtually no head.  Citrus aroma and flavor, but too sweet.  Have tried it several times and it almost always dissappoints due to excessive sweetness.

Cloudy orange body, no head no lacing, no carbonation... is this really beer? Tastes like... celery?? Someone tell me I’m not the only one that tastes this. Yes, taste and texture of celery, also oranges, probably because of the orange wedge.
Tap. Pours a very cloudy golden color with a medium white head. has a very citrus aroma. taste is orange and very sweet. thick body but easy to drink.
Pours cloudy pale yellow with a citrus aroma taste is sweet with a clean finish
Don’t be fooled people.  This beer is brewed by the Coors brewing company.  All the big beer companies are tryin to get on the craft beer trend...

Draft:  I don’t know if it was just a bad draft, but I did not appreciate this beer at all.  I had it one summer and it was the featured beer at the restaurant I was at.  Looked refreshing in the picture and it smelled pleasant and sweet.  The taste was far too watery.  My brother just told me he bought a case of another Blue Moon product and I shuddered at the thought.  Judging by the other ratings which are drastically higher than mine maybe I should try it again.  Possible I just got a bad draft. *shrugs*
From tap or bottle pours cloudy pale yellow, with a good amount of head.  Typical citrus aroma, and normally garnished with a wedge of orange.  Decent refreshing flavor and finish.

Tap.  Creamy long lasting head.  cloudy thick looking yellow body.  Aromas of citrus and corriander.  Also noticed some nuttiness.  Flavor is on the sweet side.  Good beer for drinking fast outside on a warm day.

This isn’t Belgian or White!!! Its brewed by Coors...IN CANADA. Its color is a musty diarreah brown. If you want Belgian, try Hoegaarden, if you want bottom (of the toilet bowl) this "beer" is for you.
A cloudy-golden ale with the taste of sweet oranges and wheat. Heavy but fairly smooth from start to finish. It’s a very good white ale for every once in a while.

I guess it’s ok when nothing is better on tap.  It just doesn’t hold up when compared to other examples of this style, like maybe an Allagash White.  It has a very sweet, citrusy taste-- but a little too much IMHO.  Every girl I know who hates beer, like Blue Moon.  What does that say?

One of the beers I usually fall back on when nothing better’s available.  Not an incredibly good example of the style but tasty and refreshing enough to keep me coming back.  Clear pale orange color with lots of orange in the nose.  Orange peel/coriander taste seems a bit artificial but still pleasant.

Had on tap at local pool hall.This had a somewhat weak aroma.Average head.The color was a cloudy pale yellow.It had a decent taste of wheat with coriander added.Palatte was good.slightly sour and slightly bitter.Not bad,but there are much better wheats out there,however,I was at a poolhall and was very surprised to see this there.I’m glad they had it because I would have benn forced otherwise to drink the crappy commercial high production beers.This was a great beer to have in lieu of those nasties!
Aroma is soapy lemon. Cloudy golden pour, light fluffy head. Very floral taste for a wheat beer, citrus is prominent. More distinctly lemon on the palate with wheat.

Rated 12/27/05:  I really enjoy the Belgian style Witbiers and have been trying any that can be found. This was the third one I have had and it didn’t dissapoint. It is the easiest to find and therefore I believe it must be one of the most mass produced of this style. The spices and citrus flavors balanced well, in fact I think they balanced too well. The appearance was great, I love the fact that this is an unfiltered wheat beer. I have had better from other breweries and I don’t think that the high price of this beer justifies the total flavor. I will only buy this again if no others can be found.

cloudy in apperance, not much on the nose but still carries the taste you would expect. slightly watered down but i guess thats what coors does. still you can find it on tap or bottled just about anywhere.
Cant beat sitting around all night drinking blue moon. I know its made by coors and everyone bashes it, but i will always like this beer. Very light and easy to drink.
On tap at Mile Square in Hoboken.  If i wanted a belgian white, i should have drank a Hoegaarden.  At least i would know i’m getting the real deal.  At least Coors didn’t TOTALLY mess it up.
on tap everywhere. I hate to say it but its not that bad. Drinkable decent wit. Much better than some respectable breweries wit. Yes Im talking about you victory whirlwind wit
A very good beer for men and women.  Has a hearty palate and a voluptuous appearance.  It is a beer that can go at any scene ranging from a dinner, a hot summer day, or a college party.
Nice enough attempt at a wit. Nice aroma and flavor. Not as spiced as Spring Heat. Light body. Very drinkable on a hot day.
This is probably my favorite beer. Very good smell and taste. Good with or without a slice of orange.

Bottle.  Pours cloudy white.  Nice aroma of orange peel and head.  Taste is smooth and refreshing, though a bit thin.  My hats off to Coors for brewing a purely drinkable beer that is supported by their massive distribution network.
12oz bottle, big white head.  cloudy ambercolor.  Just a lot of good citrus flavor. A little bitterness in the finish.  Nothing that special.
Good orange/spice flavor.  Very cloudy appearance.  Good beer for a macrobrew.

Bottle. Pours a murky amber/orange with a frothy white head. The aroma is of wet straw, oranges and coriander. The palate is light and lively with a dry finish. The initial taste is rather sweet with dominant citrus and coriander flavors finishing with a pleasant orange aftertaste. This is a light, refreshing and very drinkable beer.

12 ounce bottle into a weizen glass, cloudy yellow with a big white head. Aroma was nice with notes of orange peel, spice and citrus. This was lightly flavored with notes of citrus, lemon and wheat. A bit watery. Maybe good for a hot summer day if your down at the convenience store and all they have is Bud and Miller and this. Otherwise ...
Poured cloudy with a small head, fruity amoma and a refreshing palate, ideal with bbq food and a nice summer drink.

Draft.  When it was placed in front of me, I became somewhat frightened as it looked uncannily like piss.  The head was small and shortlived.  The taste started with a fruity tinge, and by the time the mouthful was swallowed, had turned into a very noticable yeast flavor.  It was ok, but after one bite of my burger, I could no longer taste the beer--excepting the yeast, though very faint.  

Only an ok beer; certainly to be chosen over a budweiser, etc, but if there is anything else available, avoid this.

Bottle and draft several times. Pale, murky orange-gold with medium head that fizzes away. Aroma is coriander, citrus and spicy yeast. Taste is similar and refreshingly drinkable. This is not a bad choice for an industrial when all else that’s available is millcoorbudlite.
Orange and cloudy with a very weak head. Hints of citrus and nuts underneath. It’s not the best wheat beer I’ve had by far...but it’s a decent brew from Coors/Molson.

i will never understand who loves this beer! it is vegetable licorice astringent zima. i would rather drink any other kind of style. its not mellow and it doesnt bite. the straight up character of rutabaga and carrot could very well put man off of beer. this is not God’s way of telling us he loves us and he wants us to be happy.

Aroma of orange corriander and peanuts. Yes, peanuts. As I have always gotten that out of this beer for some reason. Yellowish orange and unfiltered. Tastes better than other mass produced hefs. Corriander, peanuts, wheat, some citrus. Not bad, but nothing special.
I like this beer.  It is what it is.  Blue Moon spicy, different, doughy, yeasty, with Coriander and malty spice.  I was very surprised to see that it was brewed by coors.

a readily available, easy drinking wheat beer.  the yeast doesn’t shine through as it does with some wheats. it has citrus tones and moderate carbonation giving it a crisp taste.  after trying some better witbiers this one begins to taste like exhaust. meh.

Draft.  Poured a cloudy and orange with a small white head.  Citrusy aroma with some spices present.  Smooth, slightly sweet to the taste, with citrus and wheat flavors.  It always baffles me that this is from Coors.  Pretty good.
Hazy medium gold color with small head. Aroma is corn, yeast, and mild citrus. Flavor is your typical corn, wheat, and light hops. Not too bad.

On draft. A decent witbier. Had this have been the first one I’d ever tasted it would have rated a lot higher. There’s just so much more quality out there. Aroma was non-existent. Pour was a light cloudy gold with a 3 finger puffy head. Taste was orangey citrus with a delicious, almost creamy texture. Yeast and wheat in the aftertaste. Not bad.
A grassy smell on this one and a light piss color.  Lots of carbonation.  Body tastes unimpressive
I was very surprised at the taste of this beer. This doesn’t remind me at all of other witbiers at all though. I would consider it a blueberry wheat beer. Very drinkable, but not a very complex beer.
Bottle.  Aroma is yeasty and of some noble hops.  Flavor is bright, lively and slightly sweet, but never cloying.  Finishes dry, with a lively carbonation.  Pretty damn impressive for Coors.

On tap with orange.  Aroma is of light hopps, flowers, and orange.  Average white, frothy head that is mostly diminishing.  Body is hazy blond.  Flavor is of wheat and orange.  Starts moderately sweet and lightly acidic and finishes same.  Average duration.  Palate is med-light, watery, and lightly astringent.  Flat carbonation.  For a beer that’s regularly on tap it’s not bad at all.  The orange really helps the flavor and aroma.  Great job Coors.
great beer, with a citrus flavor and not too much bite, tastes great with an orange slice

Had this again yesterday, for the purposes of rating it. It is a standard white ale. Like the other beers it has that cloudy look to it. The flavour is citrusy of course, with little hops. I mean, it is surprising to see that Coors makes this and actually sells it, but I guess every brewery (except for Miller probably) has to make a beer that doesn’t totally suck.
Easy drinking smooth flavor.  Poors a cloudy gold color...and gives a decent orange flavor.
Not bad, but in the end, kind of boring.  Nice hints of orange peel.  (And I’m almost certain that I taste the slightest hint of chocolate.)

Good old blue moon. First time was in colorado by myself. Witbier always use to get me depressed. to the point where I would have to cry myself to sleep. But like all great martial artists I adapted and learned to embrace this style of beer. Plus the lemon always brightens my mood. added 06/19/07: Just had it with an orange slice. sooo good! I had no idea. none at all! witbier is so dynamic!
It’s got that light fruity flavor that is just so easy to drink.  I suppose I’ve gotten sick the fruit-punch taste in the past, but overall it continues to be a pleasant beverage.
Thick white head, nice golden color.  Easy to knock back a bunch and not feel like you’re still in college.
Pours a nice opaque golden color.  Aromas is of sweet citrus.  Not a bad beer at all. Mild flavors are refreshing. Not as distinct as some better witbiers.

April 8, 2007; 12 oz. bottle.  ("After-the-fact" rating.) Today, as an Easter Sunday guest at a relative’s home, I was offered a choice between this and a Labatt’s Blue.  Should’ve taken the Labbat’s.  I don’t care for wheat beers anyway, but the only thing distinctive about this one was the vague citrus flavor.  Otherwise, this brew was a dull, spineless and generally weird tasting concoction.  Really not enjoyable at all.

Blue Moon was the first six-pack I purchased upon turning 21 three years ago. I thought it was flavorful and exotic at the time, but as my tastes have changed/improved, I have to admit that I found a pitcher of it near undrinkable last night. Oh, it’s not bad tasting by any means, just way too sweet for my liking. The spices and orange flavors were overpowering. The appearance of this beer was a vibrant orange, no head to speak of really. I guess I’ve been a bit harsh here; it is what it is. A decent stepping stone for those trying to shy away from Miller Lite or Bud.

Small creamy, white, mostly diminishing head with a medium orange body.  Nice aroma with scents of orange and cinnamon.  Sweet flavor with a lightly acidic and bitter lasting finish.  I tasted orange and spicyness.  It had between a light to medium body and was moderately astringent.  It seems to have a uniqueness that I haven’t encountered in any other beer.

Bottle. Aroma is nutty with orange, corriander and dough, along with a musty mold smell. Color is cloudy yellow/amber with a white head which is mostly diminishing. Taste is disappointingly flat. A little sour and a little bitter. Not much else. The mouthfeel is pretty unique though. It has a light/medium body and is between watery an oily, but it’s got this nice smoothness to it. Still, a good choice over a macro pale lager.
22oz. Draft,  Had no head to speak of.  Had a cloudy, orange/gold color.  Tasted good with some fruity hints.  It was served with an orange floating in it and tasted better once I removed the orange.
great golden beer with smooth easy drinking flavor, in the vein of oberon and a cheaper substitute. good in a glass with an orange.
Poured from a 12oz bottle into a pint glass. Pours a golden colour slight cloudy and decent head. Aroma of wheat and citrus. Taste was smooth, citrus, wheat and some hops.

Bottle and draft, poured a medium cloudy gold with a white head, fragrances of malt, wheat, spices with orange and lemon citrus aromas, small sweetness on the nose, light tasting malt with citrus, medium mouth feel or less, faint citrus on the tongue, I thought the Blue Moon to be better on draft then from the bottle, this was not bad.
It’s a great beer, definitely underrated.  Finishes smooth, no aftertaste, goes good with almost any food.  Throw the orange wedge out if you get it on tap, or eat it right away.

A good solid Macro that you can get in most places. If you are looking for a good example of a Witbier this is not it. But if you are looking for a refreshing beer at the bar or your BBQ it is a good choice.

A mass-produced beer that I have had several times in the past, but never rated.  This beer is pretty good for a widely available one, but I find that it must be drunk under the right conditions.  This time I had it on tap at a restaurant in a tall glass.  Its color ranged from a dark yellow to an almost light orange color, as it is lighter at the top.  It is a cloudy beer with a foamy white head.  The aroma is naturally wheaty and hoppy, with some grain, a touch of fruit, specifically orange (which it was served with), and sweet malt.  The taste was very sweet, practically fruit.  It had a smooth, wet mouthfeel, with average to light carbonation giving it some bubbles.  A good warm weather beer, and good to have with food.

Shining cloudy gold with a solid white cover. Straightforward lemon and coriander nose does not feel too up front, rather well integrated in fact, so is the vanilla. Fairly malty in mouth, it remains quite sweet, but the balancing acidity has the sufficient force to avoid stickiness. Overall a good brew but lacks "umph" in my opinion.
excellent import . . 1st time i have ever tried it, and its a long time coming.  recommended with a slice of orange - cant wait til summer to enjoy this beer on a warm day at the beach.
This is a unique tasting beer. Fairly sweet on my palate. I’m not sure what is in it, but it seems to be wheat based. Good beer if your in the mood for something different.

On draft from a local Max and Erma’s
Cloudy orange body with a small white head.  Taste was that of orange maybe that was from the orange slice they gave me with my beer.  Someone wise once said, "never serve me fruit with my beer."  Orangey taste with a hint of wheat, overall not bad when the selection is low.

From a twelve ounce bottle purchased at "Keller’s IGA" in Cincinnati, Ohio - This brew pours an orane-hued, white-headed liquid with a sweet wheat aroma. Tastewise, it’s all blueberries to me, but lacking in palate and body.
Pours a pale yellow with a small white head. Tart aroma with notes of melon. Sweet, orange taste with lots of wheat. Thin body, slightly water.
This ale is not bad, but it is highly overrated.  I heard oohhs and aaahss about this beer, it diddnt live up to the hype...  As do most products under the coors/molson umbrella.

Very cloudy golden orage color in pint glass. Smell is severe orange. Taste is severe orange. Really doesn’t taste like a wheat beer. The orange flavor is over the top. Still more interesting than other macros, so if it’s the best thing on draft, I will get it sometimes. Very drinkable. Doesn’t get nasty as it warms up.

Ive had this one a million and times and decided to rate it after a couple at a restaurant today.  I normally wouldnt ever rate anything from Coors, but I find at restaurants that carry mostly swill, this beer will do.  Pours a cloudy light orange with a thick foamy head.  Usually throw an orange slice in there if available.  Smells of orange, and wheat mostly.  Taste is pretty smooth and easy drinking.  Not the greatest flavor, but not bad either.  Get some decent wheat and orange citrus characters.  Like I said before this beer isnt bad, when the rest of the beer list reads Budweiser, Bud Light, Coors Light, Heineken, Corona, and Miller Lite.
Only beer that has made me want to throw up.  Very yeasty and smooth, but foamy.

Bottle. Nose is oranges and yeast, some minor coriander. Cloudy, pale yellow-orange with huge frothy white head. Yeast is upfront and balanced, but the second wave is an almost artificial-tasting sweet citrus and vanilla flavor. Mouthfeel is smooth and drinkable even if it is somewhat heavily carbonated. Overall, this is a very drinkable beer, especially being that it is from Coors, but my problem with it is that the flavor lacks the subtlety of a good wit since it is obviously aimed at the average American palate.
Cloudy in appearence with a good amount of head.  Flavors of citris (orange), malt and a smooth finish.  Nice beer to have with dinner, it won’t necessarily overpower your taste buds.

Bottle... pours a semi-hazy golden color with a white head. Spicy, malty aroma. Mildly carbonated palate with flavors of citrus fruits, malt, spices, and a nice yeast balance.  Nice clean finish. Pretty unique from a lot of American versions but would be nice if it were a little bolder and more complex. It’s definitely better on tap if you can get it.

Straw colored with good white head. Coriander and wheat nose. Bartender sank an orange in it, sadly...so I taste quite a bit of that. Had a typical Belgian yeast flavor...but not quite as good as a true Belgian.

Poured a pale slightly hazy brew with a thick, creamy fizzy looking white head. Doesnt look bad for a Belgian White, especially one made by Coors. The aroma has lite coriander and lemon and some wheat smell. I drank it with an orange so that dominated the flavor. The palate and finish were just there, not really a lot to describe.

One of my favorites. It’s been my "everyday" beer lately. Very tasty
on tap, I’m seeing it more and more.
Love the color, and of course I love
that little bit of yeast at the bottom. I like
almost chewing that last sip!!!

Great cloudy beer with foamy head and soft aromas and tastes of citrus & corriander.  A unique change to your everyday ale and a perfect fall beer.  Interesting every once in a while beer and a very nice thirst quincher.

Draft. Very cloudy. Orange, deep gold color. Weak head. A nose of fruit and yeast. Long finish. Average. I’d imagine if you wanted a truly great Belgian white ale, you wouldn’t necessarily ’tap the Rockies’ to find it.
On tap; hazy yellowish-gold.  Aroma of yeast, bubblegum, some citrus. Easy drinking and a fairly good tasting wit beer.  A good standard to have around.

On tap.. Light golden color with a medium head. Aroma was a bit of yeast and some fruitiness. Flavor was mild yeast and a bit of floral and fruitiness and a bit of wheat. Refreshing beer....hold the fruit
This had a nice golden amber color with a firm head.  It had notes of spices and when served with an orange slice the citris really pleayed well off of the spicy flavors....nice beer overall!
Cloudy light amber color with a nice white head, corriander and curacao in the aroma, a touch of orange in the light delicate flavore with a bready spicy finish. Pretty Good for a mass produced ale.

In my old age i’m becoming more adventurous...at least in trying new kinds of brew. It came with an orange slice on the glass!!! It’s OK, I’m confident in my masculinity. But honestly it was a wonderful compliment to spicy BBQ fare. I love the unfiltered cloudiness.

A great summer beer. Light citrus and orange flavors. They go down like water on a warm summer day. The only knock is that there seems to be a bit of a bitter aftertaste that is not consistent with this style after drinking several. Not offensive though. All in All a pleasant drinking experience

A very trendy beer, however since it was acquired by Coors i have to say the quality has dropped tremendously. There are other witbiers out there that are substantially better. Worth a try but not a keeper."

Pours a cloudy tangerine color with head that pulls a disappearing act.   I didn’t do the orange in it.  Aroma and taste are already very fruity and sweet without the added slice.    Not bad but not the best white beer I’ve had.  Probably better in the summer.
solid white ale.  nice orangy flavor and aftertaste.  great finish, orange-tinted head.  tastes even better after adding an orange slice

I saw you standing alone with out a dream in my heart without a love of my own bob bobabob a dang a dang dang
Nice

Had this on tap. Looks orange-ish with a maelstrom of floaters and little head. Very sweet aroma and taste, nothing too special. I’ve had better witbier, but I guess this isn’t too bad coming from Coors.

Pours hazy/dull orange.  You can see the sediment in this one.  I have had this a few times with an orange slice (fruit the beer).  The citrus almost overwhelms the palate here, but overall, a refreshing summer time beer.

Weak in color, dull and orange. More sediment than I expected. I know this is an unfiltered beer, however there are almost  to many floaters to look past. What this beer lacks in color is made up in taste. A very smooth drink, with creamy texture and strong citrus flavors.  Next time I will try with the orange.
Cloudy-golden with hints of citrus, wheat, orange, and corriander in both aroma and flavour.  Fairly smooth start to finish.

Better break out your chemistry books,you have to add an orange to break down the sour acids,after adding the orange the beer is great.Cloudy in appearance,pours with a nice thick head and the smell of fruit to the nose.I  highly recommend this great beer.
Really impressed with this beer with the orange in it i dont think i would be able to handle it without.  not wallet friendly though.

I was exited to finally try this beer. So exited I figured fuck the orange I dont need it. I grabbed my frosty Trappist glass, and the rest was disappointment. I dont get why so many people think it’s great. It’s only descent one at a time.
Excellent beer.  Almost reminds me of Kalamazoo Bells Oberon Ale.  The aroma is a sweet citrus wheat scent.  I love the taste and it goes down fast, the alcohol percentage gives you a nice kick.
Not bad but the beer gets tiring after the first couple bottles/pints.  Needs the orange or it becomes kind of skunky.
The worlds best beer! Smooth Smooth Smooth!  Wheat beer is better than water as far as I am concerned!  I could drink this beer all day long!
This was a ho-hum beer for me. The only thing going for it was that it had a slight citrus flavor that I like.
meh nothing exciting at all. Pours in a very light typical wheat color and tastes a bit citrusy.

This beer is served everywhere and thats a good thing.  It is a better option than the usuals and won’t break the bank.  Pours cloudy orange with foamy white head.  Some carbonation.  Hints of citrus and wheat but not overwhelming.  Great job by Coors.  Surprising..

citrus, orange, clear, aminimal head, white foam, medium sweetness, lightly bitter, lightly sour, medium body, creamy, lively, 

I really enjoyed this beer, it is a good change of pace.
I only drink this when the moon is actually blue, thus I don’t get to drink this often.  But when I do LOOKOUT!
Bottle. Cloudy yellow. Short white head. Smooth unremarkable taste. Alittle bit of creaminess on the palate.
Nice color. Smells of wheat and orange. Taste of wheat, orange, and coriander. Nice hoppy finish. You don’t know this beer is made by coors.
Have seen this everywhere.  Tried it at Piscators’ favourite restaurant (Hooters).  They served it with an orange slice.  Nicely carbonated.  Went well with the Mexi fries
Served with an orange slice. Nice color - white, orange and cloudy. Sweet with a citrius flavor. Respectable and goes great on a hot summer day or a nice sunny day on the slopes.
Typical watered down mass-produced "belgian" style (I guess). Somewhat pleasant if you’re drinking it just to get a buzz, otherwise I don’t think I’d bother.

Cloudy orange pour with thin, white head, orange and wheat aroma.  Olfactory and taste buds are on the same page, same paragraph with this one.  For the young and inexperienced (myself included), it’s decent and reliable.
