22oz on tap at Uncle Bub’s Barbecue.  Served too cold.  A hazy orange with minimal head, no lacing.  Aroma was sweet citrus with a hint of spice.  Pleasant taste, slightly sweet and fruity with citrus connotations.  A hint of bitterness, but just barely.  Light bodied and tingly in the mouth.  Simple and decent.

This is a pretty good beer.  It is nice a cloudy in appearance, due to not being filtered. Very nice taste to it (sweet on the palate).  All in all pretty good average everyday beer for anybody.  Pretty good for watching sports at a sports bar, get this instead of bud or miller if it is on draft.

A very clean and refreshing beer. A very simple tasting beer, but good. Had on draft and they served it with an orange slice. Removed it and enjoyed the beer. It would be a nice beer during the hot summer or warm spring.
Oh come on...how can you not like this beer?  Nice citrus flavor.  Nothing too special but a great avg joe beer.

Light orange and lemon aroma, taste is light citrus orange,a slight sweetness,and a faint orange peel in the aftertaste, certainly refreshing ,probaly a good summer brew,nothing to really contemplate. Thanks LTJudge

12 oz bottle. Pours with a huge, semi long lasting white head. Body is amber, very cloudy. Aroma is orange and fruity. Nice mouthfeel, heavy carbonation. Nice clean aftertaste. Got more sickly sweet as I went on. Lowered the score some.
This really isn’t bad for a Coors product.  I don’t really like wheat beers, but this one is subtle and tastes pretty good.

pours orange with a healthy head. unfiltered.
tastes and smells of orange peel and wheat. the 
mouthfeel has just a bit more kick than is normal for the style.
carbonation is just a bit too high.
overall, i like this ale a lot. good session beer.

Not too bad.  Sweet and citrusy.  It is actually surprising to see this is a coors product.  Most likely, it is one of the best things that they do.  But still, too watery and underdeveloped.  Not bad for a coors product though.

pours a cloudy lemon yellow with a 1 1/2 finger fluffy white head. has some nice sediment and the aroma is a very mellow orange peel hops and wheat with a tiny bit of coriander. has a light body with some descent lacing and the head lasts about a quarter of the way down. flavor is a bit of orange peel hops a bit of wheat and coriander. not bad, not the best of course, but not bad. i would definetly get it over most macro (grocery store) beers. i noticed that the small orange peel hop aroma is a little better as it warms and has a little carbonation on the tongue as well.

After tasting Hoegaarden this was a huge letdown.  Someone else here summed this one up perfectly as a "poor man’s Hoegaarden."  Tastes like a Coors with a bit of rotten orange flavoring.  Unfortunately distribution of this beer has knocked Hoegaarden off our local taps.   Often have to settle for this when nothing else wheat is available.  I can only think people who rate this beer high have not tried many wheat beers.

Gotta love when the commercial description reads like a nutrition label.  Citrusy and almost milky? aroma.  Pour is a hazy golden color with lots o’ bubbles.  Taste is spicy and full of wheat and yeast but subtle.  Finish is quick.  The overall impression is of a watered down beer with some spices.  Ok but no where near the better versions of this style.
Light, citrusy, with strong qualities of wheat flavors. Light orange with a light, foamy head. Not bad for a macro.
Taste is of sweet oranges and wheat, very heavy going down, but smooth as well. All around a very well made beer
I tried this on tap with an orange slice to bring out the flavors. I have also enjoyed if from the bottle. It is a great change of pace from most of the nationally available beers.

The first time I had this was in the middle of the hot summer on tap with an orange peel. that is a great way to try it for the first time. I dont like fruity beers but this one blends well and is not to over powering. Great summer beer, but I did perfer it on tap after I tried in in the bottle.

this Nationally available product is the only offering of blue moon’s that i have tried, but it makes me want to see what else they produce.  this brew has a yellow/oragne appearance with minimal aroma.  the mouthfeel is very smooth  and dense like a stout, and the flavor is a great balance of citrus/honeysuckle sweetness and a wheat backbone.  
my only other comment is that i believe it was an independent brewery that was bought out, which explains the better pedigree.

I had no idea this was a Coors product; I just grabbed one of the last untried beers at the corner store. Says it’s brewed by Molson; same difference I guess. Anyway... Bottle, from mug. Bottle date JUN0307. Pretty aggressive white head, but it faded fast and left very little lacing. A pale orangey-yellow, very hazy body. Some sediment seen floating around; whether it’s yeast, bits of orange peel, coriander or all of the above I don’t know, but it’s nice to see, considering the sterile brand names behind this stuff. Primary aroma is a zestiness from the orange peel, and there’s a light spiciness from the coriander. I’d prefer if the aroma was stronger, but it’s not bad, such as it is. Medium-light bodied; texture isn’t thick, nor is it really thin; carbonation is soft. Flavor is...wheaty; I don’t know how to describe wheat beers, but I know one when I taste it. This beer is also brewed with oats, and maybe it’s subliminal but I think I can detect them. Finishes crisp, with a touch of grapefruit. This is the second highest-rated active beer on the Coors page, and is arguably the best, considering number one only has two ratings and is only marginally higher. So I guess that’s something. Not too shabby, considering its parentage; I was pleasantly surprised. It also got me singing the Doo-Wop version of "Blue Moon," by The Marcels, so I bumped my overall rating from 12 to 13.  :-)

Pretty good beer. Kind of a poor man’s
Hoegaarden.  Pours a cloudy golden color with decent head that it doesnt retain.  Probably the best Coors/Molson beer I’ve had.  Very drinkable.
This beer is unfairly underrated on here, probably because it’s made by Molson.  It’s typical citrusy, spicy, bubble-gummy.  It’s easy to drink.  Nothing fancy, but it’s a solid beer.
Simply aweful. Dont know why you would drink this. has a dominant apricot juice taste. Tastes like beer mixed with apricot juice gone bad. Don’t know why its rated so high.

Most of the time if I see Coors I keep walking but this is a must try Belgian White.  Pours a nice golden orange color with a decent head.  Very flavorful fruit taste.  It’s good by itself but try it with an orange wedge for extra flavor.

Took me by surprise when I had first found out Coors was responsible for this ale. While not the best Belgian white, it still manages to pack a punch with it’s spicy citrus flavor. I recommend this beer and it is very easy to find, as well as easy to drink.

Still a solid white in my eyes. Not the best beer in the world but it doesn’t really ever disappoint. Very hazy orange color with big white head. Smells fruity, spicy. Taste is kind of bland, but it has qualities of spice and fruit. Beer is simple but crisp and easy to drink.
A surprisingly good brew from the people at coor’s. Strong coriander flavor with a pretty nice finish on the palate. Are there better beers, yes, but this one is good enough and easy to find.
Draft without orange. Very tasty citrus beer. It has a cloudy yellow appearance. It is one of my favorites when going out to eat. It is light on your stomach.
Not a bad beer.  I really like the citrus taste and the brew does go down smooth.  There are much better beers out there, but for one made by a big brewery this is very good.

Yes - I know it’s a Coors product, but it is really damn good.

Took a while to get the pour right, but finally able to achieve a 1/2" head.

The cloudy, amber appearance is perfect.

I will be the first to admit when I first had this beer I did not realize it was made by Coors, which is probaby a good thing because I didn’t have  pre-perpared thinking. Nice citrus taste, even without the orange most place serve it with. At macro-brew places, this is a good choice instead of the usually Coors/Miller/Bud choices.
From a tap, this had absolutely no head, which was disappointing. Had the look of a good white ale, but barely the flavor of one.  This has definitely been watered down for wide appeal.
Pours a hazy gold color with small white head.Has a small grainy aroma to it.Slight taste of citrus,but not much else very watery also.

From what I can detect it has a yeasty smell. It looks cloudy and a dark yellow (maybe a hint of green). The head was average, quickly dissipating. Definitely smooth and light. Very crisp and refreshing beer for when you get home from work.  Nice all around beer. Would’ve been better if it had been cheaper though.
I first tried this beer several years ago and was very pleasantly surprised.  The slight citrus aroma and taste enhances the flavor and does not detract from it all.

Crisp and refreshing, cloudy appearance. Flavor not very strong but it works for this beer. Almost undetectable aroma of citrus, decent but the price makes it a little hard to buy again for a craft beer lover.

I had this for the first time in Pittsburgh at the All Star game. This beer pours a nice golden color with a nice white head. The flavor has a citrus taste. Very nice with an orange slice. Very good beer.
My favorite American Belgian white,  suprising considering it’s made by Coor’s.  A crisp wheat ale with a crisp satsifying finish.

Pours a cloudy  straw gold with lots of sediment floating around.  Grassy aroma with a sticky sweet orange aroma and mild spice.  Flavor is much the same as the aroma with a weak watery finish.  Thin body.

Used to be my favorite beer until trying the similar tasting Leinenkugel’s Sunset Wheat, which is much sweeter. Definitely tastes better in a tall glass with a slice of orange. Still, not really worth the domestic "premium beer" cost.

This wheat beer is okay. I would definitely not rate it higher than any import wheat I have tried thus far. The smell has the aroma of oranges.It can be topped with a slice of orange to seal the flavor. The added fruit surprisingly does not harm the true flavor. Semi-smooth and thick taste. One thing that surprised me was the this beer is brewed in the Rocky Mountain State.
good wheat beer, bit of orange flavor, hazy appearance, relaxed drinkable beer

Bottle. Pours a nice golden-yellow color with a creamy head that dissipates quickly. Nice flavor of spice that I can’t pin down. Pretty good mouth feel. Although I usually prefer German weissbier, this was very good. Especially considering it is made by the same people who make Coors.
Nice color upon pouring, but not too much head (just how I like it).Great taste, often negating hops.  Very smooth beer with a bit of a sugar bite.

A hazy orange yellow color, with thin white head that quickly dissolved. A sweet orange smell. A nice tangy, orange flavor. Swallows very easily, with an enjoyable aftertaste. A decent beer, and very available.
Interesting wheat beer. Definitely has a different body than most other wheat beers. It goes down nicely and cleanly. One of my favorite wheat beers.
Very thin and light. Doesn’t pack too much taste either.  I’d save my money and buy something else.

Nice golden cloudy pour with a thin white head. Aroma was citris and some orange. Flavor was very smooth and the citris and spice came thru very well.Not to bad at all and good to bring to friends house.
a hefe type beer, light in color and big in taste. must be tried with an orange slice. even without the orange it brings citrus notes in taste

Delicious!  It’s hard to believe this cloudy, golden wheat is put out by the same people that make Coors [ick.]  Perfect with a lemon or an orange slice.  This is the ideal poolside or barbeque, summer beer.

Poured a cloudy golden with a large frothy white head.  Aroma of citrusy spice, surprisingly refresing.  Taste is decent at first but too sweet and dominated by heavy toffee in the finish.  Not a whole lot of spicy complexity.  Tried it with the orange slice next, and although the orange did cut the toffee flavor, it increased the sweetness and made it taste a bit too much like soda.  Decent considering who brewed it, but still nothing exciting or worth a second try.

Tried a pint of this out in Vegas.  Pours a cloudy white/yellow with a nice white head.  Nice citrus fruit aromas carry through to the taste which is enhanced by subtle spicing.  I’m surprised to see its from MolsonCoors, as this was actually a very nice beer.  Overall I’d still give the edge to Hoegaarden White but not by much.
I really enjoyed this beer.  I was amazed that it was made by Coors.  I originally had it on tap and was a little disappointed when I later had it out of a bottle.  Maybe it was the orange???
I like all the flavors in this beer. I prefer it from the tap then the bottle. The orange slice is pretty cool...
Cloudy orange with nice fruity aroma. Sweet and citric. But I really don’t get the orange thing...

Cold 12oz bottle:  Pours a cloudy golden orange color with a small, fluffy ivory head.  Aroma and taste are of sweet malts, blueberries, bread and spice.  Smooth, well carbonated and light bodied.  Ending is sweet and malty.

bottle . . pours golden/cloudy with a light white head . . aroma is spice, clove, fruit, sweet . . tastes citrus, banana, sweet, bread . . not a bad beer, but not too much flavor . . very sweet and not complex but overall not bad . .

Not too bad overall.  Like the haze, like the initial tast, however, the aftertones seemed to linger a little to long.  Or mabey it was an old  case I had.  It is much better from a clean tap with an orange slice, tham from a bottle.
Thsi actually isn’t too bad of a beer comeing from a company that makes the least offensive and tasteless beer in the world.

the orange slice addition to this beer does indeed compliment the spiciness of the beer. but as it stands alone, the elements of the brew work well together without making an outstanding beer. the citrusy aroma is mirrored in the taste of the brew as it bears a sweetness to it.  the yellowish cloudy apearance is engaging, and it is palatable.  any beer enjoyed by so many women has to be.  as far as white beer goes, it is on track, although there are better options.
Finally a beer to rate while drinking it.  My friend seemed to favor it. In my opinion its an average beer. The head dissipates quick and has little carbonation. The flavor is also a little weak.

Sampled both on draft and bottle on numerous occasions. Pours a hazy, orange body with light white lacing. Aroma is bitter citrus and light wheat.  Taste is medium to thin with notes of  and wheat. Refreshing, and with out a doubt one of the key beers to introduce someone to a style outside of the generic pale lager. While this beer grows off of me more and more, I can still acknowledge and respect it for what it is.
It’s quite confusing to call this beer Belgian, cause it is not at all. In Belgium no-one ever heard about it.. Anywyay, the beer is ok,not the best I’ve ever drunk.
pours hazy yellow orange...citrus aroma...has a citrus wheaty taste and is creamy on the palate. it is pretty smooth and I find it refreshing on a hot summer day.

Very nice belgian white ale. Great misty appearance. Strong citrus with a light wheat flavor. I have seen this served with a slice of orange to enhance the flavor. If you like this beer please try Bell’s Oberon.
This was a rather weak-tasting beer that I wouldn’t purchase again. Somewhat of a wheat flavor.
Only two bottled beers that I buy/enjoy when the pipeline runs low on Craft Brews. Blue Moon and Sunset Wheat. Very clean finishing and refreshing beer

12oz bottle. Poured a cloudy light orange and a small white head. The aroma was sweet and heavy in citrus.  The beer tasted  like strong orange and lemon, almost like a malt beverage. So so beer. Probably better in the summer.
Hazy yellow. Bland taste with citrus notes. Slightly creamy feel. I was unimpressed.
Coors’ supposed answer to the microbrew craze of the mid 90’s.  Not bad, light taste with faint apricot flavor.  Clean finish.
Pretty okay citrus aroma and flavor.  The texture and finish were just okay too.
Very different beer than the norm.  Very orange taste.  Almost flat taste, which is biggest turnoff.  Average aftertaste.

Hazy yellow appearance with a decent head which dissipates quickly. Taste is light with some citrus and some spices. Overall fairly bland but surprisingly decent considering the source. Still wouldn’t find myself choosing this beer given much choice.

Bottle. Orange pour with plenty of sediment and decent head that died fast. Citrus fruity aroma. Citrus and flowery flavor. Well carbonated, smooth. Best Coors product I’ve had. True to style, but not my style.
Had this while Manchester United won the Carling Cup 2006....pours that cloudy yellow orange...some head...fruity and flowery in the nose..alittle weak but a enjoyable beer for an amer wit.
12 oz bottle, good for a major american brewer, but not great.  Taste is fairly decent, light citrus and spices.  Too much carbonation though, and definitely not one of the better witbiers.
More than you would expect from a major brewer. While it’s somewhat fizzy, the taste a good, fruity (similar to Lucky Charms’ marshmallows). Goes great with a slice of orange or lemon.
From a bottle, less than perfect tasting environment but enjoyable all the same. Wheaty, citrusyyy and APRICOT! Better out the bottle than when i’ve had it on draught pre-rate days.
this beer was better than i thought it would be. i loved the citrus overtone and the orange peel. a great beer.

12oz bottle in a lager glass.  Pours an opaque, hazy gold-white.  Very thin head that leaves somewhat of a trail on the glass.  At least Coors is brewing a drinkable beer. I have not tried many Belgian Whites so it is hard to compare to others.  The taste is somewhat watered down but still enjoyable.  I’d say I would have to have a taste for this brew to want to drink it.

Picked up a 6 pack on my friends persuasian and we pounded em down. Not to bad, didnt pour it out but looked very light almost orangish tint. had a slight citric smell and taste. not bad, id definatly get it again on special occassions.
on draught.  hazy light orange.  Aroma is wheat, light citrus notes.  Taste is light citrus and spices, some light esters.  light bodied.
pretty good with a hlaf orange nice color thin white head citrusy for sure. cloudy pours good clean aftertaste not bad

Tap at Kahootz: Murky yellow gold with a dissipated head swirling throughout the brew.  Citrusy aroma wih a perfumy sweet taste and an ok finish.  It is pretty mild onf the yeast.  No thanks to this pseudo micro.

Hazy pale straw color with a huge fine white head. Aroma is light citrus. Flavor also light with wheat and a touch of lemon finishing with a mild dry tartness. Thin bodied and watery with moderate carbonation. Light and refreshing.

Pale hazy yellow, well carbonated with a nice mound of a head and strange looking flakes floating around. Doughy, wheaty citrus and corriander aroma. Sweet, soft wheat and corriander flavor. Clean, watery finish. Not offensive.

Slight  crushed slag gravelly aroma. Poored hazy light yellow in my steelers glass.  Background citrus bite with nice carbonation.  No bitter finish. Decent, but not quite as good as other belgian wits.  Does not seem as refined. I also had this on tap at the North Park Deck House in Robinson township.  Did not seem as good on tap.
An excellent Witbier, tough not as good as hoegaarden.  It is cloudy white, as is common for witbiers and is light and refreshing.

It’s not great.But to be honest, it’s not that bad. Classic head, color and taste.
A little to carbonated. A slight taste  of i don’t know what. But over all, a solid effort.

Gosh, I hate admitting it, but this is a damn good beer from a commercial brewry.  Thick and cloudy.  White and golden in color.  Has a nutmeg flavor/finish with a clean after taste.  I drink this when at Hooters....best they got IMO.  Nice suprise from a mega like Coors.....not a knockout, but will due in certain situations.

Beer pours deep, cloudy gold with white head. The aroma is almost chewy with wheat - some yeast and a good dose of sweet orange zest, too. The flavor is extremely wheaty and refreshing - the orange peel is prominent, coriander not so much. A good bit of bready yeast in the after-taste. The beer is quite bubbly - carbonation lightens the taste a bit too much. The mouthfeel is pretty thin. The beer finishes crisp and a little dry. The beer could use a little more spice, but I do like the level of wheat in the flavor.
Pours blonde and cloudy with medium carb and short lived head. Ample lees present. Smells of apples pears and cinnamon. Spicy and acidic with a slight green aple sourness.

Pouring out of a 12 oz bottle into a pint glass....cloudy orange hue....creamy and crisp body..nice citrus tones....finish has a feel about is that makes you return and return and ......yeah you guessed it back again....and yeah orange peel sooo apparent in the aftertaste.....:)

Draft - Poured a light orange/yellow in color with a frothy white head.  Aroma is light on the "Belgian" yeastiness, but it does have a bready aroma along with some citrus and spices.  Flavor is medium of bready yeast with a pleasant sourness from the yeast that makes it clean  without overpowering.  Citrus and spices not as evident in the flavor.   OK, but not one that I will seek out... there are many better "Wits" out there...
plenty of nice citrus notes cloudy nice coriander flav, very easy to drink. good summer brew, ......... had again a few times lately, didn’t impress like i was at first

An above average Witbier.  On tap at Applebees, NO ORANGE. Cloudy with an off white head.  This has been one of my favorite beers for several years.  Nothing really special about it but a good solid beer that is readily available.

Draught from The Pub poured into shaker with orange garnish - Pours cloudy gold with a minimal white head; Wheat, LOTS of orange to the nose; In fact, it was a bit overpowering. The bar smoke made it easier to handle though; Wheat, orange, lemon, and some malt on the initial taste; A bready backtaste that had lots of coriander too; Not bad overall. Little more carbonation than I’d like, but it was probably the lines at the bar. Body was very nice overall and it was plenty easy to drink. Having an orange adds a lot of sweetness to it, but it’s almost too much. A wit for the masses and a very good intro beer.

A superb white ale.  Pours a cloudy amber with a white head.  Very nice aroma of orange and spice.  Spicy and smooth at the same time.  Definite orange flavor.  A great beer that is even better on tap.  Try it with a slice of orange.
I absolutely LOVE this beer.  Tastewise it is tops, it smells great and looks great to. I do believe that it is the best widly availably beer.

This is simply the best beer in the category of "most available."  It is almost anywhere.  It is absolutely delicious.  Goes well alone, or with foods, best with fish and pasta.  Great orange peel bite.  Great wheaty flavor.  Perfect smoothness / carbonation.  It’s just damn good.  Also very sexy appearance, with banners and clouds of milky unfiltered goodness in a smooth yellow / white haze.  White head that lasts.  Drink this beer.  EDIT*****Also, unfortunately, sometimes from a bottle this is not so great.  Metallic, musty, sour.  Sometimes it’s a winner, but best bet is on draught.

Bottle. I loved the color of this supposed witbier. It was a little darker than I expected.  I thought it was rather cosmetically appealing, for a Coors product.  Can definitely taste the bitterness of "orange peel," as the label says,  or whatever flavor they add to it to give it a little bit of bite.  Not bad for a beer you can buy at almost any Walmart.
Not really what I call a witbier.  Pours a cloudy tan color with a white head.  Sweet yeasty smell.  Sweet malty taste with some hints of fruit.

A witbier that appeals to the masses. I hate coors just as much as the next beer geek, but i’ve had worse beers then this. Actually a drinkable beer from coors, but very lacking as far as Belgian whites go. Has the citrusy flavor to it (which is why people like to have an orange in this brew), but it’s definitely not belgian. Good enough to drink, but as  far as Belgian whites go it totally misses the mark.
Average witbier.  Not one way or the other.  Add lemon for nice accent, smoother than expected, mild taste all around ... Better on Tap.

Tap. Gold/Orange color. Cloudy appearance. Fluffy white head. Citrus, Coriander, and spice flavors and aroma, and slight malt finish. Pleasant mouthfeel. Some lace in the glass. I enjoyed this beer very much and will get it again.

I’ve had this on many occasions. Fairly consistently, it is of poor quality. Full of flavor defects, particularly cooked-vegetables (prominent dimethyl sulfate). Occasionally metallic as well. A bit of citrus in there too... but there are MUCH better alternatives.

Bottle from some corner deli in NYC. Sampled in my hotel room. Golden-orange colour. Aroma is slightly flowery, with notes of citrus and wheat. Crisp body. Flavour of orange and pineapple, with a faint spiciness. Not really on style, but I actually don’t mind it.

[Colorado Road Trip – 2006]
I nice light Belgian brew.  A orangish brown color I wonder if they use food coloring for the color. They add so much rice to weaken this brew it needs help.    Needs more flavor and more Belgian malts.
Fairly smooth beer. Not one of my favorite beers but an okay choice all the same.

From the tap, served in a restaurant pint glass.

Poured a cloudy pale golden orange with a foamy, slightly fluffy white head that settled into a thin lacing.

Aromas of wheat malts with hints of lemon, traces of coriander and spice, and very powdery, a dry vanilla-like.

Moderate carbonation and a softly crisp, smooth and creamy lightish medium bodied mouthfeel.

Pleasant tasting while at times being a bit thin in the spice department, sweet wheat malty, hints of coriander, pepper and a light citric, a cake-like yeast powdery and a dryish malty finish.

Not a bad witbier from Coors, a good introductory beer for people who only know macros lagers, often your best choice at many restaurants.
More body than many wheat beers. Nice lemon tang to flavor. Style has too few hops for me.

Bottle:  Has a cloudy orange/yellow color with a minimal head.  Aroma of oats and slight citrus.  Has a decent spicy wheat taste though body and complexity are lacking and finishes quite dry.  Not bad though.
Orange aroma with hint of coriander; cloudy yellow in color; spicy flavor; lacks body, but a good drink
From bottle.  Pours a hazy yellow with off white head.  Coriander and light orange nose.  Flavor is heavy on the coriander, light wheat finish with a lingering metallic taste.
This beer is good especially in the summer, nice looking head, nice hoppy taste. Made with cariander and orange. a great beer to just hang out and drink on a hot summer day.

Pours a hazy orange with creamy white head. Citrus-spice aromas with some fruity notes. The taste is sweet and mild but lacks any real depth.  Good, smooth mouthfeel and citrusy flavor. Has the distinctness of a wheat beer, mild yeasty bread overtones of in-bottle fermentation

Very un-witlike in appearance-- hazy orange amber, not lemony yellow/white as expected from the style. Funny aromas too-- none of the sweaty/wet hair that is so common; instead it smells very perfumy and spicy, with tropical fruit all over the place. Fresh and light, there is a crisp celery-like note that keeps it lively and very easy to drink.

This was one of my favorite beers early in my beer drinking career. A very smooth blueberry like taste that was light at the same time. Very refreshing and enjoyable to drink. I have had numerous occasions drinking this with and without an orange and definitely perfer no orange.

One of my favorite beers that you can get pretty much anywhere.  Golden in color with a medium head.  Citrus aroma with a taste to match.  Goes down smooth, with a light taste.  When it is topped off with an orange Blue Moon is a refreshing treat.
12 oz Bottle Pours out a cloudy gold topped with a white head. There is a nice belgain aroma. The tast is nothing need the aroma.

blueeeeeeeeee moooooooooon...i can’t help but thing of so many great childhood memories when i sip this brew. 

but this brew is a crisp brew great for a summer evening.  the aroma is light, the flavor is light, and the palate is tingley.  it all needs a bit of work in the backbone dept. but who’s perfect? its made for the general public and thats how it tastes. i can drink one to refresh myself then i need something with flavor.

Coloration is gold, and a thin white head.  Aroma is a bit of malt, a bit of fruit shows up, along with a small note of coconut.  Taste is wheaty, along with fruit undertones, and is a bit watery.  Palate is thin as expected.

Blue Moon Belgian White and Killian’s Irish Red are (in my opinion) in a completely different league than the rest of the Coors Brewing Company line of products. I must admit that Witbiers are not my favorite style, in fact I did not used to be much of a fan. Recently some better micros have come my way, and I have an open mind to the idea but it won’t ever be my preferred style.

This beer pours an hazy yellow/orange. Small white fizzy head does not last long. Minimal lacing. It has a slight musky citrus smell. I got hints of subtle yeastiness and wheat in both the smell and the taste. The taste seems very straight foreword to me. Nice spices but not nearly the complexity of a Victory’s Whirlwind Witbier. The simple straight foreword flavor probably does increase the marketability to the general macro drinking population. There really is nothing offensive about this beer (even though I don’t find it overly interesting). I think it may be plenty refreshing on a hot day. It feels very bubbly and active in the mouth, but a bit empty (thin) at spots. It is crisp and refreshing. Given the brewer, it is much better than I expected, but I’m not going to go seeking it out on a regular basis. Overall; it’s an easily accessible, acceptable beer.

Hope this is helpful.
Cheers!

Nice golden amber color, the head was white and vanished in seconds. Smelled strongly of citrus. Taste was citrus (I get mostly lemon) with some spicyness, a bit of sweet, a bit of bitter. It was a bit thin and a bit transient, but I was impressed, considering it came from Molson/Coors.

Bottle.  Pours hazy yellow with a medium white head.  Aroma is typical witbier, mainly wheat malt with a bit of pepper.  Flavor is the same but much weaker.  The aroma is surprisingly robust, but the flavor doesn’t hold up, making this disappointing on the whole.

Hazy yellow color with a medium white head. Aroma is wheat with some banana and pepper. flavor is bland but you can get some wheaty notes and spice if you swirl the yeast into it. Watery and one sided. Thirst quenching, but not much else.

This beer has a very opaque, beatiful honey color. The smell is alternating in my nose between bitter and sweet; I’m ambivalent about smell.  The taste, though, is quite good.  It’s spicy, crisp, semisweet without beign syrupy, with hints of honey and citrus.  The thing to do here, and I imagine elsewhere, is to add a slice of orange.  With the orange added, I find this beer to be absolutely incredible.  However, in all fairness, my ratings are based on it’s stand-alone qualities.

Very impressed with this beer.Had it on draft.Pours a cloudy brown but a very nice bite to it.Cannot believe it is made by coors brewing because there beer is bad.Maybe coors will wake up and try as blue moon is a pretty good beer.

Draught. Pours a cloudy yellow with a faint white head. There is a wheaty aroma with faint sugar. The body is thin. Flavor is pepery and papery with faint sugar. It’s watery & rough. Some mild citrus is apparent. This is not in the top 10 best Belgian Wits.

hazy light yellow pour with nice head.  malt and spice aroma.  banana, spice, effervecence.  I used to think this beer was great when I first started drinking.  Now I can do without it.  Nice for a cheap widely distributed white

I was quite surprised with this beer. Because it’s a Canadian/American, Belgian white/wheat made by a macro brewer I didn’t think it would be good at all. A hazy orange/yellow color with a white head. Spicey aroma. Mellow wheat taste with the spices and fruit coming through towards the end. Refreshing. I tried it with an orange slice as suggested on the bottle.

I thoroughly enjoyed this beer.  For a heavier beer it is very refreshing on a hot day due to the orange citrus flavors.  I would definitely recommend this to others.  Best from tap in my opinion but still does the trick from the bottle.

Bottle. Pours out a hazy orange-yellow colour with a nice foamy head. Scent is mildly hoppy with strong citrus elements that warm your nose as the molecules hang there comfortably.  Taste is coriander, orange, and lemon. Smooth on the palate and leaves a fruity sugaryness all the way down the throat.
Why are you drinking this? Don’t you know this is Coors? Do you like the taste of water with a bit of flavoring? Put this down and get a real white.

I’ve had gallons and gallons of this over the years both on draught and from bottles.  I recently had this on draught at Smokey Bones BBQ, so I decided to finally rate it...  This brew is about the color of brown sugar.  It is cloudy and moderately carbonated with a creamy white head.  The aroma is mosty corriander.  The flavor is slightly sweet with a nice balance of orange and corriander.  The mouthfeel is smooth.  I really like this stuff on a hot summer day with a wedge of fresh orange.  Blue Moon is a great beer especially considering that it is a marco selection...
I had this on tap at Wingnuts. This is a decent white ale with some crispness. The aroma is mild and the head is minmal
Blue Moon is a pretty good white ale. The wheaty taste is best enjoyed with an orange or lemon slice, but overall a smooth although flat flavor.

The 12 ounce bottle poured a Murky apricot colored beverage with a good sized creamy white head that was mostly diminishing and left some lacing on the glass. he aroma was complex. I could make out fresh apricot, some nondescript citrus and pepper-like spice. Interesting. Te body was surprisingly and disappointingly light with medium carbonation and a thin, watery texture. The flavor started off lightly sweet and stayed that way throughout the medium finish. There was a light note of spiciness toward the finish as well. The appearance and aroma had me expecting more from this one.

Taste too much like shit. But I gave it the score I did because it is made by macrobrewing nazi’s. 
Best they have done since Bitter Beer Face commercials.

This is actually my beer of choice. Cloudy pale orange, with a nice foamy head. Toss the orange aside, as I am not a fruit in beer kinda guy. Tastes citrusy and crisp with a hint of spice in the aftertaste. A good change of pace from your every day heff.

very nice appearance however not much aroma
good flavor when orange slice is added otherwise taste is somewhat flat
Bottle.  Looks can be decieving, looks right tastes like a low grade american white.

I havent had many Belgian white ales.  This was an ok beer, although not very impressed.  Pour was good, with a thick head.  Smell of yeast, slight hops, citrus.  Texture was thick, and foamy, which I thought was the best part.  The taste was ok, but, what is that, blueberry?  Kind of odd.  I wont be drinking much of this in the future.

12 oz bottle.  Good smooth taste.  Has much carbonation bite/sting.  aroma is good, but taste is flat in comparison.  I do not get why everyone says this style is "refreshing", I find it disgusting actually...

Okay, I bought this one on a capitalist principle.  I heard recently that MolsonCoors’ numbers were up in general, and in double digits with this particular beer.  The macros should be more adventurous... Smells sweet and citrusy.  Uniformly murky orange-yellow body with initially thick but fairly quickly dissipating white head.  Tastes sweet and citrusy.  Some hints of vanilla or something like it.  Pleasant, but rather one-dimensional.  About what I expected.  If I’m looking for a real Belgian white, I’ll go with the Allagash version made right here in Maine.  Nonetheless it beats the heck out of most macro offerings.

Bottle.  Never a bad beer - my wife’s favorite.  Very consistent and always accessible.  Very nice blend of citrus and spice.  Good color with a pretty white head, nice aroma, nice balanced body.  Just a solid white. I’ve had other whites rated higher that I thought were not as good.
(Tap) Pours golden with not much head. Coriander pretty evident. Nice and refreshing. It surprised me how similar it is to Leinenkugel’s Sunset Wheat, except with less herbal flavor. Pretty good.

Nice cloudy white beer with medium flavors of orange and corriander.  Its a okay choice for someone new into belgian whites.  It’s not great or awful but its thirst quenching and good for its price range.

This beer is very popular in the bar scene and I don’t know why. Pours a cloudy yelllow-orange with an ok white head. Smell of orange and spice but the aroma is far better than the taste. Taste is very yeasty which is ok but where did the fruit and spice go that was in the aroma? Not to mention you shouldn’t have to put an orange slice in your beer to give it some flavor. Try Allagash’s belgian white for a beer of the same type that needs no such orange slice and is clearly a better beer in this catagory.

not a bad brew by any means i gotta say. its light. its a nice summer brew. ive been chilling with it a lot lately. drank a couple 24 oz cups at a csny concert and illed out real hard. chilled on a grassy park hill and sipped on half a 6 pack with a good homie and it was relaxing. recommend it and its everywhere right now for some reason. get it at safeway. get it at the bar across the street. hopefully more good brews become distributed everywhere. and more big ass brewries start putting out more quality brews instead of wack ass no flavor depressing brews.

some people will tell you that this beer is overrated, and some will tell you that it is incredible.  i don’t think it is either.  however, if you are at a bar and need something to drink large quantities of, blue moon is a good choice.

An authentic Belgian wit w/o any aroma or taste, thanks Coors.  See Leinies Sunset wheat for similiar no aroma or taste.  Hazy beer with a weak head.  No spice aroma.  No citrus in taste some slight yeast.  A very poor example of an wit.  Very poor.
Had this in both bottle and draft... ill be honest i like it... im a fan of wheat beers with some fruit.. only downfall is it has a rather bland taste..    add orange slice and ur golden
This might be the first "real" beer I ever had as a youth.  Creamy, citrus notes, mild with a nice balance carbonation.  Good beer to drink with a meal.
my favorite readily available beer. that said, dont let the bartender put and orange in it because it will overpower the natural body of the beer.
Bartender gave me a sample shot glass and that’s all I needed to know it was not for me. bland light beer with some orange juice added. I love orange flavor. so it is not bottom of barrel.
Tennessee version, cloud appearance, left a bitter aftertaste in my mouth, disappointing beer

On tap. Hazy yellowish in color with white head. An orange wedge was dropped in it by the bartender. I think the orange over powered what little beer aroma and flavor there may have been here. I smell a bit of malt and something sour behind the smell of the orange. Obviously there is a fresh citrus flavor and that was about all I could taste. Might be the slightest hint of yeast in there. This beer is way too light in flavor and aroma to overcome an orange wedge. Disappointing product. Not something I plan to try again with or without the orange wedge. How this tastless beer won any award is well beyond my level of understanding? Therefore I need to lower my overall a bit more. An orange wedge in ice water is a better choice here.
Let me start this out with: I hate Blue Moon. Okay, now that that’s out of the way: it smells great: citrus and corriander mix, but it tastes repulsive: bland and yeasty.

Pours a muddy amber ..  head stays kinda thin throughout .. nice lacing though..  aroma is very weak, almost non-distinguishable...  taste is citrusy, almost orange-rindish...  I do like this beer in the summer as it is easily available..  I don’t usually put fruit in my beers, but I find that a splash of orange juice in this really brings out the flavor.

Be careful!  Look on the left side of the label, and if it says it was brewed in Tennessee, it is brewed according to the old (and very good) recipe.  If it says it was brewed by Molson in Canada, and imported by Molson Coors, then it will be too light in body, wrong yeast, wrong hops, and not enough orange peel and coriander.

If you like this beer, make sure it’s the Memphis, Tenessee version!  The molson brewed one is a different recipe and is absolute CRAP!

When you only have brews from macros to choose from, this is going to be your best bet.  Still watery like all the other coors products, but has a little more body.  Has a slight citrus flavor with a little bit of a keg aroma.

An unclear orange beer with a white head. The aroma is sweet with notes of oranges, wheat, and soap. The flavor is sweet wheaty with notes of orange peel and lemon, leading to a short lived dry wheaty end.

Pours golden with a lot of floaties. Spicy citrus aroma. Alright mouth feel. The flavor doesn’t do much for me, for some reason I can’t put my finger on why. This is a beer that I want to love due to it’s wide availability, but I just don’t.

On Tap at Applebees. Served ice cold in a tall glass with orange slice.  Cloudy and grapefruit juice appearance.  Heavy on very sweet citrus flavors. Light bitter citrus and spice aftertaste.  I would drink this one again.
330 ml bottle. Pours cloudy amber with a nice white head.Aromas of spice and citrus and that is the taste you get.A nice refreshing drink and one that would have again.

Both bottle and tap. Bottle, in my experience, has some metallic notes; on tap it has a cleaner, fuller body, and not so "thin" as the bottle where the yeast has all collected at the bottom. One of my favorite beers, a real standby, and the third beer I ever drank!  Nice bitter orange scent and taste, some nutmeg thrown in too. For being a macro, I love it.
This beer pours a golden amber color with a nice white head on it. The taste is spiced just right for a wheat beer, and is extremely smooth. I find this beer to very drinkable and light.

(Tenessee Brewed) I have heard good things about this beer, but I never believed them because it was brewed by Coors, and all their other brews aren’t even remotely good.  However, this has been the one exception so far--it’s not bad.  Aroma is wheaty, spicey, somewhat rich.  Flavour, not too sour, not too sweet, somewhat of a rarity among this style.  There is actually some complexity to the flavour.  I am amazed.  I’m even more impressed, given that I often dislike this style.  There is a tad of a chemical flavour, but this is a mild complaint, given the overall quality of this brew.  I’d certainly drink it again, especially since in many parts of the U.S, this is one of the few decent beers that is widely available.  By the way, I am rating the Tennessee brewed beer...the generic one brewed in Canada is slightly less interesting.

Living right next to Coors and getting the freshest beer may have made me bias but I love this stuff. Pours a nice slightly opaque golden with a lingering off white head. Citrus aroma and flavor. Clean finish. Great with orange or lemon.

Bottled.  Pours a cloudy golden yellow with a small white head.  Aroma of artificial orange and cereal grains.  Taste is much the same as the aroma and little spices.  Medium bodied, sharp carbonation.  Not bad for what it is.  It also seems quite a bit sweeter when on tap--overwhelmingly so--if memory serves correctly.
Nothing too exciting here.  Pours with just a bit more orange than a proper wit should.  Aroma of coriander and oranges is nice but the mouthfeel is a little watered and bland.
Pours a cloudy gold/orange.  Tastes of citrus and orange with a little spicy flavor.  Sweet and easy to drink.  Pretty good for a macro, but not very good when compared to anything else.

My least favorite wheat beer so for far in my beer drinking. Pours a cloudy honey color with nice expanding head. Aroma is light coriander and citrus. Flavor is watered down cheap perfume with light citrus flavors. It’s not bad for a Coors beer, however it’s still not something to be too proud of.

Bottle and draft. A decent wit. I for one hate it when people but an orange slice in this drink. Decent spices in the taste but is lacking character. Smooth and clean feel. Not bad for a brew made by coors.
Pours a golden color with little head. Nice spicy and wheat flavor with citrus hints. A nice summer beer.

Bottled. Pours a cloudy peach color with a somewhat lacy white head. Aroma is hugely apricot, with a bit of orange and a nectarine or two. Medium body with medium fizzy carbonation. The taste is apricots, a bit of wheat and just the tiniest hint of spice. Quick and somewhat crisp finish.
Grainy (witbier) nose; very hazy gold color with very little head; wheaty flavor with citrus hints. Could this have been actually brewed by a macro?

Poured a cloudy pale gold with a moderate whit head.  Aroma is dominated by coriander, with some orange and wheaty cracker character.  Flavoe has a smooth bread like wheat flavor with a pleasing vegetal coriander taste that is similar to celery and shallots.  A sweet and tart orange flavor holds up.  This beer is not as delicate as hoegaarden but has its own fuller more "American" quality that is quite enjoyable in its own right.

Not real impressed with this beer, mich white head that disipates quickley, with a thin white lacing that remains throught the beer. Almost no aroma with a nice malt flavour... this beer had almost no taste but it was very refreshng would substitute this beer with desert anyday.. tasted like I mxed Orange Juice with  beer

Not a Hoegaarden but good for what it is. Pours a hazy gold into the glass. Large, creamy white head that has good retention and laces nicely as it’s drunk. Sweet / spicy flavor with hints of maple syrup (at least that’s what it tasted like to me). Again, no Hoegaarden here but not a bad brew especially considering where it came from!!

Big fan of this beer, really refreshing.  It does get old after having 5 or 6 in one sitting, but shit, what doesn’t?  Pours a vibrant, cloudy amber and tastes of oranges mostly.  Aftertaste has oranges as well, and a little alcohol bite if one lets this beer warm up too much.

Pours cloudy amber, lively, average head. A sort of "average witbier" aroma is there, ok but undistinctive. An initial sharp bitterness tempers quickly to become moderate, lasting. Medium bodied with a slight viscousness. I found it rather refreshing (a fine summer beer) and would drink again.

This foul swill is the emperor with no clothes of beers. It neither looks, tastes, nor finishes pleasant. Supposedly a premium macrobrew, it has a bitter start, and a heady middle, similar to Sam Adams; its aftertaste is afterbirth, making me wonder just what the trendy folks at the brewery left in the bottle besides the yeast sediment, which any basic brewer knows will harm the taste of your finished beer. The beer has a murky uneven look when canted into a glass. I’d rather drink OE than this, I say again, swill.

An unfiltered wheat ale spiced in the Belgian tradition for an uncommonly smooth taste. Gold medalist (white beer) at 1995 World Beer Championships, silver medalist (white beer) at 1996 and 1997 World Beer Championships. 171 calories per 12-ounce serving and 5.4% abv.   Not True.  The taste isnt smooth at all and the finish has a slight chalky film.

On tap at a Manhattan bar. Flavor give just a hint of bananas and orange...Good not great. There are certainly much better Belgain style ales out there....but I guess what do you expect from Coors...certainly better than a Silver Bullet...
this is a great spiced up cloudy wheat beer, hints of orange, and coriander, an easy to drink beer, but it still has pleanty of flavor in every sip. i like it best with an orange wedge.
Hazy golden orange. Wheat and citrus aroma, a little too sweet but otherwise bland except for the off wheat taste which I don’t like. Very little hop presence. Just not one I like.
Macro witbier that doesn’t live up to the many better examples.  Slightly hazy golden colour with minimal head.  Aroma has some wheat and orange.  Flavour is thin.

Draft, served very cold. Little aroma at this temperature, hazy light tan color, small white head, taste of slight orange and little sweetness, no mention of corriander. Not great just drinkable, should not be called a belgian at all, to big, with not enough spice or orange.

There was not much of an aroma when I had it but that was probably because the bar served it too cold. It is smoothe and has a sweet aftertaste. I still think that this beer is a bit over rated. I need to try Blue Moon at a warmer temperature to make a better judgement.

Comes out of the bottle a cloudy yellow-orange color. Has a promising bubbly head that fades fast with a little lacing. Tastes of orange and wheat malts. Very thin but refreshing. Awesome beer for the hot months.

On tap @ Hemingway’s in Oakland, PGH, PA. Served w/ a lemon slice (instead of orange-yuk) Hazy golden yellow color with white head. Aroma is wheat with spices. Flavor is smooth wheat with light spicing. This is a great, inexpensive summer beer---something that the chicks dig. I paid $1/16 oz. draft at Hemingway’s (the Wed. special).
light, orange-tones, very smooth - a little watery for me.. (im uploading some old mental notes of mine on 100+ beers to this site so i’ll keep it simple, and retaste soon)
Cloudy like a hefeweisen, as it can be for a Whit. Nice spicey phenolic chacter with a slight cwheat flavor. Nice crisp finish good whit

Bottle poured a cloudy gold with a large lasting white head. Aromas of wheat, coriander, some citrus notes and a vegtal nose. Palate was light bodied and smooth yet crisp. Flavors of wheat, coriander, some vegtel notes and a hint of citrus with a smooth refreshing finish.

Cloudy orange pour, rapidly settling white head. The tasting this rating is based on I got a lot of coconut aroma. Normally it’s more along the spicy orange peel line. A spritzy but not overly aggressive carbonation with warm toast and orange sweetness. More substance and flavor than the very low abv (the rating is based on the 3.2 version) would lead you to expect. Very light palate, but not uninteresting. Anti-macro prejudices aside, this a a fine wit. I bought the six I am rating from in a gas station that other that Blue Moon, had nothing but variations on drab American lagers. For the blessings of seriously wide distribution, I am grateful.

Was in my mind one of my top beers.  I don’t know If I am getting it from a different brewery, if one was skunked or what, but one time I loved it, one time it was pretty damn good and this last one I tried was very mediocre.  Each beer was definately inconsistent.

Hazy orange color with large head.  A good amount of flowery taste to it, while still being able to taste the wheat.  Low bitterness.  The lack of a nice hoppy finish really hurts the beer as it leaves for a very lingering finish, and the sweetness can be cloying at times.

Aroma is very light except for a little yeastiness. Colour is yellow/orange and cloudy. It has a lot of carbonation but the white head disappears fast. Taste is light with some refreshing citrus. Palate is very smooth and refreshing. Overall a very nice witbier – even though it doesn’t measure up to the original Hoegaaden Witbier.
Dull gold murky appearance – decent head- nose yeast, dull lemon, nutmeg and clove – honey, citrus, straw and yeast – mouth feel creamy and sparkly aftertaste little bitter citrus taste

Pours fairly typical for the style, although the head isn’t as long lasting as others. The aroma is wheaty with some citrus and an overwhelming amount of floral character. The floral apsects dominate the one dimensional flavor and this one sinks to levels lower than your better wits. Not bad for a US version (or TN for that matter), but certainly not a stand out. Definitely thinner than the better ones from the style. A cheap and refreshing version of the style.
I think this is one of the best mass-production beers on the American market.
Some spice adds to the baking soda flavor.  Fairly refreshing orange flavor, but not exceptional.

Orange color goes along with its orange flavor. It is light but not refreshing.  the first time I had this beer I thought it was pretty good with some good flavor, but as I have gotten more of it, there is nothing to it and it isn’t very good.  The last time I had one I didn’t even finish it.
Quite common to find on tap, seems to be everywhere lately.  Very refreshing, especially in summer.  Already citrusy, and with added orange slice is quite flavorful.

On tap at Hooters.  Pours a very cloudy bright orange with a thin lasting white head, usually served too cold which hurts the head I think.  Aroma is orangey, even if they dont throw the orange in there, with some light wheat malts, citrus, light lemon and some coriander.  Flavor is aslo very citrusy with lots of orange zest, sweet, wheaty and has a slight herbal and hoppy bitterness in the end.  Finishes with a wierd slick zestiness to it, but still easy to drink and sometimes can be refreshing.  Probably not the most authentic in its style, but a great beer to turn people on to craft beer.  It actually has a good amount of flavor to it, so its way better than any other BMC product.
Pours cloudy and orange..Malty and bready with a slight bitter finiish.This is ok when the neighbor gives it to you and you want to be nice.

Orange with lasting white head. Decent nose of orange, mild spice, and some faint yeast. Flavor doesn’t deliver on the citrus or yeast-- malty and somewhat thin, though with a balanced medium-bodied palate and a pleasant tart bite in the finish. A lingering  vague hard candy sweetness is out of place, but all in all this was much better than I was expecting-- beats the hell out of the Silver Bullet. Drank a pile of this back in college and remember it being more lemony and bitter.
doesn’t look very appealing.  very fruity; very bitter finish.  it tastes more like whiskey and water than beer.  didn’t like the brew.

I think it is safe to say that I kinda like this beer.  It’s a decent attempt at a belgian style beer by a huge macrobrewery.  This one is best on tap and with a slice of orange squeezed into it.  Give it a shot.
Bottle. This beer is ok, just on the light side. It falls short on everything. Taste is good but drops off the face of the earth. The finish is the same way. Overall it is ok, but not outstanding.
Nice cloudy yellow orange pour.  This is a great attempt at Hoegaarden, but with less flavor.  No problem with this, a sufficient cheap alternative to the imports.
Nice color of golden amber in the pour, with a decent white head.  Taste is a combination of hops, wheat, and fruity tones.  Finish is clean and crisp.
Hazy orange color with a fizzy off-white head. Sweet spiced aroma. Sweet spiced and lightly citrus flavor.
Good citrusy fruit flavors and scent. Unfiltered, cloudy and appealing look. Nothing stands out but it’s tasty.

This is  light, refreshing, and has some flavor of fruit and spices.  Appearance is a cloudy orange.   It could stand to have a lot more flavor to it, but its mass produced and commonly avaible so its a good choice when you’re out and about.

A very enjoyable beer to drink in the warmer months.  Pour into a frosted mug and drop in a slice of orange.  Get a six pack with your friend on a sunny Saturday evening, and finish it off while enjoying homemade spicy beef jerky and fine conversation.

12 oz bottle.  Orange-yellow beer, thick fast fading white head.  Aroma is typical, big bright coriander citrus, wheaty spice, some sweet malty notes in the back.  Flavour is better than I expected, lemon/orange citrus, coriander.  Bready and slightly wheaty with a bit of caramel in back. The body is a bit thin, but the flavour is pretty decent.
Bottle - Great beer to sip while watching movie or just relaxing.   Obviously unfiltered as solid pieces can be seen floating around.
A little watery, but gorgeous cloudy appearance with a nice creamy but quickly disappearing head. Nice citrus and wheat flavor. Not much of an aroma.

Cloudy blond color with almost no head. Aroma is wheat, yeast and citrus. Flavor of wheat, citrus, and grass. There is a certain distinctness about the flavor that I like, but it doesn’t show much complexity.
Very clean.  Light but still has a definite flavour.  No bite (as expected) but also not too sweet.  A good white.  Grab this one at the supermarket if you’re having trouble finding something good.

Bottle. Pours a nice cloudy yellow.  Decent head.  Smells nice, too- very citrusy and spicey.  Taste is very lemony mixed with spice (cloves?), too. However, there was too much of that lemon-citrus taste, a bit over-powering.  Not bad for the price, but not on my list of must-haves.

Poured hazed yellow with nice creamy froth. Smells of citrus and bananas. Medium nectar with residual effers. This has true wheat characteristics. Good nutty citrus, and banana with no medicinal properties. A good brew.

Pours a light amber, not as light as a true witte.  Aroma is of corriander.  Flavor is light with hints of citrus and corriander.  This isn’t even close to a true Belgian Wit like Hoegardeen or Blache De Bruges, but is still quite tasty.
Belgian is not my usual choice.  I prefer the body and flavor of a Delirium.  This appears to me like a big beer company trying to diversify.  No thanks.

Bottled.  This ale pours a nice orange color with a white head that disappears quickly.  The aroma is slightly fruity and the flavor is the same.  It’s a medium bodied beer that goes down smooth with a sweet finish that lingers a bit at the tip of the tongue.  A nice mellow flavor that goes down easy.

Bottle. Orangey-yellow with a fine white head that quickly disappeared. Sweet aroma with oranges and some spices. Sweet and lots of spicy flavours- there must be quite a mix of coriander, cinnamon?, ginger?, orange zest? Above average carbonation, dry mouthfeel, rather light body. A bit mixed feelings about this one- overspiced as it is, but then again that also makes for some new and interesting flavours.

Draught/bottle - pours nice hazy yellow with hits of citrus in the armoa. Ver light body with hints of citrus in the flavor and rember to kill your bartender if they add a slice of lemon or orange and ruin your wheat beer

Pours a orangish haze.  Has a bit of orange peel zest with some saltiness.  This is supposed o be a belgian white, but if you ever had Hoegardeen then you know this is not a great example.  Still not a bad beer, just nothing special.

Pours a hazy golden yellow. Strong hint of citrus in the aroma. Not thick by any means, but good mouth feel. Taste is dominated by orange and a nice long lasting aftertaste. This beer tastes great and is well reccomended with an orange wedge. Very smooth and refreshing, great summer brew.

Bottle.  Pours just slightly cloudy yellow with a hint of orange.  Thin white head that goes away quickly.  No lacing.  Smells like celery.  Tastes just a hint of orange and spice up front with a celery like finish.  Mouthfeel is really thin and over carbonated.  I seriously have to work to get this down.

This beer carried a lot of buzz with it by my college friends.  Less of a witbier, more of an American wheat.  Pours a hazy tan.  Obvious banana notes.  I was unaware that Coors created this, but, that explains why I can find this in Wal-Mart at 3.2 Alcohol%.  It’s worth a try if you haven’t had it and have no other options.  Oh, make them send it back if they try to put an orange in it.
Bottle sampled beer night at my house with Stegosaurus. Pours hazy golden with a decent fizzy white head, taste is wheat, spice, malty.  Aroma is also good, wheat, spicey sweet, and yeasty.
Love it with an orange - this is one of my favorite beers to get on draft.  good fruits in the flavor and a pleasing aroma.  gets the job done

Just not my cop of tea.  I suppose it beats a Miller any day, but I like my beers big, mean, and exploding with flavor.  This was light and mild.  Maybe good in 90 degree weather while you mow the lawn, but Victory’s Prima Pils would be better yet, so why bother?

Poured to a nice golden color, hazy as expected. Unfortunately, the faomy white head dissipated alomost immediately. This was very light, with a hint of fruit, but no aroma that I could detect. My wife would probably enjoy this, especially ion a warm summer night, but I want more beer taste.

Tap.  Sometimes, when you are not expecting too much, you get pleasantly surprised.  That’s what happened with this beer, nice fruity, citrusy aroma.    Pretty thin body. Sweet flavor, a little too sweet actually, but not bad.  A better witbier than I was expecting.
not too bad... it was pretty sweet, surprsingly enough, and fruity. paleish orangish color with a white head
fruity.golden, pale, clear, aminimal head, medium sweetness, light body, thin feel, lively, Great tasting beer. Almost fruity and cirtrus, but subtle at the same time.

Draught at Crown & Anchor, Las Vegas
Muddy blond color. Too cold; very light aroma; light taste, light citrus fruits. Boring.
This is one of my favorite unfiltered beers.  Pours a pale orange color,  with  medium bodied off white head.  Throw in an orange slice,  and you’ve got a pretty damn good beer.
Enjoyable at first, but as the beer continues it tires the pallete. An orange wedge adds to the flavor, but what beer needs to have flavor added to it?

A friend recommended this beer to me, but unfortunately I was a little bit disappointed. The beer had a bit too much of a "spicy" taste to me, which others may liike, but I found it takes away from the overall flavor and experience.

I am a big fan of Hoegaarden and this is one of my favorite domestic beers and one of the few domestic white beers that I know of.  I love the slightly orange taste and it goes great with a sliced orange on the side.  This is Coors’ best product by far!
Pale orange with white head.  Fruity almost stale orange aromas.  Light and crisp with heavy carbonation.  Tart orange flavors with a spicy bite.

If you can’t find Hoegaarden, this is a great American alternative.  Very smooth with hints of sweetness and slight berry if you drink it straight.  To truly enjoy this beer, add a slice of orange, you won’t be disappointed.

A good beer that without extremely high expectations and finding it fresh with a slice of orange will surprise and please you.  Blue moon is very refreshing and drinkable, a good summer brew.  It is not my favorite, but in a pinch it will suffice. Cloudy, fruity with a hint of spice, Blue Moon is a good session beer.

24mar06 six bottles for $6.17.  My buddy used to drink these when I drank  "cheapest avab."  I thought they were orange peels in a bottle at the time, but after starting to rate and drink,  I don’t think its as orangeY as I once thought.   solid pulp color with fruit finish.

Nice cloudy orange/rusty colored beer.  My favorite thing about it was the way it looked.  Something about cloudy drinks always get me.  But the flavor seemed to be lacking something very important and there wasn’t really that much to it.  Not bad for a Coors product.

Had this at the Geneva Metra station bar last December 2005. Very good. It had a citrus, mellow taste and finish. Reminded me of Sierra Nevada and Fuller’s Pale Ale. Not bad for an Belgian White produced by an American brewing giant.

Cloudy light gold, smooth.  a little tart, mostly sweet.  i find it goes best in a "black and blue" (like a black and tan).  Drinking it on its own leaves something to be desired.  i also do not enjoy twist off caps.

It’s no Hoegaarden but it’s better than pale lager, in my opinion.  Appropriately cloudy, not much aroma, way too light on the spice to really be a good imitation of a witbier but relatively smooth and pleasantly tart.  Most of my girlfriends love this beer.

Poors cloudy yellow with white head. I should have known from the peppery aroma I was not going to like this one. Pepper/spicy flavor overpowered the experience. Just not what I am looking for in a beer.

The beer I first considered my favorite.  Not anymore, but still enjoyable.  The thing that always sticks out in my mind is the punch of spicy citric flavor. So refreshing.  the aftertaste is nice as well, very mellow.  A special beer in my mind.

This is the beer that got me interested in beer to begin with, so I may have a slight bias. I had the privelege of having this last night at the Texas Roadhouse, and I was shocked when I saw the "Blue Moon" sign when I entered the building. I had no choice to but to sit down, have a burger, and have a couple Blue Moons. The appearance is not typical of a Belgian White, it looks rather orangey/goldish and had a 1/2 inch white head. The smell was full of spice and orange. It seems as though orange is a theme with this beer. The taste was superb, and the mouthfeel can only be described as refreshing. It was nicely carbonated, smooth, little aftertaste. The flavor had a nice citrus tang, and the beer was on the sweeter side. This beer is a great beer to have for any occassion, and it certainly appeals to those who claim they don’t like beer. Both myself and my cousin became interested in beer after drinking this fabulous brew. The fact that it is from Coors may make some of you pass it up, but please, try it at least once. It is a nice surprise.

Interesting, if nothing else.  The first thing that struck me was the nose of this beer.  I kid you not, notes of furniture polish and Pine-Sol hit me like a ton of bricks.  Everything about this beer screams "Macro trying hard here!"  It almost tries to seem hefe-esque.  The pour tries for a yeasty cloudiness, but ends up more like a muck.  The sweetness teeters on cloying, but passes just under the radar (and I mean "JUST under").  Wheat, citrus and melon notes to the taste, and a syrupy cane finish that reminds me of "Apple Jacks" cereal.  It’s a wheat, and I certainly applaud Coor’s for trying here, but it’s almost ruined by the finish.  I don’t recommend for a session beer, as I wouldn’t want this taste lingering in my mouth the next morning.

Blue moon is, I admit, not the top teir of wheat ale. Most bars tout it as a hefeweisen, since it’s so clowdy and orange. It isn’t as tangy and bitter as Whitbiers should be, but it is still tasty. It’s VERY impressive for a macrobrew. I prefer it to hefeweissens like Paulaner and Pyramid and many micro whibiers. Not bad for how cheap this stuff is.
Blue Moon is a decent choice at a bar that doesn’t have too many options but the flavor does not last as long as I would like.  Every time I drink one I feel like there should have been more.

This was a disappointment.  Partly because it had replaced Pilsner Urquell (one of my favorites) at my bar of choice, but the lack of depth is enough to back up any negative bias I already had.  The flavor might have been interesting...  if it had lasted for more than a tenth of a second.  If you’re in the mood for a belgian beer, get Chimay or Hoegaarden.  If I’d known that it was brewed by Coors, I’d have stayed a mile away from it.  All the faux-Belgian-ness in the world can’t hide what this beer really is: another fizzy yellow imitator.  Truly disappointing.
Is this from Coors?  Makes you go hmmm...  This is really not that bad, but the style is not my thing.
Poured yellow cloudy with minimal white head.  Spicy/sweet flavor with a very sweet finish.  Not a bad beer, but just not really my cup of tea.

Thanks for the bottle Brad! CLoudy yellow liquid sits under a frothy white head. Lots os sweet spices in the nasal category. Curacao, corriander and some clove give way to flavours akin to the aroma, with extra sweetness on the finish. Decent citric acidity bite to it as well. A good wit. Thanks BeerandBLues2!
good beer overall for an american made belgian white. a bit too sweet finish. good flavor but the sweetaftertaste brings it slightly down
Awesome taste, a little bit of orange, maybe a doughy flavor.  Very good....

Very cloudy, copper colored, what it lacks in smell it makes up for in taste.

My favorite beer yet.

Oh, and a LONG lasting taste.  Citrus and wheat, slightly bitter.

Hazy gold color with a quickly disappearing white head. Very little aroma, hard to tell but wheat with maybe just a hint of orange. Decent flavor but hey I would take a witbier over most anything else out there so I may be biased. Citrus and wheat again with an ever so slight bitter end. Really nice with a slice of orange or lemon.
Had this one on tap at a sports bar. Not much to say about this one, good or bad. I really enjoy most witbier’s and I did this one too although it wasn’t anything spectacular.

Cloudy, orangish gold coloring with a soapy white head that diminishes very quickly to almost no head.  Very gross looking clumps of yeast speckle the beer and collect on the bottom of the glass.  Some mild citrusy aromas of lemon and orange, but is smells old and fermented.  Texture is rather thin and watery, but the flavors are OK.  Some refreshing orange notes.  Thin, watery finish.
Bottle: Cloudy, initial heavy white head but fads quickly. No aroma at all. Taste is wheaty, creamy, refreshing. A good Belgium Whitbeer.

it’s a menial beer. girly, definitely.   i agree. but i’m giving it a high rating because a lot of times it’s the best beer on tap, and a lot of those times it is more that satisfactory: it’s good.  i see we have it at below 50%.  i don’t really agree with that.  it doesn’t pour particularly well, it lacks any real aroma, its aroma is neglibile.  but it does what it’s supposed to do, and it does it very well.  i’m surprised, incidentally, to see it at 5.4 % abv.  i would have guessed this to be in the pride and joy neighborhood (around 4.8 i think).  anyways.  the point is, as strange tasting a beer this is, it’s often a passable option at shitty bars, and i thank it for that.  and, since i should put up something positive: it has reasonable flavor.  neither overly complex, nor underpowered for what it’s meant to do.  rerate: too spicy and too carbonated.

My new lawnmower beer for next summer.   Refreshing - carbonated -served in a pint glass from the bottle with a slice or orange.

I recommend it for what it is - a pleasant brew.

I wish I had tried this before it was a Coors beer, but I hadn’t.  Anyway, it’s a refreshing beer with a citrusy earthy quality.  Goes down smooth and finishes clean with a mild spice note.  I wouldn’t call it Belgian, but it’s not bad for an all night beer.  Interestingly, I prefer it out of the bottle.
An incredibly good copy of a Belgian Wit and its made by Coors nonetheless.
Bottle. Minimal smell, flavor and texture. Easy to drink, and slightly better than anything else made by Coors, but not by much.
Probably the best aroma I have experienced. This is just what I have been seeking in  a wheat beer. Definitely worth while.
12 oz bottle. Aroma is wheat. Flavor starts out sweet with a hint of blueberries but fades fast and goes a little bitter. Not bad but not my favorite.

Pours a cloudy golden color with thick head that thins pretty quickly.  Aroma is of citrus and wheat.  Flavor is the same but seems watered down and doesn’t last very long.  Definately not the greatest beer out there but not the worst either.

(12 oz bottle: Hi-Time Wine Cellars in Costa Mesa, CA) Spicy coriander aroma is most noticeable, with a lightly sweet wheat aroma in the background.  Obvious coriander flavor is tempered by a fairly strong bready wheat maltiness, strong relative to most in this style, that is.  Lightly sweet and gently bitter, and all taken together, it’s just not a pleasant flavor, especially as it warms up (i.e., drink it cold!).  The flavor drops off quickly in the finish, which isn’t necessarily a bad thing here.  Light bodied with a watery finish, moderately carbonated, but it still gets kind of stale on the palate.  Golden in color and fully cloudy.  Wafer thin white head quickly dissipates completely, leaving an ugly looking liquid and nothing else.  Not enjoyable, what more need I say?

Berry and banana with a touch of buttery malt on the nose. Appears a cloudy golden color with no head but some fizz in the glass. Flavor is citrus with hints of berry and lemon grass. Some spices on the tongue. Medium to light watery body with a decent fizz. Not a bad brew but then not a great brew either.

I really enjoyed this beer.  I am not the most well versed beer drinker, but I can tell a great difference between this and Natural Light.  I do think, however, that because it is brewed in America a lot of these beer snobs automatically turn their noses up at it.  I say, turn the glass up.  Aroma is okay, but the taste is where its at.  Fruity and sweet, but spicy as well.  Very easy on the palate, and the aftertaste isn’t that of a pile of dirty hops.  Yum yum.

Nice golden unfiltered look.  Not much head.  Nice flavor of blueberry and citrus with a touch of wheatiness. Extremely smooth and drinkable however a bit one-dimensional.  No bitterness at all.  A good beer to get slammed on, however it is disapointing to sip on and enjoy.

12 oz. bottle poured a thick white head that collapsed quickly, leaving no lacing after a few drinks.  The smell seemed earthy if anything; I couldn’t pick up much for aroma. The taste is almost non-descript as well, almost like a pale lager with less carbonation.  It doesn’t taste bad by any means, but can’t really say a beer that tastes like nothing is great, but I can say it’s drinkable.
A favorite around these parts.  Wheaty/sweet taste, aroma of wheaty berries, lingering white head.  Great with a slice of orange as garnish.

About what I imagine a pint glass full of cat urine would taste like.  This seems to be a popular beer in Wisconsin, but then again, people in Wisconsin will swill anything as long as it’s got alcohol.
Very interesting taste (but that may be because I general like anything of this style).  Smells of blueberry waffles.  Tastes wheaty with hints of berries.  Slightly sweet taste as well

This is the only thing from Coors that I would call "good". It pours a hazy yellowish color and smells rather fruity. A light refreshing flavor, apricots and citrus come to mind. While certainly not anywhere nearly as good some of the other white ales out there, it serves as a easy introduction into wheat beers for those who want to venture out into new territory. Easy to drink, mild but noticable flavors and an easy-on-the-wallet price make this a perfect gateway beer.
A nice golden pour with a fluffy head.  Nice and tasty, a very nice belgain ale from a macro brewer.

Pour a smooth, light golden beer with a thick head.  Aroma somewhat spicy with hops overtones.  Taste very sweet with a shampoo-like aftertaste.  Not a bad beer if you like creamy Belgian whites.  Decent emulation.
not bad, but not wonderful.  A decent beer for a macro, amoma is good malty, yeasty and spicy.  flavor is good slightly watery.

From the bottle, pours a hazy pale yellow with a foamy white head.  No lacing on the glass, but the head doesn’t immediately fade.  Aromas of bitters, citrus, and yeast.  Tastes smooth from the start to the finish, and has a thicker feel than some other Belgians.  Tastes of oranges and lemons, with some yeasty flavors at the end.  Really no aftertaste.  Not my favorite Belgian, but not bad.

Draft. Pours like a typical Belgian wit, cloudy golden, with a wisp of a head. Slight slight Aroma of orange peel, wheat malt, and spice. Texture was a tad watery and fizzy, but flavor was of yeast, coriander, and wheat malt. Not an outstanding example of the style, but still drinkable. A good beer to use for weaning BMC drinkers off bad beer

"Pour a cloudy golden color. Different for a beer, one to end a night of drinking with. Very smooth and creamy. Has a nice citrus aroma and flavor. Couldn’t drink many at the same time but a nice beer."

Blue Moon, a mass produced (Coors!) Belgian White, looks and tastes like a goodwill effort on the behalf of brewing magnates to pry Americans from their dear and all too near cans of pale lager and into something a bit more sophisticated.  While it may not always be successful in stomping out a passionate community of withered lager drinkers, the Blue Moon takes steps to wean them off their sickly addiction and into something with more depth.  When I was a wee lad I was introduced to good beer by means of a Witbier: Hoegaarden.  Sadly, Hoegaarden is just a bit too foreign and a tad too hard to spell for the average Yankee to pick up and enjoy.  So to me Blue Moon is a good prologue to what will hopefully be many long and elaborate chapters of the book of elegant beers.  I was well into my beerological career by the time I had Blue Moon, but ordered a glass on the hypothetical premise that I had missed something potentially crucial to my education.  A scholar of literature has an equal obligation to read Jane Austen as he does to read J.K. Rowling for the same reason that both have an impact on the reading community, even though they are of disparate depths.  So the same applies here, though I can’t make any vainglorious claims to a superior understanding of beer.  As for the Blue Moon itself, the color is a very cloudy apricot orange, topped with a thin and ethereal head.  The smell is linear; a pinch of citrus and the rest is fairly yeasty.  The taste is extremely difficult for me to pick apart; I want to say it reminds me of weak salsa or corn meal, but those make it sound less appealing than it is.  The flavor may be elusive, but it isn’t complex.  It is sufficient to say that it’s miles above Coors’ popular swill, and should be used as a guiding hand when helping a victim of bad beer to find the shining path to a delicious beer future.

Was that a beer I just drank?  It looked like a beer?  It fizzed a little, had a little white head that disappeared and was kind of a hazy off gold color.  Buit I couldn’t smell anything.  It was as if water was in my glass.  And taste?  Hmm . . . not sure.  I guess it tasted like beer - nothing distinguishable or noteworthy.  I followed it up with something else just to make sure my taste bud-switch had not been put in the off position.

Pours a cloudy light orange color.  Aroma of orange citrus with some floral accents.  Light orange citrus taste - difficult to describe, but imagine drinking something with a beer body and a subdued orange zest flavor.

One of my favorite bar beers.
