This turned out to be a good beer. Light, slightly sweet flavor with hints of clove, banana and sweet relish. The spice came through as it warmed, good overall.

Nice big head on tap at Bottom Lounge in Chicago.  Citrusy, almost a sour sweet, hoppy and very drinkable.  Very good beer that is rather common when you can’t find something else that is different or want to drink something familiar.
Not the worst brew I’ve ever had. Pours a cloudy yellow/orange with a white head. Taste is sweet, malty, citrusy and a little spicey. Doesn’t taste like a true Belgian beer. OK
A nice but different type of beer. You can taste the different spices distinctly. I was impressed to see coors owned it.
A quite impressive spiced white from Coors.  Similar to the Hoegaarden mold, but much less complex in taste.  Nice summer beer.
Very unique taste, the first belgian beer I’ve had.  It made me want to sing. Babababa ba-ding-a-dong-ding Blue Moon.

Cloudy dark golden color...which I think is pretty.  Quickly diminishing head.  This beer has lots of potential on the first taste...flavors that could go more directions on the finish, but don’t.  Sweet, wheat, malty.  Pretty sweet finish.  Would personally prefer more hopps, but se la vie.

bottle - poured a nice head which disapated quickly - dark yellow - light malty smell incldes spice and citrus. The wheat taste is noticable, and a lightly fruity. Wheat sediment in bottom of glass when done. Very good beer coming from a macro-brewer.

This Witbier is suprisingly light-bodied and less wheaty than the Bavarian wheats. It is a great summer brew and a great inoffensive beer for everyone. It is light enough for the American lager favorers, yet complex enough for most afficionados of any style.

Pours a hazy straw color, minimal head that dies quickly.  Smells of banana, spice, and bubblegum.  Flavor is citrusy, slightly malty, then citrusy again ending with a weak sweetness.  No bitterness at all.  Not good, but not bad.

Brewery--on tap.

Pale yellow with a slight chill haze.  Head is minimal.

Nose:  faint maltiness with citrus and a bit of spice, but subdued as hell as you would imagine from BMC.

watery moutfeel.

Poured a large white head.  Didn't last too long and no lacing.  The brew is a hazy golden color.  Smells fruity.  Tastes of mild wheat with fruity overtones.  This is a great beer from a major brewery.

Bottle. Thick orange looking beer. Cloud-like wisps in the glass. Very light filmy head and film left on the side of the glass. Light aroma, more peppery spice than fruit, no yeast. Taste starts with spice, then fruit. A little spice in the finish. Tangerine body. Nice and interesting with the right ingredients but the whole seems to be light on the beer side - more like a cooler.
A good beer that you can find on draught at alot of places. Pours cloudy with a decent white head. A good mix of spices and fruit in this one make it a good choice.
A great beer. Turst me on this one lose the masculine look and try this beer.  A great white, very light in the stomach and great berry taste.
Tried only one of these when I was a bit wasted.  I remember it was quite tasty and little dark.  Would definately buy again.
I give Coors credit for realizing that they need to try something new.  Some fruit, coriander, and banana odors.  Tastes wheaty, citrusy, fruity, and smooth at the finish.  Not bad.
This is a pretty good beer, but I think I am just spoiled by hogaarden and alagash. But, i am impressed considering the fact that it is made by coors and i can find this commonly in grocery stores.

Becoming increasingly popular here in Connecticut, Blue Moon Belgian White is a welcome addition to any tap!  Very smooth with a nice wheaty consistency.  Cloudy. Decent head. Nice subtle presence of caramel and some banana. Taste is a little flat but is greatly enhanced by the addition of a slice of orange (!) or lemon.
Bottle.  Poured cloudy with a decent head.  Nice citrus and wheat aroma and flavor.  Overall good but there are other wheat beers I would prefer over this one.

Cloudy light amber/orangey color. Sweet, banana/fruity aroma.  Wheat flavors, with a bit of citrusy tartness - although it gets smoother and less biting when it warms up.  Not bad, but not real disctincitve.
interesting scent, wheat, some banana. First taste, instantly thought bananas the fruit, not the candy. Tastes like a wheat beer, not too original. Smooth and very drinkable.

Nice simmering cloud in the glass.  Served to me on tap with a lemon, which suffused beautifully through the top of the beer as I went down the glass.  Mild spices that compliment the citrus well.  Had at Daisy Buchanan's in Boston, my only regret is that their glasses seemed a bit small.  Beer has a bit of radiance to it as well.  Distinctive, but doesn't necessarly make an impression if you're looking to hit on people in a bar, I'd imagine.
THe beer was a beautiful golden brown with a nice aroma but the aftertaste left something to be desired, to say the least.

Hazy golden body with orange highlights and some sediment, quickly vanishing white head. Aroma is wheaty with hints of fruit and spices. Mouthfeel is very bubbly, like seltzer. Somewhat bland on the palate, this beer has lots of understated fruit flavors. Finishes with a pleasing sweetness. Decent wheat ale but nothing like a Belgian Witbier.
Good smell and initial taste, but the aftertaste is very chemical. Not my favorite.
a wonderful american version of a belgian withbier.  Pours a light orange in color with a thick white head.  Flavors of beglian yeast, slight citrus, and a little honey.  Very smooth going down.

I think this beer would be rated higher if people did not know it was a Coors product. That said, there are a number of wit beers out there that are better.I have had this beer a number of times both draft and bottle. The draft is a bit better but this rating is for the bottle. +++ Sampled from a 12 oz brown bottle this beer pours a tan - orange color with a small white head that quickly fades. The aroma is sweet, tangy and has a hint of orange. The flavor is relatively light with hints of citrus and spice. Pretty pleasant despite being the wrong color. A decent beer especially in placed that do not have much in the way of good beer.

Medium white head atop a cloudy yellow brew.  Citrus-spice aromas.  Good, smooth mouthfeel and citrusy flavor.  Has the distinctness of a wheat beer without the yeasty bread overtones of an in-bottle fermentation.
-Had on tap-

Poured a small white head with a pineapple juice like body.  Had a citris and spiced aroma.  The flavor was orangey, spicy, light hint of hops, little to no malty flavor.  The texture is very bubbley, and slightly watery.  Not my favorite, but interesting enough to get a good rating because it never gets old.

Not much a smell to this, for a belgian style, or a wheat ale, let alone both.  Decent look to it, but nothing exciting either.  Flavor was a tad on the sweet side, with not much wheat to it.  Palate just wasnt to my liking either, it was nice, but it sure could use a little kick to it.

Pours a hazy orange with creamy white head. 

Smells okay with some fruity, spicy notes. 

The taste is sweet and mild but really lacks depth. Supposedly modeled after Hoegardenn but falls very flat. 

The mouthfeel is smooth but thin and its drinkability is hurt by the fact that it is uninteresting.

note: A year and a half ago I would have said this is one of the best beers ever, but what did I know then, nothing. However this beer showed me then that there were more out there than AB, Miller, and Coors (I found out later that coors made this). So I think this is the one that helped me bridge the gap from nothing to something. Although I'll admit I wasn't old enough to be drinking it and shouldn't have known better. 

side note: I'm now a bartender and wonder what the fascination with the orange slice in this beer is. I know it makes it cool but...nevermind

Very citrusy nose from the head, all the way down. The beer is appropriately cloudy and light colored. It's a lot sweeter than many beers - not a malty sweet, though. It tastes almost like a cross between a beer and an orangey cider. Being a big cider fan, I like this a lot, but as a beer, it is definitely a little off drom the norm. What wheaty malt taste there is hangs around on the tongue for several minutes after drinking. The hops don't seem to get more pronounced as you get to the warmer beer on the bottom of the glass or bottle.

good looking cloudy pale orange color with small white head.  sweet aroma candy and malt with some bananna and grape coming out.  nice smooth wheaty body with definite bananna coming through...very decent for a macro.

Nice orange colored pour. Fluffy white head which quickly recedes to a film.  Active carbonation.  Currently dealing with spring allergies, so no real aroma to me.  Taste is rather citrusy (no twist)... orange predominantly, some spice, bananna hints, pleasant wheat on the palette.  Crisp, smooth finish.  Not too bad at all.  This is pretty cheap over here in Atlanta... I can see myself going through a few of these these summer.  Extra point or two for Coors actually making something good.

Draft, with and without a twist of orange.  Cloudy yellow color with a billowy white head that settles quickly.  Slightly spicy, wheaty aroma.  Mild citrus dominated flavor - very sweet and fruity with the addition of the orange twist.  Light body and easy carbonation.  Is this a macro???  Not too bad.
Better than I expected. Moderately sweet with a bit of spicyness. I hate to say it, but putting an orange in it makes it a lot better.

This beer fares poorly for a supposed belgian white.  I cannot get past the sickly sweet taste, it literally makes my teeth hurt its so sweet.  Light taste of citrus, quickly over powered by the sweetness.  It looks far more complex than it is with a cloudy pale yellow.  I suggest adding oranges or other citrus fruit to add more flavor.

I'm torn here, really. On the one hand, I have a difficult giving anything owned by a mega an even break. On the other hand, I'm thinkin' that if it introduces a fairly obscure style (to most American tastes) to a wider audience, then applaud it. Or maybe I could just rate it, and quit whining. So here goes.  Cloudy dark goldish orange. Nice white head.  Orange smell.  Tang, actually, plus some, I don't know, cinnamon?  Fluffy mouthfeel. Citrus, mild wheat, vanilla flavors. dryish finish, kinda like an American wheat. Decent beer from Coors.

I too had this beer served with an orange.  That was fine, I guess.  It's kind of orangey yellow like cheap OJ.  Nice head, thick and tall.  Uncomplex, regular, average, beer.  It looks fancier than I think it is.  A bit of savory spice that matched well with the citrus flavor.  Not bad, but kind of pricey.

OK, so it's not Hoegaarden. we know this. But it's not that bad. I had it served with an orange by a few HOT promo girls. Yeah that makes it go down a little easier. Not a bad Coors beer for what it is. 

Re-rate July June 30, 2004. This is total drainpour. So the server wasn't as hot as last time but the beer sucked hard. Who actually goes out and buys this swill?

An interesting experience.  Poured a thick, hazy, orange that reminded me of pineapple juice.  Solid particles danced around in streams of carbonation under a bubbly white head.  Aroma was crisp, spicy, and rather fruity.  This led me to expect a sweet, fruity flavor, but I was pleasantly surprised by a thick, wheaty flavor that was quite enjoyable. A light palate, but one that accompanied the flavor well.  This beer was different than any others I've tried, and I enjoyed the experience.

Not bad! Pours a cloudy orange blond with a medium white head. Nose is spice, wheat, and light notes of fruit. Definite spice, and yeast along with more wheat on the tongue. The finish seemed to lean on the sweeter, fruitier than expected side. Very good for a macro brewed beer.

I've lived in Colorado for three years now and this is the first time that I have tried this beer.  And I like it!  There's nothing here to jump out and grab you, but it has a clean, pleasant taste and is thirst quenching.  Nothing wrong with that!

This murky, orange/brown beer smells a lot like brown sugar.  Sweet orange taset followed with a yeasty brown sugar aftertaste.  A bit better than I remember.  There’s a bar in Lancaster that serves these poured over an orange slice which is pretty good, too.
i agree with other people this is kinda fruity and has a hint of spice its very mild tasting its a very light beer but good with mexican food

this beer poured cloudy yellow with thin white head.   i didn't detect much of aroma.  the taste was a weak mix of spice and fruit.  this is an ok beer, slightly better than most of the tasteless big name macro-brews.
smell alternates between decent fruity and plain rank. murky yellow-orange. however, taste is enjoyable, and unique.
Saw it in Michael Jakson's Untimate Beer book and thought, why not?  Bad.  Nothing to commend itself.
Blue Moon had a very nice flavor and the aftertaste was a nice sweet but not too sweet taste.  I would defienlty get this again.

smells like cloves, banana, sythentically sweetened grape bubblegum.  looks like cloudy piss with first-in-the-morning style head.  tastes OK.  like a good belgian white that was artificially sweetened... and a bit sour.   i had a bad experience with this.  though i've had it before, i ordered a pint just so i could rate it based on fresh observations.  i had 1 pint.  it was my only pint of the day.  five minutes afterwards, i puked.  this doesn't sit in my stomach well.  thanks,  coors.

Appearance: cloudy golden (like apple cider) with decent head that seemed to last a bit.

Smell: strange, at first reminded me of soap... then the scent kicked in: the smell was that of one of those urinal "breath mints."

Taste: tasted just like it smelled, but not really soapy. Instead, floraly, and fruity. Better than average taste, since it's kinda strange, but definitely not something I'd drink more than one at a time.

Mouthfeel: not bad... feels like it tastes and smells.

Drinkability: One is drinkable, two is not. This is a one-a-night beer. More than that would upset the stomach, as it's too fruity and filling (or maybe after awhile the constant smell of the urinal "breath mint" would send you gagging.)

Yellowish slight haze. Medium-light body with mild bitterness. Tropical fruit aromas. This seems to have significant amounts of citrus flavoring. Clean finish with mild floral hop notes. Certainly the best beer that Coors makes but still not great.
A bit a coriander and orange flavor, but that is about it.  Another one of those beers that college students think is the best beer in the world.

Considering it is made in a macro this is not a bad beer.  Blue Moon was my first experience with a wheat, and while I’ve since found that the true Belgian beers are better this one will do in a pinch.
One of the worst Belgian ales I've ever tasted.....not impressed. Not as bitter as a belgian ale should be, but then again it's coors...so that speaks for itself
God, if more college students knew about this stuff.... The world would be a better place.
Coors actually made a beer that has nuances of true witbier.  I'm impressed.  Nice yeasty nose and flavor.  Plenty of malt.  I'm a fan.  Thick ole head, medium bodied.

This is what people rave about???  This beer is confused as to what it is trying to be.  Its got WAY to much coriander, not enough orange.  Not enough wheat, lots of froth.  Coors really needs to re-think this one....

(Bottle) Preface: I know zilch about Witbier.  That being said, I like the malt and citrus aroma, not so wild about the hazy gold color, but it sounds like that is the trait of a witbier.  The foamy head is very light and dissipates quickly, leaving almost no lacing.  The flavor is OK- cardamon? is interesting, I like the wheaty aftertaste, even though I prefer a little more hops "bite" than this provides, but again, I'm not sure that's expected of a witbier.  I'd have to be in the mood for this, but I'd drink it again.  This is good enough to make me try some "true" Belgian Whites.
This is no Celis, but pleasant for a Coors product. It is even better when you can find it on tap.
This was pretty popular back in college.  You were high class if you drank this stuff, and you probably listened to dave mathews if you drank this.

Draft:  A little dark for a Belg. Wit style, but it has a nice lasting white head.  Pleasant orange citrus aroma with hints of ginger; wheat malt and lightly sour aroma.  I don't really pick up on any coriander, then again I'm in a bar!  Slightly tart, yeasty, and wheat malt;  lightly citrusy and acidic.  Waitress comes by with a fantastic smelling rose floral perfume.  Very nice, but not when rating a beer!  Spicy flavor, but not clovey and I can't quite place it at this time.  There is a little bit of a biting acidity, but oddly smooth mouthfeel and lighter body.  Carbonation is on the high side.  Much better on draft than from a bottle, and this is a pretty decent versin from an American brewery.

Tap.  Consumed on the ski sloped of Mt. Heavenly, in the middle of a day of ripping up my knees.  Nicely done; it lives up to its title of "Best of the beasts".  Murky-yellow, lightly spicy.  Not complex but crisp, fruity, easy, good.  Great for a macro.
This was a very pleasant tasting beer.  Smooth, complex flavors not bitter or sour and a smooth clean finish.  I will be drinking this again & again.   Definetly a must try!
Hazy yellow-orange with a thin head.  An aroma of annis?  Lightly bittered by smooth, somewhat orange-rind tinged.  Hardly "Belgian".
Not much going on here. Thin and watery with no direction. I don't see how this is a Belgian White. It's a good thing Blue Moons don't occur very often.
Very nice beer with a fruit complex.  No bitterness noted, with very little aftertaste.
Slightly hazy straw body, small white head recedes quickly, citrus/coriander nose. Very light flavor.

With a lemon wedge it's a great beer, with an orange slice it's beyond compare.  I discovered this one on special at a bar in Nashville, TN.  Now that I live in Cincy, I'm glad it knows no boundries.  It's also the first beer that my father and I agree on.

Orange cloudy pour, a nice white head, but it really didn't last as long as it should have.  Nice aroma of spices, orange, and yeast.  Lemon and orange taste with a sweetness at the end, becoming dry.  An easy to drink beer.  Perhaps not a textbook sample, but a good introduction to the style because it drinks so easily if the sweetness doesn't bother you.

Draught, at Durgin Park, Boston, MA.
 Wheat beer severed with a slice of lemon. Moderately flavoured to appeal to more people than would a full blown wheat beer. Perhaps that’s giving them more credit then they deserve. The beer finishes with a peculiar sweet finish.
Very rich taste. Many different flavors going on here. Also very light and goes down easy.

Opaque orange amber coloring..like a harvest moon.  Aroma was of oranges, cinammon and lemon. There was no head at all and it was very smooth with the taste being very much like the aroma; oranges, lemon and some spice to it.  A very decent mellow beer.

Bottle.  Cloudy golden yellow color with a foamy white head.  Wheaty aroma with only a hint of the citrus zest of the style.  Some banana and fruits int he aroma.  Medium body with a grainy dry finish.

Damn good white beer!  nice touch of spice with a great alomst golden color. This brew is a little taste of belgium brewed right here in the u.s.a. of course not as good but as good as you are to find here in the states. Good price for a 6 pack is also a plus.
Hints of spices, nice aroma but a little modest on the flavor especially for a wheat brew.  The first is refreshing but the fruitiness almost becomes too much after that.
Cloudy gold color. Fresh aroma but not really distintive. Not as much as normal Belgian White. To the taste you can#t feel the yeast, orange peel nor coriander. At least it feels fresh.
Cloudy gold color. Sweet fruity aroma with a fruity smooth flavor. Wheat taste is light from start to finish. Finishes rather dry with a little bitterness. Not bad for a Macro!
Hard to believe this is really a macro. The people I know who don't know beer yet want to sound sophisticated always get this. There was a nice fruity flavor and a little bit of spiciness.
very mild.  not enough flavor, but smooth and really easy to drink.  slice of orange was alright I guess.  white head didn't last very long; some nice spices but nothing too impressive.

Draft at California Bar @ Harrah's Tahoe.  Decent macro white beer, with enough flavor to drink on its own.  However I found adding a few drops of lemon juice gave it a sweeter, more drinkable flavor.

Thin head which dissipates quickly.  Nice fruity aroma with lemon, honey, spices and a little orange.  Color is a slightly murky light orange/gold.  Flavor is fruity also with more oranges, lemons and taste of wheat.  Finish is a little sour which is nice and a bit dry.  Would recommend this beer but don't think that too many will enjoy the sour aftertaste
Initially there is a strikingly sweet taste, ends with a hint of citrus. Decent body, wheat taste is apparent, pretty good beer.
a very interesting aftertaste, a bit fruit-ay but know complaint, not something i drink to excess, a bit heavy at times but a good beer to drink when  dining or pining

My first experience with a Belgian White.  Nice aroma with a neat almost fruity but bold flavor.  Nice beer to have at a bar with a friend but I wouldn't reccomend more than one or two at a time since too many will leave you feeling full
Its a really good wheat beer with a refreshing slightly sweet, smooth taste. It tastes really natural, and the wheat it is brewed with comes through with a nice wheat taste.
Blue moon is one of the best belgian whites I have ever tasted.  Good strong wheat flavour but no harsh aftertaste and its still easy to drink.  I like it a lot.
Pale gold in color and slightly cloudy. Has a slightly sweet aroma and tastes Belgiany, but on the sweet side. Different, but very good.
(Draught)  Poured a hazy maze color with a little to no head.  Tasted like a very watered down Belgian wheat beer.
Cloudy yellow color with a light citrus aroma.  Sweet malts and spicy hops.  Definitely good considering it comes from Coors.
This is not a bad beer. It tastes like a water down version of a belgium white beer. For the money I would go with the Saranac Hefewiezen over this.
Golden color with white head. Nice smell with a hint of orange. A pretty good beer.

It has a nice yellow color with a hint of orange, and a somewhat creamy head. The aromas are somewhat fruity, like citrus and a hint of banana. The taste is rather clean with a slightly creamy mouthfeel. While I think my buddy was expecting more from a belgium white style beer, it is not a bad beer at all. Definitely refreshing, it is a good warm weather beer, and would make a good compromise between truly good beer and the macro stuff. Very easy to drink a few of these.
Cloudy golden color, white head. Wheaty and spicy nose and flavor with a hint of orange. Decent, especially for an offshoot of Coors.
I enjoy this beer with the expected orange slice, but the beer by itself is enhoyable also. Veyr cloudy and pale color with alot of good undertones.

I can't believe that this is a Coors product. They did good buying these rights. The beer is light orange, and has orange undertones in both the scent and the flavor. Good wheat beer but not the best in this style at all. Better on tap than in the bottle. Orange slice brings out more of the orange flavor but is better without.

9/11/03:  on tap. 
 great orange-sunshine body with no head or lacing.  white bread nose.  orange and wheat flavors.  crisp and clean.
A strange tasting brew.  Taste like clove and maybe ginger with fruit to boot.  Become pretty tolerable after about half a bottle.

pours a hazy gold with little head. some fruit in the nose with a yeasty 
wheat. sweet malt with more fruit in the flavor. can't quite put my finger 
on what i'm tasting at the finish.  A pretty good belgium wheat.
this wasn't too bad.  at first the taste kind of bothered me, but after the first beer, i got used to it and grew to like it.  good stuff.

was rather surprised by this beer after picking up a 6 pack. Let it settle in my home kegerator for 2 days, then cracked one open. None of the things I dislike about regular ales. I liken it to hot-apple cider flavors mixed with a mild ale. very drinkable. I may get a 1/6bbl for my kegerator soon
Draft. Strong banana, some clove. Not as smooth as the better Belgian Whites. Enjoyable, but mid-glass started taking on a less clean finish.
Hazy yellow color with a small white head. The aroma and flavor were that of tomato juice and rotten peaches...absolutely disgusting. Decent bubbly, crisp feel.

Hazy oragne/golden body with a dense, white head.  Smells clean with fruity hops, wheat and tapioca.  Mouth feel is thin bodied and mild. Taste is blueberry, wheat, slight citrus, yeast, and white peppercorn. Aftertaste is nearly non-existant, just some residual blueberry. Overall, an interesting flavored (blueberry!), readily available beer. Shared a pitcher of this with jgb9348 (see below) from a fresh keg at the Cinema 'N' drafthouse in Arlington, VA.

Hazy orange & gold colour with a 2 centimetre thick white head. Pretty nice looking, though! Smells of pepper, blueberry, yeast and citrus. Tastes of blueberry, wheqat, white pepper and a subtle hoppiness. Some maltiness in the palate with a bunch of spicyness. A fairly strong flavoured wheat with some odd tastes, but very interesting and unique. Good from Coor's as well, because it's probably one of their only few 'quality' beers. Overall a decent wheat...I don't think i'd consider it a white, but it wasn't great and it wasn't horrible. Worth a try, because most likely, it is available to you! I shared a pitcher of this with JonR888710 from draught at the Arlington Cinema 'N' Drafthouse in Arlington, Virginia.
was a refreshing beer.. not the same spice flavor as some other belgian whites, but I enjoyed it.. served with an orange slice, which complimented it well.

Yellow tint and not very cloudy.  It also has a quickly diminishing head.  The smell is spicy.  I taste a little coriander.  It is sweet, very smooth, and boring.  There is too much of a lager-like aftertaste to me.  One thing I'd like to mention though is that it tasted much better warmer and toward the end of the glass.

Very faintly hazy lemon yellow with a large white lasting head. Mild citrus lemon flowers and stale sourdough yeast aroma. Soft low carb creamy body. Mild floral citrus and grains again in the  flavour. Disappointing weak almost clinical finish with a touch of sweetness in the aftertaste.
Blue moon is one of my favorite beers.  It has a slightly more citrusy taste than other Belgian Whites.  It is not very hoppy but heavy on the wheat and yeast.  Best with a slice of orange.

Come on, this beer has over 325 ratings, and I have consumed Blue Moon on probably over 50 different separate occasions; does it really need a descript rating? ** It’s very fruity/citric, oily light medium palate, refreshing, readily available, chicks love it, I don’t mind it either, I always buy it at my local bar, but never in the bottle, It’s not bad!
Golden color...head quickly fades...minimum lacing. I thought this was smooth light, but a little watery. I did taste a hint of blueberry. Drinkable, summer/lawnmowing beer.

Weak head that faded FAST! Dark yellow and hazy. Light fruit (mostly peach) and yeast aromas. Watery and bland with a sour citrus finish. Soda-like fizzy palate. Afterwards my wife said that I smelled like cheap beer. I promised her that I'd drink more "less cheap" beer from now on.
Wasn't all that pleased.   I thought it had a celery flavor to it.   A bit wheaty tasting & watery.   It was worth a taste, but won't be buying it again.
Had this at the Coors Brewery. Just like any other Coors or Coors Light. Light yellow color, some white head. Watery and hardly any taste.

When this beer was poured into my glass, it poured a large off-white head with fine-small sized bubbles that was long lasting. The body was cloudy and carbonation was observed. The hue of this beer was pale yellow and the nose was cruity and citrusy. There was good lacing on the sides of my glass with this beer. The flavor was mild and it lacked character. The mouthfeel was smooth, thin and watery.

Very complex flavor with flowers, citrus, spice.  Good head, smooth drinking.  A great beer to bring fishing as nobody else that has one taste will drink my beer...meaning I am drinking cold beer long after everybody else ran out.  An excellent beer as a change of pace in a bar.

This brew poured a large head of creamy fine white bubbles that left a fair lacing and a hazy softly carbonatedorange brown body.  It had very little aroma if any.  What I got was a slight malt aroma if anything.  Its flavor was yeasty bready and mildy smooth.

Color is a cloudy, pale golden yellow with lots of white foamy head about two fingers high. Smells alot like most belgiums, very lemony, citrusy orange, yeasty, with some spices. Taste is good, pretty straight up citrusy lemon and orange, a bit of spicyness and honey. The hop presence is speratic and light, noticeable in some sips, none existant in others. Feel is light and smooth with an overall gritty pulp grain feel with a citrusy tang. Its a pretty decent offering for an Americanized belgian.
This was a very good wheat beer.  And the spices were detected and nice.  I could not believe Coors of all people made this one!  Rich and mellow, with a slightly thin body and orange coloration.

On tap, hazy orange color. Fairly sweet, a bit of spice and celery flavor, mostly one-dimensional.  Thin body. Not bad, lacks a bit of spice and could be a little less sweet. Could you believe Coors is responsible for a decent beer?
Poured cloudy golden yellow.  Citrusy aroma with no head at all or lacing taboot.  It has characters of a witbeer, but it also very watered down.  OK for an American macro brewery.

Hazy golden body. Sweet, orange,cream aroma. Not much head. Smooth, but a bit watery. One of the better products from an 
American Macro- Brewery.

A very nice, citrusy ale. SOme like it with an orange wedge, though I like the taste as-is. Quite smooth and enjoyable, this is one you might have to consciously limit yourself to, as it goes down easy and leaves you wanting more.

Pleasant Belgian White.  Foggy orangish color with a mixture of wheat and citrus in the aroma.  Mild easy drinking taste of citrus, wheat, and light hops.  Left a delightful aftertaste.  I was shocked to discover Coors was capable of making such a product.
(Bottle) Light golden, medium slightly dissipating head. Light yeast, cask whiskey nose. Very floral and spicy - mild alcohol flavour. Finishes with oh-so mild burn. Nice
Pleasant enough if somewhat lacking in character.  Attempt at a Belgian Ale.  Wheaty and yeasty.  Have a Hennepin instead.  <>

Drinking Conditions: Pint glass, yeast not poured, 40°F temp.
Pours misty orange with little to no head, lacing was non existent. Aroma is very much of a German wheat beer. Classic malt smell with undertones of clove and banana. Flavor is initially sour and cloying with a small effervescence of citrus hops but then the aftertaste kicks in and destroys all flavors with an unappealing dirty musky finish. The mouth feel is over carbonated, sour and bitter, makes me want to spit it out. Overall it has good aroma, but that's about it, now I know why they put an orange in it at the bar.
golden color with very shot lived white head. Slightly fruity flavor. mild bitterness and a sweet aftertaste. A mediocre example of a belgian white. I am very suprised that this is brewed by coors.

Head quickly fizzled out, zero lacing effect, cloudy orange/peach, very thin. The fact that it is made by Coors taken into account, it is a better beer than expected, yet I'm still not a fan of this style -- it's Okay, but nothing impressive in the least.

A great tasting beer over all. What really got me was its smooth after taste. Although it is made by coors it is a good beer. I’ve had much better american made belgian whites but this wasn’t bad. A definate drink over any american macrobrew.
Wow, I didn't realise that Coors made this beer.  It's quite impresive for that fact.  An average beer but a good choice if you can't get the real deal.
A cloudy beer with light yellow color.  This Wit is tasty, but thin.  Good alternative style, but I'd choose an allagash anytime.

Hazy yellow color, as expected. Drinkable but nondescript, and I think pretty far inferior to other brew of this style I've sampled. Nothing bad here, and more than I'd have expected from the Coors folks anyway.

On tap, hazy gold orange color is pretty, but totally wrong for a wit.  Taste is grainy, with orange zest and coriander on the finish.  Reminds me greatly of Sam Adams Summer Ale.  I tasted it side by side with a Hoegaarden, and it simply was blown away by the real Belgian.

A solid wheat with a pronounced banana nose and that lovely summer back of the mouth wheat smoothness.  I had it with an orange slice as opposed to the traditional lemon and found that it lent a sweeter and rounder taste.

Wow, I dont know about this. This was one of my first ratings and I had it at a 3.4. That was when the average rating was in the low 2's. Now it is holding strong at a 3.07. But I gotta say. After having this again I am no longer much of a fan. THe nose is weak, kind of bland, Some wheat citrus thing going on, but just not pronounced. Some citrus in the taste but flat and stale. Thin bodied and quite unimpressive.
A very nice beer. Not as hoppy as one would expect, but clean and pleasant overall. Light citrusy taste; beautiful color.

This late rating is after having it again when given to me by a friend. I maintain my original opinion, that this is not terrible, but it's nothing I'd go out and purchase. It was better with an orange slice, but that's not saying much. Somewhat of a citrus essence, but definitely not a ton of flavor. Considering Blue Moon is owned by Coors might expain it's wimpy-ness.

A mass marked version of the style, not near the complexity of Hoegaarden, Celis, or Upland. Cloudy pale yellow with a little head, no lace, thin-bodied. Some citrus and spice hints on the nose. Sweeter than most witbiers, smooth. A coy bread-like taste lingers on the palate.
OK.  Mild but not too washed out.  A little malt sweetness and little decernible hopps.  Nice white head and smooth.  not much else here though

Pours light gold in color. No real head and what there is dissipates immediately. No lacing to speak of. Malt and citrus hop nose. Flavor is slightly sweet, with a hint of acidity and some funky plasticness...
Body is watery and suprisingly hollow. Finishes slightly acidy although leaving no real impression at all.
Disappointing....
about as good an impression of a belgian beer as could be expected from coors...  not too bad, though it's not so stellar on the tongue.

Great, cold, smooth brew.  Had this while enjoying the view on the Ohio River in Kentucky.  Heck, the view made the beer taste even better.  Exceptionally smooth, and goes down the same way, cold and nice.
On tap... limited mouthfeel, pale golden color, aroma of wheat and vanilla, smooth taste of malt with a hint of sweetness. Not as good as Oberon but damn good.

Very cloudy orange body, creamy white medium-sized head.  Mild malty aroma.  Light taste, somewhat spicy and sweet.  Thin mouthfeel.  Overall a pretty good beer, especially coming from Coors.  I'm impressed.
Hazy yellow orange color, not much head with a mild peach aroma. Light bodied with a creamy mouthfeel, slightly  sweet and citrusy with a hint of toffee and hoppiness at the end.

Light amber color. Large head. Aroma is malty and a touch spicy. A medium bodied white. Malts are sweet. Hops are a touch spicy. Smooth taste. Mild flavors. Not what I think of when drinking a Belgian White, but tasty enough. Mouthfeel is full and round. Finish is clean and smooth Aftertaste is slightly bitter.

Nice and creamy.  It has a creamy aftertate too.  One of the best aftertastes I have seen on any beer.  They claim this is from coors, but it's too good to really be coors, I think they are importing it.
This is not nearly as good as it was hyped to be.  A bit too spicy, it reminded me of Victory's HopDevil crossed with a belgian white.

Wow this is from Corrs!It is made at a different plant though so that might explain it. It is good real good. I had it on tap and of course like even the finest beers it is better that way but with an orange slice bringing out a sweet but not sickly  undertone I am sure this is good anyway you drink it. Wonderful
Better than I would expect from Coors, but that is not saying much. Pretty average with a cloying skunkiness at first. Mellows slightly as it breaths. Some nice spiciness.
This is exactly what you would expect from Coors. It is weak. It has hardly any aroma, and the flavor is very weak. In fact, it tastes remarkably like regular Coors.
Not a great example of a Belgian White. Head dissapears quickly and tastes a little thin for a wheat. Not a heck of alot of flavor to it either, but it washes down pizza rather well.
kind of a wheaty taste with som good hoppy taste.  it was "eh" on the low end of the "eh" scale.  perhaps almost borderline "crappy".  almost like it was made by some crappy brewer...oh wait, it was.

Lacked wheat.  Lacked yeast.  Taste: a very bare hint of wheat with plenty of warming spice.  Slight hoppy aftertaste.  Little aroma outside of some corriander and orange and lemon peel.  Not duly impressed by this one.
This was comparable to the Chimay Rouge.  It had a good amberish color and had the hint of fruit.  It wasn't too bitter.  A good beer.
Hazy golden color with minimal head. Somewhat fruity aroma. Initially kind of sweet but not overwhelmingly so. Pretty flat, but fairly enjoyable overall.

It has a rusty and mirky appearance. The aroma isn't very strong but it has a nice apple cider thang goin on.  Just a little white head around the edges. It has a good initial taste, a little bitter, somewhat crispy, but the finish is pretty weak, the flavor just seems to evaporate after every swallow. The palate is very light and smooth. It's not that this beer tastes bad, just that it doesn't really taste good.
Very tasty beer, I liked the color but not much in the aftertaste, actually my wife told me that she felt funny in her stomach after drinking it.
Smooth taste, but a little too bland for a wit.  Smells of mild coriander, and tastes basically like a mid-of-the-road pilsner with a little wheaty feel.

Lingering alcohol presence, off-peachy (if that can be understood) though not altogether bad.  Nice if there is no other beer to drink where you’re at (no other decent beer) though this beer leaves much to be desired, but it is a macro brew and coors is no abbey
Cloudy amber color with a citrusy aroma to it.  Strange flavor -- you're waiting for an aftertaste, and then ---- nothing.  It's not anything spectacular, but it's not horrible either.

Of average quality, at best. Cloudy, but unevenly so. The flavor is confused and poorly orchestrated. It has citris to it, but not really characteristic of the style or very appealing. A marginally good brew, if you don't know any better.

A very cloudly looking beer, has a distinct wheat taste to it. And I notice some people putting lemons in it? Why? But anyway its overall a fairly decent wheat beer if thats your style. For me I'll have one every once in a while if Im craving something a little different.

A cloudy, citrusy macrobrew that is actually quite tasty and not clear as water!  Refreshing and crisp, this is a good macro alternative to more expensive, albeit better, microbrews (Bells Oberon comes to mind).  I could see myself picking this one up again.

This beer pours to a cloudy orange color with very little head and a citrus aroma.  This beer is much better on tap than out of the bottle and it is also much better if you can cut up an orange and add it to the beer.  Not very good without the orange, but with the orange it is not bad at all.
Cloudy golden color; decent head, nice lace;  vanilla aroma. Taste peppery with honey/maple undertones. Would go great with Ham.

i hear this is good on draft. had a bottle that was free and thought it was all right. i wouldn't buy it unless there was nothing better.

rerate: i had this bitch on draft and it was AWESOME! tasted like a bunch of peaches. started to lose a bit of that flavor as it warmed up, which was weird. if you have to have this beer, get on TAP!!! it is much better

Pours with a cloudy golden body topped by a medium thick lasting head with some lace left behind.  Slightly sweet yet sour and citrusy (orange) aroma with vanilla and spicy notes.  Sweet and citrusy (orange) flavor with vanilla notes.  Not much of a finish.  Light bodied, smooth and refreshing.

If this is standard for the style, then I must not like the style.  Expectedly cloudy. Decent head but faded quickly.  Bottle conditioned, with noticable yeast sediment.  It was was a hard pour to leave the yeast in the bottle. There is just a flavour in this beer that I don't like.  I'm not even sure how to describe it.  Barely made it through the six pack.

I could see how this beer is one of the best macros on the site.  I drank it while on the slopes of heavenly in lake tahoe CA.  It was very refreshing...very clean....nothing special or worthy of shipping overseas but props to coors for making a not shitty tasting beer.
Good Belgian White, with thorough flavor, little aftertaste. Smooth clean texture.

I can't believe it took me so long to try this beer.  It was like a poor man's Bell's Oberon.  I'm not a wheat guy, but the spices were complimented nicely in it's sweetness... Certainly the best beer that Coors makes.  Great for a macrobrew.  Good job Colorado!
Hazy/cloudy golden color with specks of white hanging in suspension. Sweet orange and vanilla aroma. Thick feel, almost syrupy.  Butter and pepper flavor along with sweet malt.  Dry caulky finish.

The bartenderesse who served me this one asked if I wanted an orance slice with it.  An orange slice?  I really didn't want to ask why, so I just said no.  It was a deal at $2.00 a bottle, a good introduction for those ignorant of such wheaty-type beers, but not a valid "Wheat Beer".
mmmmmmm, if you like bologna sandwiches, you'll love this one, it really does taste like bologna!!!!!!
Not a very good representative for belgian whites at all. Pretty weak taste, to be honest.
Nothing to special here.  Smelled ok, tasted ok.  Wheat was very present, and almost to much for me.  Probably won't be having this again.

re-rate.
Poured a cloudy golden color.  Mild malty/citrusy aroma with even milder flavor.
very smooth and light. Easy to drink.  Had little body too it

Yellow-tan with a slight haze. Medium body with mild bitterness. Tropical fruit aromas. This seems to have significant amounts of orange fruit flavoring. Clean finish with mild floral hop notes. Refreshing and pretty good for a Coors product.

Not like a belgian beer at all. I know a Belgian guy that loves this stuff. He also drinks Budweiser like there's no tomorrow. One of the better beers that Coors puts out. I do have to give them that. Nothing spectacular.
golden,cloudy.  surprisingly sweet.  mild spices.  Most certainly Coors best product, and probably the best product made by a major American brewer. This is better than many real Belgians.

A good beer from Coors only comes along once in a blue moon.  Note:  I said good beer, not great beer.  This is moderately spicy and has a decent balance to it.  Still a bit watery, but quite drinkable.
On tap.  Cloudy dark Golden color.  The spices help this out but the hops are all but indistinguishable.  A slightly better Wheat beer.  Not bad at all for Coors.
Another imitation real beer from coors.  And what is up with this less than seventy five words garbage.
thick a little syupy, few belgian type spices but lacking whole mouth/flavor expience
Nice sweet/orange flavor. Good beer to accompany a meal, and has a sweet aftertaste. Could do with less bite. Coors?! Wow.
Hazy golden color. Small fizzy head with little lacing. Malty with a fruity and spicy flavor. Better than expected, when I head it was a Coors product.
I was surprised by the quality.  Too much bite for a wheat brew.............
nothing special about this swill,better than a coors light, but very annoying bile flavor,I'm not sure what the hell style it is, but it aint no belgium!!

Had no idea this was a Big Three brewing company....until I tasted it and then looked at the label!  Not at all memorable...but not terrible.  Lighter gold color with a non-lingering head.  Light and dry for a Belgian White.  I would suggest you try many other beers before you bother with this one.
Poured very cloudy.  Orange in color, aroma, and flavor.  Had a bit of spiciness.  Very subtle dry orange flavor.  I'd drink it again.
All the flavors of a good Wit are there but it’s to dry and harsh. Zero complexity to this beer really makes me not want another one. It also reminds me of how much I miss Celis White

This is not a beer that I could finish an entire six pack of, that's for sure. Overall I am not much on fruity beers, but I did enjoy the orange/corriander flavors and a nice clean finish with a slightly sweet aftertaste.

Not a good beer. The coriander/orange peel flavor is unpleasant at best. The beer warranted it rating only because it was fairly interesting and somewhat fresh-tasting.It's not a beer which one could drink many of. There are very few beers which I can't finish, this was one.
On tap:  Pretty good overall.  White head, mostly diminishing.  Hazy color, amber orange.  Pretty sweet and easy to drink.  Fair amount of carbonation.  I'd drink again.
Slightly hazy light orange appearance.  Citrusy and lightly yeasty nose.  Body is spritzy and sweet and malty with a touch of hops.  Finishes sweet and candyish.  Not a standout example of the style.

Had this at the Coors Brewery.  Couldn''t believe that I was drinking this type of beer at the Coors Brewery.  When it was poured, I was truly impressed with the golden/rustic look to it with the crisp white head.  Very nice aroma.  Hardly any aftertaste.
Golden color with a small white head.  Peppery aroma and flavor.............

Aroma is light and sweet with a hint of fruit.  Appearance is a foggy orangeish, pale gold.  The flavor was something I really liked with hints of friut and very little aftertaste.  The beer goes down great and is very easy to drink.  I liked this one a lot.
Amazingly good for a Coors product. Light bodied, color is good but not glowing, miniscule coriander aroma, a bit thin, texture is slightly slick, and not bad at all.
Crisp belgium white, but less full than most smaller brewers.  Smooth and easy to drink.

This goes to show that a large brewer can make a good beer.  It's not really a great example of the style, but it's got a lot of flavor and sweetness, good color, easy to drink, and maybe it'll show people the light, in terms of real beer drinking and how enjoyable it can be.
This is good,especially if you''re into a lot of taste.  A nice change if you drink a strong brews.

Rerate 12/30/02: I have to say this is still a decent beer, and the orange slice is always nice to eat. It is also nice to see people in a bar drinking this more and more instead of BudMillerCoors. It is a good introductory beer into something different for your macro pals. However, it is still a pretty weak attempt at a Wit.
12/30/01 (4.0): Wow! Silky smooth flavor and a great aroma and aftertaste.

I've never had this mass-marketed Wit before, but it seemed interesting there as a single in the liquor store in East Lansing, MI (MSU being one of my many alma maters). The aroma is fairly authentic, although it is a bit dark in the glass. Flavors wimps out a bit, but hey, if it gets people thinking about beer in a different way, that's a good thing.

Subtle spiciness and orange peel/coriander present.  Too watery--a bigger body and more spice would improve this beer a lot, however, I enjoy drinking it and Coors makes it for the masses. Not terrible by any means.

When this flavorful, amazingly non-filling beverage is consumed with a fresh orange slice; it very much quenches the thirst.  More of a warm weather favorite this beer is gaining more and more attention with the female element that typically will only drink the thin fizzy mass-produced swills.  An excellent pour and no overbearing qualities make this a keeper
YUMMY...i really enojoyed the taste of this beer, i found a hint of orange flavor to it, to bad we have to go to a diffent state to get it or id have it in my fridge all the time...

Pours a cloudy, pale golden color with a small white head. The head disappears quickly and no lacing is left on the glass. Mild spicy aroma with hints of orange and maybe coriander. Medium body and carbonation, the flavor is initially spicy with a smooth finish and lingering spice and malt flavors. Strange aftertaste that makes me think of what Budweiser would taste like if thay brewed it with some spices.
Hazy gold, with a fast fading white head.Both nose and palate leave something to be desired. A very overrated beer
Not exactly what I expect from a Belgian Wit, but it wasn''t terrible. The feel was okay and the mildly spicy finish was decent.
It''s light and insubstantial but it''s certainly not bad - definite good malt in there and some spices on close.

Well I had to get last night work is not so good of late and after my MBA class I was fed up and need a few brews. There is this little corner bar near the campus not too much going on there (in regaurds to good beers) but I went anyway. So the best I could be was Blue Moon. So they poured me one, it had a creamy orangish brown color with a foam that had a hint of orange in it. So I then tasted this brew which I was surprised at the fruitness flavor it had, hints of bananas and peaches. But other than that it was average. But it is alright on the pocket if you plan on having a few beers

Starts off nice, with a hazy golden color and decent head.  Aroma is typical of belgian wit - sweet and spicy.  Flavor was too much spice for me.  Seems like they tried to duplicate Hoegaarden (which I like), but went way overboard on the spices.
decent beer..i''m always a bit put off when you order a beer in a bar and they put in a garnish or something to help the taste. but a good beer either way.
Crisp, spicy, and full of flavor.  Not bad for a Coors beer.  It's a little light and wattery though.  I'd definately drink it again.  Not even close to a real Belgian White.
I found this beer to be quite pleasing.  It had delicious flavor, but I was pretty drunk when I tried it.  I will probably have to rerate it in the near future.

This is the first Belgian-style beer I've tried. Yeah its from Coors, but now I'm intrigued enough to try the real deals.  Quite dry, but has a good spicy/citrus taste to it.
The cloudy golden/orange color is very appealing. Funny how Coors can make something like Coors light then make something like this which actually has taste.
It kind of gets slammed because it''s a macro imitation of a Belgian style, but I don''t think it''s a bad beer.  It''s spicy and still simple enough to be accessible.  Hint of coriander maybe?

I've never tasted anything quite like this. It's kind of an ugly wheat beer, not that unfiltered wheats are particularly good looking. I guess the spices were supposed to make it taste Belgian, but to me it tasted primarily like good ol' Chap Stick original + coriander and cinammon. This is entertaining for the first five sips, but afterwards, it quickly grows old. No other redeeming qualities.
It totally tasted like medicine, at least the draft I had. Where were the hops?
Very wheaty. Sometimes that bothers me. Other than that, average brew.......
Macro-wit.  Uniteresting, gimicky, nothing like what it should be...........

cloudy yellow orange..very little head..
 Aroma of dried apricots..
Definitely not like a witbier..but I'll tell you, it had a real genuine apricot taste to it that deserves some sort of respect..the flavor moves from fruity apricot to more spicy notes..I don't give a hoot who makes this..I think its pretty damn good!
I have to say, I''m not a huge fan of this beer.  I thought it had a shampoo type nose to it.  The flavor was citrus, with a lot of carbination.

I'll go ahead and admit that I'm not a big fan of white beers, so I'll try to not let that affect my rating of this beer.  I enjoyed my experience with Blue Moon, although I'm not sure I'd buy it with my own money.  Pretty decent brew for a Macro, with an original flavor although a bit bland for my tastes.  Reminds me of Hoegaardden and some of the other whites I encountered in France and Belgium.

Fruity plum/citrus smell.  Light malty 
flavor.  Very yeasty flavor.  Not quite like
the Belgian varieties, but still nice.
this one had a lemon grass smell old hay taste and a light watery finishok for a belgian but could be alot better
A bit orange-y for a wit. No head. Thinish palate- hint of cinnamon. Crisp. Light.
It was highly recommended to me by the waiter.  To me, it tasted like heavily carbonated Budweiser with a lemon in it.  Really not right at all.  One of my patented Neck-Spasm-Inducing-Beers.
Not a bad beer for the price and readily available.  This is the beer that got me into wits.

I can''t make up my mind about this beer.  First time I ever tried it, the weather was really hot and I happened to see this on tap at a local watering hole.  It looked kinda pretty in the tall, thin glass--nice, foamy head on top of a light, golden and slightly cloudy body.  The taste was subtle & nice, especially on a such a hot day.  The next time I tried it was from a bottle.  It seemed to lose something in the translation--the taste was weaker and it didn''t pour into a glass as nicely as I remembered it on tap.

Not one of my favorites, but not that bad either...
It has a taste I've never been able to identify except to call it the "Coors taste." On top of that, it tastes like citrus perfume. Kinda funny, kinda gross. I think I will be avoiding this one.
A solid beer, nothing to get excited about, but very drinkable. Has a sweet citrus flavor.
An impressive attempt by Coors with a Belgian wheat beer. A little light and "synthetic" tasting.
This beer was a pleasant surprise to someone who prefers dark beers. It is very smooth and almost creamy tasting. Has good flavor though just a tad to "spicy.
Fairly good interpretation of the style, especially on tap. Best with a slice of orange. My wife's favorite beer.
I wonder why someone would put coors in such fancy bottles?.................
Nothing really great here, but not a bad brew. Small head, medium flavor, and I don''t see how this Belgian.
Nothing special about this one.  It is average in almost everything.  The head goes quickly, and the taste is not great, but it is far from bad too.  If it's there take it.

Almost no head and no lace.  Typical cloudiness and color for a wheat.  The spicing is a bit different, the typical flavors with a something more, I believe coriander is what someone mentioned. Over priced.

First Rate 12/22/00 A contract brewer for coors, A drinkable beer, not a great favorite. Re-Rate 09/30/02: A light "Chill Hazed" golden color, the head is white and dissipates quickly, the lace is also quite thin. Nose is malt, the front also malt, top light, the finish is moderately carbonated, dry, a pretty "Pathetic" "Wit", by any standards. Ranks #994 on my current 1000 beer masterlist.

Golden coudyness that almost glows and an average head.  Lots of citrus and orange in the nose.  Orange and coriander flavor with smatterings of hops.  Outstanding session beer, and a good introduction for the novice. Now if only coors could do this all the time.

Cloudy yellow, orange with a very small off white head.  I like the aroma and fruity flavour, though it is not for everyone and certainly not the wheaty chewiness that are characteristic of most beligian whites.
People seem to either really like this, or really dislike it.  I fall into the latter.
This has to be one of the most overrated beers on the site.  I doubt it is possible to make a wit more bland and uninteresting than this.
it smells fantastic, and is incredably smooth. i really enjoyed this beer, and it seems to be one both sexes agree on.

Had this on tap at brewpub. Hazy yellow,decent head and lacing. Typical wit aromas, a  bit yeast heavy. Thin bodied, nicely spiced with a yeasty mustiness I enjoyed.  Im going on memory here but it was average for the style but drinkable nonetheless.

Looks great in a glass, but not as much froth as I would like to see. Decent yeasty flavor but not too deep. Very drinkable in multiples - seems to be more guzzle-worthy than other white wheat beers I can recall drinking. I really like this style, but if you really want a good example of Belgian White go find some Celis White (if you can).
This is made by Coors?  Well, it's certainly the best thing Coors makes.  However, we are talking about Coors here, so even their best (which this is) is a mediocre effort.

Not a lot of character and none of the frothy head and crisp yet full body one expects from wheat.  Still, far more enjoyable than most other coors products. Some real spice in this one, but a lot less character than Cellis.

A very nice beer.  Not as much flavor as Blvd. Zon (the only other Belgian White I have tried to this point), but still good.  Great considering it is made by Coors.  Appearance was not typical of most wheat beers... most have a muddy/cloudy look, this one did not.
Very "Foggy" looking beer.    Has a very thin palate.  A decent head.  Not a bad beer, probably much better on tap.  Pub out of a bottle will serve with the absence of some my favs.
Good, if slightly bitter.  Tastes remarkably like a mix of Dixie Darkened Voodoo and Killians Irish Red.

Has a wheaty, citrus nose, accentuated by a slice of orange. Cloudy body in keeping with the Belgian White style. Much more easily drinkable than most Belgian Whites I have had; no doubt the result of mass marketing whiz Coors at the controls. Nevertheless, this is a very smooth and creamy brew; refreshing on hot summer days. Coors did a great job on this; worthy of your time.
Lacking in some dimensions, but an agreessive set of possibile futures to this discussion.  Des Deserves an update report.
Very smooth, but really lacking in flavor.  Cloudy appearance.  Very similar to Sam Adams summer ale.  I wasn't surprised to learn it was a Coors beer.

Extremely sweet aroma.  I wanna say apricot, but that might be because of the cloudy orange color.  It's still apricot after the first sip.  It's got that fall spiced fruit feel if you can imagine that.  Unique.
Great on tap with a orange wdge in it.  Nice and refreshing for a summer day.

Not a bad attempt for a big corporate brewer.  Style is basically the same as Hoegaarden White.  A nice cloudy, wheaty brew with a slightly perfumey aroma.  Some elements of spice and citrus.  I would still prefer the Hoegaarden but for a bit american corporate brew it's amazing they did so well.

Rerate Been awhile since I had one, have not missed much. Very muddled in all aspects. Still a better bet than a Bud Light, but not a true Wit. Missing the spiciness and zing. Original 3.6 Very cloudy appearance - very wheaty - lives up to its type - unlike some other macro-micro wheats found nowadays. Tangy, a good compliment to Mexican food.
Very good appearance in a tall glass, but alittle on the weak side when it comes to taste---Cellis is better.  Moonie had a little of that "big beer company" after taste---preservatives added?

Attractive, rather appropriate wit appearance, cloudy, good coloration.  Head disappates instantly.  Oh, you say this is contract brewed by Coors?  A bit of a plastic odor, but also a fair amount of corriander and lemon zest.  Has a refreshing, sour yeastiness to it, and a good spice tang.  I prefer wits to be more assertive, and this one falls into that range.  Impressive qualtiy considering the psudo-macro scale at which this is probably produced.

I was a little worried when I ordered this - I knew it was a coors product.  Much to my surprise, this was nicely spiced, smooth, fruity/citrusy.  My only complaint would be that it was a little too thin on the palate.  A nice choice when a real belgian isn't available.
Yuck.  I know Hoegaarden and Blue Moon (read Coors) You're NO Hoegaarden.  I bought a sixer of this, drank about half a glass of the one bottle and took the other five back to the packie. :P

Really not too bad for a beer made by coors.
..............................
Nice white goes down smooth,light, and easily drinkable.....................
It's not Hoegaarden, but not bad for something that comes from Coors.  .....
A decent beer.  There are definitely some things in this I wouldn't have expected being the whole Marco thing.  Citrus is evident, but very light.  Some nice spicyness.  It's just not my style.
A truely outstanding beer.  Often bashed because it is owned by a national brewery.  Hey what's the problem...Good beer for less money!
Even this elusive Coors brew deserves atleast one sampling..................

Decent.  I didn't realize this is also a wheat beer until my buddy pointed it out.  So I ran to the cupboard and got some tortilla chips.  Not the best wheat beer I've had, but it was an alright beer.
This beer has a strong citrus taste and the carbonation is a bit overpowering.  Unique taste and smell, weak head.  It seems like a quality beer, but I could not drink even a glass of it.
definatly an intresting choice.  i enjoyed...  but don't think i'll go back to it again.
Yummy.  If this were brewed by a Belgian brewery, it's average rating would be half a point higher.  It tastes very much like Hoegaarden and possesses just the right amount of spice kick.

I think that this is underrated due to the fact that it is created by one of the macros.  Blue Moon on tap is truly a fantastic and complex beer.  Nice wheat-y mouthfeel.  Noticable citrus flavor.  The coriander is perhaps a little overdone, but overall this a great American stab at the Belgian Wit beer.  Nice beer to serve at a porch party.

The perfect-looking wit, cloudy and straw-colored with a nice snowy head.  Aroma would be perfect if stronger -- again, typical lemon/cardamom zestiness.  Flavor a bit weak -- lacks something, I’m not sure what; finish a bit weak.  A good try.
Good beer to cook mussels with, spicy orange, pale grain finish.............
Not a bad beer to drink with a burger.  Only complaint is that it has a weird aftertaste.
Not my type of beer, too much bitterness. This beer smelled much better than it tasted,I think I won't try another unless maybe with an orange wedge.
not bad, but i have had better whites.  not bad on tap with an orange, but not my boat
Sour aroma. Opens up with that wheaten gaggy bitterness. Middle is very strongly wheaty. Finishes bitter and sour. Faugh. Another wheaten throat constrictor in a bottle.

I stuck my face way into the glass but couldn't get a whole lot of aroma there.  Appearance was a quite similar to a wheat beer.  It tasted alright but did not in anyway knock my socks off.  I had this on tap on a hot summer's day and couldn't help but wish I'd ordered the Paulaner Hefeweizen instead.

This beer has a very sweet citrusy aroma to it.  I could smell it a few feet away from me.  The coloration is very bazaar.  It is a creamy white coloring.  The only reason I gave the appearance rating a middle of the road number is because the head is there and then it isn't.  The taste is nothing spectacular and doesn't stick with you for very long, but not anything to turn your head at.
This is much better on tap than in the bottle. Not really up to par with the real Belgian ales, yet Blue Moon is tasty and smooth.
A couple of friends and I picked up this beer one night. The next morning we all woke up after having the strangest and worst nightmares ever. I have not touched the stuff since.

Heavy, very tasty, try it with an orange wedge (that's how we drank it in Champaign-Urbana, at least.)  I love the wheat ales, even though this is pretending to be something it is not, it's the best macrobrewed White Ale out there.

Tasty summer beer!  Not overly hoppy.  Fairly light and drinkable, yet full of unfiltered yummy flavorfulness.  They seem to be tweaking the recipe lately - seems a little sweeter (with a hint of maple?) than it used to.  Still, real nice and (thanks to its faux-microbrew status) competitively priced.

This beer was a cloudy straw color, which formed little head and left a little lace, but not much. It had a citrus, hops aroma. A definate citrus taste with some hops. Not as good as other beers of this style, but for a summer beer, better than getting some other macros off the tap.

This beer suprised me when I found out it wasn't a micro brew. It is very very mellow, very palatable. Goes excelent with food, especially refreshing with buffalo wings, or as a stand alone. It is a wheat beer, which is cloudy by nature, but don't let that fool you, it is well worth the trip to the liquor store.
It's OK, but I don't think it was actually brewed by Coors -- I think it was contracted out.
It’s an above average wit. I recommend giving it a try. Also, it’s readily available in my part of the country.

Pours a cloudy, hazy pale orange color, light fruity and yeasty aromas, small white foamy head that doesn't last too long. Spicy wheat and orange flavors, very sweet and tart for the style, medium body with a soft mouthfeel finishes sweet, a bit better than I expected, just a little sweeter than I like.

Its too damn showy, and its made by Coors, so I think a lot of people are fooled into thinking this is a micro.  I had it for the first time when I was 16 and thought it tasted pretty nasty -- I had some recently and thought of it as being a bit better, but nothing I would spend that much on, however.
Citrus aroma.  I tasted a ginger-like bite in the finish.  Nice flavors overall, but too watery compared to some of the other domestic wheat beers.

Wheaty, citrus, and yeast in the aroma. Cloudy light golden color with small head. Medium carbonation with watery body. Somewhat wheaty in taste, bit o’ citrus. Mild bitter after. Not a bad beer, refreshing but a little weak.  
For a quick quaff, it’s a dependable drink, but for any type of complexity as a Belgian Wit ... nah. My original rating was by in ’02. Now that this beer is so mainstream and ’imported’ from Canada, the profile is less complex than originally presented.
A sweet beer.  Not bad.  Reminds me of Sweet-Tarts..........................
Wonderfull summer brew with a distinct taste and very aeromatic aftertaste.  Hopsy with a lot of head.  Very smooth finish.

I've always liked this beer, especially in the summer, nice looking head, nice hoppy taste.  with hints of cariander and orange. a great beer to just hang out and drink on a hot summer day. Re-rate still think this a pretty good beer, but had to adjust my rating, as I became more familar with the style
a bit on the sweeter side, some trace of citrus, a distinct character with respect to taste. Relatively smooth. Not real good, but very inoffensive...

I very much like this beer however it IS a tad on the sweet side. Not quite as bad as honey-lager, but the sweetness could be toned down a little. This is basically Michelob Hefeweizen with slightly less hops and blueberry syrup added, just to give you a rough idea. Some people may not like it, but I really like this stuff!
I don't really like Belgian whites, but this isn't too bad.  Nice sweet flavor with a decent wheat taste.   I could drink this again

This beer has the right clousy appearance and a subtle spice taste.  There is nothing special about it, but for a mass produced faux micro, its not bad.  In Denver it was served in several places with an orange slice, which is the first time I saw that.  It wasn't bad that way, but I think a lemon slice is more traditional.
very yellow and cloudy. had it on draft and they served it with a lemon wedge. tasted sour and citrusy

This beer is okay.  I don't know that I would go too far out of my way to get it, but I don't regret trying the one I had.  The finish is pretty different.  I didn't like it at first, but warming a little does good things for it.
Very good, but the after taste tastes like Fruitty Pebbles. I don't care to much for a beer that tastes like my morning cereal.

Re-rate:  Now I can say that the draft is even better than the bottle!  I just had this with dinner - and it was so smooth!  Usually I don't like to have beer as my primary beverage with a meal - but this was wonderfully refreshing and slightly citrus tasting.

Very light citrus aroma that shows up as sweetness (not hoppy) in the taste.  Add to that the wheat and yeast flavors, and it comes together ok.  Amazingly enough, Coors has let a respectable beer keep the better part of its quality (though not all of it) after it was bought.

Distinctly citric aroma (orange, coriander).  Light, slightly hazy golden-amber-orange color.  Quite a lot of carbonation, but for a wheat beer this is not unusual.  Wheat malt flavors mix with the coriander, orange peel and a slight bit of yeastiness as well.  Aftertaste has mostly spices, wheat again, and a tad of hops for the finish.  Some definite sweetness...not sure if this beer used to be this sweet.  It has definitely got less sediment than the last time I had it (probably a year ago or so).  Not going to fool me into thinking it's authentically Belgian at all, but a beer with some tasty coriander, etc., good as long as you don't expect too much from it.  I'd fit it in the 'thirst quencher' category.  Light-bodied.

This was once my all time favorite beer and I would have rated it as such last year.  Has anyone else noticed the flavor has totally changed? It used to be a belgian white with just a hint of orange aroma.  The orange aroma has totally taken over the beer.  I still prefer it over 85% of the other beers out there but I miss the old Blue Moon.

I have to say, I really wasn't impressed by this beer. It was pretty to look at but almost a challenge to put down. It's quite expensive here and while it wasn't all together unpleasant, I feel that my money was best spent on something else.

Brings back memories of my first quality beers.  At first I am not impressed by the head but upon the initial aroma, I am convinced of its heritage.  I find it second to Hoegarden, maybe Celis if I had a comparison.  Citrus taste slightly too apparent, but not overwhelming.  I find it quite enjoyable.

It must have been the name association because years ago, when I tried it, I thought it had cheesy overtones in the aroma/flavor. Looking at it more critically today, this beer has a cloudy, banana liquer appearance with a healthy head.  Fruity, yeasty esters dominate the prickly aroma that smells of overripe banana and what may be raisins.  Taste dissapoints, however; this beer has a watered mouthfeel with the diffuse detection of yeast and ester.  Flat and parching on the palate--just not any excitement here.  The aroma is pleasant--but the beer rates poorly from that point.
Aroma just wasn't present, but the taste was almost like a 'lite' weiss beer with a bit of an almost peppermint flavor (coriander?). It was enjoyable and different, but nothing I could have often.
This is one of my favorite beers.  Very smooth, smells and tastes almost sweet, very fruity and spicy.  I haven't noticed the soapiness others have.
I loved this beer.  One of the best I have had in a while.  I wish I could drink this all the time instead of milwaukees best.  But I am cheap so I won't complain.
Like most people have said:  It is a different taste.  I like the citrus flavors, but not to sure about the almost soapy aftertaste.  Overall a very smooth and refreshing brew.

Re-Rate - I guess it’s been a while.  Aroma is citrus and wet malt.  Solid gold with thin head.  Tasting orange, malt, coriander, pepper, hay, yeast.  Carbonation is a bit high and can get a bit of a sticky feel after a while.  Will never be best in class, but still decent.

As a devoted fan  of IPA and Guiness, I probably should have known better than to try this - and my review should be taken in that  light.  The first sip screamed
"Celery!" to me, but the orange/spicy kicked in after that.  Well-made for the type I'm guessing, but not my kind of thing at all.  Above all, TOO SWEET!
i dont know what to say about this, different??.............................
Interesting Spiced Tasted.  The flavor is not as rich as I would have liked.

Had a bottle of this after work.  This brew pours a murky light gold with an abundance of dusty particles.  The average frothy white head doesn't stay around long, and has no lacing.  The bold nose is very complex and pleasant.  Toasted cereal, caramel, perfume, herbs, citrus, soapy dough, raisin, pear, coriander, ginger, clove, and pepper round out the aroma.  The yeasty pepper flavor is balanced between moderate sweetness, and acidity, with a slight bitterness.  The light oily body is a little too carbonated for my liking.  The finish is very dry.  Belgian White is not my favorite style, but this is a pretty solid offering for the genre.

There was something off-balanced about this beer's flavor. I won't say that it was a dirty, unclean beer... but there was something soapy in the mouth, and the overall flavor was a lot thinner than I expected. This beer has coriander and orange peel flavorings added. The coriander was added to give the beer its slightly spicy edge and some orange peel was added to provide the slightly citric bite. The bottle's label only states that it is spiced "...in the Belgian tradition ...brewed with natural flavorings."

The citrus taste of this beer is too overpowering....It tastes like apricots!  
Don't be fooled by the label...this beer is a Coors all the way.

I’m rerating this after a few years and expanded palate. The spicing is still almost too strong, but I can handle it now. It still isn’t the great witbier that some are, but still a shockingly flavorful beer from Coors.

Orange peel and some coriander dominate the nose.  Light and refreshing, as a wit ought to be.  This is just missing some spice and malt in the body.  And the yeast; where's the yeasty aroma and flavor I wanted?  Refreshing and light, but I was left wanting.
this was really good.  very complex taste, almost like a lite version of Great Lakes Christmas Ale

You know, this really isn’t that bad of a beer from a Macro.  I had a Sam Adams White Ale last night and decided to kill one of the 8 of these I had in the beer fridge for the wife.  Poured it after drinking an Alpha King.  Cloudy as all get out.  Stinky and yeasty to challenge the SA White Ale.  Nice mouthfeel, clingy aftertaste, you can definitely taste the orange peel.  Not bad at all, really.

Head is initially small, fizzy, white, fully diminishing. Body is hazy
dark yellow, bottle conditioned. Aroma is lightly malty (grain), with
notes of orange and coriander, light note of solvent. Flavor is
moderately sweet, lightly acidic. Finish is lightly sweet, moderately
acidic, lightly bitter, slightly unclean, slightly husky. Light to
medium body, watery texture, fizzy carbonation.  Second review and I
still don't know how anyone is rating this above average.  The hints of
soiled mattress and broom handle mar the finish, and the problem with
the aroma, as with Cave Creek Chili, is that they use spices to cover up
a poor base beer.  This is the same principle restaurants use to cover
up shitty tap water...by adding a lemon wedge.  It's like putting a
fedora and Armani on a corpse...it may be slightly more aesthetically
pleasing, but it's still dead inside.

A little disapointing, maybe i just don't like Belgiam White. Some people add cinnamon and an orange slice, i say if you need to add that crap, don't waste your time. Unless you are a girl, girls seem to like this one. No thanks yo.
Pretty damn good. Went down smooth. fruit taste was actually a good thing. Go for this over Sam adams cherry wheat.
This beer is pretty good, but the blueberry taste isn't quite strong enough.

Smells good.  A little too cloudy in appearance.  Goes down smooth, with decent flavor.  A little fruity kick to it, which is a good thing depending on the kind of mood you're in that day.  The downside is that it left me hanging after that.  I want that flavor to linger on my tounge for a few seconds.

As an aside, this brew is not immune to the occasional bad batch.  I've had more than a couple overly yeasty blue moons.  This takes a point or so off of the overall score.
A nice smooth beer, a little too fruity to be considered a great beer, but good nonetheless.
Easily the best product that Coors have ever produced.  Now f only the would market this as their main Brew...

Tasty brew, indeed.  Tried it one night out of boredom, came out with a new top 5 beer in the rotation.  has the characteristics that all beers should have, not overpowering, very smooth, doesn't come in cans.  If you're lookin for something new, give one a try.
best damn draught money can buy, get with a twist of orange. more than three of these gets old though. have a few, and then switch to something cheaper
This is the best beer made by Coors. If you're a Bud/Miller/PBR drinker looking for something a little different then give this one a try.
Taste like a combination of spices and celery.  Not one of my favorites.....
An american beligian beer, huh? ...OK...not bad.............................

When I first smelled this beer it immediately made me think of I-Hop and their blueberry syrup. Then I made the connection of the name! Overwhelmingly blueberry flavor, almost to the point of not wanting to drink it. Nice color and aroma, but couldn't have more than one.
Spicy and smooth, this stuff is really good. Someone once suggested adding a slice of orange, which was ok, but this stuff is good all by itself. Definitely recommended.
what a fantastic finish! Smoooooth!.........................................

very light sweet, spicy aroma.  The color is a nice cloudy golden color.  The flavor is sweet and spicy, with little bitterness.  This isn't a great beer by any means, but it is a beer, I could handle drinking on a semi-regular basis.

I know its not a great beer and its made by coors and all but its still one of my favourites.  Very sweet, good tastes of spice and wheat, a little too lemon.  Cloudy, honey coloured.  Not a great palate, over carbonated and not "wheaty" fealing.

When I first smelled this beer I recognized pancakes I used to get at I-hop with blueberry syrup, and then I made the connection of the name! Overwhelmingly blueberry flavor, but not to the point of making you sick. Nice drinkable beer, but couldn't have more than 3 of them.
Light malty front that slides into bright floral flavors.  great beer.......
